Select Opinions.

—————

The aim of the book is to establish by textual quotations that the Srutis, Upanishads, Puranas and Ithihasas treat only of the highly cosmopolitan science of yoga and the pratical philosophy of religion and not of earthy history and geography as too often misinterpreted in modern times.

The Times Literary Supplement, London:

………..Its object is to show that the ancient religious texts………deal only with practical religious philosophy and science of yoga; that they give no support………to the interpretation of the text……as treating of the ancient history and geography of India……….

F. W. Thomas Esquire, M. A. Hon: Ph. D. Librarian, India Office, London:

………..I think there can be no doubt that the conceptions of history, geography &c., expounded in the Puranas and similar works are of a different order from the European ideas connected with these subjects, being throughout dominated by philosophic, religious and ethical purposes. A similar phenomenon is to be observed in the religious literature of other countries, where also a need has been felt for interpretations on the lines of your own. From this point of view I feel that you are doing a service to Sanskrit literature and the religious life of your country by dissociating them from the comparison with the common sense points of view of the modern system of study………..

E. B. Havell Esquire, A. R. C. A. Late Principal, Calcutta School of Art and Keeper of the Art Gallery.

…………I think your idea of collecting authoritative texts and ofcommenting them is an excellent one. It illusteates Indian thought clearly and throws light on many obscure points………

Miss. E. C. Allison: The Vedic Mission Home.

…………I have been awake and in deep sympathy with all Indian books that bring out the true meanings and truth of your wonderful religion, science and philosophy………….. You do pull out the feather of the Westerns in splendid style, and I do thank you for it…………

Justice Sir G. N. Chandavarkar, Retired Justice of the High Court of Judicature Bombay.

………….I have found it helpful and instructive. I intend going through the whole carefully and profiting from its contents.

The Valia koil Tampuran; Consort to Her Highness the Senior Ranee of Travancore.

The book is…………a proof of your considerable acquaintance with Vedic and Puranic lore which unfortunately does not appear much to interest the present day Hindu writer……

Pandit Gandi Rao Hanumant, Dharwar.

………….I am much pleased to see the interpretation made by you for Kuru aud Kurukshetra…. Whatever you have written is authorised by the Vedas.

Indian Emigrant.

This is an epoch-making book which deserves to be carefully studied, digested and assimilated by every Hindu student, Oriental scholar, and Theosophist, and also by every student of comparative sociology………………..

M. R. Ry., R. Mahadeva Aiyer Avl. B. A. Dewan PeishkarTravancore.

……………..Your bitterest critics cannot but admire your deep schoolarship and earnestness of purpose which are writ large on every page of the book………… You have carefully fortified yourself against all attacks by unimpeachable authorities which will speak for themselves when approached with an earnest and unbiased mind ……………………………………………………………………………………………………….. …………………………………………………………………………………………………………

The Indian Patriot, Madras.

……………..The vast range of reading and study of details combined with a keen exercise of philosophical thought necessary for this novel undertaking will not appear to be in the least lacking if only a few pages of the book are carefully read through………It may be specially mentioned here that the subject matter in the book is not one of local or provincial interest; but its usefulness will surely affect the whole of India and might interest all other civilised nations of the world……….

United India & Native States.

………………The author holds it a vanity to search for a historical background for the legends and stories narrated in the Puranas and endeavours to show by various quotations that they were all intended to supplement the Vedas and Upanishads. One is a bit startled to hear a firm conviction that all the Puranas are entirely free of incoherency, but it is perhaps due to our preoccupation……………

** (Sri Sankara)

THE PER॓MANENT HISTORY
OF
BHARATA VARSHA.

————

** C**URIOUS and paradoxical as the title may appear at the very outset, it is my earnest wish and prayer that all Hindus interested in their ancient country, literature and religion, as well as those desirous of knowing Indian affairs better, will kindly condescend to peruse, at least as a pas-time, this little essay, which with all its unavoidably serious defects may be assured to be the humblest product of several years continued and anxious efforts.

It is not possible nor perhaps desirable to explain in the very beginning the exact purport of the whole, but it is hoped that the mere reading of a few pages will render its real meaning and object almost self-evident. But it might however be necessary here to be forewarned that the subject on the whole is too serious to allow its handling with indifference or contempt, and that as such it is not likely to please all or even many. It must also be confessed that it is impossible to invent any other suitable method of treatment to avoid this difficulty and that it would therefore be no cause for disappointment, if none but competent and sympathising readers interest themselves with the contents of this essay.

मास्मिन् खलः खेलतु । (Sri-Harsha)

ये नाम केचिदिह नः प्रथयन्त्यवज्ञाम् ।
जानन्ति ते किमपि तान् प्रतिनैषयत्नः ।
उत्पत्स्यते मम तु कोऽपि समानधर्मा ।
कालोह्ययं निरवधिर्विपुला च पृथ्वी ॥

(Bhava-bhuti)

** CHAPTER I.
INTRODUCTION.**

** THE** two well-known epics in the sanskrit language belonging to ancient India and the Indian nation at large are, of course, the Ramayana and the Maha Barata. That they have been for centuries past, and are even at the present day, invariably venerated by all the Hindus, as texts of religious importance, treating as they do of the histories of two of the great Dynasties of ancient Hindu Sovereigns of the celebarated Surya, and Soma Vamsas; and that they are supposed to contain ample historical incidents and instances of noble characters sufficient to impart a life interest by furnishing lofty ideals for the progress of morality, both public and private, are facts unhesitatingly admitted, on the one hand, by every pious and religious Hindu in the land: their superiority on the other hand among indigenous literary productions, in consideration of the simple sweet and fluent style in which they are written and of the abundance of happy expressions from one end of the texts to the other, fit for apt quotations in everyday life, are duly acknowledged by every Sanskrit Scholar in India and Europe. They are at the same time affording immense scope and interest for modern critical enquiries aiming at discovering and determining their worth and importance from archaeological, philological, and other scientific points of view. Every sort of attempt in these directions to analyse the contents of the texts made by all earnest enquirers in the East and West must naturally imply a clear and firm belief in the historical nature of the composition. But instances are neither wanting nor unknown of varieties of cirticisms from different quarters declaring that the epics abound in exaggerations and poeticalfancies peculiar to the Indian Nation and that they really supply but few trustworthy historical facts. However, in an unbiassed consideration of the essential nature of these epics as historical treatises, it is not logically possible nor reasonable to leave entirely out of account the descriptions so vividly and so unequivocally furnished regarding the times and places of action as well as the personalities that prominently figure in the narratives right-through. All else may perhaps be viewed with suspicion and cried down as individual observations or fancies direct, in accordance with the peculiar turn of mind or some preconceived idea with which such enquiries are so often commenced. On the contrary, it is certainly surprising to find that the net result of all critical labours pertaining to Indian subjects of this kind, for at least the past 100 years, has been more or less the rejection of all important items as useless and irrelevant and the admission of minor ones as essential to form the basis of all arguments urged forward in reviewing such topics. It would not therefore be unnatural or unreasonable to infer that there must have been some fundamental mistake, at the very outset, in the interpretation of the texts themselves, for which, of course, the local Pandits and by no means the foreign critics are responsible. The possibilities and probabilities for this unfortunate and lamentable ignorance on the part of Native Pandits, can only be sought after and traced to, the neglect of Sanskrit studies for several centuries past, and the consequent gradual diminution of religious zeal and religious practice, owing chiefly to the unsettled and disturbed state of administration during all this time, in the various centres of learning and religious activity. The formulas to solve the problems contained in these valuable literature were forgotten, bequeathed as they are by the ancient and omnicient sages to their beloved and less favoured posterity, and the keys furnished to unlock thesecrets for the purpose of utilising the hidden treasures were almost lost, or unconsciously thrown away, with the natural result, that all rude and wrong processes now employed to open, unavoidably end in breakage and damage.

2. In my humble attempt to write this little volume, I must expressly declare that I have no original plan to vindicate, no new theory to propound, no fresh commentary to offer. I only undertake the task of selecting many a relevant fact for explanation from the generally available and commonly recognised ancient literature, and I am not, therefore, liable to any serious responsibilities in treating the subject, as I am obliged to do, with my very limited knowledge of the Sanskrit Language. My main excuse for the present unqualified adventure lies in the overwhelming feelings of anxiety at the modern tendency for virtually annihilating or reducing the importance of the subjects to which the abundance of unwarranted and destructive elucidations are drifting. Further, the simplicity of style and language as well as the plainness of expression although in a somewhat disguised form, specially employedin the epics, for the express benefit of other than scholarly classes, emboldens me to proceed without much fear or diffidence:

घटोयमिति विज्ञातुं नियमः कोन्वपेक्षते ॥

To know a pot a pot, does not demand much scientific learning. The work I have thus to perform is, therefore, simple though laborious; and I am fully aware, that I can reasonably neither claim nor expect eulogiums on any account, and that for the same reason I need foster no fear of unfavourable criticisms, particularly under the circumstances explained above. I shall by all means feel amply repaid for this humble effort, provided this little production succeeds in stirring the latent capacities of intelligent scholars earnestly inclined to enlighten and benefit their inferiors.

** 3**. The Ramayana and the Mahabharatha are classed under the ancient religious literature, technically known as the Ithihasas, differing but slightly from the puranas; and the the former is styled the Adi-kavia or the first poetical composition and is commonly understood to be much earlier than the latter. The general outline of the stories narrated in both the epics is too well known, having been told by this time in different languages, in different methods and probably with different objects. To avoid tiring repetition, I shall therefore confine myself to facts absolutely necessary to be detailed for the clear exposition of the ideas, theories and practical instructions, actually conveyed by the texts. But even in doing so, the most commonly accepted or understood facts and descriptions alone shall be referred to.
** 4**. The Ramayana is generally known in our midst as an exact and complete historical treatment of the reign of Sri Rama, an incarnation of Vishnu and a descendant of the illustrious Solar Dynasty, the Surya Vamsa. He is said to have ruled in Ayodhya, the capital of the Kosala country the modern Oudh, on the banks of the Sarayu. The Tretawhich is the second yuga in the cycle of the quadruple yugas is specified to have been the period during which Sri Rama long reigned most righteously over his happy and virtuous subjects for eleven thousand years. The Ramayana text is also said to have been composed by sage Vanmiki during this reign and taught by him to the two sons of Rama, named Kusa and Lava, who were born of Sita at his hermitage. The poem was sung later on by the two children in the presence of Sri Rama, as a musical composition accompanied by the play of the musical instrument, the vina. The concluding chapters of the text styled Uttarakanda, therefore, contained the future history of Rama as predicted by Vanmiki at the time it was composed.

Whereas the Maha Bharata is understood as a similar historical treatment of the reign of Yudhistira, a descendant of the subsequent Lunar dynasty the Soma Vamsa. Hastinapura or modern Delhi was his capital and to his illustrious reign is assigned the period comprising the latter end of the third or Dwapara yuga and the beginning of the fourth or current Kali yuga. Sri Krishna, another and later incarnation of Vishnu, is described as a descendant of the Yadhava Vamsa (a branch of the Soma-Vamsa) and a close relative and contemporary of Yudhistira. A full Purana, namely the Sri Bagavatham, is written to the glory of Sri Krishna, but a great portion of his important life is detailed in the Maha Bharata itself, including the preaching of the well known Bhagavat Gita. Sri Krishna stands prominent as the leading character throughout the epic poem, which, without him, will only be insipid and lifeless. It is nothing but surprising that no serious thought has yet been given by the educated. Hindus to the correct understanding of the contents of this class of religious literature, although some interest is occasionally evinced in the various corners of this vast Indian Continent in the discussions of other collateral subjects of religion and socialism. A great portion of the Hindu population entirely believes in the truth of every description given as super-human events which actually took place in India. Another class either totally disbelieves the stories or is indifferent altogether. There are others who partly believe in their historical facts, as far as they fall within human probabilities, and treat the rest as literary flourishes in Sanskrit poetry, so common at the time the texts were supposed to be composed.
** 4**. The modern Western views on the subject expressed after due scientific enquiries,archaeologically and philologically made, almost upset the native impressions. The two epics as all other ancient literature in India, are ascertained to havebeen written in pieces, at different periods and by different authors, and finally and lately joined together as a whole. In the Ramayana, for instance, the Uttara-kanda is supposed by some to have been added as a supplementary portion, the word Uttara clearly conveying the clue for that logical inference. The antiquarians who are prepared to give the most charitable consideration, could not probably find sufficient grounds to fix the dates of these compositions beyond two or three thousand years. Some of them infer from the customs of polyandry and poligamy described in the Mahabharata, that it should have been composed earlier than the Ramayana, which contains the treatment of better morals and customs. Both the epics, as they understand, represent more or less the conditions under which the Indians lived at the times they were written. There is in fact no end of ingenious inferences, drawn from many a foregone conclusion, as to their dates authorships or compilations, which will virtually tend to reduce the religious importance generally attached to them. There are found, occasionally, educated natives also who follow these foot-steps and contribute their quota with feelings of satisfaction. Rev. Banerji in his preface to the Markandeya Purana says, “The Puranas in general contain no authentic history, there is no plot, no finish, no humour, no wit, no poetry but mere versification and combination of irrelevant and incoherent facts. Monier Williams says that the complete list of 18 Puranas given in all the Puranas is absurd and must therefore be later interpolations”.
** 5**. It cannot, however, be doubted that the origin, status, customs, religion and all else that constitute the peculiarity of the Indian nation greatly depend upon the fate of these epics and Puranas as settled, or would be settled by the western enquirers and unavoidably accepted by the civilised Hindus, the orthodoxical pundits and religious authorities simplycondemning these views from corners of villages, without being able to protest with a single sensible argument to convince even the educated portion of their community, much less the enlightened westerns. Our present lot is unfortunately cast in the midst of a very critical period, with our fossilized pundits behind and the sensible foreign cricits in front. It is almost a hundred years now since the social and religious questions in India have begun to be seriously discussed, variously interpreted and curiously criticised both by Hindus as by foreigners. For centuries in the past however, these very questions remained settled facts and demanded no reformation. That certain changes have recently occurred in the existing condition of affairs has therefore to be naturally presumed.

The Sanskrit pundits in India who have all along been the interpreters of our religious literature, have for various reasons degenerated and the western critics no doubt obtained mostly second hand informations from this class of professional pundits. It is preposterous to presume that the sanskrit language spread itself spontaneously in western countries by any other means. These are sufficient and grave facts to throw much snspicion on the correctness,tone and even relevancy of the points hotly discussed on either side. It may not be difficult to prove that several of these important problems are based upon the ignorant and unauthorised interpretations of the pundits and the consequent criticisms of foreigners, who could not naturally be entirely free from bias or apathy against alien religion and socialism.

The most important questions regarding the value or utility of the sacred Vedas, Puranas and other religious literature are easily and conveniently given up by the Hindus to be dealt with completely in accordance with the fancy of the western antiquarians. Minor or less serious questions concerning social matters are alone found to be occasionally worth discussing. This cannot however be taken to confirm the view that all ancient sacred literature is correctly andproperly reviewed by the westerns and consciously accepted in India by those who can afford to understand its real meaning. It is likely that the sum total of the moderan opinions is, but a conglomeration of a jumble of irrelevant, unwise and to some extent blasphemous talks on the sacred and practically scientific subjects long settled by our wise forefathers in the real interest of their beloved posterity. The periods for instance at which these ancient texts were composed are attempted to be ascertainel by various so called scientific processes, without taking the trouble at first to understand the meaning of their contents. More importance appears to be attached to the dates of composition or those of the supposed historical events by bringing them under the first four letters of the English Alphabet, the B. C. perio -d or A D. period, greater efforts being invariably put forth to come down to A. D. some-how rather than to B. C. The Vedas as a rule are pronounced to be earlier productions as compared with the Puranas and Ithihasas. A cursory reference to the well known Upanishads, such as, Muktika, Tarasara, Rama-Tapini, Krishna Tapini, Rama Rahasya, Sita &c. will clearly prove the absurdity of the conclusion. These Upanishads unequivocally refer to the Puranic stories said to have been composed in the Puranic period. The Puranas could therefore with equal consistency be pronounced to be earlier productions than the Vedas themselves as could be proved by the following quotation.

प्रथमं सर्वशास्त्राणां पुराणं ब्रह्मणाश्रुतम् ।
अनन्तरञ्च वक्रेभ्यो वेदास्तस्य विनिसृताः ।
अङ्गानि धर्मशास्त्रञ्च व्रतानि नियमास्तथा ॥
ब्रह्माण्डपुराणम् ॥

This conclusion is evaded probably with some preconceived object in view for which it is not quite suited. When difficulties of this kind arise, the common argument invariaably brought against all varieties of ancient literature is tocall the contradictory portions, “Interpolations,” especially when the interpretations ignorantly attempted do not tally. In the majority of cases, this prevailing mode of criticism is absurd, although it is the easiest and the most silly weapon of attack that could be resorted to. Because, it certainly implies that the possibility of the exact criticisin was prophetically discovered and the precautions to provide against them were taken by the alleged process. When the actual complaint itself is the extreme want of attention and regard for ancient religious literature locally, common sense can easily convince us, that the idea of interpolation which demands active intellectual effort supplemented by competent knowledge and skill is too far-fetched and improbable. Half the amount of time and skill supposed to have been wasted in this direction would have sufficed to search out the correct interpretations of the texts themselves. In spite of the encouragement recently given in some places to the rivival of sanskrit studies in India by way of special Colleges for the purpose, our modern pundits have not yet interested themselves in helping us out of the existing difficulties in this direction. Few of this class have ever turned their eyes to this kind of liters ture. The learned Pundit on whom the natives look up for correct interpretation and who in his turn assumes the air of a true friend, philosopher, and guide,either gazes with open mouthed wonder at the western translations and criticisms and often bluntly condemns the same with the audacity of an ignorant country boor. Pundits with additional English education occasionally found in these days, appear to fare no better but are often more easily led to fall in the western errors as well.

** 6**. It would indeed be unfair and uncharitable to omit here, the curious and apparently favourable interpretations attempted by a new sect of foreigners, who have for sometime, launched out an eclectic system, comprising all the past present and future religions, sciences and philosophies in the world, ignoring altogether the natural difficulties and theconsequent futility of reconciling even two opposed systems. I refer to the sect that preaches Hinduism, admires Budhism and believes in several other isms. There are greater chances for an educated Hindu to fall into the errors of this theosophical creed, as the English language in which the theories of this sect are expressed especially under the garb of scientific reasoning, is likely to appeal to him better than his own mother tongue. Ample instances shall be quoted subsequently showing in detail how completely the real purport of the texts is misunderstood and misinterpreted in the elucidation of the Hindu Religious subjects by professors of Theosophy. It is indeed a pity that we have by this time landed at a unique stage of existence as a nation, in which our legacy of ancient wisdom has been improperly handled and spoiled by our own men, owing to ignorance and sometimes bias and even self-interest Every subject of religious importance is totally slighted or ignored, and as a result of the new civilisation, odious comparisons are so readily made with similar western customs and habits, which, when properly analysed would be found to contain nothing in common with them in any of their details or origin.

7. The supposition of the sacred religious texts as historical or geographical treatises is in itself an egregious blunder ignorantly committed by our eastern pundits, and the consequent floods of criticisms by western scholars, as superstition, mythology, old-world simplicity, sectarianism, bigotry and what not, have been simple waste of energy and skill in the wrong direction. There are and still will be plenty of valuable materials to admire as unfathomed scientific lore for all earnest seekers of truth in the east or west, north or south. There is a fumdamental difference in the treatinent of our philosophy itself as compared with that of the west. The purely theoretical portion has a scientific and practical counterpart going hand in hand with it which is probably yet unknown in the west.

अस्ति ब्रह्मेतिचेद्वेदपरोक्षज्ञानमेव तत् ।
अहं ब्रह्मेति चेद्वेदसाक्षात्कारस्स उच्यते ॥
वराहोपनिषत् ॥
आगमोक्तं विवेकाच्चद्विधाज्ञानं तदुच्यते ।
शब्दब्रह्मागममयं परं ब्रह्मविवेकजम् ।
अन्धं तम इवाज्ञानं दीपवच्चेन्द्रियोद्भवम् ।
यथा सूर्यस्तथा ज्ञानं यद्विप्रर्षे विवेकजम् ॥
विष्णुपुराणम् ।

Constant criticisms or occasional eulogiums based upon the ignorance of this vital distinction are therefore practically useless, if not mischievous It may be interesting and perhaps surprising to note, that the eastern Architecture, Astrology, and several other Sciences, like the Histories and Geographies referred to above, are all founded upon practical philosophy, psychology and psycho physiology and have absolutely nothing to compare with the corresponding subjects elsewere. Descending further to more practical subjects of sociology. Law or Politics. the same ideal will be found more concretised. The ancient literature consists of the highest productions of the wisest of men treating unanimously as they do. of the most important subject in the world to which man alone in creation is entitled to. Man’s elevation to god-head was considered the sole object worth his life-long trial. Our ancient Rishis had the common sense and enormous practical experience to understand that the loftiest ideals of philosophy could not suit the generality of mankind, owing to their incapacity to grasp them. They therefore descended with love and sympathy to the platform of the less abstract style, providing them at the same time practical instructions to help them in ascending higher and higher by gradual progress. This process, was rescrted to as a matter of necessity for the benefit of the lower orders of society, and it is a sheer sinful mistake to attribute superstitious belief or ignorance, on their part.The unique and extreme skill and scientfic knowledge displayed by them in giving a concrete shape to their philosophical ideals are perhaps unequalled in any foreign literature.

एतदात्म्यमिदं सर्वमित्याह हिपरा श्रुतिः ।
साक्षादर्थस्वभावेन श्रुतिः सेयं प्रवर्तते ।
श्रोतुश्चित्ताविपाकेन विषण्डा विवशा श्रुतिः ।
क्वचित्कदाचिदन्यार्थंवक्ति च ब्रह्मणः पृथक् ।
साध्यसाधनसम्बन्धकथनं फलभाषणम् ।
वर्णाश्रमविभागोक्तिस्तद्धर्नोक्तिस्तथैव च ।
शोभनाशोभनोक्तिश्च भूतभौतिकभाषणम् ।
शब्दानां भेदनिर्देशस्तथार्थानाञ्च भाषणम् \।
आत्मनोन्यस्य सर्वस्य तद्भावोक्तिः सुरर्षभाः ।
मिथ्यात्वभाषणं तस्य माया सद्भावलक्षणम् ।
मायात्वोक्तिश्च मायाया बन्ध इत्यभिभाषणम् ।
गुरुशिष्यकथोक्तिश्च ब्रह्मविद्याभिभाषणम् ।
शास्त्राणामपि निर्देशस्तर्काणामपि भाषणम् ।
अन्यद्वितर्कजालं यत्तदुक्तिश्च समासतः ।
अन्यार्थेन परं ब्रह्म श्रुतिः साध्वीनतत्परा \।
चित्तपाकानुगुण्येन श्रोतृृणां परमा श्रुतिः ।
सोपानक्रमतो देवा मन्द मन्दं हितं नृणाम् ।
उपदिश्य विषण्डापि पुनः पक्वाधिकारिणः ।
एतदात्म्यमिदं सर्वमित्याह परमाद्वयम् ।
जगत् जीवेश्वरत्वादि विचित्र विभवं विना ।
केवलं चित्सदानन्दब्रह्मात्मैक्य परा श्रुतिः ।
जगत् जीवेश्वरत्वादि सर्वं ब्रह्मैव केवलम् ।
इति स्वपूर्णता ज्ञानं परमाद्वैतवेदनम् ।
इतोन्यद्यत्परिज्ञानं तदज्ञानं न संशयः ।
विचारेणायमेवार्थस्त्वयमेवाविचारणे ।
न कदाचिद्विशेषोस्तीत्येतत् ज्ञानं सुदुर्लभम् \।
स्कान्दपुराणं—सूतसंहिता ॥

It will certainly be clear from the above quotation that different grades of intellect have been taken into consideration by the wise sages in the treatment of religious subjects without losing sight of the main goal for reaching which all the requirements were provided step by step to all possible varieties of mankind. It would therefore have to be conceded that every bit of ancient literature is cosmopolitan in the widest sense of the term and contains virtually nothing but the highest philosophical truths, whether the outer garb is philosophical, historical, geographical, political, moral or legal. Unless this fact is clearly kept in view, none of these literary productions could be found to convey reasonable or consistant meaning. The modern method of interpretations, disregarding this important point cannot but land us in absurdities, so as to suspect the sanity of the authors themselves; whereas in doing so, we are only exhibiting the unsound condition of our own brains. Gnana or the actual perception or knowledge of the reality is the ultimate aim of our philosophy and religion. This knowledge is not possible to be attained without proper preparation and qualification by Yoga and Karma specially prescribed for the purpose, by the Rishis or seers who have acquired perfection by necessary and long practice of devotion. In the interest of suffering humanity they have detailed various processes suited to different grades of intellect and turn of mind, which would all tend to produce the intended effect of qualifying them to the gradual but sure attainment of perfection. The proper scientific method of procedure for religious development is described in the garb of histories and geographies, law and politics. As the subject matter pertains to the highest of abstractions imaginable, there was no other go but to resort to human affairs for description in words. The language of the One had to be translated into that of the many and thetale of the philosopher had to be told as the history of the worldly man.

चोद्यं वा व्यवहारो वा क्रियतां द्वैतभाषया ।
अद्वैतभाषया चोद्यं नास्ति नापि तदुत्तरम् ॥

** 8**. It may however be necessary to enquire whether the contents of the texts in question refer to real history, or only to some religious instructions couched in a historical form, or to both together. If we grant that they contain some serious religious matter in the disguise of a historical treatise, the necessary conclusion follows, as to the complete absence of the historical facts. To argue that they combine history with religion or philosophy, is surely untenable, although that is more or less the current opinion of the majority of educated Hindus and pundits. Want of definite opinion on the one hand and the fear of disturbing popular beliefs on the other, make them unwilling to reject either. Why the history of a particular person or persons should be pitched upon to enunciate the principles of religion or philosophy, and how could the former ever tally with the exact requirements of the latter, are matters which could not be divined by ordinary common sense. It is safer and easier to eliminate altogether the idea of religion from the whole concern. But in that case, it is difficult to prove the value of these historical facts, their correctness and cogency, their probabilities and possibilities in the sphere of human affairs.
** 9**. It is often believed that the Puranas and Ithihasas were composed for the purpose of teaching morals by example But they contain several stories and incidents whose mere narration could not sometimes be tolerated in good socities, with any sense of decorum. Panchali is said to have been married to five husbands, the Pandavas, in the Mahabharata. To establish its propriety without being misunderstood as a lawful marriage, several chapters are added as explanation for the particular instance. Several Puranas give detailed descriptions regarding the intercourse of Brahaspathi, the Deva Guru, the preceptor of gods in the heaven, with the wife of his elder brother Uchathya during her pregnancy and the curse cruelly pronounced upon the innocent unborn child who accordingly became blind for life. Tara, the wife of this very Brahaspathi is said to have been abducted by Soma or Moon and returned only after begetting a son named Budha (the planet). It would certainly be astonishing to know if any instructive morals worth the name are ever going to be drawn from these incidents. In the Dharma Sastras, the wife of the elder brother and of the Guru here alluded to, are placed on a par with the most respected and sacred mother.

ज्येष्टपत्नी राजपत्नी गुरुपत्नी तथैव च ।
पत्निमाता स्वमाता च पञ्चैते मातरः स्मृताः ॥

No perverse ingenuities could possibly justify these incidents on purely moral grounds. There is no doubt that several discourses are occasionally introduced in the Puranas treating of many a useful and moral topic, and perhaps here and there a few facts may be pitched upon as instances of heroism, justice or other virtues. But the consideration of these as the main objects of the compositions is a serious mistake which cannot but bring about the present deplorable state of affairs.
** 10**. Excepting the Ramayana alone, the Mahabharata, Sribhagavatha, the 18 Puranas and the same number of Upapuranas are all said to have been narrated by Suta to the residents of the Nimisa forest. Every reader of this religious literature accepts this as an axiomatic truth without a querry, as if Suta and the residents of Nimisa are familiar persons, and the forest itself is not far from his own abode. Suta may be passed off for the present as a learned story-teller andthe residents of Nimisa who listened to all his stories may also be supposed to have been some pious inhabitants of the forests like the Byragees and Gosayees now found in Upper India. But the geography of Nimisa at least may be enquired into at this juncture, especially as it is described to have been the sacred place in which all our ancient histories were narrated or the voluminous texts containing them were read out.

सिसृक्षमाणा विश्वं हि यत्र विश्वसृजः पुरा ।
सत्रं हि ईजिरे पुण्यं सहस्रं परिवत्सरान् ।
तपोगृहपतिर्यत्र ब्रह्माब्रह्माभवत्स्वयम् ।
भ्रमतो धर्मचक्रस्य यत्र नेमिरशीर्यत ।
यत्र वैरं समभवत् विश्वामित्रवसिष्ठयोः ॥
वायुपुराणम्।

It is clear from this description that the place refers to some locality where successive Brahmas performed a sacrifice before they created this Universe. No part of this earthy globe can therefore be pointed out for its identification, much less a corner of India. There is evidently no ambiguity or want of clearness in the description given, but the only real difficulty experienced is in reconciling the same with modern interpretations. A searching enquiry into every detail in this manner will completely convince us of the impossibility of explaining away the texts as we blindly do at present.

Another instance of such geographical description met with almost every day in religious ceremonies is that of the Bharata Varsha. This terın is ever mentioned in what is known as the Sankalpa-Mantra which precedes every ceremony like introductory prologues in dramas or Natakas. As for the Sankalpa-Mantra itself, it is supposed to describe, as current interpretation goes, the locality in which the ceremony takes place as well as the time at which it is performed. It is not however clearly comprehensible why such specificationsof time or place are demanded for religious rituals. Then meaning of the Sankalpa-Mantra as a whole, savours more of a documentary language fit to be exhibited in a Registration office. In its application especially to the Sradha or Tarpana ceremony performed in behalf of one’s parents and forefathers, the irrelevancy and absurdity of using such strictly legal language are apparent on its very face. The next and more serious difficulty to be encountered is not only the vagueness but the utter incorrectness of the geographical description itself. The most learned Sanskrit pundit is sure to be handicapped, if only a young school boy of the present day require him to identify the places. The only ridiculous explanation often forthcoming from that quarter is that such places must have existed in times of yore. Equally profitless and not the less preposterous are the scientific explanations, attempted by calling geological discoveries to their aid in this matter. The simplest and the easiest method of getting over these difficulties, is ever ready at hand for a particular class of unscruplous critics who boldly pronounce that our ancients werepitiably innocent of the correct knowledge of geography. It is thus entirely hopeless to obtain any useful information on the subject except by directly resorting to the internal evidence available in the texts themselves. The Sankalpa-Mantra in question runs thus :

जम्बूद्वीपे—भारतवर्षे—भरतः खण्डे—मेरोः दक्षिणे पार्श्वे

Jambu-Dweepam or the island of Jambu which contains Bharatavarsha is described, as the central piece surrounded by saline ocean. Six more Dweepas or islands encircle the same in succession, each being separated all round by a different variety of ocean. Begining with Lavana or salt water round the Jambu, the successive oceans are supposed to contain इक्षु or sugar-cane juice, सुरा or spirituous liquor, सर्पिor ghee, दधि or curd, क्षीरंfor milk and orउदकंpure water respectively. In spite of the very tempting character of allthese highly valuable oceans, it is indeed a pity that modern geography is unable to furnish a single clue to their whereabouts. Leaving out of account the 5 valuable oceans and the 6 Dweepas bordering them, as hopeless and useless, attempts seem to have been made by modern pundits to identify the central piece, the Jambu surrounded by saline ocean with our earthy globe. What logic led them to this ingenious infernce is probably a divine secret that will not brook cross-examination. There is no doubt however that it is from this supposition that the identification of India with Bharathavarsha is generally explained. How far this explanation will stand the test of common sense is difficult to determine. The Jambu Dweepa or the earthy globe as now supposed, is said to be divided into 9 Varshas or continens. Ilavrita in the centre, Ramyaka, Hiranmaya and Kuru in the north, Ketumal in the east, Bhadraswa in the west and Harivarsha, Kimpurusha and Bharata in the south. Bharatavarsha is thus the southernmost continent in the division which must naturally therefore find its situation near the south pole. Absurd conclusions of this kind are inevitable in the analysis of every descriptive detail furnished and the persistence to reconcile current interpretations is a sheer waste of time and energy. More of this shall be detailed in the subsequent pages as the main object of this introduction is only to convince ourselves of the necessity of seeking for other and better interpretations to arrive at correct meanings of the contents of our sacred literature. But before proceeding with the consideration of the next important point I may note here that the word Bharata-khanda as applied in the Sankalpa will immensly add to the difficulties of the modern interpretation. Granting that Bharata-varsha represents India, Bharata-khanda must naturally mean and is taken to mean, a subdivision of India like the Madras or Bengal Presidency. The same Sankalpa being recitedthroughout the length and breadth of India, no more explanation can possibly be ventured in that line of interpretation than a clear admission of its being synonymous with Bharata-varsha rendering the addition of the word redundant and meaningless. Thus at every step in the attempt to explain away in the modern fashion, we are beset with evident difficulties clearly comprehensible by ordinary exercise of common sense. And yet neither the learned pundit nor the so called civilized Hindu Gentleman ever cares to understand the texts in their proper light. The pundit feels satisfied by occasionally adding one nonsense to another to create consistency. The civilized gentleman often thinks it beneath his acquired dignity and a waste of his precious time to approach the timebarred absurdities of his forefathers. He entirely forgets at the same time, that his borrowed ideas of civilisation and gentlemanliness proceeded from the west, where such utter indifference to ancient civilisation is only treated with contempt.
** 11**. We have by this time noticed more or less how the attempts to identify geographical descriptions in the Puranas with localities known by those names in India are entirely misleading and futile. It is also desirable to form some definite idea in this introduction itself, how the question of time fares in the same class of ancient literature. Every unbiased reader of these texts will be compelled to concede that the specifications of time wherever found are so clear and unambiguous that no want of precision or exactness could be attributed to them. The facilities for securing unalterable specifications are greater in the Indian method than are available in the west. The various astronomical details like the Ayanas, Rithus, Tithis, Stars &c. are taken advantage of on all such occasions. The common sweeping criticisms as to their vagueness are therefore entirely unfounded. But at the same time it is necessary to ascertain how far our ownpundits can stand, in their usual method of interpretations, the test of examination of the internal evidence gathered from the texts themselves. We may conveniently proceed with our enquiry from the date of creation itself.

चैत्रेमासि जगत् ब्रह्मा ससर्ज प्रथमेहनि ।
शुक्लपक्षे समग्रं वै तदा सूर्योदये सति ।
वत्सरादौ वसन्तादौ बलिराज्ये तथैव च ।
नारदपुराणम् ।

The passage quoted above creates no special difficulties until we reach the last factor. The very first creation of this universe by Brahma is said to have taken place during the reign of Mahabeli the Emperor. How this particular item could be explained in itself, or in conjunction with its previous details, is surely a perplexing riddle to every scholar or critic native or foreign. In spite of the exact specifications furnished, the whole thing is a hard nut to crack. No archaeology or geology can afford to help us out of this difficulty and no pundit can explain away in his usual fashion without exhibiting his ignorance and arrogance. Let us descend for the present from the very beginning of creation to our own times leaving a long and sufficient interval to be dealt with according to the fancy or caprice of every existing critic on the subject. There is apparently no serious dispute as to our having got over a period of five thousand and odd years in the Kali era and lived the life of good old inhabitants of India or Bharata-varsha all the time. The latter circumstance is however a condition precedent to the former, as curiously enough none of the four yugas occur beyond the limited boundaries of the Bharatavarsha.

चत्वारि भारते वर्षे युगानि कवयोऽब्रुवन् ।
कृतं त्रेताद्वापरञ्च कलिश्चान्यत्र न क्वचित् ॥

Without passing on to the point at issue, it is not convenient to halt at this stage to consider just now, whether on accountof the advent of the yugas in our midst within the Indian soil alone, we are comparatively placed in a better or worse condition than our fellow creatures outside. I might however mention here probably to the surprise of all pundit classes, that the pride now cherished by them as the residents of this Punnya Bhumi or holy land, is really unwarranted by the religious texts. The Indians or the dwellers of the Bharatavarsha are described as the most short lived among the inhabitants of the Jambudweepa. They are hardly blessed with more than a hundred years of age, whereas, the longivity of the life of those outside in the remaining eight varshas (representing of course in accordance with the current interpretations, the continents of Europe, Africa, America, Oceania and the remaining portions of Asia) is supposed to extend to ten thousand years in addition to several other special privileges.

** एषु पुरुषाणां अयुतं पुरुषायुवर्षाणां देवकल्पानां नागायुतप्राणानां वज्रसंहननबलवयोमोदप्रमुदितमहासौरतमिथुनव्यवायापवर्गवर्षधृतैकगर्भकलत्राणां तत्र तु त्रेतायुगसमः कालो वर्तते ॥**

** श्रीमद्भागवतम् ॥**

Whatever may be the real gist of the passage quoted, it is impossible to obtain at any time any reasonable reconciliation between worldly facts, meaning of the texts and the current interpretations.

To return again to the subject of time, the commencement of the current Kali era dates from the hour of Sri Krishna’s quitting the earth for ascension to heaven.

यस्मिन्नहनियर्ह्येव भगवानुत्ससर्जगाम् ।
तदैवेहानुवृत्तोसावधर्मप्रभवः कलिः ॥
श्रीमद्भागवतम् ॥

यस्मिन् दिने हरिर्यातो दिवं सन्त्यज्यमेदिनीम् ।
तस्मिन्नेवावतीर्णोयं कालकायो बलीकलिः ॥
विष्णुपुराणम् ॥

A general survey of a few leading events which will furnish a continued and unbroken account of this period of 5000 years may suffice for our enquiry here at present.

Not long after the departure of Sri Krishna, the Pandavas retired to the forest and finally disappeared. Parikshit, the grand-son of Arjuna then ascended the throne at Hastinapura in the beginning of the Kali yuga. He is said to have ruled for a thousand years, and after him his son Janamajaya who performed the Sarpa-Sacrifice ruled, for a period of three thousand years. His son and successor Satanika is also said to have ruled for a similar long period of three thousand years and the line continued for some time in this manner.

**हस्तिनापुरमध्यस्याभिमन्योस्तनयस्ततः ।
राज्यमेकसहस्रञ्च ततोभूज्जनमेजयः ।
त्रिसहस्रं कृतं राज्यं शतानीकस्त्ततो भवत् ।
पितुस्तुल्यं कृतं राज्यं … … … ॥
**

** भविष्यपुराणम् ॥**

The glaring inconsistencies in the very arithmetic of these facts as compared with the current Kali era, are easily and readily accounted for by our learned pundits as events which took place in different kalpas. But neither this information nor the names of such kalpas are mentioned in the texts. The argument brought forward however, clearly implies that their author the present Vyasa by name Krishna-Dwipayana has detailed in his 18 Puranas historical incidents which took place in various kalpas that passed before him. Fresh Vyasas are said to appear in every Dwaparayuga and they are naturally expected to compose histories only of a particular Chathuryuga, probably their own limited period.

The idea that History repeats itself, is perhaps required to be understood here in its most literal sense, which is at best a physical impossibility and a meaningless absurdity. But even granting the possibility of exact repetitions of History in this peculiarly wonderful Indian soil, the Vyasas would certainly be out of order in their treatment of one set of historical facts, if they confound and mix up facts from one or more other sets. However willingly and respectfully we may view the arguments of our venerable pundits, it is impossible to conceal their flagrant ignorance of the real contents of these invaluable production.

अज्ञात्वा शास्त्रहृदयं मूढो वक्त्यन्यथान्यथा \।
अविज्ञाय च तत्वार्थं बुद्धेरज्ञानवैभवात् ॥

** 12**. Even a cursory examination of the general outline of the stories in the Puranas and other ancient literature, has by this time convinced us of the fact that the descriptions of time and place found in them are inexplicable riddles demanding other than current methods of interpretations, to arrive at their correct meanings. It must be clearly confessed that the pundit’s attempts to conceal his ignorance and to confound the illiterate, give no relief to the enquiring minds, nor are the irresponsible and gratuitous criticisms condemning everything ancient and sacred on the false plea of scientific reasoning, of any avail to those earnestly enquiring for truth. The worth of our sacred legacy is evidently being tested at present only by mistaken processes and an early and amicable solution by a reconciliation between these two extremes, also appears to be perfectly hopeless. It is practically impossible to make our pundits understand our critical position in this matter at the present stage of our modern civilisation. Nor are the western critics whom we are bound by sheer justice to credit with keener perception, untiring energy and praiseworthy interest, likely to set usright though they have been to a great extent capable of setting us in motion. They could not of their own accord sufficiently approach the subject which is utterly strange and new to them. Our pundits should however be given full credit for having preserved our literature intact to this day, although it was only like the treasury guards without knowing the real contents of the treasury. The best possible use should therefore be made of the existing knowledge in their possession and whenever their help in the proper direction is available, it should not be declined. On the contrary, little help could be expected from the western critics for the proper solution of the questions, beyond the informations as to the sort of criticisms likely to emanate from foreign lands. The English translations of Sanskrit literature are in themselves very often dangerous and misleading. They entirely lose the clue specially contained in words having several meanings. Agastya or Kumba-Sambhava, for instance, is often found translated as Pot-born Rishi. The facilities for useful enquiry completely end with such translations. Attempts to trace anything further serious out of them, might result in fun instead, like the retranslation of Hamilton’s bridge into Barber’s bridge in Madras. Simpler western mistakes in this direction are also very common. The name Vara-nasi has been changed into Vana-rasi or Benaris, and Vatoda into Varota or Baroda. With these altered names, we lose entirely the chances of discovering any important facts which the original words are capable of disclosing by the very meanings they convey. The word Trivandrum the anglicised form of tiru-ananthapuram was once found represented into a combination made up of a tree, a van and a drum. Such ingenious perversities have only to be carefully avoided in serious religious enquiries. It is also necessary to notice that proper names in Sanskrit generally specify something, whereas in the west such wordsseldom convey any meaning. The names Ayodhya and London may be taken for example, the former clearly meaning ‘invulnerable.’ Besides the mistakes of the above kind, the most important and technical words commonly used in this sacred literature are translated and defined improperly. Difficulties caused by the ignorance of correct definitions are sometimes got over easily by calling them esoteric and occult. There is hardly any esoterism or occultism in these religious texts. No doubt there are several technical terms used but they are also clearly defined. The scientific treatment of every subject demands the use of such terms and no one ever thinks of calling them occult or esoteric on that account. In law books for instance, there is always a chapter at the commencement giving the definitions of terms technically used throughout the text. There is certainly no justification to call law books occult sciences for that reason. Our venerable sages never cared or intended to hide from us any valuable information known to them, otherwise, we would not have been favoured with the existing voluminous literature on the subject. For aught we know, the occultisms and esoterisms may be necessary to a Theosophist for his peculiar subject, but our ancient religion and philosophy with less pretensions are complete in themselves without them, whatever may be their worth to an unsympathetic eye. Foreign religions which refuse to accept our tenets as well as those which try to oppose us can virtually do no harm, owing to a clear understand ing of their difference and opposition. But it demands the utmost caution to deal with the curious method in vogue of explaining our religious literature by occulitisms and secret doctrines, especially as the texts proclaim to the contrary.

ज्ञानादेव हि कैवल्यं इति शास्त्रेषु डिंडिमः ॥

No proclamations by beat of drum are evertaken to be secret or occult. Further, granting that the ultimategoal is the same in every religion, the methods of procedure are entirely different. Nay, even in our own religion, several methods are prescribed which are not meant to be mixed up halfway. To jump from one particular route to another in the middle of a journey is surely absurd and unprofitable. To supplement therefore the existing local ignorance of the subject with exotic methods of explanation will only accelerate the tendencies to complete ruin. In the study of our sacred religion such extraneous processes are strictly prohibited.

अश्रद्धालोरविश्वासो नोदाहरणमर्हति ।
श्रद्धालुरपि सर्वत्र वैदिकेष्वधिकारतः ॥

But this does not in the least mean that blind faith is ever demanded as is often wrongly supposed to be. For every important subject in the world there ought to be a limited boundary, and it ought not to be transgressed if any good should come out of its study. Full scope for discussions in scientific methods is amply provided and freely allowed to arrive at definite and reasonable conclusions.

अनुग्राहकतर्कश्च कुरुते तर्कवेदनम् ।

But the illogical and irrelevant criticisms commonly in vogue consequent on the entire and unadulterated ignorance of the subject will not be tolerated either in religious or other serious subjects.

स्वानुभूत्यानुसारेण तर्क्यतां मा कुतर्क्यताम् ॥

To venture criticisms without the least knowledge or study of a subject is styled Kutarka. This is exactly the prevailing mistake that does all the present harm. In the majority of criticisms offered in this manner there is hardly any tinge of originality nor any evidence of earnest research. They may after all be summed up into two indefinite and trite expressions, namely, ‘exageration and poetical fancy’. Theyare always too vague to serve any extent to which and the reason for which these criticisms may be applied and how far the remaining portions may be taken for historical truth are seldom stated in definite language. Any serious attempt to do so will doubtless betray the inadmissibility of such remarks in the literature in question as they are sure to create new difficulties to be encountered.

Earnest and honest enquiry on the other hand, will easily lead us to the conclusion that not only every word or sentence but even a syllable or numerical figure has its exact purpose to serve and meaning to represent. At the zenith of the glorious civilisation of the twentieth century in this holy land, it is not uncommon to hear of lectures on vedantism invariably commenced with an entirely wrong difinition of Sruti or Vedas themselves. The Anta or end of the Vedas is mercilessly dragged to the platform without a correct knowledge of the very Adi or begining. A strong tendency appears to be cherished somehow in modern days towards the free exposition of this vedantism to an undesirable and objectionable extent. It is wrongly considered a convenient make-shift to reconcile all differences of religion and philosophy in the world. Although its impracticability for this purpose is stamped on its very face, it might be passed over as an excusable mistake. But there is another and more dangerous aspect of this high sounding Vedantism capable of bringing about the most pernicious results. It is constantly preached by the illiterate and the majority of moral bankrupts, as a plea for freedom of action in the field of ethics. It would indeed be a pity if the philosophers of the west were ever to guage the worth of Indian morals and Indian philosophy from the wisdom of these miscreants. For this lamentable state of matters, no fault of any kind canpossibly be attributed to the introduction of western civilisation and its method of study. Strength of character, thoroughness in the investigation of a subject, critical spirit of enquiry and several other valuable virtues peculiar to the western civilised nations demand grateful admiration. They are not so fickle or unsteady to be easily carried away by momentary alterations of views on serious matters. The Indians are on the contrary as the late Justice Sir Muthuswamy Iyer has regretfully expressed, sometimes prone to be led away by the petty vanities of dress and taste without any attraction for the sterling virtues of the westerns. The mere apish imitation of unimportant and locally unsuited customs or habits of the west, is, to say the least a culpable insult to the most generous spirit of the British Administration. How far the serious charges of indifference and wantonness imposed upon our own countrymen here are true, may be easily ascertained by a mere explanation of the mistaken interpretations of Sruti above referred to. This word is commonly explained and interpreted as a synonym for the Vedas, for the simple reason, that the Vedas have all along been taught orally from generation to generation, and that in the ancient days known as the Vedic period there was no possibility of communication by other means, as writing and printing were then unknown. A correct knowledge of the technical meaning of this word as used in the religious texts will clearly prove the absurdity and irrelevancy of the explanation now given. Srutipramana is one of the six varieties of proofs classified in Sanskrit Logic such as direct perception, analogy &c.

प्रत्यक्षमनुमानञ्च शब्दञ्चोपमया सह ।
अर्थापत्तिरभावश्च षड्प्रमाणमिति स्मृतम् ।
अक्षादिकरणैर्दृश्यं प्रत्यक्षं तदिहोच्यते ।
लिङ्गालिङ्गादिविज्ञानं अनुमानमिति स्मृतम् ।

आप्तोक्तिवचनैर्गम्यं शब्द मेवमुदाहृतम् ।
तत्सादृश्याद्यथागम्याह्युपमाचोत कीर्तिता ।
दिवाभोजनमस्तीति रात्रौ नास्तीति गम्यते ।
अर्थेनैवार्थविज्ञेया चार्थापत्तिरिति स्मृतम् ।
भ्रान्तिज्ञानेह्यभावे तु स्वयंज्ञानन्तु गम्यते ।
भ्रान्त्याभावे स्वयंज्ञानमभावमिति कीर्तितम् ।

The instructions from an Apta or Professor of a practical subject with which he is practically acquainted, is described, as Sabda or Sruti pramana. The instructions received from him furnish only a theoretical knowledge which has afterwards to be converted into practical knowledge by actual experiment or experience, in order to attain to the level of the professor’s knowledge. Until this is done, the instructions received and the knowledge acquired, are only through hearing or Sruti and not by experience. This is the exact technical meaning of Sruti, and as such it has absolutely no reference to writing or printing. The same instructions written or printed in the most improved press of the modern day, will only be an inferior form of Sruti as compared with the direct lecture of the professor or Rishi. ऋषिदर्शनान् । The word Rishi denotes a person who has obtained the real knowledge by direct personal experience and his description of such experience is first grasped by Sruti or hearing by his scholars who have afterwards to practise for themselves and become Rishis or Seers like their master. The following from Yaska Niruktom clearly explains the same.

ते अवरेभ्यो असाक्षात्कृतधर्मभ्यो उपदेशेन मन्त्रान् सम्प्रादुः । तेषां हि श्रुत्वा ततः पश्चात् ऋषित्वमुपजायते । ते अवरेभ्यो अवरकालीनेभ्यो शक्तिहीनेभ्यः उपदेशेन शिष्योपाधिकया वृत्या मन्त्रान् ग्रन्थतो अर्थतश्च सम्प्रादुः तेऽपि चोपदेशेनैव जगृहुः ॥

Thus it is evident how a very serious and injurious mistake is ignorantly and unconsciously committed to the entire detriment of all subsequent inferences and conclusions on the most important subject. It is doubtless the pundit’s mistake to have interpreted Sruti as being so called from the circumstance that it is only taught orally from father to son or from teacher to student. Naturally from this mistaken information furnished, the western critic deduced his corollory that writing was probably unknown in the Vedic period. The word अक्षर letter or Alphabet, लिपि writing, लिखित written, मुद्रितstamped or printed abundently found in ancient literature will disprove the cogency of this inference. The Yantras and Chakras drawn in geometrical designs are filled with letters making up the mantras, such as, Mahanarayana-yantra in Mahanarayana Upanishat, Nrisimha-yantra in the Nrisimha-tapani Upanishad, Panchakshara, Ashtakshra and Srisukta mantras have all their Yantras and Chakras containing letters. In matters of this kind the internal evidence available is the safest and the most proper source of correct information. Materials like wood, metal, clay or stone are, all liable to destruction in various manner, but literature constantly renewed by writing, study and use, is alone likely to overcome and survive the inevitable ravages of time.

13. Having waded through the quick sands of time and place found in ancient literature, we may try our chance with the peculiar personalities commonly figuring in them. Most of the avathars or incarnations do not possess full human details but are provided with four human hands, such as, Matsya, Kurma, Varaha, Narasimha, Kalki and Hayagriva. Rama and Krishna the chief heroes of the Ramayana and Maha-Bharata although represented in human form are coloured blue or green. The Rakashasas are of a horrible beastly class the chief among them Ravana is gifted with ten heads and twenty hands. The military officers ofRama namely, Sugriva, Hanuman, Jambavan, Angada &c. are monkeys and bears. Among the Asuras, Mahisha has a buffaloe’s head. Among the Gods, Ganesa has an elephant head, Brahma has four heads, Siva sometimes five heads and Subramonia six. The Bhadrakauli among Godesses, possesses a hundred terrible faces. The Yakshas. Gandharvas, Kinnaras and Kimpurushas have all animal faces of various descriptions. In fact, exercises in multiplication, permutation and combination of almost all shapes in the existing created beings, are worked out with untiring skill and energy to the utter bewilderment of the modern Historian.
The origin and birth of several of the characters are equally perplexing. In the Ramayana, Sita is described as having been born from the furrowed ground.

यज्ञभूमि विशुद्धयर्थ कृषतो लाङ्गलेनमे ।
सीतामुखात् समुत्पन्ना तस्मात् सीतेति विश्रुता ॥

In the Maha-Bharata, Panchali is said to have sprung from the fire-place.

द्रुपदस्य कुलेजाता वेदिमध्यादनिन्दिता ।

Agastya was born from a pot. अगस्त्यः कुम्भसम्भवः ।

Bhishma son of Santanu was born of river Ganges.

** शन्तनुस्तु खलु गङ्गां भागीरथीमुपयेमेतस्यामस्य जज्ञे देवव्रतः । यमाहुर्भीष्मइति ॥**

Drona son of Bharadwaja was born without a mother.

बृहस्पतेर्बृृहत्कीर्तेर्देवर्षेर्विद्धिभारत ।
अंशाद्रोणं ससुत्पन्नं भारद्वाजमयोनिजम् ॥

It was from Bharata son of Dushyanta that Bharata-Varsha took its name. Dushyanta’s parents were Illila and Rathanthari. Illila’s parents Tresnu and river Jumna and Tressnu’s were Anthyanar and river Saraswathy.

** अन्त्य नारस्तु खलु सरस्वत्यां द्वादशवार्षिकसत्रमाजहार । तमुदवसाने सरस्वत्यभिगम्य भर्तारं बरयामास ।**

त्रस्नुं सरस्वती पुत्रं अन्त्यनारादजीजनत् ।
इलिलं जनयामास कालिन्द्यां त्रस्नुरात्मजम् ।

** इलिलस्तु रथन्तर्थांदुष्यन्तादीन् पञ्चपुत्रानजीजनन् । स एव दुष्यन्तो विश्वामित्रदुहितरं शकुन्तलां नामोपयेमे । तस्यामस्य जज्ञे भरतः ।**

महाभारतम् । आदिपर्व ॥

The Puranas abound with curious and mysterious parentages of this kind which are readily swallowed by the readers like smooth gelatined pills. They may even go to the length of thinking that without them the ancient history is not worth the name. Whereas, application of a single serious thought upon such important topics has however become a rarity, partly from consideration of wasting precious time and partly from fear of being criticised as blasphemous by pundits and the orthodox classes. The pundits anxious to exhibit their erudition are only too ready to come down upon every body with authoritative quotations against raising questions regarding the rationale of such descriptions. Quotations like the following from the Bhagavatgita and other texts are considered conclusive proof of the religious importance of blind ignorance in such matters. Evil consequences of a very serious nature are emphatically predicted by disturbing the existing beliefs. To cause loss of faith by reasoning or thinking is considered irreligious and sinful mischief.

न बुद्धिभेदं जनयेदज्ञानां कर्मसङ्गिनाम् ।
जोषयेत्सर्वकर्माणि विद्वान् युक्तस्समाचरन् ॥

A learned yogi should not disturb the faith of the ignorant who is earnestly engaged in karmas. He should only encourage him keeping himself at the same time unattached. This is the meaning of the text and there is nothing wrong to mislead. But the mistake lies in its application by theignorant pundit and to the wrong persons. The pundit as at present is neither a ngani nor a yogi privileged to quote such passage, and the educated classes like the B. As or B. Ls to whom it is often applied could not be so bluntly and so easily condemned as the ignorant. Nor do they commonly come under the class of people attached to the performance of karmas ordained by the Sastras. Quotations of this sort are therefore completely inapplicable under the present conditions and could only be taken for adding insult to injury. It is high time for the pundits to understand clearly that evasive and abusive explanations of this kind experimented on the modern public will only bring them to greater disrepute and that the only possible means of making themselves useful is by exerting their best in the right direction to vindicate the worth and importance of our hoary and sacred literature. There is not the slightest doubt that without any unnecessary attempt to criticise others or without waste of time and energy in borrowing from others, much profitable work could be accomplished by the utilization of our ancestral property, if only a loving and earnest aspiration is aroused for the reclamation of lost treasures.

स्वगृहे पायसं त्यक्त्वा भिक्षामटति दुर्मतिः ।

Rejecting the sweet porridge at home the fool begs for alms elsewhere.
14. Before closing this introductory chapter, it is desirable to obtain a rough idea, if possible, of the general introduction found at the commencement of every Purana or Ithihasa. It begins with the unbearable burden of the mother earth caused by the multitudes of worldly sins and her prayer to be relieved of the same. The Puranas give in detail the description of her visit to the Vishnu Loka and of her complaint represented there in the form of a cow. Then comes the promise kindly given of a particular incarnation on the earth and the assurance of redressing all her grievancesby necessary actions. This little prologue is quietly introduced without giving any cause for suspicion like many other incidents, and is invariably passed over without feeling any difficulty. But with a slight waking from slumber, one is sure to find himself in the midst of a riddle. Earth in any known form such as a garden, field, hill or valley has never been seen complaining to anybody of any matter. Nor is the idea of her going away to some other Loka easily imaginable by those who are helplessly bound down to her surface. The difficulty is augmented by having to imagine in addition that her representations are made in the form of a cow. The mute cow is as unqualified for this serious purpose as the dead material with which the earth is composed. First of all how could the earthy globe itself be affected by burden or weight created by worldly sins is a fit subject for scientific enquiry. How she could easily transform herself into a cow and travel to etherial regions in that state without wings provided, are impossibilities in physical nature. The representations of grievances in human language by a cow are beyond ordinary comprehension. If she were described as having taken a woman’s form at least it would have given us some relief, but it is evident from the various Puranas that the ancient sages are not prepared to grant even that much. In these circumstances there is no other go but to resort to our venerable pundits for help who always stand unshaken like an adamantine rock to face all possible difficulties in this direction. They have their ready solution at hand which they are ever generous to offer gratis. “In olden days the Godess earth could represent her grievances wherever she likes and she is able to do this in the form of a cow”, is virtually the explanation. Blessed are those who are satisfied with this enlightened explanation. But unfortunately the majority of mankind could not afford with their poor brains to grasp the magnitude of wisdom imbedded in the explanation. However it ispractically useless to proceed with the stories narrated in thePuranas and Ithihasas without understanding the correctmeaning of this introduction here referred to, and it is certainthat until it is satisfactorily explained, no reliance canbe placed on any further interpretation of the subsequentpassages in the texts. But there is an impression prevailingin some quarters that the Vedas alone contain the purestand the oldest ideas of Hindu religion and that the Puranasand Ithihasas are subsequently added and are to a greatextent interspersed with mythical stories and rituals as wellas extraneous and sectarian matters. Their careful study istherefore considered unimportant as they do not come up to thehigh standard of the Vedas and Vedantas with which theyhave probably no concern. Much indifference is observableamong Sanskrit scholars generally in the study of this literature. The Puranas and Ithihasas do not seem to receive attheir hands even the interest usually evinced in novel reading.Detailed information shall be furnished on the subject in thesucceeding chapter but a mere reference may be made to ithere by the following quotation showing their importantrelation to the Vedas and Vedangas.

यो विद्याच्चतुरो वेदान् साङ्गोपनिषदो द्विजः।
नचेत्पुराणं संविद्यान्नैव सस्याद्विचक्षणः।
इतिहासपुराणाभ्यां वेदं समुपबृंहयेत्।
बिभेत्यल्पश्रुताद्वेदो मामयं प्रहरिष्यति।

The Ithihasas and Puranas serve the purpose of commentariesto the Vedas. Partial knowledge without a study of themis so dangerous that the Vedas themselves seem to be afraidof such ignorant scholars.

______________

CHAPTER II.

RELIGIOUS TEXTS AND PHILOSOPHY.

OUR conspectus in the last chapter, of the varietiesof mistaken notions current on the ancient andsacred literature of our mother country, creates a necessityfor proper enquiries, with a view to determine, whether afterall, there is anything worth enquiring into or worth preserving as useful and valuable knowledge for the presentand future generations. It may be necessary for this purpose to stick to some convenient order of treatment lest welose the main and important points and fail to follow theconnected links in proper succession. The subjoined classification may be found sufficient to answer the requirements,although it is impossible to have exclusively distinct logicaldivisions in matters of this nature—

(1) The classification of the Texts and the generalcharacter of the subjects treated therein.

(2) A short description of the ideals of Hindu Philosophy and Religion.

(3) Explanations of some of the Geographical details.

(4) Interpretations of a few important historical incidents and the calculations of time connected therewith.

(5) The meanings of personalities prominently figuringin these religious texts.

For the sake of convenience, the last three namely3, 4 & 5 may be dealt with in a full separate chapter.The treatment of all the above points shall be mostly byquotations from the texts themselves rather than by offeringindependent and original suggestions or explanations. Itis unnecessary to reiterate here that the modern currentinterpretations and criticisms are entirely unwarrantedand unsupported by the contents of the texts and are therefore only mere inventions according to the fancy andcaprice of each critic who often voluntarily gives out hisopinions or sometimes feels bound to express, to maintainhis acknowledged position as an authority. In either casethe value of his opinions has only to be calculated upon hispersonal importance and not upon their correctness or cogency.For, if the opinions were only perfect as we are naturallyprone to believe, they should have been capable of beingcarried right-through every page of these texts without inconsistencies and irrelevancies. That this is seldom foundpossible has been amply proved. The only choice left for us under these circumstances is to come to the inevitableconclusion that the defects observed almost at every stepare either owing to the mistakes in the texts themselves, orowing to the unauthorized misinterpretation of the so-calledauthorities. But no modern critic however biased andunsympthetic has gone to the length of denying even literarycapacities to the venerable authors of the sacred Texts.ordinary Sanskrit scholar cannot fail to admire the beautiesof ancient literature and the immense wisdom of its authors.Under these circumstances it is neither useful nor safe toaccept any opinions as correct unless they are directly supported by evidence obtained from the texts themselves.

SECTION 1.

The Classification of the Texts.

** 1.** Knowledge or Vidya in the highest sense of theword is divided into two classes, the Practical and Theoretical,the Para and the Apara. Even the most sacred and importantVedas including all other sastras fall only under theTheoretical Division called Apara. The recognition of such a clearand distinct division is the peculiar characterestic of theIndian Philosophy and Indian religion. The highest knowledge to be attained as the Summumbonum of human existencetherefore lies beyond the plains of thought and reasoning:—

द्वे विद्ये वेदितव्ये हि परा चैवापरा च ते।
तत्राऽपरा तु विद्यैषा ऋग्वेदो यजुरेव च।
सामवेदस्तथाथर्ववेदश्शिक्षा मुनीश्वर।
कल्पो व्याकरणञ्चैव निरुक्तं छन्द एव च।
ज्योतिषञ्च तथानात्मविषया अपि बुद्धयः।
अथैषा परमा विद्या ययात्मा परमाक्षरम्।
यत्तददृश्यमग्राह्यं अगोत्रं रूपवर्जितम्।
अचक्षुश्रोत्रमत्यर्थं तदपाणिपदं तथा।
नित्यं विभुं सर्वगतं सुसूक्ष्मं च तदव्ययम्।
तद्भूतयोनिं पश्यन्ति धीरा आत्मानमात्मनि।
तदेतदक्षरं सत्यं तद्विज्ञायविमुच्यते।
ज्ञानेनैव हि संसारविनाशो नैवकर्मणा॥

रुद्रहृदयोपनिषत्।

The following is another similar logical classification ofthe subject into three divisions instead of two, namely ParaVidya and Bhranti.

भ्रान्तिर्विद्या परं चेति शार्वं रूपं परे विदुः।
अयथा बुद्धिरर्थेषु बहुधा भ्रान्तिरुच्यते।
यथार्थाकारसंवित्तिः विधति परिकीर्त्यते।
विकल्परहितं तत्त्वंपरमित्यभिधीयते।

श्रीशिवमहापुराणम्।

अर्थेषु बहुरूपेषु विज्ञानं भ्रान्तिरुच्यते।
आत्माकारेणसंवित्तिर्बुद्धिर्विद्येति कीर्त्यते।

सौरपुराणम्।

आगमोक्तं विवेकाच्च द्विधाज्ञानं तदुच्यते।
शब्दब्रह्मागममयं परं ब्रह्मविवेकजम्।
अन्धंतम इवाज्ञानं दीपवच्चेन्द्रियोद्भवम्।
यथा सूर्यस्तथाज्ञानं यद्विप्रर्षे विवेकजम्॥

विष्णुपुराणम्।

All perverted knowledge is Bhranti. All scientific knowledge is Vidya and the highest knowledge beyond Vidya isParom. The Vedas and all other Sastras will therefore beclassed under Vidya which is clearly defined as scientifictreatment of truth.

The following is again another classification into Paroksham and Aparoksham Nganom.

अस्ति ब्रह्मेति चेद्वेद परोक्षज्ञानमेव तत्।
अहं ब्रह्मेति चेद्वेद साक्षात्कारस्स उच्यते।

वराहोपनिषत्।

The theoretical knowledge of the existence of theAbsolute and the Practical experience of the same are treatedas two distinct divisions of true knowledge.

The Vedas and their divisions are detailed below:—

निश्वासभूता मे विष्णोः वेदा जातास्सुविस्तराः।
तिलेषु तैलवद्वेदे वेदान्तस्सुप्रतिष्ठितः।
ऋग्वेदस्य तु शाखाः स्युः एकविंशति संख्यकाः।
नवाधिकशतं शाखा यजुषो मारुतात्मज।
सहस्रसंख्यया जाताः शाखास्साम्नः परन्तप।
अथर्वणस्य, शाखाः स्युः पञ्चाशद्भेदतो हरे।
एकैकस्यास्तु शाखाया एकैकोपनिषन्मता॥

मुक्तिकोपनिषत्।

The Vedas originated from the breath of Vishnu. TheVedanta is their imbedded essence. The Ric Veda has 21branches or sub-divisions. The Yajus contains 109. TheSama 1000 and the Atharva 50: Total 1180. Each branchor Sakha has an Upanishat attached.

Vidya consists of the following 14 subjects.

अङ्गानि वेदाश्चत्वारो मीमांसा न्यायविस्तरः।
पुराणं धर्मशास्त्रञ्च विद्या एताश्चतुर्दश।
यया स देवो भगवान् विद्यया विद्यते परः।
साक्षादेव हृषीकेशः तत् ज्ञानमिति कीर्तितम्॥

पद्मपुराणम्।

The chief among these the Veda is virtually single andit has also a single meaning. The Ithihasas and Puranasare its commentaries, and other texts will not be religiouslyrecognised which do not coincide with this Veda in theirapplication.

इतिहासपुराणाभ्यां वेदं समुपबृंहयेत्।
वेदाः प्रमाणं प्रथमं स्वत एव ततःपरम्।
स्मृतयश्च पुराणानि भारतं मुनिपुङ्गवाः।
अन्यान्यपि मुनिश्रेष्ठाः शास्त्राणि सुबहूनि च।
सर्वं वेदाविरोधेन प्रमाणं नान्यवर्त्मना।
एक एव द्विजा वेदो वेदार्थश्चैक एव तु॥

सूतसंहिता।

That the Veda is but one is reiterated in various texte.Its subdivisions as well as the Puranas are only meant for theclear understanding of its meanings.

एकवेदस्य चाज्ञानात् वेदास्ते बहबः कृताः॥

महाभारतम्।

द्वापरे द्वापरे विष्णुर्व्यासरूपेण सर्वदा।
वेदमेकं सबहुधा कुरुते हितकाम्यया।
अल्पायुषोऽल्पबुद्धींश्च विप्रान् ज्ञात्वा कलावथ।
पुराणसंहितां पुण्यां कुरुतेऽसौ युगे युगे।

स्त्रीशूद्रद्विजबन्धूनां न वेदश्रवणं मतम्।
तेषामेव हितार्थाय पुराणानि कृतानि च।

देवीभागवतम्।

The following clearly states what is really the onlymeaning of the Veda or its subdivisions.

श्रुतिस्मृतिपुराणानि प्राहुरेकत्वमात्मनः।
अनुग्राहकतर्कश्च कुरुते तर्कवेदनम्।
शिवागमेषु चाद्वैतं बभाषे परमेश्वरः।
नारायणोऽपि चाद्वैतं बभाषे स्वागमेषु च।
अन्ये च योगिनः सर्वे प्राहुरद्वैतमात्मनः।
तथापि परमाद्वैतं नैव वांछन्ति मानवाः।
केचित्सामान्यमद्वैतं वदन्ति भ्रान्तचेतसः।
विशेषं द्वैतमाश्रित्यन तेषामस्तिवेदनम्।
द्वैतमेव हि सर्वत्र प्रवदन्ति हि केचन।
न ते मनुष्याःकीटाश्चपतङ्गाश्च कटा हि ते॥

सूतसंहिता।

“The Vedas, Smritis, Puranas, science of logic and allthe Agamas unanimously treat of the Oneness of the Supreme.The Yogis express the same opinion from their direct experience, and yet few are prepared to accept it. Some allowit to a small extent as a matter of courtesy and they are surelyfools. But there are others, who totally deny it and theyare neither human beings nor even the lowest kind of worms.They could only be treated as dead clod of earth”.

What is meant by Sruti or Veda has been already explained as the knowledge theoretically obtained from thegreat Rishis of their experience and results of experiments.The vedangas, six in number, come next. They are namedbelow—

छन्दः पादौ तु वेदस्य हस्तौ कल्पेऽथ पठ्यते।
ज्योतिषामयनं चक्षुर्निरुक्तं श्रोत्रमुच्यते।
शिक्षाघ्राणन्तु वेदस्य मुखं व्याकरणं स्मृतम्।
तस्मात्साङ्गमधीत्यैवब्रह्मलोके महीयते॥

** अर्थावबोधे निरपेक्षतया पदजातं यत्रोक्तं तन्निरुक्तम्॥**

छन्द्रः— is metrical science, prosody.

**कल्पः—**is a sacred precept or rule, low or ordinance.

**ज्योतिषं—**is a tract on astronomy.

**शिक्षा—**is the science which teaches the proper pronunciation of words and laws of euphony.

**व्याकरणं—**is grammar, grammatical analysis.

निरुकं— is etymological interpretation of words, especiallyof those occurring in the Vedas and which convey inthemselves without the help of other words, the intended meaning in full.

A knowledge of these six angas or limbs of the Vedas isabsolutely necessary to understand the correct and fullmeaning of the contents of the Vedas.
