Unless we remember thisfact throughout the enquiry of our subject we are sure to fallinto modern pit-falls in the elucidation of Hindu religion.All reasonable criticisms on moral, mental or physiologicalquestions connected with the subject may prove useful atleast to clear any doubts regarding the knowledge ourancients possessed. But all other attempts to pick holes byirrelevant methods will only fall out of the mark and proveunprofitable and uncharitable undertaking.

The very first principle in Hindu Religion here enunciated is this Yoga which is classified into Gnana-yoga andKarma-yoga. It is absolutely necessary to form very clear ideasof these terms to avoid mistakes later on. We have alreadyhad several definitions of them in the previous quotations.The following passages may furnish additional explanations.

संयोमस्त्वात्ममनसोर्योग इत्युच्यते बुधैः।
प्राणावानसमा योगो योग इत्यपि केचन।
विषयेन्द्रियसंयोगो योग इत्यप्यपण्डितैः॥
विषयासकचित्तानां ज्ञानं मोक्षश्चदूरतः॥

(1) स्कान्दं काशीखण्डम्।

कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम्।
तस्मात्सर्वगतं ब्रह्म नित्यं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम्।
एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं नानुवर्तयतीह यः।
अघायुरिन्द्रियारामो मोघं प्रार्थ ! स जीवति।
यस्त्वात्मरतिरेब स्यादात्मतृप्तश्च मानवः।
आत्मन्येव च सन्तुष्टः तस्य कार्यं न विद्यते।
नैव तस्य कृतेनार्थो नाकृतेनेह कञ्चन।
न चास्य सर्वभूतेषु कश्चिदर्थव्यपाश्रयः।
तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर।
असतो ह्याचरन् कर्म परमाप्नोति पूरुषः॥

(2) भगवद्गीता।

कर्मणा प्राप्यते धर्मो ज्ञानेन च न संशयः।
तस्मात् ज्ञानेम सहितं कर्मयोगं समाधयेत्।
प्रवृत्तं च निवृत्तं द्विविधं कर्म वैदिकम्।
ज्ञानपूर्वंनिवृत्तं स्थात् प्रवृत्तं वदतोऽन्यथा।
तस्मान्निवृतं संसेव्यं अन्यथा संसरेत्पुनः।
कर्मणा क्षीयते पापं ऐहिकं शैर्विकं तथा।
मनः प्रसादमध्येति ब्रह्म विज्ञायते नरः॥

(3) कूर्मपुराणम्।

किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः।
तत्ते कर्म प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात्।
कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः।
अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः। .
कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येत् अकर्माणि च कर्म यः।
स बुद्धिमान् मनुष्येषु स युक्तःकृत्स्नकर्मकृत्।
त्यक्त्वा कर्मफला सङ्गं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः।
कर्मण्यभिप्रवृत्तोऽपि नैव किञ्चित् करोति सः।
निराशीर्यतचित्तात्मा त्यतसर्वपरिग्रहः।
शारीरं केवलं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम्।
यथेधांसि समिद्धोऽग्निः भस्मसात् कुरुतेऽर्जुन !।
ज्ञानाग्निः सर्वकर्माणि भस्मसात् कुरुते तथा।
न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते।
तत्स्वयं योगसंसिद्धः कालेनात्मनि विन्दति।
श्रद्धावान् लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः।
ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्तिमचिरेणाधिगच्छति।
सांख्ययोगौ पृथक् बालाः प्रवदन्ति न पण्डिताः।
एकमप्यास्थितः सम्यगुभयोर्विन्दते फलम्।
यत्सांख्यैः प्राप्यते स्थानं तद्योगैरपि गम्यते।
एकं सांख्यं च योगं च यः पश्यति स पश्यति।
कायेन मनसा बुध्या केवलैरिन्द्रियैरपि।
योगिनः कर्म कुर्वन्ति सङ्गं त्यक्त्वात्मशुद्धये।
अनाश्रितः कर्मफलं कार्यं कर्म करोति यः
स सन्यासी च योगी च न निरग्निर्न चाक्रियः।
यं सन्यासमिति प्राहुः योगं तं विद्धि पाण्डव !।
न ह्यसन्यस्तसंङ्कल्पो योगी भवति कञ्चन।
आरुरुक्षोर्मुर्योगं कर्म कारणमुच्यते ।
यदा हि नेन्द्रियार्थेषु न कर्मस्वनुषज्जते।
सर्वसङ्कल्पसन्यासी योगारूढस्तदोच्यते।
यं लब्ध्वा चापरं लाभं मन्यते नाधिकं ततः।
यस्मिन् स्थितो न दुःखेन गुरुणापि विचाल्यते।
तं विद्यात् दुःखसंयोगवियोगं योगसंज्ञितम्।
युंजन्नेवं सदात्मानं योगी विगतकन्मषः।
सुखेन ब्रह्मसंस्पर्शमत्यन्तं सुखमश्नुते॥

( 4 ) भगवद्गीता॥

Q. No. I. The merging of the mind into Atma is, defined as Yoga, by the wise. The joining of Prana and Apanabreaths together is also known as Yoga among some people.The attainment of worldly desires is also styled Yoga by theignorant, to whom of course real knowledge or salvation isout of question.

Q. No. II. The Karmas ordained have originated fromthe Vedas and the Vedas from the Eternal Atma. TheKarmas being thus connected with the Eternal are requiredto be performed with the object of attaining the EternalAtman and with no other motive. They do not howeverrefer to those who have already attained the Atman and areenjoying Eternal bliss, as they have nothing to gain by theKarimas.

Q. No. III. The Karmas are either evolving or involving in their character. Those combined with gnanacause involution and they should be followed for the attainment of the Supreme as they destroy sins and bring on Eternal Happiness. But those tending to evolve, only increaseworldly miseries.

Q. No. IV. The Karmas are those ordained. Vikar,mas are those prohibited and Akarmas are those capableof producing no effects. Even the ordained ones should beperformed only so as to produce no effects relinquishing alldesires. The wise perform them in this manner. Gnana destroys the effects of all past Karmas as fire destroys fuel andleads to salvation. It is attained by constant practice ofYoga. Sankya and Yoga are not two distinctly separatemethods as their ultimate results are the sameis attained the other is also attained. There is no Sanyasawithout subduing the mind or relinquishing all desirescompletely as the word signifies. It is therefore synonymouswith Yoga. The Sanyasis and Yogis perform karmas without attachment, mentally, intellectually, physically and bythe mere senses with the object of purifying their hearts.Abandoning ordained karmas does not therefore inean Sanyasa or Yoga. Karmas are a matter of necesssity to thoseonly preparing for Yoga, but to those who have risen toYogi’s stage, mental quietness is more important. He is saidto have risen to the state of a Yogi who is not led away bythe senses, effects of Karmas or desires of any kind. Thatwhich leads to the greatest gain and that which is not affectedby sorrows or pains, is described as Yoga. By the practiceof this Yoga, all sins are removed and extreme happiness isenjoyed by the pleasant contact with the Brahman.

11. A very natural question which cannot bepassed over in this connection, is the one generally consideredmost important by common people, namely the utility of allthese practices prescribed in religion such as, Sankya. YogaKarma &c. Unless this can be scientifically proved andestablished it is impossible to convince any body of the necessity of religion. Any amount of authoritative injunctionsinsisting on blind belief cannot produce lasting or beneficialresults. It is therefore highly desirable to examine the textscarefully as to what cogent arguments are adduced for thispurpose.

विहाय कामान् यः सर्वान् पुमांश्चरति निस्पृहः।
निर्ममो निरहङ्कारः स शान्तिमधिगच्छति।
एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ! नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति।
स्थित्वास्यामन्तकालेऽपि ब्रह्म निर्वाणमृछति॥

(1) भगवद्गीता।

चित्तमेव हि संसारस्तत्प्रयत्नेन शोधयेत्।
यश्चित्तस्तन्मयो भवति गुह्यमेतत्सनातनम्।

चित्तस्य हिं प्रसादेन हन्तिकर्म शुभाशुभम्।
प्रसन्नात्मात्मनि स्थित्वा सुखमव्ययमश्नुते॥

(2) मैत्रेय्युपनिषत्।

चित्तसत्ता परं दुःखं चित्तत्यागः परं सुखम्।
अतश्चित्तं चिदाकाशे नयक्षयमवेदनात्।
दृष्ट्वा रम्यमरम्यं वा स्थेयं पाषाणवत्सदा।
एतावतात्मयत्नेन जिता भवति संसृतिः॥

(3) अन्नपूर्णोपनिषत्।

देहाभिमाने गलिते विज्ञाते परमात्मनि।
यत्र यत्र मनो याति तत्र तत्र परामृतम्।
भियते हृदयग्रन्थी छिद्यन्ते सर्वसंशयाः।
क्षीयन्ते चास्य कर्माणि तस्मिन् दृष्टे परावरे॥

( 4 ) सरस्वतीरहस्योपनिषत्।

Quotation No. I. Relinquishlng all desires and egoismleads to peace of mind, ultimately to salvation—

Q. No II. The inind is at the root of all worldlymiseries. It should therefore be scrutinised and purified. Itis also capable of producing every desired effects its servicesshould therefore be utilized for Yoga leading to Eternalhappiness.

Q. No. III. The tendency of the mind ever to sproutwith desires produces grief. Destruction of this tendency isproductive of happiness. It should therefore bedirected forthe practice of Yoga which will soon overcome all the worldlymiseries.

Q. No. 1V. After the destruction of egoism and theknowledge of Brahman, the mind enjoys felicity wherever itgoes. All doubts are then cleared and all sins are destroyed.

These quotations clearly state that by the processes ordained, the existing miseries of the world are got over aswell as the future possibilities of the same. Besides, eternalhappiness or bliss is also attained. But what is the sort ofhappiness obtainable and whether it is worth aiming at withthe amount of trouble and inconvenience incidental to religious practices, are discussed in detail in the followingpassages.

ब्रह्मानन्दं प्रवक्ष्यामि ज्ञाते तस्मिन्नशेषतः।
ऐहिकामुष्मिकानर्थव्रातं हित्वा सुखाय ते।
आनन्दस्त्रिविधो ब्रह्मानंन्दो विद्यासुखं तथा।
विषयानन्द इत्यादौ ब्रह्मानन्दो विविच्यते।
आनन्दादेव भूतानि जायन्ते तेन जीवनम्।
तेषां लयश्च तत्रातो ब्रह्मानन्दो न संशयः।
विज्ञानमय उत्पन्नो ज्ञाता ज्ञानं मनोमयः।
ज्ञेयाः शब्दादयो नैतत्त्रयमुत्पत्तितः पुरा।
त्रयाभावे तु निद्वैतः पूर्ण एवानुभूयते।
समाधिसुप्तिमूर्छासु पूर्णः सृष्टेः पुरा तथा।
मास्त्वद्वैते सुखं किन्तु सुखमद्वैतमेव हि
किं मानमिति चेन्नास्ति मानाकांक्षा स्वयं प्रभे।
स्तामद्वैतस्वप्रभत्वे वद सुप्तौ सुखं कथम्।
शृणु दुःखं तदा नास्ति ततस्ते शिष्यते सुखम्।
अंधस्सन्नप्यनन्धः स्याद्विद्धोऽविद्धोऽथ रोग्यपि।
अरोगीति श्रुतिः प्राह तच्च सर्वे जना विदुः।
न दुःखाभावमात्रेण सुखं लोष्टशिलादिषु।
द्वयाभावस्य दृष्टत्वादिति चेद्विषमं वचः।
मुखदैन्यविकासाभ्यां परदुःखसुखोहनम्।
दैन्याद्यभावतो लोष्टे दुखाद्व्यूहो न सम्भवेत्।
स्वकीये सुखदुःखे तु नोहनीये ततस्तयोः।
भावो वेद्योऽनुभूत्यैव तदभावोऽपि नान्यतः।
महत्तरप्रयासेन मृदुशय्यादिसाधनम्।
कुतः सम्पाद्यते सुप्तौ सुखं चेत्तत्र नो भवेत्।
दुःखनाशार्थमेवैतदिति चेद्रोगिणस्तथा।
भवत्वरोगिणस्त्वेतत्सुखायैवेति निश्चिनु।
तर्हिसाधनजन्यत्वात्सुखं वैषयिकं भवेत्।
भवत्वेवात्र निद्रायाः पूर्वं शय्यासनादिजम्।
निद्रायां तु सुखं यत्तज्जन्यते केन हेतुना।
सुखाभिमुखधीरादौ पश्चान्मज्जेत्परे सुखे।
आत्माभिमुखधीवृत्तौ स्वानन्दः प्रतिबिम्बति।
अनुभूयैनमत्रापि त्रिपुट्या श्रान्तिमाप्नुयात्।
तच्छ्रमस्यापनुत्यर्थं जीवो धावेत्परात्मनि।
तेनैक्यं प्राप्य तत्रस्थो ब्रह्मानन्दः स्वयं भवेत्।
कुमारादिवदेवायं ब्रह्मानन्दैकतत्परः।
स्त्रीपरिष्वक्तवद्वेद न बाह्यं नापि चान्तरम्।
बाह्यं रथ्यादिकं वृत्तं गृहकृत्यं यथान्तरम्।
तथा जागरणं बाह्यं नाडस्थिःस्वप्न आन्तरः।
सुखमस्वाप्समत्राहं न वै किश्चिदवेदिषम्।
इतिसुप्ते सुखज्ञाने परामृशति चोत्थितः।
यदज्ञानं तत्र लीनौ तौ विज्ञानमनोमयौ।
तयोर्हि विलयावस्था निद्राऽज्ञानं च सैव हि।
विलीनघृतवत्पश्चात्स्याद्विज्ञानमयो घनः।
विलीनावस्थ आनन्दमयशब्देन कथ्यते।
सुप्तिपूर्वक्षणे बुद्धिवृत्तिर्या सुखबिम्बिता।
सैव तद्बिम्बसहिता लीनानन्दमयस्ततः।
अन्तर्मुखो य आनन्दमयो ब्रह्म सुखं तदा।
भुक्ते चिद्विबम्बयुक्ताभिरज्ञानोत्पन्नवृत्तिभिः।
अज्ञानवृत्तयस्सूक्ष्मा विस्पष्टा बुद्धिवृत्तयः।
इति वेदान्तसिद्धान्तपारगाःप्रवदन्ति हि।
विज्ञानमयमुख्यैर्यो रूपैर्युक्तःपुराधुना।
स लयेनैकतां प्राप्तो बहुतण्डुलपिष्टवत्।
प्रज्ञानानि पुरा बुद्धिवृत्तयोऽथ घनोऽभवत्।
घनत्वं हिमबिन्दूनामुदग्देशे यथा तथा।
तद्धनत्वं साक्षिभावं दुःखाभावं प्रचक्षते।
लौकिकस्तार्किका यावत् दुःखवृत्तिविलोपनात्।
अज्ञानबिम्बिता चित्स्यान्मुखमानन्दभोजने।
भुक्तं ब्रह्म सुखं त्यक्त्वा बहिर्यात्यथ कर्मणा।
आस्तामेतद्यत्र यत्र सुखं स्याद्विषयैर्विना।
तत्र सर्वत्र विध्येतां ब्रह्मानन्दस्य वासनाम्।
विषयेष्वपि लब्धेषु तदिछोपरमे सति।
अन्तर्मुखमनोवृत्तावानन्दः प्रतिबिम्बति॥

पञ्चदशी।

ब्रह्मानन्दो वासना च प्रतिबिम्ब इति त्रयम्।
अन्तरेण जगत्यस्मिन् आनन्दो नास्ति कश्चन।
तथाच विषयानन्दो वासनानन्द इत्यम्।
आनन्दौ जनयत्रास्ते ब्रह्मानन्दः स्वयम्प्रभः।
य आनन्दमयः सुप्तौ स विज्ञानमयात्मताम्।
गत्वा स्वप्नं प्रबोधं च प्राप्नोति स्थानभेदतः।
नेत्रे जागरणं कण्ठे स्वप्नः सुप्तिर्हृदम्बुजे।
आपादमस्तकं देहं व्याप्य जागर्ति चेतनः।
देहतादात्म्यमापन्नस्तप्तायः पिण्डवत्ततः।
अहं मनुष्य इत्येवं निश्चित्यैवोवतिष्ठते।
उदासीनः सुखी दुःखीत्यवस्थात्रयमेत्यसौ।
सुखदुःखे कर्मकार्ये त्वौदासीभ्यं स्वभावतः।
बाह्यभोगान्मनोराज्यात्सुखदुःखे द्विधा मते।
सुखदुःखान्तरालषु भवेत्तूष्णीमवस्थितिः।
न कापि चिन्तामेऽस्यद्य सुखमास इति ब्रुवन्।
औदासीन्ये निजानन्दभानं वक्त्यखिलो जनः।
अहमस्मीत्यहङ्कारसामान्याच्छादितत्वतः।
निजानन्दो म मुख्योऽयं किंत्वसौ तस्य वासना।
नीरपूरितभाण्डस्य बाह्ये शैत्यं न तज्जलम्।
किन्तु नीरगुणस्तेन नीरसत्तानुंमीयते।
यावद्यावदहङ्कारो विस्मृतोऽभ्यासयोगतः।
तावत्तावत्सूक्ष्मदृष्टेः निजानन्दोऽनुमीयते।
सर्वात्मना विस्मृतस्सन् सूक्ष्मतां परमां व्रजेत्।
तूष्णीं स्थितौ न शून्यत्वं शून्यबुद्धेश्च वर्जनात्।
अलीनत्वान्ननिद्रैषा ततो देहोऽपि नो पतेत्॥

निराकाशे सदादीनामनुभूतिर्निजात्मनि।
अवकाशे विस्मृतेऽथ तत्र किं भाति ते वद।
शून्यमेवेति चेदस्तु नाम तादृक् विभाति हि।
अत्यन्तं निर्जगद्व्योम यथा ते बुद्धिमाश्रितम्।
तथैव सन्निराकाशं कुतो नाश्रयते मतिम्।
निर्जगद्व्योम दृष्टं चेत् प्रकाशतमसी विना।
क्व दृष्टं किञ्च ते पक्षे न प्रत्यक्षं वियत् खलु।
अभावो येन भावेन ज्ञायते शून्यवादिना।
तस्य भावस्य सद्भावो वद केन निवार्यते।
निरधिष्ठानविभ्रान्तेरभावादात्मनोऽस्तिता।
शून्यस्यापि स साक्षित्वादन्यथा नोक्तिरस्ति ते॥

तादृक्त्वादेव तत्सत्त्वं औदासीन्येन तत्सुखम्।
आनुकूल्यप्रातिकूल्यहीनं यत्तन्निजं सुखम्।
आनुकूल्ये हर्षधीः स्यात्प्रातिकूल्ये तु दुःखधीः।
द्वयाभावे निजानन्दो निजदुःखं न तु क्वचित्।
निजानन्दे स्थिरे हर्षशोकयोर्व्यत्ययः क्षणात्।
मनसः क्षणिकत्वेन तयोर्मानसतेष्यताम्।
तच्चिन्तनं तत्कथनमन्योन्यं तत्प्रबोधनम्।
एतदेकपरत्वं च ब्रह्माभ्यासं विदुर्बुधाः॥
विषयानन्दवद् विद्यानन्दो धीवृत्तिरूपकः।
दुःखाभावादिरूपेण प्रोक्त एष चतुर्विधः।
दुःखाभावाश्च कामाप्तिः कृतकृत्योऽहमित्यसौ।

प्राप्तप्राप्योऽहमित्येव चातुर्विध्यमुदाहृतम्।
ऐहिकं चामुष्मिकञ्चेत्येवं दुःखं द्विधेरितम्।
जीवात्मा परमात्मा चेत्यात्मा द्विविध ईरितः।
चित्तादात्म्यात्रिभिर्द्देहैर्जीवस्सन् भोक्तृतां व्रजेत्।
परात्मा सच्चिदानन्दस्तादात्म्यं नाम रूपयोः।
गत्वा भोग्यत्वमापनस्तद्विवेके तु नो भयम्।
भोग्यभिछन् भोक्तुरर्थे शरीरमनुसंज्वरेत्।
ज्वरास्त्रिषु शरीरेषु स्थिता न त्वात्मनो ज्वराः।
व्याधयो धातुवैषम्ये स्थूलदेहे स्थिता ज्वराः।
कामः क्रोधादयः सूक्ष्मे द्वयोर्बीजं तु कारणे।
अद्वैतानन्दमार्गेण परात्मनि विवेचिते।
अपश्यन् वास्तवं भोग्यं किन्नामेछेत्परात्मवित्।
सार्वभौमादिसूत्रान्ता उत्तरोत्तरकामिनः।
अवाङ्मनसगम्योऽयमात्मानन्दस्ततः परः।
तैस्तैः काम्येषु सर्वेषु सुखेषु श्रोत्रियो यतः।
निस्पृहस्तेन सर्वेषामानन्दाः सन्ति तस्य ते।
सर्वकामाप्तिरेषोक्ता यद्वा साक्षी चिदात्मना।
स्वदेहवत्सर्वदेहेष्वपि भोगानवेक्षते॥

अथात्र विषयानन्दो ब्रह्मानन्दांशरूपभाक्।
निरूप्यते द्वारभूतस्तदंशत्वं श्रुतिर्जगौ।
एषोऽस्य परमानन्दो योऽखण्डैकरसात्मकः।
अन्यानि भूतान्येतस्य मात्रा मेवोपभुंजते।
शान्ता घोरास्तथा मूढा मनसो वृत्तयस्त्रिधा।
वैराग्यं क्षान्तिरौदार्यं इत्याद्याश्शान्तवृत्तयः।
तृष्णा स्नेहो रागलोभावित्याद्याघोरवृत्तयः।
सम्मोहो भयमित्यांद्याः कथिता मूढवृत्तयः।
वृत्तिष्वेतासु सर्वासु ब्रह्मणश्चित्स्वभावता।
प्रतिबिम्बति शान्तासु सुखं च प्रतिबिम्बति।
जले प्रविष्टश्चन्द्रोऽयं अस्पष्टः कलुषे जले।

विस्पष्टो निर्मले तद्वद्वेधा ब्रह्मापि वृत्तिषु।
न घोरासु न मूढासु सुखानुभव ईक्ष्यते।
शान्तास्वपिक्वचित् कश्चित्सुखातिशय ईक्ष्यताम्।
गृहक्षेत्रादिविषये यदा कामोभवेत्तदा।
राजसस्यास्य कामस्य घोरत्त्वात्तत्र नो सुखम्।
काम्यलाभे हर्षवृत्तिः शान्ता तत्र महत्सुखम्।
भोगे महत्तरं लाभप्रसक्तावीषदेव हि।
महत्तमं विरक्तौ तु विद्यानन्दे तदीरितम्।
एवं क्षान्तौ तथौदार्ये क्रोधलोभनिवारणात्।
यद्यत्सुखं भवेत्तत्तत् ब्रह्मैव प्रतिबिम्बनात्।
वृत्तिष्वन्तर्मुखा स्वस्य निर्विघ्नं प्रतिबिम्बनम्।
सत्ता चितिस्सुखं चेति स्वभावा ब्रह्मणस्त्रयः।
मृछिलादिषु सत्तैव व्यज्यते नेतरद्वयम्।
सत्ता चितिर्द्वयं व्यक्तं धीवृत्या घोरमूढयोः।
शांतवृत्तात्रयं व्यक्तं मिश्रं ब्रह्मेत्थमीरितम्।
अमिश्रं ज्ञानयोगाभ्यां तौ च पूर्वमुदीरितौ।
असत्ता जाड्यदुःखे द्वे मायारूपं त्रयन्त्विदम्।
असत्ता नरशृङ्गादौ जाड्यंकाष्ठशिलादिषु।
घोरमूढधियोर्दुःखं एवं मायाविजृम्भिता।
शान्तादिबुद्धिवृत्यैक्या न्मिश्रं ब्रह्मेति कीर्तितम्।
एवं स्थितेऽत्र यो ब्रह्म ध्यातुमिछेत्पुमानसौ।
नृशृङ्गादिमुपेक्षेत शिष्टं ध्यायेद्यथातथम्।
शिलादौनामरूपेद्वेत्यक्त्वासन्मात्रचिन्तनम्।
त्यक्त्वा दुःखं घोरमूढधियोः सञ्चिद्विचिन्तनम्।
शान्तासु सच्चिदानन्दांस्त्रीनप्येवं विचिन्तयेत्।
कनिष्ठमध्यमोत्कृष्टास्तिस्राश्चिन्ताः क्रमादिमाः।
मन्दस्य व्यवहारेऽपि मिश्रब्रह्मणि चिन्तनम्।
उत्कृष्टं वक्तुमेवात्र विषयानन्द ईरितः।
औदासीन्ये तु धीवृत्तेः शैथिल्यादुत्तमोत्तमम्।

चिन्तनं वासनानन्दे ध्यानमुक्तं चतुर्विधम्।
न ध्यानं ज्ञानयोगाभ्यां ब्रह्मविद्यैव सा खलु।
ध्यानेनैकाग्र्यमापन्ने चित्ते विद्यास्थिरीभवेत्।
विद्यायां सच्चिदानन्दा अखण्डैकरसात्मताम्।
प्राप्य भान्ति न भेदेन भेदकोपाधिवर्जनात्।
शान्ता घोराः शिलाद्याश्च भेदकोपाधयो मताः।
योगाद्विवेकतो वैषा मुपाधीनामपाकृतिः।
निरुपाधिब्रह्मतत्वे भासमाने स्वयम्प्रभे।
अद्वैते त्रिपुटी नास्ति भूमानन्दोऽत उच्यते॥

Ananda or happiness is classified into three sorts,Brahmananda, Vidyananda and Vishayananda; the last twobeing only varieties of the first. Before creation, the triad,namely knowledge, knower and the known is absent. Itbecomes absent in Samadhi, sleep and giddiness. In Samadhitherefore, the idea of enjoyment of happiness cannot belogically predicted, but the state of Samadhi is eternalbliss itself. It is self-luminent and need not be describedor measured.

The happiness in sleep is next explained. In sleep theblind is not blind, the wounded is not wounded and the illis not ill. This is established by Sruti as well as by experience. It is no doubt from the absence of grief or painin sleep that the existence of happiness is inferred. Butthis argument cannot however be extended to the stones orother inorganic substances, which exhibit no signs of griefor pain. The inference of pleasure or pain enjoyed, isgenerally drawn from the external features of the livingbody which are absent in these. Downy cushions and otherconveniences for sleep are generally procured at great costand trouble. If there is no happiness in sleep why shouldthis be done? If they are meant for the removal of pain, theyought to cure diseases causing pain, which they do notThat these are capable of producing some comfort and pleasurebefore sleep may be admitted, but still the question of happiness alleged to exist during sleep remains unanswered.The explanaticn is as follows. The Jiva when tired ofthe waking state of life in which the triad (of knower, knownand knowledge) exists, returns to the Brahman its originalsource, and becoming one with it, obtains the Brahmaic felicity which is neither internal nor external like the happinessenjoyed in the fond embrace of a dearly beloved wife. Justbefore sleep, when all the mental functions are abated, theIntellect enjoys quietude and consequent felicity, with whichit emerges itself also into Ignorance or the cause body, whereall the effects of past Karmas or Vasanas get consolidated forthe time being like water into ice, or like a measure of ricereduced to flour losing the individuality of the grains. Thisstate is known as sleep, Agnana or Anandamayakosa. Agnanais established owing to the forced return to the miseries ofthe waking state, still to toil on in accordance with the effectsof previous Karmas.

Whenever the mind turns inside leaving all the externalobjects, the Vasana, the symptom of Brahmaic felicity isexperienced. After the attainment of a desired object alsothe mind rests in contentment and the same sort of felicityis obtained. It is the same felicity that appears in all thethree states in different forms, in sleep, dream and wakingstate In the waking state it occupies the whole body likefire in a heated piece of iron and maintains the idea that ‘Iam a human being &c.’ In that state. happiness, grief andindifference or rest in contentment are experienced. Happiness and grief are related to action, indifference or rest toinaction. Happiness and grief are again either external andinternal, by actions and thought. The interim betweenhappiness and grief is rest; during which all people experienceand express the existence of a felicity on account of thewant of mental worries. The mere egoism, the feelingthat I am, is alone existent at the time. The felicity experienced under this condition is known as Vasanananda.Although it is not exactly the Brahmnaic felicity it has someof its symptoms. By contact with a pot filled with cold water,the feeling of cold is experienced though it is not the watercontained in the pot. This felicity increases in proportion tothe abandonment of egoism, which when completely abandonedfull felicity is procured. This is exactly the happiness obtained by Samadhi. It is unlike the consolidation of mentalfunctions in sleep, but it is the abandonment of all such functions. Samadhi is therefore not sleep and the scientific prooffor it lies in the fact that the physical body does not fallduring the process. When all the material objects are forgotten, that which remains is the Akasa or Ether. Whenthat idea is also eliminated, the Brahman is experieneed.It is not void or nothing, for the simple reason that it isunseen. The Akasa itself is unseen as no idea of it could beformed without light or darkness mixed with it. Bothare therefore ideas conceivable by the IntellectNihilists affirming non-existence cannot logically deny theexistence of the self. The discovery of the non-existence ofthe phenomenal which is destitute of foundation, confirmsthe existence of the self which is conscious of Nihilism itself.Similarly the happiness attached to the Brahman is likethat experieneed in the complete absence of pleasure andpain, which state of happiness is seldom enjoyed long, owingto the tendency of mind to bring on pleasure and pain constantly. Vidyanada or happiness arising from self-knowledgeis also a modification of the Intellect like Vishayananda ormaterial happiness. It is of four sorts: absence of pain ormisery—acquisition of the desired object, satisfaction ofhaving accomplished the proper work and the attianmentof what ought to be attained. By proper philosophicalanalysis and meditation, happiness accrues from the specifiedstates.

In the analysis of material happiness or Vishayananda,the three states of mind have to be noticed. Namely, tranquil,(Santa) active, (Ghora) and ignorant (Moodha). Resignation,generosity &c. fall under tranquil modifications, avarice, passion, desire &c. come under active, folly and fear underignorant states of mind. The Brahman reflects in the mindaccording to the respective clearness of these states In theactive and ignorant states, the reflection is absent owing totheir want of clearness. In the tranquil state alone, thereis slight reflection at times.

Existence, Intelligence and bliss are the three attributesof Brahman as already noticed. In clay, stone &c. there isonly, existence. In the active and ignorant states of mind,existence and Intelligence are present. In the tranquil statebliss also is present. When all the three attributes are thuspresent, it is known as Misra-Bramhan or mixed withBrahman. In Gnana and Yoga the connection of Brahmanis purer.

The attributes of Maya are opposed to those of Brahmanas non-existence, dullness and misery. Man’s horn is anexample of non-existence; dullness or want of intelligenceis perceivable in wood and stone; and misery in the activeand ignorant states of mind. In the tranquil state there is atouch of Brahman as already described.

In consideration of all the facts detailed above regardingMaya, Brahman and mind, any one desirous of meditating onBrahman should reject non existence like man’s horn etc. andmeditate on,

(1) Existence, in stones etc. omiting their formsand names.

(2) Existence and Intelligence, in active and ignorant states of mind.

(3) Existence, intelligence and bliss, in tranquilstates of mind.

These are the three kinds of meditation in their order ofimportance.

The fourth and the most important one is meditation orVasanananda already described where all the functions of theIntellect are at a stand still. Complete bliss is attained bythis process and it is known as ‘Bhumananda’.

The above quotations give a complete idea of the definitePsychological theories long known to the ancient Rishis anddetailed in ancient religious literature. The theories are sological and so clear that they will not brook any wanton oroff-hand criticisms. The whole of it is pure Psychology untainted with any sectarianisms or superstitions, and too plainand unambiguous to allow any scope for esoterisms or occultisms except perhaps when read by those possessing extremely dull brains. The various grades of religious practiceordained, will and must conform to the general Psychologicalprinciples here enunciated. The real utility and religiousnecessity will therefore doubtless depend upon their conformity with them. All mischievous attempts to establish religious sanction for illogical and unscientific follies or wickedness should only be boldly rejected as stupid or pernicious asthe case may be. This work however is not so very difficultto accomplish with the help of common sense and liberal education. But the real difficulty and danger lie in the correctunderstanding of the meanings of practical details, expressedin the ancient style. Every earnest enquirer is likely to belead astray and to be easily disgusted, even by respectfullylistening to the ignorant, dogmatic and irrelevant interpretations of the modern self-constituted authorities, the majorityof them being completely innocent of such serious subjects.It is thus, that the purely vedantic portion of our religion issomewhat appreciated by Western scholars, but the practicaland most valuable portion is viewed with suspicion and considered mythological and unscientific. The main object of thisbook is to seek for reasonable explanations available in thetexts themselves with a view to remove the mistaken impressions, and if possible to create a scientific interest in the so-called mythologies. Most valuable and scientific truths contained in the sacred literature became mythical at first to theIndian Pundits themselves, owing to their degeneration andconsequent incapacity to understand them in their properlight. It is therefore no wonder and certainly no injusticethat alien nations with their present advanced civilizationshould criticise the same in the manner they do. It ishowever only surprising that they are so tolerent in spiteof the very flagrant absurdities shamelessly exhibited in thelocal interpretations.

In these circumstances, it is highly necessary that ageneral description of the practical processes prescribed forreligious advancement should be noticed here, at least asbriefly as possible. Every text on the subject starts withYoga. This word has been sufficiently explained already invarious manner. But its root meaning, gives the exactapplication, namely Yuj, to join the lower self with thehigher, the Jivatma with the Paramatma. It is thus themost general term used in the Technology of this literature.Yoga is generally classified into Gnana-yoga and Karma-yoga, but the one is not completely exclusive of the other,the functions of thought or mind are more prominent in theformer and those of action in the latter. This main distinction however, is sometimes applied in a higher and oftenin a some-what lower sense. For instance, pure meditationof Bramhan is styled Gnana-yoga and other mental functionspreparatory to Dhyana or meditation are known as Karma-yoga, without having any reference to physical action.This is a higher and more philosophical application. Inthe same manner, more prominence being given to physicalaction, the religious Karmas performed, without any desirefor the fruits thereof are styled Karma yoga. In all thesehowever the prevailing idea is action, physical, mental or both, but not idleness, sleep or intoxication.

प्रथमोमन्त्रयोगश्च स्पर्शयोगो द्वितीयकः।
भावयोगस्तृतीयस्यादभावश्च चतुर्थकः।
सर्वोत्तमो महायोगः पञ्चमः परिकीर्तितः।
ध्यानयुक्तो जपाभ्यासो मन्त्रयोगः प्रकीर्तितः।
नाडीशुध्यधिकोयस्तु रेचकादि क्रमान्वितः।
समस्तव्यस्तयोगेन जयोवायोः प्रकीर्तितः।
बलस्थिरक्रियायुक्तो धारणाद्यैश्चशोभनैः।
धारणात्रयसंदीप्तो भेदत्रय विशोधकः।
कुम्भकावस्थितोभ्यासः स्पर्शयोगः प्रकीर्तितः।
मन्त्रस्पर्शविनिर्मुक्तो महादेवं समाश्रितः।
बहिरन्तर्विभागस्थःस्फुरत्संहरणात्मकः।
भावयोगस्समाख्यातः चित्तशुद्धिप्रदायकः।
विलीनावयवं सर्वं जगत्स्थावरजङ्गमम्।
शून्यं सर्वं निराभासं स्वरूपं यत्र चिन्त्यते।
अभावयोगः सम्प्रोक्तश्चित्तनिर्वाणकारणः।
नीरूपःकेवलः शुद्धः स्वच्छन्दश्च सुशोभनः।
अनिर्देश्यः सदालोक्यः स्वयं वेद्यः समन्ततः।
स्वभावो भासते यत्र महायोगः प्रकीर्तितः।
नित्योदितः स्वयंज्योतिः सर्वचित्तसमुत्थितः।
निर्मलः केवलोह्यात्मा महायोग इति स्मृतः।
अणिमादिप्रदाः सर्वे सर्वे ज्ञानस्य दायकाः।
उत्तरोत्तरवैशिष्ट्यमेषु योगेष्वनुक्रमात्॥

(1) लिङ्गपुराणम्।

यमोहि नियमस्त्यागो मौनं देशश्च कालतः।
आसनं मूलबन्धश्च देहसाम्यश्च दृक् स्थितिः।
प्राणसंयमनश्चैव प्रत्याहारश्च धारणा।
आत्मध्यानं समाधिश्च प्रोक्तान्यङ्गानि वै क्रमात्।
सर्वं ब्रह्मेति वै ज्ञानादिन्द्रियग्रामसंयमः।
यमोयभितिसम्प्रोक्तोभ्यसनीयो मुहुर्मुहुः।
सजातीयप्रवाहश्च विजातीयतिरस्कृतिः।
नियमोहि परानन्दो नियमात्क्रियते बुधैः।
त्यागोहिमहतापूज्यः सद्यो मोक्षप्रदायकः।
यस्माद्वाचोनिवर्तन्ते अप्राप्यमनसा सह।
यन्मौनं योगिभिर्गम्यं तत्भजेत्सर्वदा वुधः।
आदावन्ते च मध्ये च जनो यस्मिन्न विद्यते।
येनेदं सततं व्याप्तं सदेशो विजनः स्मृतः।
कल्पना सर्वभूतानां ब्रह्मादीनां निमेषतः।
कालशब्देन निर्दिष्टं ह्यखण्डानन्दमद्वयम्।
सुखेनैव भवेद्यस्मिन्नजस्रं ब्रह्मचिन्तनम्।
आसनं तद्विजानीयादन्यत्सुखविनाशनम्।
सिद्धये सर्वभूतादिविश्वाधिष्ठानमद्वयम्।
यस्मिन् सिद्धिं गताः सिद्धास्तत्सिद्धासनमुच्यते।
यन्मूलं सर्वलोकानां यन्मूलं चित्तबन्धनम्।
मूलबन्धस्सदासेव्यो योग्योसौ ब्रह्मवादिनाम्।
अङ्गानां समता विद्यात्समे ब्रह्मणि लीयते।
नो चेन्नैव समानत्वं ऋजुत्वं शुष्कवृक्षवत्।
दृष्टिं ज्ञानमयीं कृत्वा पश्येत् ब्रह्ममयं जगत्।
सादृष्टिः परमोदारा न नासाग्रावलोकिनी।
द्रष्टृदर्शनदृश्यानां विरामो यत्र वा भवेत्।
दृष्टिस्तत्रैव कर्तव्या न नासाग्रावलोकिनी।
चित्तादिसर्वभावेषु ब्रह्मत्वेनैव भासनात्।
निरोधस्सर्ववृत्तीनां प्राणायामः स उच्यते।
निषेधनं प्रपञ्चस्य रेचकाख्यस्समीरितः।
ब्रह्मैवास्मीति या वृत्तिः पूरकोवायुरुच्यते।
ततस्तद्वृत्तिनैश्चल्यं कुम्भकः प्राणसंयमः।
अयश्चापि प्रबुद्धानां अज्ञानां घ्राणपीडनम्।
विषयेष्वात्मतां दृष्ट्वा मनसञ्चित्तरंजकम्।
प्रत्याहारस्सविज्ञेयोऽभ्यसनीयो मुहुर्मुहुः।
यत्र यत्र मनो याति ब्रह्मणस्तत्रदर्शनात्।
मनसा धारणश्चैव धारणा सा परा मता।
ब्रह्मैवास्मीति सद्वृत्या निरालम्बतया स्थितिः।
ध्यानशब्देन विख्यातः परमानन्ददायकः।
निर्विकारतया वृत्या ब्रह्माकारतया पुनः।
वृतिविस्मरणं सम्यक् समाधिरभिधीयते।

(2) तेजोबिन्दूपनिषत्।

देहेन्द्रियेषु वैराग्यं यम इत्युच्यते बुधैः।
अनुरक्तिः परे तत्वे सततं नियमः स्मृतः
सर्ववस्तुन्युदासीनभावं आसनमुत्तमम्।
जगत्सर्वमिदं मिथ्याप्रतीतिः प्राणसंयमः।
चित्तस्यान्तर्मुखीभावः प्रत्याहारस्तु सत्तम।
चित्तस्य निश्चलीभावो धारणा धारणं विदुः।
सोऽहं चिन्मात्रमेवेति चिन्तनं ध्यानमुच्यते।
ध्यानस्य विस्मृतिः सम्यक् समाधिरभिधीयते॥

अहिंसा सत्यमस्तेयं ब्रह्मचर्यं दयार्जवम्।
क्षमा धृतिर्मिताहारः शोचञ्चेति यमादश।
तपस्सन्तुष्टिरास्तिक्यं दानमाराधनं हरेः।
वेदान्तश्रवणञ्चैव ह्रीर्मतिश्च जपो व्रतः।
आसनानि तदङ्गानि स्वस्तिकादीनि वैद्विज।
वर्ण्यन्ते स्वस्तिकं पादतलयोरुभयोरपि।
पूर्वोत्तरेजानुनी द्वे कृत्वासनमुदीरितम्।
सव्ये दक्षिणगुल्फन्तु पृष्ठपार्श्वे नियोजयेत्।
दक्षिणेऽपि तथा सव्यं गोमुखं गोमुखं यथा।
एकं चरणमन्यस्मिन् ऊरोवारोप्य निश्चलः।
आस्तेयदिदमेनोक्तं वीरासनमुदीरितम्।
गुदं नियम्यगुल्फाभ्यां व्युत्क्रमेण समाहितः।
योगासनं भवेदेतदिति योगविदो विदुः।
ऊर्वोरुपरिवैधत्ते यदा पादतले उभे।
पद्मासनं भवेदेतत्सर्वव्यापि विषापहम्।
पद्मासनं सु संस्थाप्य जानूर्वोरन्तरे करौ।
निवेश्य भूमावातिष्ठे द्व्योमस्थः कुक्कुटासनः।
कुक्कुटासन बन्धस्थो दोर्भ्यांसम्बध्य कन्धरम्।
शेते कूर्मवदुत्तान एतदुत्तानकूर्मकम्।
पादांगुष्ठौ तु पाणिभ्यां गृहत्विा श्रवणावधि।
धनुराकर्षकाकृष्टं धनुरासनमीरितम्।
सीविनीं गुल्फदेशाभ्यां निपीड्यव्युत्क्रमेण तु।
प्रसार्य जानुनोर्हस्ता वासनं सिंहरूपकम्।
गुल्फौ च वृषणस्याधः सीविन्युभयपार्श्वयोः।
निवेश्य पादौ हस्ताभ्यां बध्वाभद्रासनं भवेत्।
सीविनीपार्श्वमुभयं गुल्फाभ्यां व्युत्क्रमेणतु।
निपीड्यासनमेतच्च मुक्तासनमुदीरितम्।
अवष्टभ्य धरां सम्यक् तलाभ्यां हस्तयोर्द्वयोः।
कूर्परौ नाभिपार्श्वे तु स्थापयित्वा मयूरवत्।
समुन्नतशिरः पादं मयूरासनमिष्यते।
वामोरुमूले दक्षांघ्रि जान्वोर्वेष्टितपाणिना।
वामेन वामांगुष्ठन्तु गृहीतं मत्स्यपीठकम्।
योनिं वामेन सम्पीड्य मेढ्रादुपरिदक्षिणम्।
ऋजुकायस्समासीनः सिद्धासनमुदीरितम्।
प्रसार्य भुविपादौ तु दोर्भ्यामङ्गुष्ठमादरात्।
जानूपरि ललाडन्तु पश्चिमन्ताणमुच्यते।
येनकेनप्रकारेण सुखं धार्यञ्चजायते।
तत्सुखासनमित्युक्तं अशकस्त समाचरेत्।
आसनं विजितं येन जितं तेन जगत्रयम्।
यमैश्च नियमैश्चैव आसनैश्च सु संयतः।
नाडीशुद्धिश्च कृत्वादौ प्राणायामं समाचरेत्॥

( 3 ) त्रिशिखब्राह्मणोपनिषत्

Quotation No. IV.

सांकृते शृणुवक्ष्यामि योगं साष्टाङ्गदर्शनम्।
यमश्च नियमश्चैव तथैवासनमेव च।
प्राणायामस्तथा ब्रह्मन् प्रत्याहारस्ततः परम्।
धारणा च तथाध्यानं समाधिश्चाष्टमं मुने।
अहिंसा सत्यमस्तेयं ब्रह्मचर्यं दयार्जवम्।
क्षमा धृतिर्मिताहारः शौचं चैव यमादश।
वेदोक्तेन प्रकारेण विना सत्यन्तपोधन।
कायेन मनसा वाचा हिंसा हिंसानचान्यथा।
आत्मा सर्वगतोच्छेद्यो न ग्राह्य इति मे मतिः
सचाहिंसा वरा प्रोक्ता मुने बेदान्त वेदिभिः।
चक्षुरादीन्द्रियैर्दृष्टं श्रुतं घ्रातं मुनीश्वर।
तस्यैवोक्तिर्भवेत्सत्यं विप्रतन्नान्यथा भवेत्।
सर्वंसत्यं परं ब्रह्म न चान्यदिति या मतिः।
तच्चसत्यं वरं प्रोक्तं वेदान्तज्ञानपारगैः।
अन्यदीये तृणे रत्ने काञ्चने मौक्तिकेऽपि च।
मनसा विनिवृत्तिर्या तदस्तेयं विदुर्बुधाः।
आत्मन्यवात्मभावेन व्यवहारविवर्जितम्।
यत्तदस्तेयमित्युक्तं आत्मविद्भिर्महामते।
कायेन वाचा मनसा स्त्रीणांपरि विवर्जनम्।
ऋतौ भार्यां तदा स्वस्य ब्रह्मचर्यंं तदुच्यते।
ब्रह्मभावे मनश्चारं ब्रह्मचर्यं परन्तप।
स्वात्मवत्सर्वभूतेषु कायेन मनसा गिरा।
अनुज्ञा या दया सैव प्रोक्ता वेदान्त वेदिभिः।
पुत्रे मित्रे कलत्रे च रिपौ स्वात्मनि सन्ततम्।
एकरूपं मुने यत्तदार्जवं प्रोच्यते मया।
कायेन मनसा वाचा शत्रुभिः परिपीडिते।
बुद्धिक्षोभनिवृत्तिर्या क्षमा सा मुनिपुङ्गव।
वेदादेवविनिर्मोक्षस्संसारस्य नचान्यथा।
इतिविज्ञाननिष्पत्तिधृतिप्रोक्ता हि वैदिकैः।
अहमान्मा न चान्योस्मीत्येवमप्रच्युता मतिः।
अल्पमृष्टाशनाभ्याञ्च चतुर्थांशावशेषकम्।
तस्माद्योगानुगुण्येन भोजनं मितभोजनम्।
स्वदेहमलनिर्मोक्षो मृज्जलाभ्यां महामुने।
यत्तच्छौचं भवेत् बाह्यं मानसं मननं विदुः।
अहंशुद्ध इतिज्ञानं शौचमाहुर्मनीषणः।
अत्यन्तमलिनो देहो देही चात्यन्तनिर्मलः।
उभयोरन्तरं ज्ञात्वा कस्य शौचं विधीयते।
ज्ञानशौचं परित्यज्य बाह्ये यो रमते नरः।
समूढः काञ्चनं त्यक्त्वा लोष्ठं गृह्णाति सुव्रत।
तपस्सन्तोषमास्तिक्यं दानमीश्वर पूजनम्।
सिद्धान्तश्रवणञ्चैव ह्रीर्मतिश्च जपो व्रतम्।
एते च नियमाः प्रोका स्तान् वक्ष्यामि क्रमाछ्रुणु।
वेदोक्तेन प्रकारेण कृछ्रचान्द्रायणादिभिः।
शरीरशोषणं यत्तत् तप इत्युच्यते बुधैः।
को वा मीक्षः कथं तेन संसारं प्रतिपन्नवान्।
इत्यालोकनमर्थज्ञाः तपः शंसन्ति पण्डिताः।
यदृच्छालाभतो नित्यं प्रीतिर्या जायते नृणाम्।
तत्सन्तोषं विदुः प्राज्ञाः परिज्ञानैक तल्पराः।
ब्रह्मादिलोकपर्यन्ताद्विरक्त्या यल्लभेत्प्रियम्।
सर्वत्र विगतस्नेहं सन्तोषं परमं विदुः।
श्रौतस्मार्ते च विश्वासे यस्तदास्तिक्यमुच्यते।
न्यायार्जितधनं श्रान्ते श्रद्धया वैदिके जने।
अन्यद्वा यत्प्रदीयन्ते तद्दानं प्रोच्यते मया।
रागाद्यपेतं हृदयं वागदुष्टानृतादिना।
हिंसादिरहितं कर्म यत्तदीश्वरपूजनम्।
सत्यं ज्ञानमनन्तञ्च परानन्दं परं ध्रुवम्।
प्रत्यगित्यवगन्तव्यं वेदान्तश्रवणं बुधाः।
वेदलौकिकमार्गेषु कुत्सितं कर्म यद्भवेत्।
तस्मिन् भवति या लज्जा ह्रीस्सैवेति प्रकीर्तिता।
वैदिकेषु च सर्वेषु श्रद्धा या सा मतिर्भवेत्।
गुरुणा चोपदिष्टोऽपि तत्र सम्बन्धवर्जितः।
वेदोक्तेनैव मार्गेण मन्त्राभ्यासो जपः स्मृतः।
कल्पसूत्रे तथा वेदे धर्मशास्त्रे पुराणके।
इतिहासे च वृत्तिर्या सजपः प्रोच्यते मया।
स्वस्तिकं गोमुखं पद्मं वीरसिंहासने तथा।
भद्रं मुक्तासनं चैव मयूरासनमेव च।
सुखासनसमाख्यच्च नवमं मुनिपुङ्गव।
जानूर्वोरन्तरे कृत्वा सम्यक् पादतले उभे।
समग्रीवशिरः कायः स्वस्तिकं नित्यमभ्यसेत्।
सव्ये दक्षिणगुल्फन्तु पृष्ठपार्श्वे नियोजयेत्।
दक्षिणेऽपि तथा सव्यं गोमुखं तत्प्रचक्षते।
अंगुष्ठावधि गृह्णीयात् हस्ताभ्यां व्युत्क्रमेण तु।
ऊर्वोरुपरि विप्रेन्द्र कृत्वा पादतलद्वयम्।
पद्मासनं भवेत्प्राज्ञ सर्वरोगभयापहम्।
दक्षिणेतरपादन्तु दक्षिणोरुणि विन्यसेत्।
ऋजुकायस्समासीनो वीरासनमुदाहृतम्।
गुल्फौ तु वृषणस्याधस्सीविन्याः पार्श्वयोः क्षिपेत्।
पार्श्वपादौ च पाणिभ्यां दृढं बध्वा सुनिश्चलम्।
भद्रासनं भवेदेतद्विषरोगविनाशनम्।
निपीड्य सीविनीं सूक्ष्मं दक्षिणेतरगुल्फतः।
वामं याम्येन गुल्फेन मुक्तासनमिदं भवेत्।
मेढ्रादुपरि निक्षिप्य सव्यं गुल्फं ततोपरि।
गुल्फान्तरञ्च संक्षिप्य मुक्तासनमिदं मुने।
कूर्पराग्रे मुनिश्रेष्ठनिक्षिपेन्नाभिपार्श्वयोः।
भूम्यां पाणितलद्वन्द्वं निक्षिप्यैकाग्रमानसः।
समुन्नतशिरः पादो दण्डवद्व्योम्निसंस्थितः।
मयूरासनमेतत्स्यात् सर्वपापप्रणाशनम्।
येनकेनप्रकारेण सुखं धैर्यं च जायते।
तत्सुखासनमित्युक्तं अशक्तः तत्समाश्रयेत्।
आसनं विजितं येन जितं तेन जगत्रयम्।
अनेन विधिना युक्तः प्राणायामं सदा कुरु॥

( 4 ) श्रीजाबालदर्शनोपनिषत्

Quotation No. I., Five kinds of Yoga in their orderof importance are here detailed, Mantra-Yoga; Sparsa-Yoga;Bhava-Yoga; Abhava-Yoga; and Maha-Yoga. All of themare productive of the eight wonderful powers called Ashtaaiswarya and all of them lead to Salvation. The utteringof a Mantra or Japa combined with meditation is knownas Mantra-Yoga. Practice of Prana-Yama or control ofbreath according to prescribed methods is called Sparsa-Yoga. The meditation of Bramhan as completely pervadingevery-where, both internally and externally, is styledBhava-Yoga The meditation of pure Brahman, forgettingthe phenomenal altogether, is called Abhava-Yoga. Leavingeven this meditation, the complete union with Brahman, isMaha-Yoga.

Q. Nos. II. III & IV. These explain the componentparts of Yoga called Angas, and their subdivisions. Mostof these are defined in two different ways as already noticed.There is a higher and philosophical definition, as also, anordinary and less philosophical one, useful of course for theless qualified in religious practice.

** Quotation II** refers to 15 angas, while III and IV give only the usually known 8 Angas. The 8 Angas are explained below, together with the extra 7 which are moreor less included in them.

  1. Yama—The control of the senses arising throughknowledge obtained of the existence of Brahmanin everything, or loss of attachment to the sensesand the physical body.

  2. Niyama—is earnest desire to attain the state ofBrahman, or constant practice towards the attainment of the Brahman and for the elimination of itsobstructions.

(a) Tyaga—is the elimination of all worldly desires.

(b) Mounom—or complete silence is the worship ofBrahman which cannot be dealt with either bywords or thought.

(c) Vijanom—or solitude is the all prevading Brahman itself, in which no idea of personality existsat any time.

(d) Kala—or time means the Brahman possessingthe capacity to create in no time, the whole of theuniverse.

3.Asana—is posture or that state of mind in whichthe contemplation of Bramhan is most convenientand pleasant, or complete indifference to allmundane affairs.

(a) Sidha-Asana—is the contemplation of that Brahman which procures Sidhi or salvation.

(b) Mula-Bandha—refers to the Brahman itselfwhich is the foundation for everything.

(c) Samata—or keeping all the limbs in the bodyin proper position. This literal meaning is treatedas an inferior one and the idea of complete merging in the Brahman is explained as Sainata.

(d) Drishti—or sight. Looking at the tip of thenose is not what is really meant but to keep thesight on the spot where the ideas of knower,known and knowing entirely vanish, i. e. Brahmanitself.

  1. Prana-yama—or regulation of breath. This isliterally meant only for the dull and less qualifiedpeople. To be assured that the external worldis but a hallucination is the real meaning, or tostop all mental functions by such assurance. Thethree processes of which it is composed are;

Rechaka—or exhaling breath: this in the higher senserefers to the rejection of all false notions of the world.

Pooraka—or inhaling: this similarly refers to thetaking in of the idea that there is nothing but Brahman.

Kumbhaka—or filling in the breath: this also refersto the retaining of the idea that Brahman is the only reality.

  1. Prathyahara—turping of the mind inwards, havingclearly understood the real nature of the external.

  2. Dharana—or steadiness of mind, by perceivingBrahman everywhere.

  3. Dhyana—is the contemplation ofpure Brahman.

  4. Samadhi—is the highest state of Intellect afterthe Dhyana or contemplation itself is dropped.
    The subdivisions of the 8 Angas above defined aredetailed below; First, Yama consists of:—

1.Ahinsa—or harmlessness by thought, word anddeed, or the knowledge of Atma as incapable ofbeing injured.

  1. Satyam—or truthfulness, telling truth about whatis seen, heard or experienced, or the fact that Brahman alone is true.

  2. Asteyam—non-stealing, is not to desire for others’property either trifle or valuable, or not to confoundAtma with what it is not.

  3. Brahmacharyam—is chastity, or, direction ofmind towards Brahman.

  4. Daya—is mercy.

  5. Arjava—is sincerity.

7.Kshema — is forgiveness.

  1. Dhriti— is self-command.

  2. Mita-Bhojana— proper and holy meals.

  3. Soucha — is purity of heart and body.

Secondly-Niyama consists of:—

  1. Tapas — is penance; or earnest philosophical enquiry.

2.Santosham — is contentment.

3.Astikyam—is Theism.

  1. Dana — is charity.

  2. Easwara-poojanom, is worship of God without anyinjury to any created being.

  3. Sravana, is study of philosophy and religion.

  4. Hri, is blushing at everything unjust and irreligious.

  5. Mati, is determination.

  6. Japam, repetition of manthras, or study of religion and philosophy.

  7. Vratom is practice of devotion.

Thirdly, different Asanas or postures conducive to thepractice of Yoga are detailed. They may not be of muchuse except to those who take to actual practice. They areall however supposed to have the additional effect of improving the physic by regulating the current of air throughoutthe body.

The following are the names of usually known postures; Swastika, Gomukha, Veera, Yoga, Padma, Kukkuta,Uthana-kurma, Dhanu, Sinha, Bhadra, Mukta, Mayoora,Matsya, Sidha, Paschimamthana, and Sukha. The lastSukhasana is meant for feeble constitutions, unfit to practiseany others. Any posture in which the mind becomes.steadyis allowed for practice.

In the above enumeration of the 8 Angas of Yogaand of their subdivisious, we see that the 20 duties prescribedin Yama and Niyama almost exhaust the moral and religiousduties required of man in any civilized country. Withoutcompletely adhering to all these duties, no one is qualifiedto enter the technical portions of Yoga commencing withAsana, Pranayama &c. All impostures as Yogis, by hypocrites, moral wrecks and selfish, humbugs are denounced inthe strongest terms.

कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन्।
इन्द्रियार्थान् विमूढाद्मा मिथ्याचारस्य उच्यते॥

भगवद्गीता।

Without performing the duties ordained, all pretensionsby mere physical inaction combined with mental mischiefare surely, the characteristics of an extremely stupid hypocrite.

It must be specially noted here that the moral necessityfor all these duties is enforced on the ground of their purifying the heart of man and of preparing him to higherstages of religious development. Unlike the theories of thewest, the standard of morality is simple and clear. Thatwhich conduces to take man near to his Creator is of religious and moral value. The psychological explanation forthis has been already given. The mind attains the SantaVriti in the performance of all these duties and the happiness resulting from an approach to the Brahman is realized.

‘नघोरासु न मूढासु शान्तासु च यथा सुखम् ‘॥

In this connection it is perhaps necessary to meet theoccasional criticisms proceeding from the west regarding theideas of Hindu worship, or Easwara-poojanom, one of the20 duties prescribed by Yama and Niyama. It is supposedthat the relation between God and man is conceived inIndia as one subsisting between master and servant withoutany scope for mutual love, that religion originates from fearof punishment and that worship is sought only as a meansof avoiding the same. This is indeed a very uncharitableview of every religion that admits God as the creator of theUniverse. Here the most natural conception of relation isthat of parent and child with ample scope for mutual love.

(1) Raghuvamsa of Kalidas

जगतः पितरौ वन्दे पार्वतीपरमेश्वरौ।

(2) Lalitha Sahasranama

श्रीमाताश्रीमहाराज्ञी श्रीमत्सिंहासनेश्वरी।

The first natural idea of God under the circumstancesis that of a parent and the next one is that of a just ruler.Even understanding the matter in its ordinary significance,there is no scope for criticisms of the kind referred to.Besides, we have already seen that the philosophical conclusion arrived at is, that the Atman is the ultimate entityand it is identical with the real ego or Ahom, stripped of all,its gross environment.

अयमात्मा परानन्दः परप्रेमास्पदं यतः।

This Atman is therefore the only object for true love.Much less is the scope for the alleged criticism even from aphilosophical point of view. Bhakti or love for love’s sakeis prescribed as the most important ingredient in the worshipof God, without which all formalities and rituals are pronounced to be entirely useless.

भक्तिरेव गरीयसी।

The following classification of Bhakti may be of someinterest.

त्रिविधा कथिताह्यत्र मनोवाक्कायसम्भवा।
लौकिकी वैदिकीचान्या भवेदाध्यात्मिकी तथा।
ध्यानधारणयाबुध्या रुद्राणां स्मरणं हि तत्।
रुद्रभक्तिकरीचैषा मानसीभक्ति रुच्यते।
व्रतोपवासनियमैः यतेन्द्रिय निरोधिभिः।
कायिकीभक्ति रुद्रस्य ज्ञानध्यानस्य धर्मिणाम्।
गन्धमाल्यैश्च विविधैः धातुभिश्चोपपादिता।
महेश्वरं पुरस्कृत्य भक्तिस्सा लौकिकी मता।
वेदमन्त्रहविर्यागैःया क्रिया वैदिकी मता।
अग्निभूम्यनिलाकाश निशाकर दिवाकरान्।
समुद्दिश्य कृतं कर्म तत्सर्वं दैविकं भवेत्।
आध्यात्मिका तु द्विविधा रुद्रभक्तिः स्थिता मुने।
साङ्ख्याख्या यौगिकी चान्या विभागं तत्र मे शृणु।
चतुर्विंशति तत्वानि प्रधानादीनि संख्यया।
अचेतनानि योज्यानि पुरुषः पञ्चविंशकः।
चेतनः पुरुषो भोक्ता न कार्यं तस्य कर्मणः।
रुद्रः षड्विंशकः कर्ता सर्वज्ञश्चेतनः प्रभुः।
रुद्रतत्वाधिकञ्चापि ज्ञानतत्वं विदुर्बुधाः।
सांख्ये कृता भक्तिरेषा सद्भिराध्यात्मिकी मता।
प्राणायामपरो नित्यं ध्यायते नियतेन्द्रियः।
धारणां हृदये धृत्वा ध्यायते यो महेश्वरम्।
योगजा मानसी व्यास रुद्रभक्तिः परा स्मृता॥

स्कान्दपुराणं, आवन्त्यखण्डम्॥

Bhakti or devotion is classified into those by mind,word or deed, also into Lowkika, Vydika and Adhyatmika.Bhakti by Dhyana and Dharana is mental; by control ofsenses, fasting &c. is physical, by worship with flowers,scents &c. is Lowkiki, by worship of fire, earth, air, sky, sunor moon is Dyvika; Bhakti by analysing the Tatwas according to the teachings of Sankhya is Adhyatmika, and bhaktiby regulation of breath &c. is Yogic.

Before closing this section on the philosophical treatment of Hindu Religion, I am constrained to feel that areiteration of the argumentsadduced in our ancient literature for establishing the existence of a something calledBrahman or Atma, apart from Reason or Intellect, will notbe quite out of place, under the modern state of ignoranceof the subject. The vital distinction between Budhism andHinduism, or virtually between Atheism and Theisin isbased upon the absence or presence of this Atman. Allsystems which do not pass beyond the province of Reason orBudhi fall under some form of Budhism. The whole life ofthe Great Sankara appears to have been devoted to thefighting out of this important question in India against theBudhists. He is however, by no means the originator ofthis conception of Atma in India as it is the key-note of allIndian sacred literature. Nor are the incomplete theorieslike those of Budhism and its allied systems the discoveriesso to speak of any particular philosopher or Religionist inIndia as is mistakenly understood at present. The completephilosophical and scientific analysis of the subject taken upby our venerable Rishis of old, contains references, descriptions, criticisms and definite conclusions called Sidhantas onevery important point at marked stages of the analysis. Thescientific analysis of every subject will require this procedureto follow and will inevitably produce similar results. In aphilosophical analysis, all possible and plausible systemswill have to be enumerated, examined and criticized. It istherefore preposterous to affirm that any of the theoriesor con-clusions arrived at in the course of the logical treatment of a subject, are independent and subsequent discoveries of any particular person or persons. More so, whenthe matter in question is one that has been speciallynoticed, criticized and rejected as illogical and blasphemous.Budhism as already explained is a system that explainsevery thing by means of the Reasoning faculty or Budhidenying the existence of any substratum beyond. Budhior reasoning faculty is the ultimate terminus for thesetheorists. This was long found to be an inadequate andincomplete system of thought unable to explain any of theimportant and ultimate questions in philosophy. In fact,in our ancient treatises real philosophy worth the nameonly commences, at this very point of Budhistic terminus.The Vedanta specially deals with matters which ordinaryreason cannot account for. In the discussion of this serioussubject which is a boundary dispute between Theism andAtheism, no rhetorical quibbles or clever abuses will be of anyavail. It should be treated as an anxious scientific enquiryand no inferior matters should be unnecessarily thrust into confound the consideration of the main topic. Everytechnical word used in the course of the discussion shouldbe clearly defined and circumscribed so as to allow nomargin for prevarication. and the value of exact scientificconclusions inevitably arrived at should not be underrated on account of prejudices. The newness or strangeness ofthe facts should not interfere with their complete acceptanceas strict logical inferences.

इन्द्रियाणि नरैः पञ्च षष्ठं तन्मन उच्यते।
सप्तमी बुद्धिमेवाहु क्षेत्रज्ञं विद्धि चाष्टमम्।
चक्षुरालोकनायैव संशयं कुरुते मनः।
बुद्धि रध्यवसानाय साक्षी क्षेत्रज्ञ उच्यते॥

(1) ब्रह्मपुराणम्।

The five senses perform the perceptions of objects, thesixth factor mind or manas compares and discriminates andthus creates doubt, the seventh Reason or Budhi clearsdoubts and settles; the eighth Kshetragna or life principlestands witness to the functions of all these seven.

भूमि रापोनलो वायुः खं मनो बुद्धिरेवच।
अहङ्कार इतीयं मे भिन्ना प्रकृति रष्टधा।
अपरेय मितस्त्वन्यां प्रकृतिं विद्धि मे पराम्।
जीवभूतां महाबाहो ययेदं धार्यते जगत्।
एतद्योनीनि भूतानि सर्वाणी त्युपधारय।
अहं कृत्स्नस्य जगतः प्रभवः प्रलयस्तथा।
मत्तः परतरं नान्यत् किश्चिदस्ति धनञ्जय।
मयि सर्वमिदं प्रोक्तं सूत्रे मणिगणा इव॥

भगवद्गीता।

“The five subtle Elements,mind or manas. Budhi or Reason Ahamkarom or Egoism make up the 8 Prakritis calledApara or inferior, the life Principle or Jiva which supportsthe above is known as Para or superior Prakriti or Maya.There is nought in the universe which is not made up ofthese 9. But I am really the material and efficient causesof all of them. As beads strung in & thread, everythingis attached to me.”

इदं शरीरं कौन्तेय ! क्षेत्रमित्यभिधीयते।
एतद्यो वेत्ति तं प्राहुः क्षेत्रज्ञ इति तद्विदः।
क्षेत्रज्ञं चापि मां विद्धि सर्वक्षेत्रेषु भारत।
क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोर्ज्ञानं यत्तज्ज्ञानं मतं मम॥

(3) भगवद्गीता।

“This body comprising the external and internal organsis called Kshetra and that which knows or discriminatesthese from itself in the body is called Kshetragna. But inall the bodies or kshetras, I am the Kshetragna commonto all. A clear knowledge of these facts by & philosophicalanalysis is the way to get the real knowledge or gnana.”

शब्दस्पर्शादयो वेद्या वैचित्र्याज्जागरे पृथक्।
ततो विभक्ता तत्संविदैकरूप्यान्नभिद्यते।
तथा स्वप्नेऽत्र वेद्यं तु न स्थिरं जागरे स्थिरम्।
तद्भेदोऽतस्तयोः संविदेकरूपा न भिद्यते।
सुप्तोत्थितस्य सौषुप्त तमोबोधे भवेत्स्मृतिः।
सा चावबुद्धविषयाऽवबुद्धं तत्तदा तमः।
स बोधो विषयाद्भिन्नो न बोधात्स्वप्नबोधवत्।
एवं स्थानत्रयेऽप्येका संवित्तद्वद्दिनान्तरे।
मासाब्दयुगकल्पेषु गतागम्येष्वनेकधा।
नोदेति नास्तमेत्येका संविदेषा स्वयम्प्रभा॥

(4) पञ्चदशी।

In the waking state we experience varieties of soundtouch &c. Although their experiences vary, the knowledgeof all these experiences is but one. The process is the samein dream, except that the scenes are more transient. Theexperience of ignorance and darkness or complete absenceof feeling in sleep, is remembered after waking. That ignorance, is therefore a fact that is known. In this manner,the knowledge during these three states of life in the courseof a day is uniform. This knowledge is called Samvit,and is ever self-luminous. Months, years and yugas maycome and go, this Samvit remains the same without risingor setting”.

It is difficult to find exact equivalents for these termsin English as the method of classification itself is slightlydifferent from the western one. Budhi may be translatedas the Reasoning faculty and Manas as the thinking faculty.Ahamkara egoism or the idea of the personal self is sometimes added to these two as in quotation No. II, all thethree being generally known as the internal organs orinstruments. There is thus a necessity for a somethingseparate from these three, to use them and to serve as theirsupport. This is known as Kshetragna, or Jiva or lifeprinciple. This might to some extent correspond to theconsciousness or apriori principle of the western philosophers. But both the Kshetragna and Kshetrom are classedunder Prakriti or Maya, as Para and Apara (vido Q. II)The Kshetragas or Jiva is thus capable only of being conscious of what takes place in the sphere of Kshetrom. Itstands as the enjoyer or sufferer as the case may be. It isnot independent but is subject to certain unavoidable lawsenforced. The enactment and enforcement of these lawsbelong to Eswara or lord of all.

मायां तु प्रकृतिं विद्यान्मायिनं तु महेश्वरम्॥

Maheswara rules through Maya and is connectedwith it. As long as this idea of lording over everything ismaintained, Maheswara is not the pure Brahman yet.Beyond even this conception, beyond the atmosphere ofMaya is the Paramatma, the ultimate and only reality.

Thus we have the Brahman, Eswara, Jiva and theJagath; although virtually there is nothing but the firstBrahman. The remaining three are classified and definedas well as their mutual relations explained, only with theexpress object of removing the mistaken conceptions of theignorant, by progressive method of raciocination. This isthe sum total of the long established theory of Hindu philosophy, as well as Hindu Religion. All further details andvarieties of difference are based on these philosophical conclusions.

It must however be specially noticed here, that theclassification of various stages from Jagath to Brahman, isnot based upon mere imagination or superstition. The stages are neither mere allegories nor unscientific trifles. In thelanguage of Philosophy and from the stand point of the realGnani and Yogi, they may be boldly proclaimed as false.But for the ordinary mankind, they represent true scientificfacts demanding all possible care and consideration. Untilthe stages are got over by steady and long practice as prescribed, it is useless, nay injurious to slight them in anymanner. The modern tendency of every idle fool to stylehimself a vedanti will only result in additional calamitiesa fit reward for his impertinence.

In consideration of the main topic in this essay, I fearthe present section is somewhat prolonged, and I shalltherefore close the same by repeating a few selected portionsfrom the passages already quoted above to have a clearidea of the chapter as whole.

यथाभातस्वरूपेण सत्यत्वेन जगछ्रुतिः।
अङ्गीकृत्य हितं नॄणां कदाचिद् वक्ति सादरम्।
अतीव पक्वचित्तस्य चित्तपाकमपेक्ष्य सा।
सर्वं ब्रह्मेति कल्याणी श्रुतिर्वदति सादरम्॥

अध्यारोपापवादाभ्यां निष्प्रपञ्चं प्रपञ्च्यते।
शिष्याणां बोधसिद्ध्यर्थं तत्त्वज्ञैः कल्पितः क्रमः॥

The Sruti takes up the world as appears true to mankind in general and begins to analyse and explain for thebenefit of the unqualified, but to the fully qualified, it givesout the ultimate truth that everything is Brahman. Granting the popular mis-conception for argument’s sake, it isafterwards falsified by logical reasoning. This is the procedure adopted by the wise, consisting of Adhyaropa andApavada. This clearly implies that all mistaken theories,in the course of the treatment will be similarly dealt with.Budhism and its congnate theories will find their placesthere, and will receive their due criticisms. They are therefore no original theories promulgated after the Vedas cameinto existence. Subsequent followers of these refuted and prohibited theories stand charged, as it were, as offendersunder the condemning sections of the Vedas. This is animportant fact entirely unnoticed by the Archaeologists ofthe modern day. Further, the preaching of the ultimateconclusion of the Vedas to the unqualified is prohibited asnot only useless but also dangerous, owing to the possibilityof misunderstanding and of consequent mischief.

आदौ शमदमप्रायैर्गुणैश्शिष्यंविशोधयेत्।
पश्चात्सर्वमिदं ब्रह्म शुद्धस्त्वमिति बोधयेत्।
अज्ञस्यार्द्धप्रबुद्धस्य सर्वे ब्रह्मेति यो वदेत्।
महानरकजालेषु स तेन विनियोजितः।
प्रबुद्धबुद्धेः प्रक्षीणभोगेच्छस्य निराशिषः।
नास्त्यविद्यामलमिति प्राज्ञस्तूपदिशेत् गुरुः॥

महोपनिषत्॥

In communicating the ultimate knowledge of Brahmanas making up everything in the world, the student should be first examined as to his having attained the necessaryqualifications by practice of Sama, Dama & c. It is a greatsin to teach the fact to the ignorant or partly qualified.Again,

तर्हि ब्रूहि स मूढः किं जिज्ञासुर्वा पराङ्मुखः।
उपास्ति कर्म वा ब्रूयात् विमुखाय यथोचितम्।
मन्दप्रज्ञन्तु जिज्ञासुं आत्मानन्देन बोधयेत्॥

पञ्चदशी॥

There are two varieties of fools, one anxious to knowthe real subject and the other indifferent or even perverseto it. To the latter, only some lower form of religious Karmasor worship shall be taught, but to the former the subjectmay be explained through the idea of personal happiness.

The origin or cause of creation of the world as explainedabove may be noticed here again.

न स्वभावाज्जगज्जन्मस्थितिध्वंसा मुनीश्वराः।
न मया केवलेनापि न च केवलकर्मणा।
प्राणिनां कर्मपाकेन मया च मुनिसत्तमाः।
जगतः सम्भवो नाशः स्थितिश्च भवति द्विजाः॥

The creation, preservation and destruction of Jagat areperformed by Easwara in accordance with the Vasana oreffects of previous karmas of each individual soul. They cannot therefore be attributed to Easwara alone or to karmain itself. A combination of both is required. Next to Jagat,the Jiva and Easwara have to be noticed.

चैतन्यं यदधिष्ठानं लिङ्गदेहश्च यः पुनः।
चिच्छाया लिङ्गदेहस्था तत्सङ्गोजीव उच्यते।
माहेश्वरी तु मायायास्तस्या निर्माणशक्तिवत्।
विद्यते मोहशक्तिश्च तं जीवं मोहयत्यसौ।
ईशकार्यं जीवभोग्यं जगद्वाभ्यां समन्वितम्।
कार्योपाधिरयं जीवः कारणोपाधिरीश्वरः।

Jiva or individual soul is a combination of linga orsubtle body, the reflection of Brahman on it, together withthe Brahman as the basis. Easwara is the creator and Jivathe enjoyer. Eswara refers to the idea of cause and Jivato its effect. Easwara acts through Maya which has thepower of creation as well as that of veiling truth from Jiva.Again,

ईश्वरत्वं च जीवत्वमुपाधिद्वयकल्पितम्।
चिच्छायावेशतः शक्तिः चेतनेव विभाति सा।
तच्छक्त्युपाधिसंयोगात् ब्रह्मेवेश्वरतां ब्रजेत्।
कोशोपाधिविवक्षायां याति ब्रह्मैव जीवताम्।
देहेन्द्रियादियुक्तस्य जीवाभासभ्रमस्य या।
अधिष्ठानचितिः सैषा कूटस्थात्र विवक्षिता।
जगत्भ्रमस्य सर्वस्य यदधिष्ठानमीरितम्।
त्रय्यन्तेषु तदत्र स्यात् ब्रह्मशब्दविवक्षितम्।
अवाङ्मनस गम्यं तं श्रुतिर्बोधयितुं सदा।
जीवमीशं जगद्वापि समाश्रित्य प्रबोधयेत्।
सर्वथा शक्तिमात्रस्य न पृथक् गणना क्वचित्।
शक्तिकार्यं तु नैवास्ति द्वितीयं शङ्कयते कथम्।
निरंशेऽप्यंशमारोप्प कृर्त्स्नेशेत्रेति पृछतः।
तद्भाषयोत्तरं ब्रूते श्रुतिः श्रोतृहितैषिणी।

Brahman itself becomes Easwara in relation to Sakti orMaya and becomes Jiva in relation to the 5 kosas. Whenit is viewed as the basis of the mistaken conception of Jivatogether with the senses etc., it is called Kootastah; whenviewed as the basis of the mistaken conception of the worldas a whole, it is named Brahman in the Vedas. The Srutisimply takes up the Jagat. Jiva and Easwara with the express object of explaining the existence of the unknowablebasis called Brahman. The Sakti referred to as belonging to Brahman is never existent in itself nor is it capable ofdoing anything by itself Brahman is without parts andwithout a second, but it is mistakenly presumed as beingoccupied by Sakti or Maya, and the consequent furtherenquiry as to whether it is fully or partly so combined with it, is answered by Sruti in the same strain of language, with-out directly contradicting the question.

The above passages clearly point out that the ordinaryideas of Jagat, Jiva and Easwara originate from their mis-taken conceptions called Avidya, Agnana or ignorance, whichis no doubt a particular modification of Budhi or Intellectignana, Vidya or knowledge must therefore be obtained fromthe same source. The quality and quantity of these modifications necessarily vary, as well as their effects. Easwaraand Jiva have been amply defined as the reflection ofBrahman on Maya and Avidya respectively. Maya andAvidya therefore represent the pure and impure states ofthe Intellect. The march onwards therefore from the conditioned Jiva to the Almighty Easwara and thence to the pureunconditioned Brahman has to be conducted through thehelp of this Budhi by improving itself. As long as we donot practically arrive at the correct philosophical conceptionof the material world, we must continue as bound Jivasunder the complete control of Easwara, subject to all thekarmic laws enforced by Him in accordance with our karmasthrough Vasanas or the effects of previous karmas good andbad.दैवं कर्मफलं प्रोक्तं(vide Maha-Bharata). Definite procedureis prescribed to improve the Intellect until it becomes Mahator the Great, called the Satwic Maya in which the Satwaguna is predominant over the remaining two gunas or natureof Prakriti which is described as a state in which all thethree gunas are in equipoise. Prakriti thus means theabsence of the work of even Satwa-guna passing beyond theidea of an almighty and allwise Being called Easwara. Thisstate is called Prakriti-laya or merging in Prakriti, thehighest position that could be attained by Karina-Yoga.

One of the most important points to be noticed herebefore closing this section is the commonest criticism regarding the processes above described as well as their practicalresults. It is generally believed that they add nothing tothe progress of science in the world nor to the real welfareof the public at large. Besides, if everybody becomes a philosopher, the world will not go on, is the ordinary fearof many a worldly-wise man and woman. This fear demandsno serious criticism especially after this lengthy treatmentof the subject that has preceded. This plausible argumentis equally applicable to every worldly and material affair.If everybody turns out a merchant, there would be none tobuy, if everyone becomes a ruler, there would be none to beruled. Such remarks are inadmissible in the treatment ofserious scientific subjects and may be passed over withoutfurther notice. But the question concerning the effects ofthe practices referred to, require to be carefully dealt within this connection. The practice of Yoga described in thepreceding pages are productive of tangible results, not asdirect effects of the processes, nor as the attainments ofobjects aimed at. The main object of course, is the subjugation of the mental distractions and the development of thetrue and latent capacities of the Intellect or Budhi, bywhich alone, Salvation from the miseries of the world isattainable. The tangible effects of the practice of Yoga arethus collateral results which come to a Yogi without aimingat them and without special efforts for the same. They aredescribed as the 8 Sidhis. Some temporary approaches tothem may also be accomplished by other means to someextent, but they would only be of a very inferior quality,being within the province of material science. The realYogi does not and should not care for these developedpowers which follow him naturally in his practice of Yoga.On the contrary he is strictly prohibited from relishingthem or taking advantage of them for worldly purposes,lest he lose steadiness in his practice which solely has thehighest object in view, namely salvation.

The Linga Puranom already quoted states

अणिमादिप्रदाः सर्वे सर्वे ज्ञानप्रदायकाः॥

The practice of Yoga leads to true knowledge but alsobestows the 8 kinds of Sidhis. The following passages givedetailed explanation of the matter.

द्विविधा सिद्धयो लोके कल्पिताकल्पितास्तथा।
रसौषधिक्रियाजालमन्त्राभ्यासादिसाधनात्।
सिध्यन्ति सिद्धयो यास्तु कल्पितास्ताः प्रकीर्तिताः।
अनित्या अल्पवीर्यास्ताः सिद्धयस्साधनोद्भवाः।
साधनेन विनाप्येवंजायन्ते स्वत एव हि।
स्वात्मयोगै कनिष्ठेषु स्वातन्त्र्यादीश्वरप्रियाः।
प्रभूतास्सिद्धयो यास्ताः कल्पनारहिताः स्मृताः।
सिद्धा नित्या महावीर्यांश्छारूपस्वयोगजाः।
चिरकालाप्रजायन्ते वासनारहितेषु च।
तास्तु गोप्या महायोगात्परमात्मपदेऽव्यये।
विना कार्यं सदा गुप्तं योगसिद्धस्य लक्षणम्।
यथाकाशं समुद्दिश्य गछद्भिः पथिकैः पथि।
नानातीर्थानि दृश्यन्ते नानामार्गास्तु सिद्धयः।
स्वयमेव प्रजायन्ते लाभालाभविवर्जिते।
योगमार्गे तथैवेदं सिद्धिजालं प्रवर्तते॥

योगशिखोपनिषत्॥

The Sidhis are obtained by two different processes, oneis artificial and the other is natural. Those originatingthrough the help of medicines, chemicals, physical actionsor even Manthras are called artificial. They are transientand not very effective. Those naturally attained throughYoga, by the grace of the Almighty, are permanent andefficacious. The same Sidhis will occur even without Yoga,if only the old Vasanas are relinquished by long habit.They should be concealed by a Yogi in the interest of hismain object. In flying up above the earth with the objectof soaring high, one is likely to see several holy places and paths below, without any special effort; similarly, in soaringhigh through Yoga different kinds of Sidhis naturally appearto the Yogi.

A more detailed description is given below:—

योगयुक्तस्सदा योगी लघ्वाहारो जितेन्द्रियः।
सूक्ष्मास्तु धारणास्सप्त भूराद्या मूर्ध्नि धारयेत्।
धरित्रीं धारयेद्योगी तत्सौख्यं प्रतिपद्यते।
आत्मानं मन्यते चोर्वी तद्बन्धं च जहाति सः।
तथैवाप्सु रसं सूक्ष्मं तद्वद्रूपं च तेजसि।
स्पर्शे वायौ तथा तद्वद्बिभ्रतस्तस्य धारणाम्।
व्योम्नःसूक्ष्मां प्रवृत्तिं च शब्दं तद्वज्जहाति सः।
मनसा सर्वभूतानां मनस्याविशते यदा।
मानसीं धारणां बिभ्रन् मनस्सूक्ष्मं च जायते।
तद्वद् बुद्धिमशेषाणां सत्वानामेत्य योगवित्।
परित्यजति सम्प्राप्य बुद्धिसौक्ष्म्यमनुत्तमम्।
परित्यजति सूक्ष्माणि सप्त त्वेतानि योगवित्।
सम्यग् विज्ञाय योऽलर्क !तस्यावृत्तिर्न विद्यते।
एतासां धारणानां तु सप्तानां सौक्ष्ममात्मवान्।
दृष्ट्वा दृष्ट्वा ततस्सिद्धिं त्यक्त्वा त्यक्त्वा परां व्रजेत्।
यस्मिन् यस्मिंश्च कुरुते भूते रागं महीपते !।
तस्मिंस्तस्मिन् समासक्तिं सम्प्राप्य स विनश्यति।
तस्माद्विदित्वा सूक्ष्माणि संसक्तानि परस्परम्।
परित्यजति यो देही स परं प्राप्नुयात् परम्।
अणिमा लघिमा चैव महिमा प्राप्तिरेव च।
प्राकाम्यं च तथेशित्वं वशित्वं च तथा परम्।
यत्र कामावशायित्वं गुणानेतांस्तथेश्वरान्।
प्राप्नोत्यष्टौ नरव्याघ्र परं निर्वाण सूचकान्।
सूक्ष्मात्सूक्ष्मतमोणीयान् शीघ्रत्वं लघिमा गुणः।
महिमाशेषपूज्यत्वात् प्राप्तिर्नाप्राप्यमस्य यत्।
प्राकाम्यमस्य व्यापित्वादीशत्वं चेश्वरो यतः।
वशित्वाद्वशिमा नाम योगिनः सप्तमो गुणः।
यत्रेछास्थानमप्युक्तं यत्र कामावशायिता।
ऐश्वर्यकारणैरेभिर्योगिनः प्रोक्तमष्टधा।
मुक्तिसंसूचकं भूप! परं निर्वाणमात्मनः।
ततो न जायते नैव वर्द्धते न विनश्यति।
यथा जलं जलेनैक्यं निक्षिप्तमुपगछति।
तथात्मा साम्यमभ्येति योगिनः परमात्मनि॥

(1) मार्कण्डेयपुराणम्॥

द्वाविंशति विधं सिद्धं सिद्धसाधनकारणम्।
अणिमा लघिमा प्राप्ति प्राकाश्यं महिमा तथा।
ईशित्वं च वशित्वं च तथा कामावशायिता।
दूरश्रवणमेवेति परकाय प्रवेशनम्।
मनोयायित्वमेवेति सर्वज्ञत्वमभीप्सितम्।
वह्निस्तम्भं जलस्तम्भं चिरं जीवित्वमेव च।
कायव्यूहं च वाक्सिद्धिः मृतानयनमीप्सितम्।
सृष्टीनां करणं चैवप्राणाकर्षणमेव च॥

(2) ब्रह्मवैवर्तपुराणम्॥

ये ये भावाः स्थिता लोके तानविद्यामयान् विदुः।
सर्वेच्छा जालसंशान्ता वात्मलाभो भवेन्मुने !।
स कथं सिद्धिजालानि कथं वाञ्छत्यचित्तकः।
अपि शीतरुचा वर्केसुतीक्ष्णेऽपीन्दुमण्डले।
अप्यधः प्रसरत्यग्नौ जीवन्मुक्तो न विस्मयी॥

(3) वराहोपनिषत्॥

मोक्षस्य बहवश्शास्त्रेप्रोच्यन्ते प्रतिबन्धकाः।
अणिमादीच्छया तुल्यः प्रतिबन्धो न कश्चन।
ब्रह्मद्रोहगुरुद्रोहशिवद्रोहादिपातकम्।
अन्यच्चपातकं सर्वं सिद्धिरूपेण वर्तते॥

(4) तत्त्वसारायणम्॥

*** Quotation No I***. In the proper practice of Yogathrough meditation on the 5 elements separately, on themind and on the Intellect as required by the science ofYoga, the Yogi, not only obtains control over them, but isalso accompanied by the respective Sidhis connected withthem. But if he cherishes any desire for these Sidhis, heis sure to be ruined. By utter indifference to them hereaches his ultimate goal.

The Sidhis are 8 in number. 1, Anima is the power ofbecoming small to a minute atom, 2, Laghima is swiftness, 3, Mahima is greatness; 4, Prapti, the power to obtaineverything, 5, Prakamya is the power of pervading every-where, 6, Easitwom is the majesty of Eewara or Lord; 7,Vasitwom is the power to control and subdue every thing;8, Kamavasayitwom is the power to attain every thingwithout desiring for them. The appearance of these Sidhisare signs of near approach to Salvation.

*** Q. No. II.*** Everything phenominal in the world isthe effect of agnana or ignorance and the complete renunciation of desire for the same leads to Salvation. How couldtherefore a Yogi ever desire for these Sidhis? He will notfeel astonished even if the sun becomes cold and the moonbecomes hot nor if the fire burns down-wards.

*** Q. No. III***. Among the varieties of obstructions enumerated in the sastras against the attainment of Yoga, noneis so dangerous as the desire for the Sidhis. All possiblekinds of sins will result from a longing for them.

The quotations disclose the possibilities of developingin man the powers detailed above by the processes of Yoga.They are also said to appear in those who relinquish al.worldly desires without any practice of Yoga. Inferior andtranscient varieties of these extraordinary powers are obtain.able to a limited extent by other physical and direct meansfalling within the scope of material science.There areseveral texts specially treating of Yoga and it is beyond thescope of this essay to dilate further on the subject. It may however be noted here that Yoga is not the main object, butis only one of the means adopted to reach the ultimate goal.It no doubt secures certain desired results for progress in this direction, but there are other equally important mattersto be carefully attended to at the same time.

द्वे बजे चित्तवृक्षस्य वृत्तिव्रततिधारिणः।
एकं प्राणपरिस्पन्दो द्वितीया दृढभावना।
यदा प्रस्पन्दते प्राणो नाडीसंस्पर्शनोद्यतः।
तदा संवेदनमयं चित्तमाशु प्रजायते।
सा हि सर्वगता संवित्प्राणस्पन्देन बोध्यते।
योगिन श्चित्तशान्त्यर्थं कुर्वन्ति प्राणरोधनम्।
प्राणायामैस्तथा ध्यानैः प्रयोगैर्युक्तिकल्पितैः।
चित्तोपशान्तिफलदं परमं विद्धि कारणम्।
सुखदं संविदस्वास्थ्यं प्राणसंरोधनं विदुः।
दृढभावनया त्यक्तपूर्वापरविचारणम्।
यदादानं पदार्थस्य वासना सा प्रकीर्तिता।
अवासनत्वात्सततं यदा न मनुते मनः।
अमनस्तातदोदेति परमोपशमप्रदा।
यदा न भाव्यते भावः क्वचिज्जगतिवस्तुनि।
तदा हृदम्बरे शून्ये कथं चित्तं प्रजायते।
वासनारशनाहीना जीवन्मुक्ता हि ते स्मृताः।
पूर्वदृष्टमदृष्टं वा यदस्याः प्रतिभासते।
संविदस्तत्प्रयत्नेन मार्जनीयं विजानता।
तदमार्जनमात्रं हि महा संसारतां गतम्।
तत्प्रमार्जनमात्रं तु मोक्ष इत्यभिधीयते।
कालसत्ता कलासत्ता वस्तुसत्तेयमित्यपि।
विभागकलनां त्यक्त्वा सन्मात्रैकपरो भव।
यावद्विलीनं न मनो न तावद्वासना क्षयः।
न क्षीणा वासना यावच्चित्तं तावन्नशाम्यति।
यावन्नतत्त्वविज्ञानं तावच्चित्तशमः कुतः।
यावन्नचित्तोपशमो न तावत्तत्ववेदनम्।
यावन्नवासनानाशः तावत्तत्वागमः कुतः।
यावन्नतत्वसम्प्राप्तिः न तावद्वासनाक्षयः।
वासनाक्षयविज्ञानमनोनाशा महामते !।
समकालं चिराभ्यस्ता भवन्ति फलदा मताः।
भावाभावे पदार्थानां हर्षामर्षविकारदा।
मलिना वासना यैषा सा सङ्गइति कथ्यते।..
यत्रास्ति वासनालीनं तत्सुषुप्तं न सिद्धये।
निर्बीजा वासना यत्र तत्तुर्ये सिद्धिदं स्मृतम्॥

(1) अन्नपूर्णोपनिषत्॥

वासनाक्षयविज्ञानमनोनाशा महामते !।
समकालं चिराभ्यस्ता भवन्ति फलदा मताः।
त्रय एवं समं यावन्नाभ्यस्ताश्च पुनः पुनः।
तावन्न पदसम्प्राप्तिर्भवत्यपि समाशतैः।
एकैकशो निषेव्यन्ते यद्येते चिरमप्यलम्।
तन्नसिद्धिं प्रयछन्ति मन्त्राः सङ्कीर्तिता इव।
त्रिभिरेतैश्चिराभ्यस्ते र्हृदयग्रन्थयो दृढाः।
निःशङ्कमेव त्रुट्यन्ति बिसछेदाद् गुणा इव।
जन्मान्तरशताभ्यस्ता मिथ्या संसारवासना।
सा चिराभ्यासयोगेन विना न क्षीयते क्वचित्।
सम्यगालोचनात्सत्याद्वासना प्रविलीयते।
वासनाविलये चेतः शममायाति दीपवत्।
संत्यक्तवासनान्मौनादृते नास्त्युत्तमं पदम्।
भावसंवित्प्रकटिता मनुरूपां च मारुते।
चित्तस्योत्पत्युपरमां वासनां मुनयो विदुः।
दृढाभ्यस्तपदार्थैकभावनादतिचञ्चलम्।
चित्तं सञ्जायते जन्म जरामरणकारणम्
वासनावशतः प्राणस्पन्दस्तेन च वासना।
क्रियते चित्तबीजस्य तेन बीजाकर क्रमः।
द्वे बीजे चित्तवृक्षस्य प्राणस्पन्दनवासने।
एकस्मिंश्च तयोः क्षीणे क्षिप्रं द्वे अपि नश्यतः।
असं व्यवहारत्वात् भवभावनवर्जनात्।
शरीर नाशदर्शित्वाद्वासना न प्रवर्तते।
वासनासम्परित्यागाच्चित्तं गछत्य चित्तताम्।
अवासनत्वात्सततं यदा न मनुते मनः।
अमनस्ता तदोदेति परमोपशमप्रदा।
अव्युत्पन्नमना यावद्भवानज्ञाततत्पदः।
गुरुशास्त्रप्रमाणैस्तु निर्णीतं तावदाचर।
ततः पक्वकषायेण नूनं विज्ञातवस्तुना।
शुभोऽप्यसौ त्वया त्याज्यो वासनौधो निराधिना।
द्विविधश्चित्तनाशोऽस्ति सरूपो रूप एव च।
जीवन्मुक्तः सरूपस्यादरूपो देहमुक्तिगः।
चित्तनाशाभिधानं हि यदा ते विद्यते पुनः।
मैत्रादिभिर्गुणैर्युक्तं शान्तिमेति न संशयः।
भूयो जन्म विनिर्मुक्तं जीवन्मुक्तस्य तन्मनः।
सरूपोऽसौ मनोनाशोजीवन्मुक्तस्य विद्यते। .
अरूपस्तु मनो नाशो वैदेहीमुक्तिगो भवेत्।
मनसोऽभ्युदयो नाशो मनोनाशो महोदयः।
हस्तं हस्तेन सम्पीड्य दन्तैर्द्दन्तान् विचूर्ण्य च।
अङ्गान्यङ्गैःसमाक्रम्य जयेदादौ स्वकं मनः।
उपविश्योपविश्यैकां चिन्तकेन मुहुर्मुहुः।
न शक्यते मनो जेतुं विना युक्तिमनिन्दिताम्।
अङ्कुशेन विना मत्तो यथा दुष्टमतङ्गजः।
अध्यात्मविद्याधिगमः साधुसङ्गतिरेव च।
वासनासम्परित्यागः प्राणस्पन्दनिरोधनम्।
एतास्ता युक्तयः पुष्टाः सन्ति चित्तजये किल।
सतीषु युक्तिष्वेतासु हठात्तन्नियमन्ति ये।
चेतसो दीपमुत्सृज्य विचिन्वन्ति तमो जनैः।
वासना द्विविधा प्रोक्ता शुद्धा च मलिना तथा।
मलिना जन्महेतुः स्याछुद्धा जन्मविनाशिनी।
अज्ञानसुघनाकारा घनाहङ्कारशालिनी।
पुनर्जन्मकरी प्रोक्ता मलिना वासना बुधैः।
पुनर्जन्माङ्कुरं त्यक्त्वा स्थितिः संभृष्टबीजवत्।
बहुशास्त्रकथा कन्था रोमन्थेन वृथैव किम्
अन्वेष्टव्यं प्रयत्नेन मारुते ! ज्योतिरान्तरम्।
दर्शनादर्शने हित्वा स्वयं केवलरूपतः।
य आस्ते कपिशार्दूल ! ब्रह्म स ब्रह्मवित्स्वयम्।
अधीत्य चतुरो वेदान् सर्वशास्त्राण्यनेकशः।
ब्रह्मतत्त्वं न जानाति दर्वी पाकरसं यथा॥

(2) मुक्तिकोपनिषत्।

*** Quotation No. I.*** There are two causes for the working of the mind, one is Prana-spanda or life breath and theother Vasana or old associations. The process of breathingstarts up mind and the yogis therefore for the purposeof controlling mind, practise control over breathing, byPranayama, Dhyana and other ingenious methods. Controlling mind by means of controlling breath is however adifficult process, as compared with the method of directlycontrolling the same by gnana. Vasana is the tendencycaused by previous associations without the actual existenceof any extraneous causes at the moment. When this tendency is annihilated, the mind’s flow is also virtually stopped.When Vasana is destroyed, the state of Jivan-mukta isattained. Without controlling Vasana, mind cannot becontrolled and vice versa. Without gnana or real knowledge,neither Vasana nor mind can be controlled. Thus the practice of controlling Vasana as well as mind must go hand inhand with the acquirement of real knowledge.When the vasanaic tendency is towards material objects, it is called ‘Sanga’ or attachment. Its latent state in sleep does notmean its destruction. When it actually loses its tendency,it is called Thurya or highest state of bliss.

*** Q. No. II.*** The practice of controlling mind and Vasanaas well as the acquirement of gnana should be carried onsimultaneously, and they will remove all doubts obstructingthe path to salvation. Any one of them by itself, howeverwell attended to, will not be effective. The false notions ofthe existence of the phenomenal is the result of the associations acquired in hundreds of previous lives. They willnot therefore easily quit without continued strenuous practice of the required remedy. Meditation of the true Brahmandestroys Vasana. By destruction of Vasana, the mind’saction is stopped. Salvation is never attained without thecessation of the work of Vasana and mind. Vasana is thetendency to propel the mind in a particular direction, similar to previous associations, and it subsides after creatingsuch inducement to the mind. Study of philosophy,abandonment of worldly affairs and noting the mortality ofthe physical body will check the force of Vasana. The mind then ceases to work. Until this peace of mind isattained, the ordinances in the Sastras and the instructionsof the Guru or teacher should necessarily be acted out. Bysuch work good Vasanas will result and they should also berelinquished when the real truth is known. Cessation of thework of mind is of two varieties, Saroopa or retaining itsmere form and Aroopa completely formless, the former beingthe state of Jivan-mukta’s mind and the latter of Videhamukta. Jivan-mukta’s mind will be full of kindness,sympathy & c. He has also acquired the privilege of stopping further births like the Videha-mukta. Thus it is clearthat mind’s predomination results in misery and its subsidence produces bliss. It should therefore be somehow subdued, by squiezing hands, or biting teeth or by difficultpostures. By erratic efforts or unsystematic methods, it isimpossible to subdue the mind, like a mad elephant withouta sharp bill hook. Study of philosophy, association with thewise, checking of Vasana, controlling breath and such othersare ingenious processes adopted for the purpose. When suchproper methods are available, it is useless and foolish totake to any other rude procedure. Vasana is of two kinds,pure and impure; the former full of consolidated egoism, islike solidified darkness, leading to misery and endless birthsbut the latter like fried seeds incapable of sprouting destroysthe possibilities of future births and miseries. It is uselessto keep ruminating over various Sastras repeatedly read,without seeking for the light within. Rejecting the seenand the unseen, one who remains steady in the meditation ofBrahman, is the knower of Brahman and Brahman itself.If even after learning all the Vedas and the various Sastras,one does not obtain the knowledge of Brahman, he is likethe ladle unable to relish the sauce in which it lies emersed.

A psychological distinction is enunciated in the abovequotations, between Vasana and mind or chitta, the formeras the result of previous associations and experiences, andthe latter as a mere blank ready to be acted upon by Vasanaas well as present perceptions. The motion of Prana or lifebreath sets up both Vasana and mind in motion. By controlling respiration. Vasana is checked and vice versa. Bycontrolling mind, Vasana and resparation are checked. Theseare thus mutually acted upon. But the process of checkingVasana and mind by merely controlling breath is somewhatrude and difficult, and could not lead to the ultimate goalwithout Tatwagnana or knowledge of Brahman. Whereas,the method of checking Vasana and mind by gnana andindirectly Prana, is the best and safest way to attainsalvation.

Some of these important Psychological facts may appearnew and strange to the western scientists and philosophers.But they deserve serious and practical trial, before beingcondemned as autedeluvian, unscientific superstitions. Itmay however be noticed here that the above fundamentalPsychological principles lie at the root of every importantordinance, religious, ethical and social, prescribed and practised in Hindu religion, except perhaps a few insignificantand sometimes absurd customs which have crept in, in courseof time, owing to the complete ignorance of these principles.

On account of the serious character of these principles,it is not desirable to pass over without giving some detailedexplanation of them as could be gathered from the texts.

Among the three important factors above dealt with,namely, Vasana-ksheya, Manouasa and gnana, the lastgnana or real philosophical knowledge ranks first, and thissecond chapter has been almost exclusively devoted to thatsubject. The remaining two therefore demand fuller explanation than is already given. Vasana has been defined asthe net result of the previous karms and that it is eitherpure or impure as the case may be. The impure Vasana isof two kinds strong and weak known as Thivra and Manda,the former produces desire, anger, envy, pride & c. and isknown as Asuri as well as Vishaya-vasana; the latter is ofthree kinds, Sastra-Vasana, Loka-Vasana and Deha-Vasana.All these are impure differing only in kind and degree. Thepure variety is known as Dyvee. How the impure Vasanastend to produce misery and repeated births and how the pureones help the onward progress to salvation are explained inthe following quotations. The mind also, irrespective of itsactions in the directions propelled by the Vasanas, has itsnatural tendency to connect itself with the external worldthrough the sensations and with the internal throughthought. How these tendencies will in themselves obstructthe proper path, if left unchecked is also clearly explainedhere.

लोकवासनया जन्तोः शास्त्रवासनयापि च।
देहवासनया ज्ञानं यथावन्नैव जायते।
द्विविधो वासनाव्यूहः शुभश्चैवाशुभश्चतौ।
वासनौघेन शुद्धेन तत्र चेदनुनीयसे।
तत्क्रमेणाशु तेनैव मामकं पदमाप्नुहि।
