अथ वेदशुभो भावस्त्वां योजयति सङ्कटे।
प्राक्तनस्तदसौ यत्नाज्जेतव्यो भवता कपे !।
शुभाशुभाभ्यां मार्गाभ्यां वहन्ती वासना सरित्।
पौरुषेण प्रयत्नेनयोजनीया शुभे पथि।
अशुभेषु समाविष्टं शुभेष्वेवावतारयेत्।
अशुभाच्चालितं याति शुभं तस्मादपीतरत्।
द्रागभ्यासवशाद्याति यदा ते वासनोदयम्।
तदाभ्यासस्य साफल्यं विद्धि त्वमरिमर्दनम्।
सन्दिग्धायामपि भृशं शुभामेव समाचर।
शुभायां वासना वृद्धौ न दोषाय मरुत्सुत॥

(1) मुक्तिकोपनिषत्॥

उद्धरेदात्मनात्मानं नात्मानमवसादयेत्।
आत्मैव ह्यात्मनो बन्धुरात्मैव रिपुरात्मनः।
सत्त्वं रजस्तम इति गुणाः प्रकृतिसम्भवाः।
निबध्नन्ति महाबाहो ! देहे देहिनमव्ययम्।
तत्र सत्त्वं निर्मलत्वात्प्रकाशकमनामयम्।
सुखसङ्गेन बध्नाति ज्ञानसङ्गेन चानघ !।
रजो रागात्मकं विद्धि तृष्णा सङ्गसमुद्भवम्।
तन्निबध्नाति कौन्तेय ! कर्मसङ्गेन देहिनम्।
तमस्त्वज्ञानजं विद्धि मोहनं सर्वदेहिनाम्।
प्रमादालस्यनिद्राभिस्तन्निबध्नाति भारत !।
सत्त्वं सुखे सञ्जयति रजः कर्मणि भारत !।
ज्ञानमावृत्य तु तमः प्रमादे सञ्जयत्युत।
सत्त्वात्सञ्जायते ज्ञानं रजसो लोभ एव च।
प्रमादमोहौ तमसो भवतोऽज्ञानमेव च।
सर्वद्वारेषु देहेऽस्मिन् प्रकाश उपजायते।
ज्ञानं यदा तदा विद्याद्विवृद्धं सत्त्वमित्युत।
लोभः प्रवृत्तिरारम्भः कर्मणामशमः स्पृहा।
रजस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे भरतर्षभ !।
अप्रकाशोऽप्रवृत्तिश्चप्रमादो मोह एव च।
तमस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे कुरुनन्दन !।
द्वौ भूतसर्गौलोकेऽस्मिन्दैव आसुर एव च।
अभयं सत्त्वसंशुद्धिः ज्ञानयोगव्यवस्थितिः।
दानं दमश्च यज्ञश्च स्वाध्यायस्तप आर्जवम्।
अहिंसा सत्यमक्रोधस्त्यागश्शान्तिरपैशुनम्।
दया भूतेष्वलोलुप्त्वं मार्दवं ह्रीरचापलम्।
तेजःक्षमा धृतिः शौचमद्रोहो नातिमानिता।
भवन्ति सम्पदं दैवीमभिजातस्य भारत !
दम्भो दर्पोऽभिमानश्च क्रोधः पारुष्यमेव च।
अज्ञानं चाभिजातस्य पार्थ ! सम्पदमासुरीम्।
दैवीसम्पद्विमोक्षाय निबन्धायासुरी मता॥

(2) भगवद्गीता॥

Quotation No. III.

अनात्मन्यात्मभावेन देहभावनया तथा।
पुत्रदारैः कुडुम्बैश्च चेतो गच्छति पीनताम्।
आधिव्याधिविलासेन समाश्वासेन संसृतौ।
हेयाहेयविभागेन चेतो गच्छति पीनताम्।
स्नेहेन धनलोभेन लाभेन मणियोषिताम्।
आपातरमणीयेन चेतो गच्छति पीनताम्।
दुराशा क्षीरपानेन भोगानिलबलेन च।
आस्था दानेन चारेण चित्ताहिर्याति पीनताम्।
बन्धो हि वासनाबन्धो मोक्षः स्याद्वासनाक्षयः।
वासनास्त्वं परित्यज्य मोक्षार्थित्वमपि त्यज।
मानसी वासनाः पूर्वं त्यक्त्वा विषयवासनाः।
मैत्र्यादिभावना नाम्नीगृहाणामलवासनाः।
ता अप्यन्तः परित्यज्य ताभिर्व्यवहरन्नपि।
अन्तः शान्तः समस्नेहो भव चिन्मात्रवासनः।
तामप्यन्तः परित्यज्य मनोबुद्धिसमन्विताम्।
शेषे स्थिरसमाधानो येन त्यजास तं त्यज॥

ज्ञानवासिष्ठम्॥

Q. No. IV.

सङ्कल्पो विचिकित्सा श्रद्धाऽश्रद्धा धृतिरधृतिर्ह्रीर्धी-
र्भीरित्येतत्सर्वं मन एवेति लक्षणम्॥

अन्यत्र मना अभूवन्नादर्शमन्यत्र मना अभूवन्नाश्रौषमिति॥
मनसाह्येष पश्यति मनसा शृणोतीति॥

श्रुतयः॥

Q. No. V.

जीवद्वैतं तु शास्त्रीयमशास्त्रीयमिति द्विधा।
उपाददीत शास्त्रीयमा तत्त्वस्यावबोधनात्।
आत्मब्रह्मविचाराख्यं शास्त्रीयं मानसं जगत्।
बुद्धे तत्त्वे तच्चहेयमिति श्रुत्यनुशासनम्।
अशास्त्रीयमपि द्वैतं तीव्रं मन्दमिति द्विधा।
कामक्रोधादिकं तीव्रं मनोराज्यं तथेतरत्।
उभयं तत्त्वबोधात् प्राङ् निवार्यं बोधसिद्धये।
शमः समाहितत्त्वं च साधनेषु श्रुतं यतः।
बोधादूध्वं च तद्धेयं जीवन्मुक्तिप्रसिद्धये।
कामादिक्लेशबन्धेन युक्तस्य न हि मुक्तता।
बुद्धाद्वैतस्वतत्त्वस्य यथेष्टाचरणं यदि।
शुनां तत्त्वदृशां चैव को भेदोऽशुचिभक्षणे।
काम्यादिदोषदृष्ट्याद्याःकामादित्यागहेतवः।
प्रसिद्धो मोक्षशास्त्रेषु तानन्विष्य सुखी भव।
त्यज्यतामेष कामादिर्मनोराज्ये तु का क्षतिः।
अशेषदोषबीजत्वात् क्षतिर्भगवतेरिता।
ध्यायतो विषयान् पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते।
सङ्गात् सञ्जायते कामः कामात् क्रोधोऽपि जायते।
क्रोधात् भवति सम्मोहः सम्मोहात्स्मृति विभ्रमः।
स्मृतिभ्रंशात् बुद्धिनाशो बुद्धिनाशात् प्रणश्यति।
शक्यं जेतुं मनोराज्यं निर्विकल्पसमाधितः।
सुसम्पादः क्रमात्सोऽपि सविकल्पसमाधिना।
बुद्धतत्त्वेन धीदोषशून्येनैकान्तवासिना।
दीर्घं प्रणवमुच्चार्य मनोराज्यं विजीयते।
जीवन्मुक्तेः परा काष्ठा जीवद्वैतविवर्जनात्।
लभ्यतेऽसावतोऽत्रेदमीशद्वैताद्विवेचितम्॥

पञ्चदशी॥

*** Quotation No. I.*** ‘The Vasanas are either good or bad.They are also classified into, Loka-vasana, Sastra-vasanaand Deha-vasana. The good ones ultimately lead to salvation, but the bad ones lead to misery, and should thereforebe turned to good directions by any amount of effort. Thepredominance of good vasanas never causes any harm’.

*** Q. No. II.*** ‘Save Atma by Atma itself. It is its ownfriend and enemy. There are three gunas originating fromPrakriti that connect themselves with it, namely, Satwa,Reja and Tama. Satwa is bright and pure, and it leads tobliss and gnana. Reja leads to action, desire and greed.Tama leads to ignorance, sleep and idleness. There are twovarieties of creation, known as Dyva and Asura; the formeris recognised by the tendency to harmlessness, tapas, gnana,peace of mind, kindness and other good qualities leading tosalvation; whereas the latter is known by the tendency toanger, greed, pride, ignorance and other bad qualities leading to bondage’.

*** Q. No. III.*** ‘The mind becomes dull and thick byworldly desires and attachments and becomes subject tobondage. When the Vasanas, both internal and externalare relinquished the goal is easily reached’.

*** Q. No. IV.*** ‘Mind is at the bottom of all sensations, offaith and faithlessness, strength, fear and cowardice & c. Infact mind is everything’.

*** Q. No. V.*** The duality of ideas created by Jiva is oftwo kinds, the Sastric and the reverse. The former alludesto the spirit of philosophical enquiry, which should also berelinquished after the attainment of knowledge. The latteris divided into two classes, weak and strong. Anger, desire,greed & c. are styled strong, and mere mental distractions areknown as weak. Both of these should be destroyed longbefore true knowledge is obtained. Mental distractionshowever are not to be slighted, as they also produce allpossible evils, by creating desire, anger, ignorance, loss ofmemory & c. They could be destroyed only by the processof Nirvikalpa-Samadhi which should succeed Savikalpa. Itis a mistake to affirm that one who has really attained to theknowledge of self, is permitted to lead any kind of life afterwards with impunity. The main idea inculcated in the text,is the getting rid of all possible means leading to angerdesire & c. and several sensible methods are provided for thesame therein. Without taking to any of these prescribedmethods, if one leads a very despicable life on the ground ofhis being a gnani, there is hardly any difference betweenhim and a dirty dog’.

It is a bare fact that there are still several importantmatters to be explained in this section devoted to the generaltreatment of Hindu Religion and philosophy. It must alsobe confessed without reserve, that even what little has beenwritten in this essay could certainly have been done muchbetter by abler and more competent hands. But I trust Imay however be kindly permitted to consol myself, that Ihave not as far as I can understand, tampered with the subjects either by misquoting or mistranslating. I have alreadyexpressed plainly in the beginning of this second chapter thatI would entirely refrain from volunteering any opinion of myown accord, without quotations from proper texts. I humblyhope that I have strictly kept on to my pledge in this matter all along, and any misconceptions or misunderstandingsof views that might arise so far, could only be reckoned asdifferences of opinions against the texts themselves, In thenature of things such differences are quite possible and theyhave actually existed from the beginning of time. What theyare and how they occur are clearly foretold and explainedby our omnicient ancient sages. That there is therefore nothing to be surprised in the modern state of affairs could beeasily gathered from the following quotations:

Quotation No. I.

अद्वितीय ब्रह्मतत्त्वं न जानन्ति यथा तथा।
भ्रान्ता एवाऽखिलास्तेषां क्व मुक्तिः क्वेह वा सुखम्।

वराहोपनिषत्॥

Q. No. II.

भ्रमः पञ्चविधो भाति तदेवेह समुच्यते।
जीवेश्वरौ भिन्नरूपौ इति प्राथमिको भ्रमः।
आत्मनिष्ठं कर्तृगुणं वास्तवं वा द्वितीयकः।
शरीरत्रय संयुक्त जीवस्सङ्गी तृतीयकः।
जगत्कारणरूपस्य विकारित्वं चतुर्थकः।
कारणाद्भिन्नजगतस्सत्यत्वं पञ्चमो भ्रमः॥

तरवोपि हि जीवन्ति जीवन्ति मृगपक्षिणः।
स जीवति मनो यस्य मननेनोपजीवति।

Q. No. VII.

यामिमां पुष्पितां वाचं प्रवदन्त्य विपश्चितः।
वेदवादरताः पार्थ नान्यदस्तीति वादिनः।
कामात्मानः स्वर्गपरा जन्मकर्म फलप्रदाम्।
क्रियाविशेषबहुलां भोगैश्वर्यगतिं प्रति।
भोगेश्वर्य प्रसक्तानां तयापहृत चेतसाम्।
व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिः समाधौ न विधीयते।
त्रैगुण्य विषया वेदा निस्त्रैगुण्यो भवार्जुन।
निर्द्वंन्द्वो नित्यसत्वस्थो निर्योग क्षेम आत्मवान्।
यावानर्थ उदपाने सर्वतः संप्लुतोदके।
तावान् सर्वेषु वेदेषु ब्राह्मणस्य विजानतः॥

भगवद्गीता।

Q. No. VIII.

इतोन्यद्यत्परिज्ञानं तदशनं न संशयः।
विचारेणा ममेवार्थः अयमेवा विचारणे॥

सूतसंहिता॥

Q. No. IX.

अज्ञात्वा ग्रन्थतत्त्वानिवादं यः कुरुते नरः।
लोभाद्वाप्यथहादम्भात् सः पापीनरकं व्रजेत्।
निर्णयश्चापि छिद्राणान तद्वश्यति तत्वतः॥

ब्रह्मपुराणम्॥

Q. No. X.

अज्ञात्वा शास्त्रहृदयं मूढो वक्त्यन्यथान्यथा।
मूर्खाणां निर्णयस्त्वास्तां अस्मत्सिद्धान्त उच्यते।
नानुतिष्ठति कोप्येतदिति चेन्मानुतिष्ठतु।
पुरुषस्यापराधेन किमुपास्तिः प्रदूष्यति।
इतोऽप्यतिशयं मत्वा मन्त्रान् वश्यादिकारिणः।
मूढा जपन्तु तेभ्योऽतिमूढाः कृषिमुपास्यताम्।
कालेन परिपच्यन्ते कृषिगर्भादयो यथा।
तद्वदात्मविचारोपि शनैः कालेन पच्यते।
प्रतिबन्धो वर्तमानो विषयासक्तिलक्षणः।
प्रज्ञामान्द्यंकुतर्कश्च विपर्ययदुराग्रहः।
शमाद्यैः श्रवणाद्यैश्च तत्र तत्रोचितैः क्षयम्।
नीतेऽस्मिन् प्रतिबन्धेऽतः स्वस्य ब्रह्मत्वमश्नुते।
मग्नस्याब्धौ यथाऽक्षाणि विह्वलानि तथास्यधीः।
अखण्डैकरसं श्रुत्वा निष्प्रचारा बिभेत्यतः।
न जानामीत्युदासीनव्यवहारस्य कारणम्।
विचारप्रागभावेन युक्तमज्ञानमीरितम्।
अमार्गेण विचार्याथ नास्तिनोभाति चेत्यसौ।
विपरीतव्यवहृतिः आवृतेः कार्यमिष्यते।
देहद्वयचिदाभासरूपो विक्षेप ईरितः।
कर्तृत्वाद्यखिलः शोकःसंसारख्योऽस्य बन्धकः।
परोक्षज्ञानतो नश्येद सत्वावृत्तिहेतुता।
अपरोक्षज्ञाननाश्या ह्यभानावृत्तिहेतुता।
अभानावरणे नष्टे जीवत्वारोपसंक्षयात्।
कर्तृत्वाद्यखिलः शोकः संसाराख्यो निवर्तते।
निवृत्ते सर्वसंसारे नित्यमुक्तत्वभासनात्।
निरङ्कुशा भवेत्तृप्तिः पुनः शोकासमुद्भवात्।
बहुजन्मदृढाभ्यासात् देहादिष्वात्मधीः क्षणात्।
पुनः पुनरुवेत्येवं जगत्सत्यत्वधीरपि।
विपरीता भावनेयमैकाग्र्यात्सा निवर्तते।
तत्वोपदेशात् प्रागेव भवत्येतदुपासनात्॥

पञ्चदशी॥

Q. No. XI.

अतिदूरात् सामीप्यादिन्द्रियघातान्मनो नऽवस्थानात्।
सौक्ष्म्यात् व्यवधानादभिभवात् समानाभिहारात् च॥

सांख्यकारिका॥

Q. No. X11

द्वैविध्यं सर्वलोकेषु सर्वत्र द्विविधो जनः।
रागीचैव विरामी च तयोश्चित्तं द्विधा पुनः।
विरागी त्रिविधः कामं ज्ञातोज्ञातश्च मध्यमः।
रागी च द्विविधः प्रोक्तो मूर्खश्च चतुरस्तथा।
चातुर्ये द्विविधं प्रोक्तं शास्त्रजं मतिजं तथा।
मातस्तु द्विविधा लोके युतायुक्तेति सर्वधा।
रागो यस्यास्ति संसारे स रागीत्युच्यते ध्रुवम्।
दुःखं बहुविधं तस्य सुखञ्च विविधं पुनः।
धनं प्राप्य सुतान् दारान् मानञ्चविजयं तथा।
तदप्राप्य महद्दुःखं भवत्येव क्षणे क्षणे।
कार्ये तस्य सुखोपायः कर्तव्यं सुखसाधनम्।
तस्यारातिस्स विज्ञेयः सुखविघ्नं करोति यः।
सुखोत्पादयिता मित्रं रागयुक्तस्य सर्वदा।
चतुरो नैवमुह्येत मूर्खस्सर्वत्र मुह्यति।
विरक्तस्यात्मरक्तस्य सुखमेकान्तसेवनम्।
आत्मानुचिन्तनं चैव वेदान्तस्य च चिन्तनम्।
दुःखं तदेतत्सर्वे हि संसारकथनादिकम्।
शत्रवो बहवस्तस्य विज्ञस्य शुभमिछतः।
कामः क्रोधः प्रमादश्च शत्रवो विविधा स्मृताः।
बन्धुस्सन्तोष एवास्य नान्योऽस्ति भुवनत्रये॥

देवीभागवतम्॥

×

The points noticed in the above quotations do not directly concern the main subject under reference, but they onlyrefer to the possible, causes of misunderstanding and therefore do not demand complete or literal translations. Thefacts detailed however may appear to some extent as insulting exaggerations, but nevertheless, they are unfortunatelytoo true. The sacred subject dealt with in our religious literature is unlike other scientific matters which require onlya capable intellect to grasp them, but here a good deal ofmental training and other ethical qualifications are neededto appreciate and utilize the valuable instructions conveyed.They are of course not meant for mere fools, and more especially never intended for bad men. Worldly prejudices, personal pride and jealousy, unworthy character and conduct,are particular disqualifications, although they may not be soobjectionable for the study of other sciences. The passagesquoted above point out in detail, the mistaken notions thatinterfere with the correct perception of real truth, The Ragis or those given up to worldly desires, have as a class,their own settled ideas of happiness and misery which obstruct the path to real knowledge.

रागो यस्यास्ति संसारे स रागीत्युच्यते ध्रुवम्।

Then again, intellectual incapacity, intellectual perversity and strong desires in the wrong direction greatly interfere with the possibility of acquiring real knowledge.

प्रज्ञामान्द्यंकुतर्कश्च विपर्यय दुराग्रहः॥

A worldly-wise man destitute of philosophical thoughtis not even reckoned as a born or living human being, in thesacred literature. He is rejected as a useless old donkey.

स जीवति मनो यस्य मनमेनोपजीवति।
जातास्त एव जगति जन्तवस्साधु जीविताः।
ये पुनर्न्नेह जायन्ते शेषा जरठगर्दमाः॥

Prevention of future miseries on account of re-births,is the main object aimed at throughout the texts. The general plea for non-perception of truth is a simple display ofidleness and want of thought. It is styled Agnana. Enquiry in the wrong direction is known as Avarana. Identification of Self with the gross and subtle bodies is called Vikshepa. These mistakes always bring on the miseries ofSamsara. They cannot be got over all on a sudden withoutworking gradually against them. The goal will then be reached in course of time, as in agriculture and conception.

कालेन परिपच्यन्ते कृषिगर्भादयो यथा॥

The passages quoted above from the various ancienttexts, unanimously inculcate the necessity of philosophic meditation and religious devotion. Professor Masson thus expresses the same idea with equal force in our own times-‘A nation without philosophy has the mark of the beast upon it and is going the way of all brutality.” Another serious point noticed in this connection is the evil consequensesof misinterpreting without a knowledge of the subject andactuated by pride and jealousy and more especially throughthe spirit of fault-finding.

अज्ञात्वा ग्रन्थतत्वानि वादं यः कुरुते नरः।
लोभाद्वाप्यथवादम्भात् स पापी नरकं व्रजेत्।
निर्णयं चाऽपि छिद्रात्मा न तद्वक्ष्यति तत्वतः॥

It is earnestly hoped that these serious warnings from ourvenerable sages will create a sincere spirit of enquiry in theright direction, and an abundance of useful information maysoon be forthcoming from every competent and sympatheticquarter, instead of unprofitable and quarrelsome attacks oninsignificant personal merits or demerits.

ओंकारावर्तरम्या यजुरमलजला सामगम्भीरेघोषा
ऋग्वेदाथर्वकूला क्रमपदपुलिना न्यायशास्त्रोत्तरङ्गा।
अङ्गग्राहावनद्धा शतपथगमना ब्रह्मविद्यार्णवान्ता।
विद्वद्वाग् जाह्नवीयं क्षपयति दुरितं सर्वदा शर्मदा नः॥

CHAPTER III.

PLACE, TIME AND PERSONALITY.

THElast three sections enumerated in the classificationgiven at the beginning of the last chapter are meantto be treated here with a view to furnish the necessary cluesto discover the real significance of Places, Times and Personalities, as found described in the ancient religious literature.That the descriptions do not refer actually to any of themas such, but specify more philosophical and scientific matters,has been already explained in the first chapter itself-callthem mythologies or allegories as you wish, they nevertheless convey definite instructions based upon scientific and philosophical facts. In concretising the abstract ideas for thebenefit of the less qualified, much scientific knowledge hasbeen displayed to make them useful in every way, both forpresent purposes and for future progress. ‘शास्त्राय च सुखाय च’is a common saying in the mouth of all the Hindus. Butneither mythologies nor mere allegories can afford to servethese important purposes. These two English words areused by most critics generally conveying an insinuation as tothe absence of usefulness in comparison with the modernscientific discoveries. How far the criticisms are correct, thesubject must speak for itself.

Another kind of criticism that might come forward, isthrough the Interpolation theory, a weapon that is too oftenused indiscriminately, whenever the interpretations given donot suit the critic’s individual taste or whim, or frighten himout of his wits. Quotations from acknowledged texts likethe Sratis, Upanishads, Smritis and Puranas cannot be condenined in this careless fashion without similar authoritativequotations to the contrary and without being able to giveother reasonable explanations to satisfy the enquiring minds.If the possibility of Interpolation is brought in, simply tocriticise the texts themselves as meaningless trash and theirvenerable authors as crazy fools, the unsympathetic interloper is fully welcome. It is certainly be-neath the dignityof a sane man to notice such scurrilous and profitless criticisms.

Before commencing with the necessary quotations, ithas to be observed that they will not be generally available,exclusively referring to place, time or personality. Veryoften they will be found combined with explanations of anytwo or all the three. It will not therefore be possible tostick exactly to the order in the classification.The necessaryquotations and explanations shall be subjoined, without,however, generally departing from the order specified.

But another and more serious difficulty that is unavoidable here, cannot be passed over without being specially noticed. The definitions in the passages to be quoted mightoften apply to more than one fact or to the same fact in ahigher or lower sense. I must certainly confess here thatwith my limited knowledge of the subject, it would be hopeless to attempt satisfactory explanations for all of them. Everylearned scholar who is a sympathiser and well-wisher of thissubject, whether native or foreigner is earnestly requested,in behalf of humanity at large, to take up the matter witha loving spirit and furnish further useful instructions. ButI cannot help repeatedly maintaining in this connection,that the current method of interpretation, inevitably leadingto the infamy of our sacred literature is absolutely unauthorised. The mistake, as will be evident from the followingpassages, can be easily discovered to have originated from theignorance of the higher nature of the matters dealt with, aswell as by the unconscious or perverse obstinacy of puttingthe cart before the horse. Apart from the unfortunato mistake that has for some time crept in, neither the preciousliterature nor its venerable authors, are responsible for thepresent deplorable state of affairs. Vanmiki’s vivid andtouching description in the Ramayana, of Sita’s sad predicament while confined in the Asoka Forest, quoted below, willI trust be an exact and appropriate parallel to the pitiablecondition to which, our ancient religious literature is at present reduced.

अभूतेनापवादेन कीर्तिं निपतितामिव।
आम्नायानामयोगेन विद्यां प्रशिथिलामिव।
सन्नामिव महाकीर्तिं श्रद्धामिव विमानताम्।
प्रज्ञामिव परिक्षीणां आशां प्रतिहतामिव।
आयतीमिव विध्वस्तां आज्ञां प्रतिहतामिव।
दीप्तामिव दिशं काले पूजामपहतामिव।
पौर्णमासीमिव निशां तमोग्रस्तेन्दुमण्डलाम्।
पद्मिनीमिव विध्वस्तां हतशूरां चमूमिव।
प्रभामिव तमोध्वस्तामुपक्षीणामिवापगाम्।
वेदीमिव परामृष्टां शान्तमग्निशिखामिव।
उत्कृष्टपर्णकमलां वित्रासितविहङ्गमाम्।
हस्तिहस्तपरामृष्टामाकुलामिव पद्मिनीम्।
पतिशोकातुरां शुष्कां नदीं विस्रावितामिव।
परया मृजया हीनां कृष्णपक्षे निशामिव।
गृहीतां लालितां स्तम्भे यूथपेन विना कृताम्।
निश्वसन्तीं सुदुःखार्तां गजराजवधूमिव।
ददर्श दीनां दुःखार्तां नावं सन्नामिवार्णवे।
छिन्नां प्रपतितां भूभौ शाखामिव वनस्पतेः।
धूप्यमानं ग्रहेणैव रोहिणींधूमकेतुना।
पिनद्धां धूमजालेन शिखामिव विभावसोः।
ग्रहेणाङ्गारकेणेव पीडितामिव रोहिणीम्।
प्रियं जनमपश्यन्तीं पश्यन्तीं राक्षसीगणम्।
स्वगणेन मृगीं हीनां श्वगणेनावृतामिव।
तां स्मृतीमिव सन्दिग्धामृद्धिं निपतितामिव।
विहतामिव च श्रद्धामाशां प्रतिहतामिव।
सोपसर्गां यथा सिद्धिं बुद्धिं सकलुषामिव।
प्रभां नक्षत्रराजस्य कालमेघैरिवावृताम्।
संस्कारेण यथा हीनां वाचमर्थान्तरं गताम्॥

सुन्दरकाण्डम्॥

The above is an exceedingly beautiful and poetical exposition of the sad and pitiable condition of unmerited disrepute in this material world. Our sacred religious literaturehas suffered all its present calumnny for no intrinsic fault ofits own.The indigenous Pandit commenced explaining theunknown subject, with his limited knowledge in the Sanskrit language and without caring to understand its philosophical and religious importance. His smattering knowledgeof Sanskrit in the midst of a large population entirely strangeto the language, emboldened him to offer irrelevant and unreasonable explanations, forgetting his own ignorance in thetechnicalities of the literature and his utter want of religious study and philosophical thought. He was able to continue for a long time in this strain without a protest, whichnaturally confirmed his mistaken opinion as to the absenceof anything more serious in the texts than what he has conceived without a study. The foreign critic who sought information from the Pandit in a mere spirit of curiosity andinterest of novelty, obtained only his views on the subject,without knowing at the same time that the Pandit was asmuch a stranger as himself in the field in question. Withhis better education however, the critic was soon able to perceive the absurdity of the explanations in themselves, andunfortunately commenced his critical operations against theliterature instead of against the Pandit. His mistake is tosome extent excusable, but the actual evil consequences areexactly the same as if he dealt with the subject without afeeling of respect and sympathy and without a sincerespirit of earnest enquiry. The literature as a whole is bythis time somehow surrounded by all the negative and positive evils possible.

अभूतेनापवादेन कीर्तिं निपतितामिव।
संस्कारेण विना हीनां वाचमर्थान्तरङ्गताम्।
स्वगणेन मृगीं हीनां श्वगणेनावृतामिव॥

सुन्दरकाण्डम्।

1. As already arranged in the classification wemay start with the descriptions of places found in the so-called geography in the literature. The names given ofcourse are very often stubbornly identified with knownlocalities and holy centres and more often explained asspots that existed in times of yore, but now submerged,extinct or somehow unknown.

The Vaidikic objections commonly raised against seeking for their correct meanings or even questioning theirmeaningless interpretations, have been already noticed asalso the supposed dangers of disturbing the current religiousignorance of the subject. It hardly needs the repetition ofthe fact, that complete ignorance and unbecoming arrogancelie at the bottom of these silly objections. The vague andevasive explanations styled occultisms and secret doctrinesare equally irrelevant, especially as the few specific explanations unconsciously given out by the Theosophist can beeasily proved to fall exactly under the category of localmisinterpretations.

The following quotations refer to our religious geography, if geography it may be called until it is clearlyunderstood.

Quotation No. I.

अव्यक्तपृथिवीपद्मं मेरुस्तस्य च कर्णिका।
महायोगी महादेवो जगध्येयो जनार्दनः।
सर्वलोकगतोऽनन्तो व्यापको मूर्तिरव्ययः।
न तस्य प्राकृता मूर्तिर्मांसमेदोस्थिसम्भवा।
योगित्वाच्चेश्वरत्वाच्च सर्वरूपधरो विभुः।
तन्निमित्तं समुत्पन्नं लोके पद्मं सनातनम्।
कल्पशेषस्य तस्यासौ कालस्य गतिरीदृशी।
तस्मिन् पद्मे समुत्पन्नो देवदेवश्चतुर्मुखः।
प्रजापतिपतिर्देवः ईशानो जगतः प्रभुः।
तस्य बीजनिसर्गं हि पुष्करस्य यथार्थवत्।
कृत्स्नं प्रजानिसर्गेण विस्तरेणैव वर्ण्यते।
तदम्बु वैष्णवः कायो यतो रत्नविभूषितः।
पद्माकारा समुत्पन्ना पृथिवी सवनह्रदा।
तत्तस्य लोकपद्मस्य विस्तरं सिद्धभाषितम्।
वर्ण्यमानं विभागेन क्रमशः शृणुत द्विजाः।
तत्र या सा मया तुभ्यं कर्णिकेत्यभिविश्रुता।
तां वर्ण्यमानामेकाग्र्यात्समासेन निबोधत।
तत्र ब्रह्मसभा रम्या ब्रह्मर्षिजनसङ्कला।
नाम्ना मनोवती सा तु सर्वलोकेषु विश्रुता।
तत्रेशानस्य देवस्य सहस्रादित्य वर्चसः।
महाविमानसंस्थस्य महिमा वर्तते सदा।
तत्र जाम्बूनदं नाम सुवर्णमनलप्रभम्।
पिबन्त्यमृतकल्पं च प्रीत्या जम्बूफलासवम्।
मोक्षते दक्षिणे वर्षे जम्बू लोकेति विश्रुता।
यस्या नाम्ना समाख्याता जम्बूद्वीपेति मानवैः॥

इयं च पृथ्वी लक्षकोटिशतानेकसंख्याता पूर्णातेषु च सिद्धविद्याधराणांनिलयाः। तद्यथा मेरोः पार्श्वतःकेसरवलयालवालं सिद्धलोक इति कीर्यते।इयं च पृथ्वी पद्माकारेण व्यवस्थिता। एष सर्वपुराणेषु क्रमः सामान्यतःप्रतिपाद्यते॥

वराहपुराणम्॥

Q. No. II.

ते अलोका महाप्राज्ञा नाशमायान्ति ये च वै।
सर्वदैवस्थिता ये च ये लोकाश्च सनातनाः॥

पद्मपुराणम्॥

Q. No. III.

प्रकाशश्चाप्रकाशश्च लोकालोकः स उच्यते।
आलोकस्तस्य चार्वाक्तु निरालोकस्ततः परम्।
आलोके लोकशब्दस्तु निरालोके सलोकता।
लोकार्थं सम्मतो लोको निरालोकस्तु बाह्यतः।
तम एवनिरालोकममर्यादमदेशिकम्।
देवानाप्यविदितं व्यवहारविवर्जितम्।
अण्डस्यान्तस्त्विमे लोकाः सप्तद्वीपा च मेदिनी।
भूलोकोऽथ भुवर्लोकःस्वर्लोकोऽथ महस्तथा।
जनस्तपस्तथा सत्य एतावान् लोकसंग्रहः।
अण्डानामीदृशानान्तु कोट्यो ज्ञेयाः सहस्रशः।
तिर्यगूर्ध्वमधस्ताच्च कारणस्याव्ययात्मनः।
कारणैः प्राकृतैस्तत्र ह्यवृता प्रतिसप्तभिः।
दशाधिक्येन चान्योन्यं धारयन्ति परस्परम्।
परस्परावृताः सर्वे उत्पन्नाश्च परस्परात्॥

वायुपुराणम्॥

Q. No. IV.

चतुर्दशैव स्थानानि वर्णितानि महर्षिभिः।
लोकाख्यानि तु यानि स्युर्येषु तिष्ठन्ति मानवाः।
सप्त तेषु कृतान्याहुरकृतानि तु सप्त वै।
भूरादयस्तु संख्याताः सप्तलोकाः कृतास्त्विह।
अकृतानि तु सप्तैव प्राकृतानि तु यानि वै।
भूर्लोकप्रथमालोका महदन्ताश्च ते स्मृताः।
आरभ्यन्ते तु तन्मात्रैः शुद्धास्तेषां परस्परम्।
चतुर्दशानां सर्वेषां पुनरावृत्तिहेतवः।
योगं तपश्च सत्यं च समाधाय तदात्मनि।
षष्ठे काले निवर्तन्ते तत्तदाह विपर्यये।
सत्यं तु सप्तमो लोको अपुनर्मार्गगामिनाम्।
ब्रह्मलोकः समाख्यातो ह्यप्रतीघातलक्षणः॥

वायुपुराणम्।

Q. No. V.

प्राणासन् ह्यविशेषास्तु विशेषान्योन्यवेशनात्।
पृथिव्याद्याश्चवाय्वन्ताः परिछिन्नास्त्रयस्तु ते।
गुणापचयसारेण परिच्छेदो विशेषतः।
शेषाणां तु परिच्छेदः सौक्ष्मान्नेह विभाव्यते।
भूतेभ्यः परतस्तेभ्यो ह्यालोकः परतः स्मृतः।
भूतान्यालोक आकाशे परिच्छिन्नानि सर्वशः।
तथा ह्यालोक आकाशे भेदास्त्वन्तर्गता मताः।
कृत्स्नान्येतानि चत्वारि अन्योन्यस्याधिकानि तु।
यावदेतानि भूतानि तावदुत्पत्तिरुच्यते।
जन्तूनामिह संस्कारो भूतेष्वन्तर्गतो मतः।
प्रत्याख्याय च भूतानि कार्योत्पत्तिर्न विद्यते।
तस्मात्परिमिता भेदाः स्मृताः कार्यात्मकास्तु ते।
करणात्मकास्तथैव स्युर्भेदा ये महदादयः।
इत्येष सन्निवेशो वो मया प्रोक्तो विभागशः।
सप्तद्वीपसमुद्राया याथातथ्येन वै द्विजाः।
विस्तारान्मण्डलाञ्चैव प्रसंख्यातेन चैव हि।
वैश्वरूपं प्रधानस्य परिमाणैकदेशिकम्।

अधिष्ठानं भगवतो यस्य सर्वमिदं जगत्।
एवं भूतगणाः सप्त सन्निविष्टाः परस्परम्।
एतावान् सन्निवेशस्तु मया शक्यः प्रभाषितुम्।
एतावदेव श्रोतव्यं सन्निवेशे तु पार्थिव।
सप्त प्रकृतयस्त्वेताः धारयन्ति परस्परम्।
ताः स्वल्पपरिमाणेन प्रसंख्यातुमिहोच्यते॥

वायुपुराणम्॥

Q. No. VI.

पातालात् ब्रह्मलोकान्तं ब्रह्माण्डं परिकीर्तितम्।
तत ऊर्ध्वे च वैकुण्ठो ब्रह्माण्डात् बहिरेव सः।
तदूर्ध्वे चैव गोलोकः पञ्चाशत्कोटियोजनात्।
ऊर्ध्वं धराया भूर्लोको भुवर्लोकस्ततः परः।
स्वर्लोकस्तु ततः पश्चात् महर्लोकस्ततो जनः।
ततः परस्तपो लोकः सत्यलोकस्ततः परः।
ततः परो ब्रह्मलोकस्तप्तकाञ्चननिर्मितः।
एवं सर्वं कृत्रिमं तद्बाह्याभ्यन्तर एव च।
नित्यौ गोलोकवैकुण्टौ सत्वौशश्वदकृत्रिमौ॥

ब्रह्मवैवर्तपुराणम्॥

Q. No. VII.

मानसो नाम यः पूर्वोविश्रुतो वै महर्षिभिः।
अव्यक्त इति विख्यातः शाश्वतोऽथाक्षयोऽव्ययः।
यतः सृष्टानि भूतानि जायन्ते च म्रियन्ति च।
सोऽसृजत् प्रथमं देवो महान्तं नाम नामतः।
आकाशमिति विख्यातं सर्वभूतधरः प्रभुः।
आकाशादभवद्वारि सलिलादग्निमारुतौ।
अग्निमारुतसंयोगात् ततः समभवन्मही।
ततस्तेजोमयं दिव्यं पद्मं सृष्टं स्वयम्भुवा।
तस्मात्पद्मात्समभवद् ब्रह्मा वेदमयो विधिः।

अहङ्कार इति ख्यातः सर्वभूतात्मभूतकृत्।
अग्निमारुततोयानां वर्णा क्षितितलस्य च।
आकाशसदृशा ह्येते भिद्यन्ते तत्त्वदर्शनात्।
अदृश्यो यस्त्वगम्यो यः कः प्रमाणमुदीरयेत्।
मानसोऽग्निःशरीरेषु जीव इत्यभिधीयते।
सृष्टिः प्रजापतेरेषाभूताध्यात्मविनिश्चये॥

नारदपुराणम्।

Q. No. VIII.

**(a) **

बुद्धिद्रव्येण दृश्येत मनोदीपेन लोककृत्।
महतस्तमसस्तात परे तिष्ठन्नतामसः।
स च मानस इत्युक्तः तत्वज्ञैर्वेदपारगैः।
विमलो वितमस्कश्च निर्लिङ्गोऽलिङ्गसंज्ञकः।
योगमेतत्तु योगानां मन्ये योगस्यलक्षणम्।
एवं पश्यं प्रपश्यन्ति आत्मस्थमजरं परम् ॥
यस्माद्यदभिजायेत तत्तत्रैव प्रलीयते।
लीयन्ते प्रतिलोमानि सृज्यन्ते चान्तात्मना।
अनुलोमेन जायन्ते लीयन्ते प्रतिलोमतः।
एकत्वञ्चबहुत्वञ्चप्रकृतेरनु तत्त्ववान्।
एकत्वं प्रलये चास्य बहुत्वं च प्रवर्तनात्॥

**(b ) **

न स वेद परं ब्रह्म यो न वेद चतुष्टयम्।
व्यक्ताव्यक्तञ्च यत्तत्वं सम्प्रोक्तं परमर्षिणा।
व्यक्तं मृत्युमुखं विद्यादव्यक्तममृतं पदम्।
निवृत्तिलक्षणं धर्ममृषिर्न्नारायणोऽब्रवीत्।
तत्रैवावस्थितं सर्वं त्रैलोक्यं सचराचरम्।
निवृत्तिलक्षणं धर्ममव्यक्तं ब्रह्म शाश्वतम्।
प्रवृत्तिलक्षणं धर्मं प्रजापतिरथाब्रवीत्।
प्रवृत्तिः पुनरावृत्तिर्निवृत्तिः परमागतिः।
तां गतिं परमामेतिनिवृत्तिपरमो मुनिः॥

प्रकृत्या सर्गधर्मिण्या तथा त्रिगुणसत्त्वया।

विपरीतमतो विद्यात् क्षेत्रज्ञस्य स्वलक्षणम्।
प्रकृतेश्च विकाराणां द्रष्टारमगुणान्वितम्।
क्षेत्रज्ञमाहुजीवन्तु कर्तारं गुणसंवृतम्॥

**(c) **

हिरण्यगर्भो भगवानेष बुद्धिरिति स्मृतः।
महानिति च योगेषु विरिञ्चिरिति चाप्यजः।
सांख्ये च पठ्यते शास्त्रे नामभिर्बहुधात्मकः।
विचित्ररूपो विश्वात्मा एकाक्षर इति स्मृतः॥

**(d) **

विद्याविद्ये त्विदानीं मे त्वं निबोधानुपूर्वशः।
अविद्यामाहुरव्यक्तं सर्गप्रलयधर्मिणीम्।
सर्गप्रलयनिर्मुक्तो विद्यो वै पञ्चविंशकः॥

परस्परन्तु विद्यां वै त्वं निबोधानुपूर्वशः।
यथोक्तमृषिभिस्तात सांख्यस्यास्य निदर्शनम्।
कर्मेन्द्रियाणां सर्वेषां विद्या बुद्धीन्द्रियं स्मृतम्।
बुद्धीन्द्रियाणां च तथा विशेषा इति नः श्रुतम्।
विशेषाणां मनस्तेषां विद्यामाहुर्मनीषिणः।
मनसः पञ्चभूतानि विद्या इत्यभिचक्षते।
अहङ्कारस्तु भूतानां पञ्चानां नात्र संशयः।
अहङ्कारस्य च तथा बुद्धिर्विद्या नरेश्वर !।
बुद्धेः प्रकृतिरव्यक्तं तत्त्वानां परमेश्वरम्।
विद्या ज्ञेया नरश्रेष्ठ ! विधिश्चपरमः स्मृतः।
अव्यक्तस्य परं प्राहुर्विद्यां वै पञ्चविंशकम्।
सर्वस्य सर्वमित्युक्तं ज्ञेयं ज्ञानस्य पार्थिव !।
ज्ञानमव्यक्तमित्युक्तंज्ञेयो वै पञ्चविंशकः।
तथैव ज्ञानमव्यक्तं विज्ञाता पञ्चविंशकः।
विद्याविद्यार्थितत्त्वेन मयोक्ता ते विशेषतः॥

महाभारतं शान्तिपर्व॥

Q. No. IX.

एवं विधैरहोरात्रैः कालगत्योपलक्षितैः।
अपक्षितमिवास्यापि परमायुर्वयः शतम्।

यदर्घमायुषस्तस्य परार्धमभिधीयते।
पूर्वः परार्धोऽपक्रान्तो ह्यपरोऽद्य प्रवर्तते।
पूर्वस्यादौ परार्धस्य ब्राह्मो नाम महान् अभूत्।
कल्पो यत्राभवद् ब्रह्मा शब्दब्रह्मेति यं विदुः।
तस्यैव चान्ते कल्पोऽभूद्यं पाद्ममभिचक्षते।
यद्धरेर्न्नाभिसरस आसील्लोकसरोरुहम्।
अयं तु कथितः कल्पो द्वितीयस्यापि भारत !।
वाराह इति विख्यातो यत्रासीत्सूकरो हरिः।
कालोऽयं द्विपरार्धाख्यो निमेष उपचर्यते।
अव्याकृतस्यानन्तस्य अनादेर्जगदात्मनः।
कालं कर्म स्वभावच्चमायेशो मायया स्वया।
आत्मन्यदृछया प्राप्तं विबुभूषुरुपाददे।
कालाद् गुणव्यतिकरः परिणामस्वभावतः।
कर्मणो जन्म महतः पुरुषाधिष्ठितादभूत्।
महतस्तुविकुर्वाणाद्रजसत्वोपबृंहितात्।
तमः प्रधानस्त्वभवद् द्रव्यज्ञानक्रियात्मकः।
सोऽहम्इति प्रोक्तो विकुर्वन् समभूस्त्रिधा।
वैकारिकस्तजसश्च तामसश्चेति यद्भिदा।
द्रव्यशक्तिः क्रियाशक्तिः ज्ञानशक्तिरिति प्रभो !।
यदैतेऽसङ्गता भावा भूतेन्द्रियमनोगुणाः।
यदायतननिर्माणे न शेकुर्ब्रह्मवित्तम !।
तदा संहत्यचान्योन्यं भगवछक्तिचोदिताः।
सदसत्त्वमुपादाय चोभयं ससृजुर्ह्यदः।
वर्षपूगसहस्रान्ते तदण्डमुदके शयम्।
कालकर्मस्वभावस्थो जीवो जीवमजीवयत्।
स एव पुरुषस्तस्मादण्डं निर्भिद्य निर्गतः।
सहस्रोर्वंघ्रि बाह्वक्षः सहस्राननशीर्षवान्।
यस्येहावयवैर्लोकान् कल्पयन्ति मनीषिणः।
कट्यादिभिरधः सप्त सप्तोर्ध्वं जघनादिभिः।
भूर्लोकः कल्पितः पद्भ्यांभुवर्लोकोऽस्य नाभितः।

हृदा स्वर्लोक उरसा महर्लोको महात्मनः।
ग्रीवायां जनलोकश्च तपोलोकस्तनद्वयात्।
मूर्द्धभिः सत्यलोकस्तु ब्रह्मलोकस्सनातनः।
तत्कट्यां चातलं क्ऌप्तं ऊरुभ्यां वितलं विभोः।
जानुभ्यां सुतलं शुद्धं जङ्घाभ्यान्तु तलातलम्।
महातलन्तु गुल्फाभ्यां प्रपदाभ्यां रसातलम्।
पातालं पादतलतः इति लोकमयः पुमान्।
भूर्लोकःकल्पितः पद्भ्यां भुवर्लोकोऽस्य नाभितः।
स्वर्लोकः कल्पितो मूर्ध्ना इति वा लोककल्पना॥

श्रीमद्भागवतम्॥

Q. No. X.

अकारो दक्षिणः पक्षः उकारस्तूत्तरस्मृतः।
मकारं पुच्छमित्याहुरर्द्धमात्रा तु मस्तकम्।
पादादिकं गुणास्तस्य शरीरं तत्त्वमुच्यते।
धर्मोऽस्य दक्षिणं चक्षुरधर्मोऽथोपरः स्मृतः।
भूर्लोकः पादयोस्तस्य भुवर्लोकस्तु जानुनी।
सुवर्लोकः कटीदेशे नाभिदेशे महर्तगत्।
जनोलोकस्तु हृद्देश कण्ठे लोकस्तपस्ततः।
भ्रुवोर्ललाटमध्ये तु सत्यलोको व्यवस्थितः।
सहस्रार्णमतीवात्र मन्त्र एष प्रदर्शितः।
एवमेतां समारूढो हंसयोगविचक्षणः।
न भिद्यते कर्मचारैः पापकोटिशतैरपि॥

नादबिन्दूपनिषत्॥

Q. No. XI.

द्वीपाः सप्त समाख्याताः समुद्रैः सप्तभिर्वृताः।
क्षारक्षीरेक्षुसुरया दध्ना चैव घृतेन च।
स्वादूदकेन च भृतौ द्विगुणैर्द्विगुणस्तथा।
भूर्लोकोऽथ भुवर्लोकः स्वर्महर्जन इत्यपि।
तपः सत्यश्च कथिताः पार्थ सप्तसुरालयाः॥

लोकालोकः परतरः पर्वतोग्रमहोच्छ्रयः।
द्वैतमर्थः स नियतो योऽसौ रविरुचामपि।
वैराजमथ वैकुण्ठं कैलासमिति नामतः।
मेरोश्शृङ्गत्रयं मूर्ध्नि ब्रह्मविष्णुशिवालयम्॥

भविष्यत्पुराणम्॥

Before translating the above passages, I may notice thatmany more explanatory quotations are available touching onthe points here started with, without in the least contradictingeach other. In fact, contradiction is an unknown factor inour religious literature, although that is the only thing thatis seen by our modern jaundiced eyes. To those who arereally interested, I only fear that the quotations are alreadytoo many.

Two stages of creation or evolution are here detailed,the Sukshma and Sthula (the subtle and the gross). TheLoka-padma or lotus of universe which is said to have sprungfrom the naval of the Almighty, is the subtle one which retains in a latent form, the sum total of all the effects of previous karmas of all creatures in toto. The spherical Bramhanda which is said to have originated from this lotus refersto the sum total of gross creation, virtually the cosmologicalconception of every living being. It will be easy to conceivethat geometrically, the sphere is the exact figure for this representation. If a boundary all round is marked, as far asthe eye or mind could reach in all directions according to thevarying capacities of the individual the resultant figurewould certainly be a sphere for all. The life-giving energyand the glory of the Eternal Bramhan which pervadethroughout this sphere is represented for the purpose of worship, in a human form known as Virat, whose several limbsare specialised sometimes as three and sometimes as fourteenseparate Lokas. More than this introductory remark, it is

×

not necessary here to dilate upon the subject, nor am I sufficiently qualified to explain correctly the different applications of this description of the evolution of the religious universe.

It may however be easily observed that the subtle evolution and its subsequent gross stage come down only up tothe five gross elements in their totality of existence and intheir infinite form. The modern attempt therefore to identify finite holy localities on the surface of the earth withany of the boundless matters specified above is nothing lessthan a positive mistake.

सप्तद्वीपा च मेदिनी। The earth consisting of seven islandsin regular circles, one within the other, with their separating oceans made up of milk, ghee etc., is probably anotherdescription of gross Bramhanda or sphere. The seven islandsrepresent the seven Prakritis (made up of five elements,Ahamkara or egoism and Budhi or intelligence) without losing their individualities by admixture and being separatedfrom one another by broad oceans intervening. These processes of evolution which originate from the force of Prakriti or maya which is in itself entirely dependent upon theEternal Bramhan, are taken advantage of, to meditate on theglories of the Bramhan indirectly. This is a highly developed form of Bhaktiyoga. The Yogis have their own technical use of them, the Chakras and Adharas in the human body representing the same factors as above described. Theyappear to furnish ample scope for physiological and psychological researches, which might prove profitable even to themodern scientist. At any rate, it is but sheer sin to misunderstand and misinterpret such serious matters, so freely,especially when the concluding inferences end in ignominyand shame to the sacred literature in question.

Q. No. I.

“The eternal lotus representing the Avyakta-Prithivior the unmanifested primary earth, has originated for theuse of Janardhana or Anantha who is the Maha Yogi destitute of mortal or fleshy body. By his yoga and glory hetakes all forms. At the end of a Kalpa or involution, this isexactly the Avyakta-Prithivi that remains. The four facedBramha originated from the lotus, which is therefore described as the original cause for all creation. The water inwhich this lotus sprung up is the body of Vishnu. The realnature of this lotus can be known only from the Sidhas.The central pericarp of this lotus is Meru, where there is aSabha or council-chamber called Manovati, in which Bramhaand Bramha-rishis live in their glorious state. There thegolden Jambu-tree suplies the sweetest juice of its fruits.The region to the south of this tree is therefore known asJambu-Dwipa. This lotus earth is one hundred leksha kotiin extent. All round its pericarp, the Meru. is called Sidhaloka. This is the recognised method of describing this lotusearth in all the Puranas.”

Those who know language, can understand that thePandit and the critic are not Sidhas, that their geographicalearth is not the Avyakta-Prithivi specified here, and that theVaraha-purana containing this sacred passage, is not therefore meant for their foot-ball match. The complete and inexcusable ignorance of the volunteer corps of modern interpreters of this sacred subject is here exposed in the brightestand broadest light possible. Further persistence on theirpart must prove only their arrogance, perversity and culpable antipathy. The council chamber of Bramha named Manovati in the centre of this lotus is sufficiently significant toevery unbiased reader.

×

Q. Nos. II & III.

“The eternal is Loka and the transient is Aloka. Brightand not bright combined is Lokaloka, which is preceded byAuloka and followed by Niraloka. Auloka is applied toLoka recognised as fit for contemplation. Niraloka is outside it, dark and boundless, unknown even to the Gods anddestitute of transactions. The seven-islanded earth and theseven Lokas, namely, Bhu, Bhuva, Swa, Maha, Jena, Tapaand Satya, are the Lokas inside the Bramhanda. Thereare innumerable Bramhandas, all surrounded by the sevenPrakritis in regular succession, each of the Prakritis beingten times greater than its preceding one.”

The Pandit and the critic cannot pitch upon a singleword here to justify their identification of Loka with geographical earth, on the contrary, all possibilities of such mistaken interpretations are particularly removed. The passages quoted are easily understandable, but it must be confessed that they do not supply understanding with them.

Q. No. IV.

“Fourteen stages are prescribed by the Rishis for theuse of man, in his devotional progress, and they are described as fourteen Lokas, seven of which are known as Kritaor accomplished, beginning with Bhu upwards representingthe pure and unmixed subtle elements, Ahamkara and Mahat. The remaining seven are lower and less important.The ascent to these Lokas is by Yoga, tapas and truth, andthe descent is by their opposites. Bramha’s Loka is knownas Satya-loka from which there is no more return.”

The fourteen Lokas are here clearly explained as alluding to fourteen Sthanas or positions assigned for man in hisreligious development. Where is now the Pandit’s India in

×

the Puranas, the Critic’s Asia Minor and the Theosophist’sTibetan desert? Are they not unnecessarily manufacturing geography to confound the poor religious Hindu andwhat do they virtually gain by this wanton mischief?

Q. No. V.

“The pure subtle clements first originated, which becamegross afterwards only by their admixture. They are distinguished by the number of properties, they possess. Beyond these subtle elements is Auloka. In this Akasa ofAuloka, the subtle elements remain unmixed. Without theseelements, there is no creation or destruction of creatures.As long as they exist there is birth. From Mahat downwards they are original causes and the elements produce effects. The above is the real description of the arrangementof the seven Dwipas with their intervening oceans, theirextents and sites, all approximately explained by the use ofsome small figures. The whole of this description alludes tothe Lord’s Prakriti consisting of the seven Bhutas and theirmutual relation in holding each other. I am able to explainthe subject only thus far, but that will suffice for your practical purpose.”

The enumeration of the seven Dwipas and the intervening oceans of milk, ghee, etc., is clearly mentioned here asalluding to the philosophical explanation of the working ofthe seven Prakritis. The approximate details of extent, siteetc., are also stated to have been given with a view to furnish an idea of the unperceivable facts. Where is the difficulty here to understand these plain statements and whereis the reasonable chance for misunderstanding them? Thereal fact is that such passages are never seen or never carefully noticed. The self-constituted interpreters are in suchgreat hurry to enlighten others, that they can ill afford towaste their valuable time for their own understanding.

×

Q. No. V1.

“From Patala up to Bramha-loka is called Bramhanda.Bhu-loka is above the earth and Bhuva above it.The remaining five are similarly above one another. Above allthese and outside Bramhanda is Vykuntha. Further aboveit is Go.loka of fifty koti yojanas in extent. Of these, Vykuntha and Go-loks are alone real and eternal, the remainingLokas being all artificial.”

There is hardly any scope for misinterpretation here.The Bhu-Loka is clearly stated as lying high above the earth.The geographical earth of the Pandit, critic and Theosophistis thus positively eliminated from the list of Lokas, and thereis therefore no room available for their valuable operations.They may now conveniently retire from the field altogetherand take to more profitable and less injurious work.

Q. No. V11.

“The eternal Avyakta is known to the Rishis as Manasa,to which the birth and death of all creatures are traced.From this Mahan originated known as Akasa. From thisAkasą, the remaining four subtle elements originated. Thedivine lotus was then created, from which Ahamkara knownas Bramha in the form of Vedas originated. All the elements mentioned here are like the Akasa in character, theirindividual differences are known only by the knowledge ofthe Tatwas. Being unperceivable and unreachable, theirmeasurement is impossible. The Agni or fire called Manasaalludes to the Jiva residing in all bodies. The above is theAdhyatmic or philosophical description of the creation workedby Prajapathi.”

What a clear and unambiguous description is here given? The creation reffered to is a philosophical one and notmaterial; and the elements specified are subtle and unperceivable. What has the modern geography of a minute

portion of the crust of the earth todo with this Adhyatmic description of religious philosophy?

Q. No. VIII.

(a) “He who wants to create the Lokas must observewith the Intellect lighted up by the mind. That whichtranscends Mahat and Tamas cannot be Tamas or darkness.It is named Manasa by the wise. It is the formless and thepurest of the pure. This is the characteristic of Yoga, bywhich the Atma within is discovered. The effect always merges in its cause. Birth or evolution is by descent andvariety, and involution or merging is by ascent and unity.”

(b) “Four facts should be known for obtaining theknowledge of Para-Bramhan, namely, Vyakta, Avyakta,Pravrithi and Nivrithi. Pravrithi as instructed by Prajapathi refers to action resulting in succession of births, and Nivrithi as taught by Narayana Rishi refers to the process ofsecuring salvation without rebirth. Jiva is known as thedoer and Kshetragna as the seer of the work of the Prakritis”

(c) “The Intellect is known by the name of Bramhain Sankhya philosophy and Mahan in Yoga philosophy. Heis of various forms constituting the universe and is expressedby a single letter.”

(d) “I shall tell you the distinction between Vidya andAvidya. Avyakta which evoles and involves is Avidya, andVidya is the twenty-fifth Tatwom which is destitute ofthese. Again, these two terms are also used in explainingthe mutual relation of the Tatwas in the Sankhya philosophy by the venerable Rishis. The twenty-fifth Tatwom isVidya as compared with Avyakta, which in itself is Vidyain its relation to the Intellect. The Intellect is Vidya toAhamkara and so on.”

The above passages furnish clear definitions of important technical terms invariably misunderstood.

  1. Manasa, is beyond Mahat or Intellect and Tamaor Avyakta. It represents the twenty-fifth Tatwom.

  2. The pure Intellect is known as Bramha in theSankhya philosophy and as Mahan in the Yoga philosophy.

  3. Pravrithi evolves and Nivrithi involves.

  4. That which evolves is Avidya and that which involves is Vidya. The highest Vidya is the twenty-fifth Tatwom.

The Vidya of the modern interpreters is doubtless theireffort to produce confusion and annoyance.

Q. No. 1X.

“Thus the Bramha’s day and night are ascertained.According to this calculation, as if he were also mortal, hisage is fixed as extending to only a hundred years. The firsthalf of it is said to be over in which he is known as Sabda-Brahman and the period is called Padma-kalpa. The secondhalf referring to the present time is Varaha-kalpa in whichHari assumed the Varaha or boar form. The two periodsspecified, constitute but a twinkling of the Lord’s eyes,figuratively described here. Kala, Karma and Swabhavacombined evolve the Jagat. Kala or time produces the different Gunas. Swabhava or nature produces changes, andKarma gives rise to Mahan. From Mahan, Ahamkaraoriginates, consisting of Vaikarika, Tyjasa and Tamasa, representing Gnana, Kriya and Dravya Saktis. When thesubtle elements, senses and mind remained separate, theywere unable to create. By the force of the Lord they joinedmutually and produced the Anda or egg. After thousandsof years, the Purusha came out breaking this egg from with-in. His limbs are described by the wise as representing thefourteen Lokas. The Bhu as representing his feet, Bhuvahis naval and Swa, his head, is another enumeration of theLokas”.

The above passage clearly confirms the views alreadyexpressed in the preceding quotations. The descriptions inevery Purana only explain the subject in the same strain andnever contradict each other as are ignorantly and unnecessarily criticized.

Q. No. X.

“A Hamsa-Yogi who is an expert in the PranavaManthra is never affected by the effects of his Karmas. Theletter A, represents the right side of the Manthra, U, theleft side, M, the tail and the half Mathra, its head. Dharmaand Adharma are its two eyes. Its limbs are its propertiesrepresented by the 14 Lokas and the whole body constitutesTatwom.”

The Lokas are here explained as representing theproperties of Om or the Pranava-Manthra. Whatever thismay mean to an ordinary lay man, it is certain that theLokas here specified do not in the least refer to the Pandit’s,critic’s or Theosophist’s nativity.

Q. No. X1.

“The seven Dwipas surrounded by the seven oceans ofmilk, ghee &c. as well as the seven Lokas, namely Bhu,Bhuva &c, represent the seven abodes of the gods. Beyondthese, is the mountain called Lokaloka with its three peaksnamed Vyraja, Vykuntha and Kylasa, the abodes of Bramha,Vishnu and Siva. The description of this mountain in aconcrete form must be understood as having a doublemeaning.

The seven-islanded earth and the Lokas are here clearlystated as alluding to the regions of the gods, and the description of the mountain beyond containing the abodes of Brahma, Vishnu and Siva is required to be understood in a different light. The modern interpreters are no doubt determined

not to understand anything religious and philosophical inthe proper light, but it is a wonder how they could layclaims to the divine regions here enumerated, without proving themselves to be gods. As they believe they are thehighest authorities for the interpretation of our religioustexts, they probably believe they are gods too. It is indeeda pity that these self-made authorities are virtually morenegative than positive in their methods of operation. Theyare unable to offer us any reasonable explanations on difficult points referred to them. They invariably answer usonly by abuses and display of anger. It might be that personally they feel no difficulty with regard to the subject as awhole, and that therefore they readily dispose of ourquestions.

पठ्यतां पठ्यतामेषस्टमग्रेभविष्यति।
इति पाठयतां पुसां काठिन्यं कुत्रवर्तते॥

2. The well-known 14 Lokas have now been to someextent examined. The centre of the Lotus of Universe andthat of the seven-islanded earth is described as Meru.Whether this refers to the mount Meru or the Himalayas orto some other mountain further north in the Tibetan valleysor even near the north Pole, as generally interpreted, deserves to be noticed.

भ्यामवस्थितः सर्वतः सौवर्णःकुलगिरिराजो
मेरुः द्वीपायामसमुन्नाहः कर्णिकाभूतः कुवलयक

मूले षोडश सहस्रं तावताऽन्तर्भूम्यां प्रविष्टः॥

श्रीमद्भागवतम्॥

मानसस्येह या मूर्तिः ब्रह्मत्वं समुपागता।
तस्यासन विधानार्थं पृथिवी पद्ममुच्यते।

व्योमशब्दं चतुश्शृङ्गंसर्वदेव मयञ्च यत्।

Q. No. V1.

गुदस्य पृष्ठभागेऽस्मिन् वीणादण्डस्सदेहभृत्।

मेरुमध्ये स्थिताया तु मूलादाब्रह्म रन्ध्रगा॥
मेरोर्वामे इडा दक्षे पिङ्गला च स्थिते उभे॥

प्रबोधयन् शनैर्भानुं मेरुशृङ्गं नयेसुधीः॥

षट्चक्रनिरूपणम्

Q. No. I.

“The middle of Jambu-Dwipa is Elavrita Khanda, inthe centre of which is Meru 33,000 Yojanas in extent at itstop and 16,000 Yojanas in depth inside the earth”.

Here the Pandit alone is likely to fight for the correctness of the measurements. 16,000 Yojanas here given as thedepth of Meru inside the earth is equal to 12,8000 miles, buthis poor tiny earth has only one sixteenth of this figure forits diameter, which fact he has probably yet to learn. TheMeru is therefo re certainly not a mountain on this earth orthis earth is not the one on which Meru stands. In spite ofthese unavoidable difficulties, the Pandit can well afford to

place the Puranic Meru on his geographical earth.He isable to perform more wonderful feats, if only he could securecompetent audience for appreciation.

Q. No. II.

“To place, the Manasa that became Bramhan, on a seat,the lotus earth is prescribed. Its pericarp extending to theskies is Meru, seated on which Bramha creates the Lokas. "

The creation of the Lokas theinselves, is here said to beconducted by Bramha, seated on this Meru, The Merusurely is not therefore his creation, nor is it in the Lokas.And yet it is a mountain with which the modern interpreters are very familiar.

Q. No. III.

“The starry regions are one hundred thousand yojanashigher than the Moon, and Meru is two hundred thousandyojanas higher still,”

Perhaps according to the formula for modern interpretation, the regions above the stars mean Tibet or CentralAsia. The interpretation simply displays impertinence orinsanity.

Q. No. IV.

“The latent subtle condition in which the elements & c.remain after a kalpa or involution is known as the Lord’sMaya. This very thing is called Meru and Deva-Loka.”

It is surely disgraceful to comment further upon themodern interpretations of such passages which clearly definethe technical meanings of terms used in our religiousliterature.

Q. No. V.

“From Vyoma or Akasa, the Vyoma-mahi or Akasicearth originated in which thirty-three Yegna-devas keep

playing. This Akasic-earth is known as Meru and Dharma,Vedas and Devas. It has four peaks consisting of the fourVedas.”

This is a fuller and plainer explanation of the wholematter. It serves also undoubtedly as the final death-blowto all impudent trespassers. The readers are earnestly requested to note and remember this quotation particularly.

Q. Nos. VI, VII & VIII.

“The spinal column made up of twenty-one small bonesis called Meru. It has a hollow passage through its centreextending to the brain called Brahma-nadi and Sushumna.On its either side are Ida and Pingala”. This is the Yogicapplication of the terms referring to the location of the sameTatwoms in the human body and does no: practically differfrom the explanations already given. The modern enlightened interpreters need not on any account search for aloop-hole here.”

We understand from the above quotations that Meru isthe centre of the seven-islanded earth, seated on whichBramha or creator of the Universe produces the Lokas andthat Meru refers to the Vedas and Dharmas in general. Itsfour peaks are the four Vedas. It is clear therefore that theseven-islanded earth represents none of the created articleswe can pitch upon. Bramha is thus the purified Intelligenceseated in the midst of the Vedas, creating or exhibiting theLokas or the glories of God that should be seen and experienced before attaining salvation. The evolution andcreation detailed represent the progressive stages throughwhich a knowledge of Saguna-Bramhan or Bramhan combined with pure Maya may be obtained.

3. The seven-islanded earth, with Jambu island inthe centre and Bharata-Uarsha at the southern extremity of

Jambu in which we are at present supposed to live, maynext be enquired into. Let us first see whether any clue asto its real significance is procurable.

Q. No. I.

इमां सप्तपदां ज्ञानभूमि माकर्णयानघ।
नानया ज्ञातया भूयो मोहपङ्के निमज्जति।
वदन्ति बहुभेदेन वादिनो योगभूमिकाः।
अवबोधं विदुर्ज्ञानं तदिदं सप्तभूमिकम्।
मुक्तिस्तु ज्ञेयमित्युक्ता भूमिका सप्तकात्परम्।
ज्ञानभूमिश्शुभेछाख्या प्रथमा समुदाहृता।
विचारणा द्वितीया तु तृतीया तनुमानसी।
सत्वापत्तिश्चतुर्थीस्यात्ततोऽसंसक्ति नामिका।
पदार्थभावना षष्टी सप्तमी तुर्यगा स्मृता।
आसमन्तस्थिता मुक्तिः यस्यां भूयो न शोचति॥

महोपनिषत्।

Q. No. II.

स्थितः किं मूढ एवास्मि प्रेक्ष्योहं शास्त्र सज्जनैः।
वैराग्य पूर्व मिछेति शुभेछेत्युच्यते बुधः।
शास्त्रसज्जन सम्पर्क वैराग्याभ्यास पूर्वकम्।
सदाचार प्रवृत्तिर्या प्रोच्यते सा विचारणा।
विचारणा शुभेछाभ्यां इन्द्रियार्थेषु रक्तता।
यत्र सा तनुतामेति प्रोच्यते तनुमानसी।
भूमिका त्रितयाभ्यासाच्चित्तेऽर्थविरतेर्वशात्।
सत्वात्मनि स्थिते शुद्धे सत्वापत्तिरुदाहृता।
दशा चतुष्टयाभ्यासा दसंसर्ग फला तु या।
रूढसत्व चमत्कारा प्रोक्ताऽसंसक्ति नामिका।
भूमिका पञ्चकाभ्यासात् स्वाद्मारामतया भृशम्।
आभ्यन्तराणां बाह्यानां पदार्थानामभावनात्।
परप्रयुक्तेन चिरं प्रत्ययेनावबोधनम्।

पदार्थभावना नाम षष्ठी भवति भूमिका।
षट्भूमिका चिराभ्यासात् भेदस्यानुपलम्भनात्।
यत्स्वभावैक निष्ठत्वं सा ज्ञेया तुर्यगा गतिः।
शुभेछादि त्रयं भूमि भेदाभेदयुतं स्मृतम्।
यथावद्वेद बुध्येदं जगज्जाग्रति दृश्यते।
अद्वैते स्थैर्यमायाते द्वैते च प्रशमं गते।
पश्यन्ति स्वप्नवल्लोकं तुर्यभूमि सुयोगतः।
विछिन्न शरदभ्रांश विलयं प्रविलीयते।
सत्वावशेष एवास्ते हे निदाघ दृढीकुरु।
पञ्चभूमिं समारुह्य सुषुप्ति पदनामिकाम्।
शान्ताशेषविशेषांशस्तिष्ठत्यद्वैतमात्रके।
अन्तर्मुखतया नित्यं बहिर्वृत्तिपरोऽपि सन्।
परिश्रान्ततया नित्यं निद्रालुरिव लक्ष्यते।
कुर्वन्नभ्यासमेतस्यां भूम्यां सम्यक् विवासनः।
सप्तमी गाढसुप्त्याख्या क्रमप्राप्ता पुरातनी।
यत्र नासन्नसद्रूपो नाहं नाप्यनहंकृतिः।
केवलं क्षीणमनन आस्तेऽद्वैते तिनिर्भयः।
अन्तश्शून्यो बहिश्शून्यश्शून्यकुम्भ इवाम्बरे।
अन्तः पूर्णो बहिः पूर्णः पूर्णकुम्भ इवार्णवे॥

भूमित्रयेषु विहरन् मुमुक्षुर्भवति।
तुरीयभूम्यां विहरन् ब्रह्मविद्भवति।
पञ्चमभूम्यां विहरन् ब्रह्मविद्वरो भवति।
षष्ठभूम्यां विहरन् ब्रह्मविद्वरीयान् भवति।
सप्तमभूम्यां विहरन् ब्रह्मविद्वरिष्ठो भवति॥

वराहोपनिषत्॥

Q. No. III.

मनसा कर्मणा वाचा सज्जनानुप सेवते।
यतः कुतश्चिदानीय नित्यं शास्त्राण्यपेक्षते।
तदासौ प्रथमामेकां प्राप्तो भवति भूमिकाम्।

एवं विचारवान् यस्यात् संसारोत्तारणं प्रति।
स भूमिकावानित्युक्तःशेषस्त्वार्य इति स्मृतः॥

अक्ष्युपनिषत्॥

Quotations No. I, II & III.

“Seven Bhumikas are enumerated which are known asGnana-bhumikas or Yoga-bhumikas. Real perception orknowledge is Gnana and it has seven Bhumikas. The firstis called Subhecha, or the earnest desire to get over themiseries of Samsara. The second is Vicharana, or investigation and reflection accompanied by good conduct and annihilation of desires. The third is called Thanu-manasi, wherethe desires for the objects of senses are reduced. The fourthis Satwapathi, or Satwic turn of mind consequent on thepractice in the previous Bhumikas. The fifth is Asamsakti,or natural dislike for desires combined with attachment toSatwic matters. The sixth is Padartha-bhavana; or the conception of the real truth, which is secured by the eliminationof all obstructive items, both external and internal. Theseventh is Turyaga, or the state of remaining in the reacondition of Bramhan, consequent on the absense of all ideasof difference. In the first three Bhumikas, there is in thewaking state, a combined feeling of difference and no difference. In the fourth, the world appears like a dream. Inthe fifth and sixth the Yogi appears like a sleepy man. Inthe seventh, he is entirely absorbed and appears as if completely asleep. In the first three he is known as Mumukshu.In the fourth, he is styled Bramhavit. In the fifth he isBramhavid-vara, in the sixth Bramhavid-variyan and in theseventh Bramhavid-varishta. Enquiry after the Sastrasfrom all quarters available with the object of getting overthe miseries of Samsara, and due respect towards the wise,are the qualifications to secure the first Bhumika. He woh

×

has secured this is called a Bhumikavan. Others who havenot advanced to this stage are called Aryas”.

The term Bhumika here used is sufficiently significant,and the divisions of the Bhumikas explained are exactly thesame in number as in the seven islanded earth. One whodoes not own even the first Bhumika is styled an Arya, orhomeless wanderer. The word Arya as commonly usedtechnically applies to a religious man conducting himselfrespectably in accordance with the Sastras. But even he isnot entitled to a single Bhumika until he qualifies himself asspecified. The religious earths or Bhumikas enumerated inthe texts are not therefore meant for the Aryas, much lessfor the common people. They represent the regions of godsas already noticed, and it is useless, on the part of the moderntype of religious authorities, to covet them with their existing qualifications.

4. The number of passages already quoted, will itis hoped, convince every reasonable and unbiased enquirer,of the general trend of the classifications and descriptionsgiven, in the manner dealt with in the literature. The 14Lokas, the seven-islanded earth and the Meru are entirelydifferent from the idas and opinions now prevailing aboutthem and it makes no difference whether they are meant toestablish their importance in favour of the Hindu Religionor specially meant to annul the same. Although perhaps itis not fully understood as to what the contents of thesepassages exactly apply, it is certain that they do not in theleast corroborate the current interpretations.

Jambu being the central island within the seven-islanded earth, its geographical descriptions may now be examinedin detail.

Quotation. No. I.

अथ योगवतां श्रेष्ठमसृजद्भूरिवर्चसम्।
स्रष्टारं सर्वलोकानां ब्रह्माणं सर्वतो मुखम्।
तस्मिन् हिरण्मये बहुयोजन विस्तृते।
सर्वतेजो गुणमये पार्थिवैर्लक्षणैर्वृते।
तच्च पद्मं पुराणज्ञा पृथिवी रूपमुत्तमम्।
नारायणसमुद्भूतं प्रवदन्ति महर्षयः।
या पद्मसारता देवपृथिवी परिचक्ष्यते।
ये पद्मसारगुरवः तान् दिव्यान् पर्वतान् विदुः।
हिमवन्तञ्च मेरुञ्च वीलं निषधमेव च।
कैलासं शृङ्गवन्तञ्चतथाद्रिं गन्धमादनम्।
पुण्यं त्रिशिखरञ्चैव कान्तं मन्दरमेव च।
उदरं पिञ्जरञ्चैव विन्ध्यमस्तञ्च पर्वतम्।
एते देवगणानाञ्च सिद्धानाञ्च महाद्मनाम्।
आश्रयाः पुण्यशीलानां सर्वकाम फलप्रदाः।
एतेषामन्तरे देशो जम्बूद्वीप इति स्मृतः।
जम्बूद्वीपस्य संस्थानं यज्ञिया यत्र वै क्रियाः।
तेभ्यो यद्द्रवते तोयं दिव्यामृत रसोपमम्।
दिव्यतीर्थ शतायामाःसरस्यः सरितः स्मृताः।
यान्येतानीह पद्मस्य केशराणि समन्ततः।
असंख्येयाः पृथिव्यन्ते विविधाश्चैव पर्वताः।
यानि पत्मस्य पर्णानि भूरिपूर्वाणि पार्थिव।
ते दुर्गमाः शैलचिता म्लेछदेशाः प्रकीर्तिताः।
यान्यधोभाग पर्णानि ते निवासास्तु भागशः।
दैत्यानामसुराणाञ्चपन्नगानाञ्च पार्थिव।
तेषां मध्येऽन्तरं यत्तु तत्रासह्येति संज्ञितम्।
महापातक कर्माणो मज्जन्ते यत्र मानवाः।
पत्मस्य चान्तरे पत्म एकार्णवगता मही।
प्रोक्तास्ते दिक्षुसङ्घाताश्चत्वारः सलिलाकराः।

एवं नारायणस्यार्थे मही पुष्करसम्भवा।
प्रादुर्भावो प्ययं तस्मान्नाम्नापुष्कर संज्ञितः।
एतस्मात् कारणाद्यज्ञे पुराणैः परमर्षिभिः।
यज्ञियैर्वेददृष्टान्तैर्यज्ञेषु विचितिः कृता।
एवं भगवता तेन विज्ञेयाथ धरा चिता।
पर्वतानां नदीनाञ्च रचना चैव निर्मिता॥

पद्मपुराणम्॥

Q. No. II.

यथाहि पुरुषः पश्येदादर्शे मुखमाद्मनः।
एवं सुदर्शनो द्वीपो दृश्यते चकमण्डलः।
सुदर्शनो नाम महान् जम्बूवृक्षस्सनातनः।
तस्य नाम्ना समाख्यातो जम्बूद्वीपस्सनातनः॥

पद्मपुराणम्।

Q. No. III.

सृष्टिस्तु द्विविधा ज्ञेया देवासुर विभेदतः।
हरिभक्तियुता दैवी तद्धीना ह्यासुरी स्मृता।
जम्बूप्लक्षाभिधानौ च शाल्मलश्चकुशस्तथा।
क्रौञ्चःशाकः पुष्करश्च ते सर्वे देवभूमयः॥

बृहन्नारदपुराणम्॥

Q. No. IV.

कर्मभूमिश्च गौर्ज्ञेया श्रुतिरूपा जगन्मयी।
यस्तां पाति च भो ब्रह्मन् सगोप इति विश्रुतः।
इयं भूमिर्महाभागा सर्वदा च सनातनी।
मेरुर्वै च न मेरुश्च द्वीपाश्चासंस्तथा न हि।
इलावर्तादि खण्डाश्च सन्ति नैव क्वचित् क्वचित्॥

भविष्यपुराणम्॥

Q. No. I.

The Rishis as well as those who know the Puranas saythat the golden lotus-earth of very huge size originated

from Narayana. Bramha, the greatest of Yogis and thecreator of the Lokas, originated from this lotus. Theessence of this lotus is called Deva-prithivi or the divineearth. Its hardest essence is known as constituting divinemountains, namely, Himavat, Meru, Nila, Nishadha, Kylas,Sringavan, Gandhamadans, Trisikhara, Kantha, Mandara,Udara, Pinjara, Vindhya and Astha. These holy mountainsare the regions of the Devas and Sidhas, in the midst ofwhich lies the Jambu-Dwipa. The situation of this Jambu-Dwipa is recognised as being where the acts of man aredevotional in character. The sweet waters oozing out ofthese devotional Karmas are known as the holy rivers. Thefilaments of this lotus are the various mountains. Thepetals at the top represent the regions of Mlechas, those atthe bottom allude to the abodes of Dythias, Asuras andPannagas. The space between the petals is the abode of thesinners, called Asahya. There is another lotus inside thislotus surrounded on all the four sides by the sea. Thus thelotus-earth has originated from the bigger lotus for the sakeof Narayana and therefore known as Pushkara or lotus. Forthese reasons, the Rishis made their enquiries for the earth,mountains and rivers here specified, by taking to devotionaland Vedic processes.”

The above is a pretty exhaustive and clear explanationof the religious earth and its general details, which could bediscovered only by vedic and devotional processes. Thesituation of Jambu. Dwipa is specially noted as where theacts of man are devotional in character.

जम्बूद्वीपस्य संस्थानं यज्ञिया यत्र वै क्रियाः।

What better explanation is possible to be furnished, forthe prevention of misinterpretation, and what better proofis required to show that nothing short of sheer misinterpretation is obtained at present ?

Q. No. II.

“A Jambu tree called Sudersana stands in the middle ofSudersana-Dwips and hence this Dwipa is known also bythe name of the eternal Jambu-Dwipa. The Sudersans.Dwipa appears circular like a wheel, like the reflection ofour face in a mirror.”

We have by this time, more or less understood the gistof the general descriptions of the religious regions.

अवबोधं विदुर्ज्ञानं तदिदं सप्तभूमिकम्।

The seven stages or Buunis clearly allu le to thedegrees of real knowledge to be attained step by step bydevotional processes. It is absurd even to imagine that thevenerable Rishis produced so much of voluminous literaturefor the purpose of describing our poor earthy sphere and thetransactions of its silly and insignificant residents. Fromthe sacred plains of their clear intellect, the worldly peoplecannot but appear as stupid, sleepy or intoxicated beingsteeped in Agnana.

अद्वितीय ब्रह्मतत्वं न जानन्ति यदा तदा।
भ्रान्ता एवाखिलास्तेषां क्व मुक्तिः क्वेह वा सुखम्॥

The literary productions of our Rishis therefore do nottreat of the regions of the ignorant. A description of theGnana-Bhumis is the only natural and useful instruction tobe expected or obtained from them. If we do not lose sightof this important fact, we can easily understand the meanings of their narrations in the Puranic form. The vexedJambu Dwipa is also said to be known as Sudersana-Dwipa,and the word Sudersana plainly means ‘worthy sight’. Thevenerable Rishis will not stoop to describe ‘unworthy sights’,under which the whole of the cosmology of the worldlyise man inevitably falls. The Dwipa under reference is.

the devotional sphere which is mentioned as capable of beingseen only like a reflection in the mirror. The perception ofthe geographical divisions of our mother earth, has certainlyno such restrictions or limitations, and it does not stand inneed of the Pandit’s or Critic’s help.

Q. No. III.

“Creation itself is of two kinds, the Dyva and theAsura, the former being that which is accompanied by devotion to Hari, and the latter without it. The seven Dwipasnamely, Jambu, Plaksha, Salmala, Kusa, Krouncha, Sakaand Pushkara are Devabhumis or devine earths, belongingto the Dyva creation.”

The distinction here pointed out settles the whole question. The word Asura is here used, in its ordinary technicalsense. Asu is life and ra is addicted to, referring thereby tothis material world with all its paraphernalia of humanvanities and miseries. It is therefore evident that the religious texts have left it out of consideration altogether. Theworldly-wise Pandit, the modern enlightened historian andarchæologist as well as the mistaken Theosophist, may nowvery well retire from this field, without discredit to theirprofessions and without any loss to the general public.

Q. No. IV.

“The Karma-bhumi refers to the cow known as theVedas. He who rules over it is called a Gopa. This specified Bhumi, no doubt is ever eternal. The Meru, the Dwipasand the Khandas such as Elavrita &c. have in reality noseparate existence”.

The Go or cow, the Karma-bhumi or region of actionand the Vedas are thus synonymous terms used in our religious literature with their specific applications. Withoutunderstanding these simple technicalities of the subject, what

×

a funny state of affairs now prevails in the identification ofthe Vedas practically with the geographical earth! ThePandit further believes that this earthy globe is also literallya beautiful cow of the Nellore or Bombay breed. Withthese egregious mistakes for the foundation caused by unalloyed ignorance, ingenious interpretations of the sacredtexts are now-a-days offered from all quarters of the globefor the religious benefit of the indifferent and lazy Hindu,who there by feels exceptionally lucky, as he seldom thinksof finding out anything for himself in this matter. The fallof the modern Hindu having been from a great height, consciously or otherwise, it must certainly have injured himvery seriously. The deterioration is however a real fact,whatever might be the causes attributed. There are differentvarieties of this fallen class among us, some of which maybe styled the orthodox and others the heterodox or moreplainly heretical. The former varieties ordinarily fall underthe uneducated classes and are invariably found to be farinferior even to our veritable pandits. The latter varietiesmake up the majority and include a great portion of themodern educated gentlemen, as well as the indifferent, lowand wicked among the uneducated. The chief object of thisessay is only to appeal to the educated, and the remainingclasses may be conveniently omitted for the present. It isindeed a pity that the majority of this educated class couldbe practically identified with the foreign critic, minus ofcourse, his laudable spirit of enquiry. False, apish andmeaningless imitation is doubtless the ruling fashion of theday with its disgraceful and dangerous consequence of de-nationalisation. Civilization, education or progress, as understood in modern or ancient times, never demands this pernicious tendency. Its dangers are immensely augmented bythe special fact that everything prescribed for a Hindu is

based upon well established fundamental principles of religion, which he has now long forgotten. The possibility ofrediscovering these valuable principles, now or hereafter, fromthese externalforms, is virtually being destroyed by thecurrent mania for foreign imitation. It is humbly hopedthat this will not be misunderstood as preaching superstitionor obstructing progress. Unsuited, unnecessary and extremely inartistic imitations, positive vices, obstinate andignorant indifference to one’s own religion, hardly add toprogress of any known description. The attempt of theeducated gentleman, to conceal his wanton mistake or toexcuse himself on the ground of enlightenment, is as futileas that of the orthodox and the Pandit, and his educationonly holds him all the more responsible. As long as humanreason ordinarily continues to command its due respect, nofalse conduct on the plea of civilization could pass off for atrue coin in any part of the civilized world.

विद्यया विनयावाप्तिः सा चेदविनयावहा।
किं कुर्मः कं प्रतिब्रूमो गरदायां स्वमातरि॥

5. It is confidently hoped that the passages quotedall along with regard to the 14 Lokas, the seven islandedearth, the Meru and the Jambu, will be understood as explaining religious matters clearly and unambiguously in thestrongest and plainest terms the Sanskrit language is capableof expressing. The current ideas about them as representingmaterial or physical entities like geographical continentsand mountains are entirely irrelevant. Although it is noteasy to understand them fully, with our very limited knowledge of the subject at present, yet the general classificationsand descriptions are sufficiently comprehensible. The termspoint to some divine matters to be experienced in the progressive advancement of yogic and devotional practicesw

There will no doubt be a good deal of Psychological andphysiological principles underlying them, and the whole of itis some serious science and sacred religion, which could notbe played with in the present fashion. It will be more safeand honourable to leave it alone, if no interest is forthcomingor no knowledge is procurable. It makes no differenee withwhat motive it is misinterpreted. In any case, the process isa mistake and the consequent result is unwholesome in everyway. The terms under reference belong to the Sanskritlanguage, and it would be sheer weakness of the brain toexpect to find their meanings in the dictionaries of alienlanguages. Equally so, is to hope for their explanationsfromforeign creeds like Theosophy preached in the land,especially when they fetch no appreciation in their owncountries. The simple mistake lying at the root of all thisconfusion is in having unnecessarily picked up some religiousterms from the sacred texts, without looking backwards andforwards, a single inch beyond. Opinions are easily andimmediately formed, commentaries and criticisms followedin quick succession, and all possible perversities are inventedto establish the mistaken ideas promulgated. In the longrun, as irɔny of fate would have it, the mistaken explanations given by these self-constituted interpreters, graduallyled to the present indifference and contempt for the subjecton the whole, being virtually reckoned as old-world superstitions and worthless compilations.

The central island Jambu-Dwipa is described as dividedinto 9 Varshas or continents, the Bharata-Varsha being thesouthernmost one which is now understood as representingIndia. It is this vexed Bharata-Varsha that is at the bottomof all the existing geographical confusion. Detail descriptions of these Varshas are found in most of the Puranas, butnothing more than bare outlines and faint suggestions can

be attempted here. Those who desire to take deeper interestin the matter may apply directly to the texts themselves.But it may be noted here that Bharata-Varsha is to someextent distinctly different in character from the remaining8 Varshas said to be contained in the Jambu-Dwipa. Thefollowing quotations will, it is hoped furnish the requiredexplanations and clues for the correct understanding of thesubject.

Quotation. No. I.

एषां मध्ये इलावृतं नामाभ्यन्तरवर्षं यस्य नाभ्यामवस्थितः सर्वतःसौवर्णः कुलगिरिराजो मेरुः द्वीपायामसमुन्नाहःकर्णिकाभूतः कुवलयकमलस्य मूर्द्धनि द्वात्रिंशत् सहस्रयोजन विततो मूले षोडशसहस्रं तावताऽन्तर्भूम्यान् प्रविष्टः॥ उत्तरोत्तरेणेलावृतं नीलः श्वेतः शृङ्गवानिति त्रयो रम्यक हिरण्मय कुरुणां वर्षाणां मर्यादागिरयः प्रागायता उभयतः क्षारोदावधयो द्विसहस्रपृथव एकैकशःपूर्वस्मात् पूर्वस्मादुत्तर उत्तरो दशांशाधिकांशेन दैर्घ्यएव ह्रसन्ति॥एवं दक्षिणेनेलावृतं निषधो हेमकूटो हिमालय इति प्रागायतायथा नीलादयोऽयुत योजनोत्सेधा हरिवर्ष किम्पुरुष भारतानां यथा संख्यम्॥तथैवेलावृतमपरेण पूर्वेण च माल्यवत् गन्धमादना वा नीलनिषधायतौ द्विसहस्रं पप्रथतुःकेतुमाल भद्राश्वयोः सीमानं विदधाते॥ मन्दरो मेरुमन्दरः सुपार्श्वःकुमुदः इत्ययुतयोजन विस्तारोन्नाहा मेरोश्चतुर्द्दिशमवष्टंभगिरय उपक्ऌप्ताः॥चतुर्ष्वेतेषु चूत जम्बूकदम्बन्यग्रोधाश्चत्वारः पादपप्रवराः पर्वतकेतव इवाधिसहस्र योजनोन्नाहा स्तावद्विटप विततयः शतयोजन परिणाहाः॥ ह्रदाश्चत्वारःपयोमध्विक्षुरसमृष्टजलायदुपस्पर्शिन उपदेवगणायोगैश्वर्याणि स्वाभाविकानि भरतर्षभधारयन्ति ॥देवोद्यानानि च भवन्ति चत्वारि नन्दनं चैत्ररथं वैभ्राजकं सर्वतोभद्रमिति॥

तत्रापि भारतमेव वर्षं कर्मक्षेत्रमन्यान्यष्ट वर्षाणि स्वर्गिणां पुण्यशेषोपभोगस्थानानि भौमानि स्वर्गपदानि व्यपदिशन्ति॥ एषु पुरुषाणामयुतपुरुषायुवर्षाणां देवकल्पानां नागायुतप्राणानां वज्रसंहनन बलवयोमोदप्रमुदित महासौरत मिथुनव्यवायापवर्गवर्षधृतैगर्भ कलत्राणां तत्र तु त्रेतायुगसमः कालोवर्तते॥

नवस्वपि वर्षेषु भगवान्नारायणो महापुरुषःपुरुषाणां तदनुग्रहायात्मतत्वव्यूहेनाद्मनाऽद्यापि सन्निधीयते॥

Q. No. II.

भारतेषु स्त्रियः पुंसो नानावर्णाः प्रकीर्तिताः।
नानादेवार्चने युक्ता नानाकर्माणि कुर्वते।
परमायुःस्मृतं तेषां शतं वर्षाणि सुव्रताः।
नवयोजनसाहस्रं वर्षमेतत्प्रकीर्तितम्।
कर्मभूमिरियं विप्रा नराणामधिकारिणाम्।
चत्वारि भारते वर्षे युगानिकवयोऽब्रुवन्।
कृतं त्रेता द्वापरञ्च कलिश्चान्यत्र न क्वचित्।
यानि किम्पुरुषाद्यानि वर्षाण्यष्टौ महर्षयः।
न तेषु शोको नायासो नोद्वेगः क्षुद्भयं न च।
रमन्ते विविधैर्भावैः सर्वाश्च स्थिरयौवनाः॥

कूर्मपुराणम्॥

Q. No. III.

क्षारोदधेरुत्तरं यद्धिमाद्रेश्चैव दक्षिणम्।

भारते तु कृतं कर्म शुभंवाऽशुभमेव वा।
आफलक्षयणं कर्म भुज्यतेऽन्यत्र जन्तुभिः।
अद्यापि देवा इछन्ति जन्म भारतभूतले॥

बृहन्नारदपुराणम्।

Q. No. IV.

तस्य भरतस्य पिता ऋषभः हेमाद्रेर्द्दक्षिणं वर्षं महद्भारतं नाम शशास॥

वराहपुराणम्।

भरताद्भारतं वर्षं भरतात्सुमतिस्त्वभूत्॥

अग्निपुराणम्।

Q. No. VI.

वैद्युतो लौकिकाग्निस्तु प्रथमो ब्रह्मणः सुतः।
