“Many divine rivers with plenty of waters have sprungfrom the divine lakes. TheAkasa or sky which is thesupport for the elements and the Gods, isitself theocean herecalled Soma. The divine holy river known as Akasa ganga,starts from thisAkasa and runs through the same. Itpasses through the regions of air and stars, playing about inall directions. Its holy waters are used by the Siddhas.Like the sun it appears and reappears every day’.

It is a fine description of Ganga. The Akasa calledalso Soma is the subtle element known as Akasa in ourreligious philosophy. The waters of this river are said tobe available only for the Sidhas. The Pandit therefore in his present attitude towards our religious texts cannot hopeto obtain a drop of its holy waters.

Q. No. XIV.

“The holy waters of the Ganga are the liquid forms ofVishnu and of Siva. Ganga is the Prakriti and the supportof Bramhandas. She represents Sudha-vidya, Sudha dharmaand the form of Para-bramhan. Siva keeps her on his headfor the sake of protecting the universe. Siva extracted theessence of the Yoga-upanishad and converted into this Gangafor the benefit of mankind”.

This supplies additional explanation on the constitutionof Ganga. It is clearly stated to be the essence of Yogarepresenting Sudha-vidya and Sudha-dharma. Our sacredGanga is therefore full of technical importance and deservesto be studied very carefully, without of course being misledby the Pandit and the Critic, who have evidently lost theirclaims to approach this Ganga of our ancient religion.

Q. No. XV.

“The Agni or fire known as Samsya, Havya-vahanaand Ahavaniya in our religion, fell in love with the follow-

ing sixteen rivers; Kaveri, Krishnaveni, Narmada, Yemuna,Godavari, Vitasta, Chandrabiaga,Iravati, Vipin, Kousiki,Satadru, Sarayu, Sita, Saraswati, Hradini and Pavani”.

That a fire falling in love with a number of rivers cannot be literally interpreted, is a fact any ordinary personcan understand, except perhaps the learned Pandit. Thename of the fire is technically significant, and it is describedhere in detail as Ahavaniya. The Pandit however knows itonly as a fire lighted in a pot with paddy husk. There arethree kinds of fire mentioned in the religious literature.They are said to be located in three parts of the humanbody. Ahavaniya is in the face, Garhapathya in thestomach and Dekshinagni in the heart.

त्रीणि स्थानानि भवन्ति मुखे आहवनीय उदरे गार्हपत्यो हृदि दक्षिणाभिः॥

When the specific reference of these fires and similarly ofthe rivers are ascertained by studying the texts, the passagequoted here will be full of meaning. It is a technicalsubject which neither the Pandit nor the Critic can ever hopeto understand by sheer pretension and insolence. We mighthowever for our present purpose be assured that the fire herementioned does not refer to the one burning in the Pandit’spot as it could not possibly marry a river which containswater. Fire thrown into a river would immediately beextinguished. The rivers also similarly could not refer toany running streams in India. In spite of all this, thePandit must maintain the fire as fire, and rivers as rivers inIndia. May God bless his brains.

** 10.** The descriptions of places, forests, hills andrivers in the above quotations are sufficiently explicit as towhat they do not represent. They are stated to be heavenlyand not earthly. Several of them are specified as seated in

the human body. The sources of heavenly rivers enumerated are traced to the sky and the fire. The plainness andclearness of such descriptions found, page after page, in thevarieties of ancient literature, without in the least contradicting one another, are so tempting that every line inducesone to reiterate the criticism as to the depth of ignoranceexhibited in the modern reckless interpretations. It isevident that the mistakes primarily originate from sheerignorance, and subsequent perversity, from pride and inpertinence.

The subjoined is a quotation from Suprabheda agama.The Agamas are more directly in touch with such matters,as they always deal with more practical and ceremonialportions of religious and philosophical subjects. The passagehere, quoted completely specifies the significance and application of all the preceding descriptions. The whole of itrefers to the Upasana-marga, detailing the higher glories ofGod, apart from those connected with the earthy and transient cosmology with which the ordinary worldly-wise manis at present acquainted. It is a geography of the higherand purer sphere of existence, if geography it should be
styled. The two geographies have nothing in common, nay,they are diametrically opposed to each other. Confoundingthe two is doubtless a sin, as it is virtually denying thehigher one, which alone is capable of giving us any safeabode. How the modern interpreters will therefore fare inthe light of these sacred passages reproduced here, I leavethe readers to think well and judge for themselves. Themost charitable view that can be taken in the matter is, thatthe task of these misinterpreters is unnecessary and unprofitable, if not uncalled for.

“Fools rush in where angels fear to tread”.

अध्वानं षड्विधं प्रोक्तंतत्त्वाध्वादि विनायक।
तत्त्वाध्वा प्रथमं विद्धि भुवनाध्वा द्वितीयकम्।
मन्त्राध्वावै तृतीयन्तु वर्णाध्वा वै चतुर्थकम्।
पदाध्वा पञ्चमं ज्ञेयं कलाध्वा षष्ठमं स्मृतम्।
षड्विधैरध्वभिर्मार्गैःसंविशेदेकमीश्वरम्।
तत्वाध्वानं समासेन भूकटाहादिकं शृणु।
पृथिव्यादीनि मायान्तम्अध्वानं वर्ण्यते क्रमात्।
कालाग्नेःशतरुद्रान्तं ब्रह्माण्डमति संस्मृतम्।
कालाग्निरुद्रदेवस्य तस्योर्ध्वे भुवनं विदुः।
लोकालोकस्वनाम्नातुपर्वतं वृत्तरूपतः।
लोकपाला स्थितास्तत्र सिद्धामरनिषेविताः।
तस्यान्तर्भासते सूर्यस्त्वन्धकारस्तथापरः।
लोकालोकस्समावृत्य गर्भोदधि समुद्रकान्।
गर्भोदधि समावृत्य पार्थिवावरणं स्मृतम्।
पार्थिवन्तु समावृत्य कटाहं कोटिविस्तृतम्।
कटाहं मेरुमध्यान्तं पञ्चाशत्कोटयः स्मृताः।
कटाहेस्य घनं कोटिःपञ्चाशत्कोटयः स्मृताः।
भूलोकश्चसमाख्यातो भुवलोकं ततः शृणु।
लक्षयोजनमानेन सूर्यलोकं विधीयते।
द्वादशादित्य वसवो रुद्राश्चैकादशस्तथा।
अश्विनौ द्वौ स्त्रयस्त्रिंशत् सञ्चरन्ति शिवेच्छया।
मेरुप्रदक्षिणेनैव भुवलोकमिति स्मृतम्।
तस्योपरि तु लक्षेणचन्द्रलोकं विधीयते।
चन्द्रोर्ध्वेलक्षमात्रेण स्थितन्नक्षत्रमण्डलम्।
लक्षद्वये बुधं विद्यात् द्विलक्षे भार्गवः स्मृतः।
लक्षद्वये तु चाङ्गारो द्विलक्षे तु बृहस्पतिः।
सौरिर्लक्षद्वयो प्रोक्तोमुनयो लक्षयो जने।
अत्रिश्चैववसिष्ठश्च पुलस्त्यः पुलहः क्रतुः।
भृग्वङ्गिरा मरीचिश्व मुनयस्सप्त कीर्तिताः।
उपरिष्टात् ध्रवः प्रोक्तस्त्वेकलक्षप्रमाणतः।

चन्द्रलोकात् ध्रुवान्तश्च स्वर्लोकामति कीर्तितम्।
दशपञ्च च लक्षाणि भूतष्पृष्ठात् ध्रुवान्तकम्।
ततोपरि महर्लोकं द्विकोटियोजनं स्मृतम्।
पञ्चाशीति च लक्षाणि जनलोकमिति स्मृतम्।
अष्टकोटि तपोलोकं उपर्युपरि संस्थितम्।
द्वादशैव तथा कोटिस्सत्यलोकं विधीयते।
महर्लोकादि सत्यान्तं रुद्रास्तत्र निवासिनः।
कोटिषोडशमानेन ब्रह्मलोकं विधीयते।
कोटियोजनमानेन विष्णुलोकं प्रकीर्तितम्।
नवकोटिप्रमाणेन रुद्रलोकमिहोच्यते।
प्रोक्तोयं पृथिवी पश्चात् आप्यं तत्वमतः शृणु।
ब्रह्माण्डपरितस्थाप्य दद्यात् दशगुणावृतम्।
अमरेशं प्रभावञ्च नैमिशं पुष्करं तथा।
आषाढीशञ्च पिण्डीशं हारभूतश्च वाकुलम्।
प्रोष्टं गुह्याष्टकं ह्येवं जलावरणमाश्रितम्।
ऊर्ध्वे दशगुणेनैव वह्ने रावरणं महत्।
हरिश्चन्द्रं सुशैलञ्च जल्पेरम्रातिकेश्वरम्।
महाकालं मध्यमञ्च केदारं भैरवं तथा।
अतिगुह्माष्टकं ह्येवम्अग्न्यावरणमाश्रितम्।
वाय्वावरणमूर्ध्वे तु वह्नेर्दशगुणं महत्।
गया चैव कुरुक्षेत्रं नखलं नाखलं तथा।
विमलञ्चाट्टहासश्च महेन्द्रं भीम एव च।
गुह्याद्गुह्याष्टकं ह्येवम्अनिलावरणे स्थितम्।
तदूर्ध्वन्तु भवेद्व्योम स्थितं दशगुणावृतम्।
वस्त्रापदं रुद्रकोटि रविमुक्तं महालयम्।
गोकर्णं भद्रकर्णञ्चसुवर्णाक्षञ्च स्थाणुकम्।
पवित्राष्टकमेवं हि व्योमावरणमाश्रिताः।
अतः ऊर्ध्वमहङ्कारं स्थितं दशगुणेन तु।
खगलेन्दु करण्डञ्चोमाकोटि मण्डलेश्वरम्।
कौञ्जरं शङ्कुकर्णञ्च स्थूलेश्वरं स्थलेश्वरम्।

स्थानाष्टकमिदं विद्यात् पूर्वाद्यैश्शान्तकं स्थितम्।
श्वेतगुह्याष्टकं प्रोक्तं रक्तं चैवा जुगुप्सितम्।
गुह्यात्गुह्याष्टकं पीतं कृष्णश्चैव पवित्रकम्।
स्थानाष्टकं स्फटीकाभं एवं पञ्चाष्टकं स्मृतम्।
पृथिव्यापस्तथा तेजो वायुराकाशमेव च।
अहङ्कारस्तथा बुद्धिर्गुणमव्यक्तमेव च।
रागत्वञ्च ततस्तस्मिन् दशपञ्चेन्द्रियाणि च।
विद्या काल कला माया आत्मानन्तु तथैव च।
शुद्धविद्या च सादाख्यं बिन्दुनादं तथैव च।
द्वितीयं शक्तितत्त्वञ्चप्रथमं शक्तिमेव च।
षट्त्रिंशत्तत्त्वमेतानि शिवतत्वोद्भवा इह।
ब्रह्माण्डं पृथिवी ज्ञेया प्रकृत्यं जलकं स्मृतम्।
तेजो विद्यान्तमेवं हि वायुस्सदाशिवान्तकम्।
व्योम शक्त्यन्तमेषां वै पञ्चतत्वेषु संस्थितम्।
एतानि पञ्चतत्त्वानि सुतत्वे तु स्थितानि तु।
मायान्तानि च तत्त्वानि शिवतत्वमुदीरितम्।
विद्यातत्त्वादिशक्त्यन्तं विद्यातत्त्वमिति स्मृतम्॥

सुप्रभेदागमम्॥

“The Adhwas, means or methods are of six sorts,namely, Tatwa, Bhuvana, Manthra, Varna, Pada and Kala.By these six processes, the Eswara who is single may beknown. The first one, Tatwa-adhwa begins with thesubtle element, the earth, and extends to Maya. This Prithivi or earth includes all the divine Lokas. The Bhu-lokais 50 koti yojanas in extent. Bhuva-loka extends roundthe Meru and contains the Sun’s loka of Leksha yojanas.The Moon’s loka is Leksha yojanas above the sun. Thestarry regions, Leksha yojanas above the moon. Budha orMercury is 2 Leksha yojanas above. Bhargava or Venus is2 Leksha yojanas above. Angara or Mars is still 2 Lekshayojanas above. Brihaspathi or Jupiter is again 2 Leksha

yojanas above. Souri or Saturn is still 2 Leksha yojanashigher. The Sapta-rishis, namely, Atri, Vasishta, Pulasthya,Pulaha, Kretu, Angira and Marichi are a Leksha yojanasabove. Dhruva or the Polar star is a Leksha yojanas higherstill. From the Moon to Dhruva is Swar-loka. AboveSwar-loka is Mahar-loka of 2 koti yojanas. Above it isJena-loka of 85 Leksha-yojanas. Then Tapo-loka of 8 kotiyojanas. Above it is Satya-loka of 12 koti yojanas. Fromthe Mahar to Satya, Rudras reside. Above these is Bramha-loka of 16 koti yojanas. Above it is Vishnu-loka of 1 kotiyojanas. Above still is Rudra-loka of 9 koti yojanas. Allthe above Lokas put together make up Prithivi-tatwom.Ten times greater in extent is Water-tatwa all round thePrithivi. The following are situated within it, namely,Ameresa, Prabhava, Nimisa, Pushkara, Ashadhisa, Pindisa,Harabhuta and Vakula. Ten times still larger is the encirclement by fire, within which lie, Harischandra, Susyla.Jelpera, Amratikeswara, Mahakala, Madhyama, Kedara andBhyrava. Ten times greater again is Air-tatwa withinwhich lie, Gaya, Kurukshethra, Nakhala, Naakhala Vimala,
Attahasa, Mahendra and Bhima. Ten times this air isAkasa within which lie, Vastrapada, Rudrakoti, Avimukta,Mahalaya, Gokarna, Bhadra-karna, Suvarnaksha and Sthanuka. Ten times greater still is the encirclement of Aham-kara, within which lie, Khagalendu, Karanda, Umakoti,Mandaleswara Kounjara,Sankukarna,Sthuleswara and Staleswara. The following is the list of 36 Tatwas originating fromSivatatwom, the 5 subtle elements, Ahamkara, Budhi, Guna,Avyakta, Raga, 15 senses, Vidya, Kala, Maya, Atma, Sudha-vidya, Sadakhya, Bindu, Nada and 2 Saktis. Bramhandais known as Prithivi, and Prakriti is known as water. Up toVidhya is fire-tatwa, up to Sadasiva is Air-tatwa, up toSakti is Akasa-tatwa, up to Maya is Siva-tatwa and up toSakti is Vidya-tatwa”.

An ordinary lay man could easily feel here the highlytechnical smell of the subject. Most of the proper namesintroduced in the passage quoted, are entirely unknown andmeaningless to the Pandit, Critic and Theosophist, and yetthey would venture to catch some of them from the middleof the description and attempt to make some silly and shameless use of them. The treatment of the subject however, istoo plain, to deceive any one possessing common sense, byextraneous explanations. The whole of it is clearly statedas representing the 36 religious Tatwams. In the astronomical description given here the Moon is placed far abovethe Sun, but it will be invariably found so described in allthe Puranas and Itihasas without mutual contradictions.This might certainly form a fit subject for the exercise ofthe ingenious brain of the Pandit who is likely to go so far as to establish that in Puranic times, the Moon was stationedabove the sun. Volumes might be written on the contraryby the Critic on the Indian ignorance of astronomicalsubjects, until they were learnt from the Greeks, Romansor even the Red Indians. The point in question will bedeferred for subsequent treatment as these unsympatheticelucidators will hardly find anything very interesting tothem here. There are several other important matters whichmany ordinary people may take for serious scientific factsyet unknown to the Western scientist. These collateralobservations may perhaps be rejected as vain hopes emanating from superstitious beliefs; let us therefore leave themhere and proceed with the main subject.

In the apparently geographical form of descriptiondetailed in the above passages, the general schemeis prescribed for religious meditations on the higher glories of theCreator. It should be carefully noticed and rememberedhere that the Bramhanda as described is beyond the possible

cosmological conception of ordinary man. It includes the14 Lokas explained above, but in itself extends only to atenth fraction of the sum total of earthy element. Encircling this earthy element, lies the element of water ten timesgreater in extent. Within this environment, the familiarnames, Nimisa, Pushkarom &c. are found, and are probablysignificant as Thirthas or holy baths. Similarly round theelement of water, the region of fire is described ten timesgreater in extent. Within this also several names appear,such as Harischandram, Kedarom &c., and they may besignificant as cremation grounds. Beyond fire is the environment of air, within which Gaya, Kurukshetrom &c., aredescribed as situated, and they may be significant as connected with Prana-yama or regulation of breath. Beyondair is the encirclement by sky or ether, within which Avimuktom, Mahalayam, Gokarnam &c. are mentioned, andthey may be significant as higher states still. Beyond ether
is the encirclement of Ahamkara or Egoism ten times geeaterin extent. The whole of this geography is clearly stated.in the latter part of the quotaion as referring directly to the36 Tatwas well-known in the philosophical analysis. Virtually, all these signify the higher states of mind and intellect, developed and purified, by religious meditations, alwaysof course accompanied by the strictest practice of the highestmorals.

The chief object aimed at in this little volume beingonly to get at the right method of interpretation and not anexhaustive treatment of even a portion of the subject, thepresent section dealing with the so-called Indian Geographymay well be closed here. But the modern ignorance andperversion exhibited in the interpretation of this religiousgeography is so great that it might be necessary and useful,to summarise the import of the passages hitherto quoted, forconstant reference.

** (1)** The religious geography has absolutely nothing todo with India or even the mother earth as a full globe. Itdeals with far more serious and subtler facts.

ऊर्ध्व धरायाः भूर्लोकः भुवर्लोकस्ततः परः॥

(2) The Jambu-Dwipa, in the middle of the sevenislanded earth, is the devotional sphere mentioned in our religion and has no reference to any earthy or materialstuff.

जम्बूद्वीपस्य संस्थानं यज्ञिया यत्र वैक्रियाः॥

(3) The Bharata-varsha, one of the nine divisions ofthis Jambu-Dwipa, represents the Karına-kanda or sphereof religious Karmas ordained for the pious Hindu.

(4) The 14 Lokas making up the Bramhanda is onlyene-tenth of the Prithivi or earth described in the Puranas.

(5) Round this Prithivi-tatwom is the Water-tatwomten times greater than the Prithivi and is said to containthe Puranic Nimisa, Pushkara etc.

(6) Similarly ten times greater in extent is each of theremaining elemental Tatwoms, Ahamkara, Budhi etc. In each of these, several of the Puranic centres are mentioned.

This is the plain description of our technical religiousgeography, dealing with the pure devine Tatwoms prescribed for religious and philosophical meditation on the realglories of God. Tatwom means ‘That-ness’ or that whichpertains to the real and eternal Eswara. The Pandit whounnecessarily meddles with our religious literature cannotapproach the Tatwoms without philosophical study andthought. He thus ignorantly reduces them to his villagegeography which is ordinarily dirty and unhealthy. He

has not yet secured the first Bhumi among the seven enumerated for the religious Hindu. He is not even in theBharata-varsha, which as a matter of grace, he is allowed tomention in the Samkalpa of his religious cermonies. Hemust open his eyes now, if he does not wish to sink deeperstill in degeneration. At any rate, he has no rights, legal,political, social or religious, to drag the innocent religiousHindu to the mire of his ignorance and force him to bedrowned with him. The foreign Critic, the civilized Hinduwho is his apish imitator and the Theosophical juggler, whowere all originally deceived and misled by the learnedPandit, might now honourably retire from the field carryingthe Pandit with them if they choose. It is certainly nomatter for disgrace, as all men are apt to err in this materialworld. The Pandit doubtless has however been originallythe cause of all this present confusion, and his mistakes arehere exposed with the best available evidence and authority.It is absurd to criticise the science of Arithmetic on accountof a problem mistakenly worked out by its student. Themistaken impressions regarding our religious geographyhave become current only through the ignorant interpretations of our veritable Pandit. Let him now be once for alldismissed from the council of religious advisers in India, andlet more respectable members bè substituted. Amen!

न जिघ्रत्याम्नायं स्पृशति न तदङ्गान्यपि सकृ-
त्पुराणं नादत्ते न गणयति किं च स्मृतिगणम्।
पठंच्छुष्कं तर्कं परपरिभवार्थोक्तिभिरसौ
नयत्यायुः सर्वं निहतपरलोकार्थयतनः॥

** 11.** The next point demanding enquiry is thedescription given in our ancient literature regarding Time ascalculated by Yugas and their cycles. But before commencing with this, it may be necessary to say something about

the existing and recognised Thirthas or Holy baths in India,as they still stand an inexplicable riddle, especially after theelaborate treatment of their geography in the precedingpages. It cannot but be confessed here, that, with ourpresent limited knowledge of the subject as a whole, thepassages from sacred texts reproduced above, serve, more orless, only as destructive elucidations rather than constructive.The difficulty and confusion here is nothing new. Theyhave been unconsciously caused all along, by our venerablePandits, as repeatedly observed, by misunderstanding thehigher and lower application of the intended object. TheThirthas themselves are distinctly classified as Manasa andBhowma, mental and physical, internal and external, theformer being certainly recognised as more important thanthe latter. The subjoined quotations clearly enumerateand explain the special value of Manasa-thirthas.

Quotation. No. 1.

वसिष्ठ उवाच।

मानसान्यपि तीर्थानि वक्ष्यामि शृणु पार्थिव।
येषु सम्यङ्नरस्नात्वा प्रयाति परमाङ्गतिम्।
सत्यं तीर्थं क्षमा तीर्थंतीर्थमिन्द्रियनिग्रहः।
सर्वभूतदयातीर्थं तीर्थमार्जवमेव च।
दानं तीर्थंदमस्तीर्थ सन्तोषस्तीर्थमेव च।
आत्मतीर्थंध्यानतीर्थंपुनस्तीर्थं शिवस्मृतिः।
तीर्थानामुत्तमं तीर्थंविशुद्धिर्मनसः पुनः।
न जलाप्लुतदेहस्य स्नानमित्यभिधीयते।
स स्नातो यो दमस्नातः शुचिः स्निग्धमना मतः।
यो लुब्धः पिशुनः क्रूरेः दाम्भिको विषयात्मकः।
सर्वतीर्थेष्वपि स्नातः पापो मलिन एव सः।
न शरीरमलत्यागात् नरो भवति निर्मलः।
मानसे तु मले त्यक्ते भवत्यत्यन्त निर्मलः।

जायन्ते च म्रियन्ते च जलेष्वेव जलौकसः।
न च गछन्ति ते स्वर्गम्अविशुद्धमनो मलाः।
विषयेष्वतिसंरागो मानसो मल उच्यते।
तेष्वेव हि विरागोस्य नैर्मल्यं समुदाहृतम्।
दानमिज्या तपः शौचं तीर्थमेव श्रुतं तथा।
सर्वाण्येतानि तीर्थानि यदिभावो हि निर्मलः।
निगृहीतेन्द्रियग्रामो यत्र यत्र वसेन्नरः।
तत्र तस्य कुरुक्षेत्रं नैमिषं पुष्कराणि च।
ज्ञानपूते ध्यानजले रागद्वेष मलापहे।
यः नाति मानसे तीर्थे स याति परमां गतिम्॥

पत्मपुराणम्॥

Q. No. II.

स्नानं मनोमलत्यागः शौचमिन्द्रियनिग्रहः।
अहम्ममेति विण्मूत्रलेपगन्धादि मोचनम्।
शुद्धशौचमिति प्रोक्तं मृज्जलाभ्यान्तु लौकिकम्।
चित्तशुद्धिकरं शौचं वासनात्रयनाशनम्।
ज्ञानवैराग्यमृत्तो यैः क्षालनाछौचमुच्यते॥

उत्तमा तत्वचिन्तैव मध्यमं शास्त्रचिन्तनम्।
अधमा मन्त्रचिन्ता च तीर्थभ्रान्त्यधमाधमा॥

मैत्रेय्युपनिषत्॥

Q. No. III.

बहिस्तीर्थात्परं तीर्थम्अन्तस्तीर्थंमहामुने।
आत्मतीर्थंमहातीर्थम्अन्यत्तीर्थंनिरर्थकम्।
चित्तमन्तर्गतं दुष्टं तीर्थस्नानैर्न्नशुध्यति।
शतशोपि जलैर्धौतं सुराभाण्डमिवाशुचि॥

श्रीजाबालदर्शनोपनिषत्॥

Q. No. I

** **“Vasishta said, ‘Oking’, I shall describe to you the mental Thirthas or holybaths, by bathingwell in which, man attains emartcipation.Truthfulness is & Thittha, so is

forgiveness, control of the senses, mercy, straightforwardness, charity, contentment, Dhyana, devotion to Siva etc.The highest among the Thirthas is purity of mind, becausesimple dipping of the body in water is not recognised as aholy bath.A cruel, haughty, sensual, miserly wretch,never gets purified by bathing in all the sacred rivers orother baths. He is still a dirty sinner as before. Theaquatic animals born and dying in water, do not on thataccount get their minds purified or obtain salvation. Intensedesire for worldly pleasures is known as mental impurity;its removal is mental purification. The place in which amentally purified person resides, is really the Nimisa, Pushkara and Kuru-kshetra. The mental Thirtha is filled withthe water of Dhyana, purified by gnana and capable of
washing away the dirt of desire, anger etc. He who bathesin this Thirtha is sure to obtain liberation”.

Q. No. II.

Snana or religious bath means removal of mentalimpurity and soucha or cleanliness means controlling thesenses. Merely washing the body with water and clay isbut the worldly bath. The dirt of egoism sticking on allover the body should be washed away by the water and clay,of gnana or knowledge, and vyragya or freedom frompassion. The meditation of the Tatwas is the highest, studyof the Sastras ranks next and that of Manthras is thelast. The mania for the external holy baths is the lowest.”

Q. No. III.

“The internal Thirthas are more important than theexternal ones. Atma-thirtha is the highest, all the rest areuseless. Bathing in the external Thirthas with an evil mindinside, never procures purity. A pot containing toddy neverbecomes pure by any amount of washing outside”.

Thirtha generally means a remedy, means or expedient.In religion, it especially refers to all the processes of purification prescribed. The term is applied therefore to both internal and external purifications The modern mistakelies in interpreting it as dealing with the external purifications alone. From the above quotations, we have seen thatthe external processes as such, are of no avail, unless accompanied by internal purifications. The texts speak veryclearly on the point, and the modern interpreters thereforeboldly explain otherwise.

** 12.**The extreme importance of moral rectitude, charity and sincere religious devotion is established by theabove passages as opposed to hypocracy and mere externalcleanliness. In spite of the very strong language used inthese quotations, it is however a very interesting point tonote, how the idea of baths in holy centres as a religioussubstitute for, or a supplement to, the canons enunciatedabove, struck the ancients, in the interest of the lower ordersof society. The subjoined quotations assign simple reasons,sufficiently scientific and convincing, so as to induce everyreasonable person to appreciate the necessity and advantageof resorting to these Thirthas.

Quotation. No. I.

निसर्गात्सलिलं मेध्यं निर्मलं शुचि पाण्डरम्।
मलहं पुरुषव्याघ्र द्रावकं दाहकं तथा।
तारकं सर्वभूतानां पोषणं जीवनं तथा।
आपो नारायणो देवः सर्ववेदेषु पठ्यते॥

पद्मपुराणम्॥

Q. No. II.

दीपनं वृष्यमायुष्यं स्नानमूर्जाबलप्रदम्।
कण्डूमलश्रमस्वेदतन्द्रातृद्दाह पाप्मजित्॥

अष्टाङ्गहृदयम्॥

Q. No. III.

भौमानामपि तीर्थानां पुण्यत्वे कारणं शृणु।
यथा शरीरस्योद्देशाः केचिन्मेध्यतमाः स्मृताः।
तथा पृथिव्यामुद्देशाः केचित्पुण्यतमः स्मृताः।
प्रभावादद्भुताद्भूमेः सलिलस्य च तेजसा।
परिग्रहान्तु नीनाञ्चतीर्थानां पुण्यता स्मृता।
तस्मात्तीर्थेषु सर्वेषु मानसेषु च नित्यशः।
उभयेष्वपि यः स्नाति स याति परमां गतिम्॥

पद्मपुराणम्॥

Q. No. I.

“Water is by nature pure and purifying. It is the life-giving food for all created things. All the Vedas say thatwater is the form of Narayana”,

Q. No. II.

“Bathing in water accelerates digestion, increases strength and rernoves itch, dirt, sweat, laziness, thirst, heat andsin".

The use of water as an external purifier is vividly explained here. No other element could possibly be substituted for the purpose, and hence water and bath constitutethe chief items in external purification.

Q No. III.

“I shall narrate to you the reasons assigned for thesacredness of the holy centres established in the various parts of the country. In the human body itself, some partsare considered good and others not so. Similarly some portions of the earth are good and others bad. The Thirthasare established in consideration of this important fact.Some places are healthy by nature and sometimes possessrare and convenient situations and contain excellent water,

Combined with these, there must be another essentialcondition, namely, the recognition by the great Rishis.All such Thirthas are sacred and should be visited. But themental Thirthas already enumerated must always be attended to. One who takes to both the Thirthas will attainsalvation”.

** 13**. The above passages deserve and demand themost patient and careful scrutiny; and it must be emphatically affirmed that they do not confirm or even corroboratethe current interpretations, assigning historical importanceto the Holy centres in India and connecting them with specific descriptions found in the Puranas and Itihasas, takingthem as representing places of historical incidents. In theface of the so-called geography examined already, it is unnecessary at this stage to reiterate the arguments for theconviction of any reasonable being as to the absurdity andirrelevancy of the modern views. The only point for useful enquiry here would be to trace the causes that led to thesemistakes.

We have seen all along, that the procedure adopted inour sacred literature was to descend step by step from thehighest philosophical truths to suit the varying intellectualcapacities of man, without at the same time losing sight ofthe main goal. The Puranas and Itihasas took up theVedas and served as their commentaries, treating the purely philosophical truths, in accordance with certain definiteformulas prescribed in the Vedas themselves, and consistentlyfollowed throughout.The abstract ideas were to someextent concretised and narrated in the garb of Divine histories and geographies. The subsequent pages of this book,will it is hoped make this clearer still. In the meantime,something must be said at this stage regarding the identification of certain places in India with the names found in

the literature. For the very commencement of religiouspractice, the purification of mind and body was found anecessary preliminary step, owing to the degeneracy of manas he is at present, and the two distinct processes above detailed were formulated. As regards the means for externalpurification, the efficacy of good water, none can deny. Theinfluence of healthy forests, fresh air and enchanting scenerycombined with beautiful temples situated in the adjoininglocalities, where abundance of fresh water is procurable inthe shape of falls and running rivers, will certainly be admitted by all, as not only exhilerating to the physical bodybut also soothing and ennobling to the worry-ridden mind.This is exactly the sum and substance of the quotationsreproduced above. Any further twisting of their meaningis unwarranted by the texts and therefore unauthorised.The application of certain terms from the literature, asnames to places or persons, cannot certainly be an exeuse fortheir misinterpretation. The names of Gods invariablyfound applied to all the Hindus, will not justify their stylingthemselves as Gods in comparison with the human beingselsewhere. No more serious argument is required to establish the mistakes in the confounding of earthy spots inIndia with the ideas conveyed by certain religious andphilosophical terms, especially when their meanings are unknown and unsought for. It is equally absurd and insultingto be told that religious centres and holy baths exist only inIndia and all outside is unholy. On the contrary, if westick on to the current interpretations, the passages hithertoreproduced will clearly prove that everything outside Indiais bliss and happiness and everything within is ephemeraland miserable. The eternal and blissful region is describedas lying to the north and beyond the Himalayas. VideMaha Bharatom Santi-parva.

उत्तरे हिमवत्पार्श्वेपुण्ये सर्वगुणान्विते।
पुण्यः क्षेम्यश्च काम्यश्च स परो लोक उच्यते॥

Hundreds of cases like this may be quoted if necessaryillustrating the absurdity of the modern interpretation. Infact, the localities, their dimensions and other descriptionsgiven in the texts, seldom correspond, and are never meantto correspond, with the modern attempted identifications.The river Saraswathy mentioned in the Puranas had certainly no physical existence at all, but it is now explainedas Antar-vahiny or running underground unseen at Allahabad. The impossible junction of Kaveri in Deccan andNarbuda in Central Provinces, as also the situation of Dwaraka described as on the banks of the Jumna and within theboundaries of Indraprasta or Delhi, found mentioned in thesubjoined quotation will certainly take our Pandits by surprise.

कावेरी नर्मदां यत्र सङ्गता लोकविश्रुता।
तत्र स्नात्वा शुचिर्भूत्वा कुबेरस्सत्यविक्रमः॥

क्षेत्रं कलिन्दजातीरे मत्तुल्यास्तत्र ये मृताः।
विरिश्चे रचिता तत्र स्वकीया द्वारकापुरी।
इन्द्रप्रस्थान्तरावर्ति न्येषा या द्वारका द्विज।
नातः परतरं मर्त्येतीर्थमस्त्यखिलार्थदम्॥

पद्मपुराणम्॥

The subsequent applications of these terms as names tocommon objects might have been for the purpose of familiarising the public with their usage and set them athinking,at least in their leisurely moments. It is no doubt aningenious method of spreading the higher philosophicaltruths among the ordinary people to give them a sort ofcurrency and permanency which could never be expected by

mere publication of books or even by preaching. The stories often utilized as models for religious and moralinstructions tend to keep them in memory as they haveactually done. The majority knows them only in thismanner, but a very limited minority might have heard thePuranas read and explained on religious and festive occasions.Somehow, a great portion of the literature has become incourse of time, the household property of every Hindufamily. The highest gratitude of every pious Hindu is therefore due to the wise and venerable sages for the great boonthus rendered. But the Pandit who stands in the way offurther progress, which the far-seeing Rishis certainly hadin view, is liable for his uncalled for interference and unprivileged forwardness in thrusting in, his misinterpretations.

The new alien creed styled Theosophy which is generally misunderstood as supporting Hindu religion, is equallyresponsible for voluntarily propogating mistaken theories inthe land pertaining to the contents of our sacred literature.It is certainly too late now for its disciples to conceal ignorance with occultisms and secret doctrines. The mistakescommitted with regard to the point in question are exactlysteriotyped repetitions of our local Pandits, and do not even exhibit an atom of originality in them, in spite of theirstrenuous efforts to give them a scientific shape. The usualmistakes lie at the bottorn and are irremediable at the topFor the purpose of offering convincing and conclusive proofof this fact, it will suffice at this juncture to illustrate oneserious and important blunder exhibited by Theosophicalignorance of the so-called geography in our sacred literature.

The subjoined quotation from Mrs. Besant’s Sanathana Dharma, page 234, will bear ample testimony to thetruth of the above remarks, Many a repeated identificationof Bharata Varsha with India by Mrs. Besant, within he

small para itself here reproduced, is verily the oldest rottenmistake of our local wise acres.

“In the ancient days Jivatma was prepared for entranceinto each caste through a long preliminary stage outsideIndia; then he was born into India and passed into eachcaste to receive its definite lessons; then was born away from India to practise these lessons; usually returning toIndia to the highest of them, in the final stages of hisevolution”.

It is however desirable to find out if possible whetherthere are any cogent reasons for describing in the sacredtexts, certain philosophical ideas in the form of cities, mountains and rivers and giving thern an appearance of geographical treatment. It must be clearly remembered that they areinvariably mentioned as divine and not earthly as we havealready seen. Their venerable authors are not thereforeresponsible for the modern confusion of these with terrestrialobjects. High abstract truths which will not permit ofbeing easily expressed in human language had to be somehow explained.

चोद्यं वा व्यवहारो वा क्रियतां द्वैतभाषया।
अद्वैतभाषया चोद्यं नास्ति नापि तदुत्तरम्॥

“There is no scope for question or answer in the languageof Adwitom. The language of Dwitom is the only availablemedium for such purpose”. The material world is thereforethe last resort for their analogical illustrations. Thus,certain religious and philosophical ideas were treated asGods, especially those representing the spiritual or efficientcauses in the philosophical analysis of creation and evolution.For the same reason the transformations of Prakriti ormaterial cause or the Tatwas as they are styled, had to be

described as the region of Gods, in the form of divinecities, divine mountains and divine rivers &c. Again, themain difficulty was not completely overcome. The forms
of Gods are yet unknown and they were represented in thebest imaginable form of man, with necessary alterations,additions and paraphernalia, the details of which shall betreated in the subsequent section III of this chapter. In thesame manner, the devine cities, hilis and rivers could onlyresemble the earthly ones, with necessary alterations in size,colour and material &c. In the Yoga sastras, the nervouscentres which form the physiological bases for the aboveTatwas were often described as mountains and Peattas orseats, and the never ending currents of Vasanas, thoughts orbreath were naturally represented as ever-coursing rivers,
carrying with them everything they catch on their way totheir ultimate destination. We have already seen thatGanga, Yamuna and Saraswati represent, Ida, Pingala andSushumna Nadis, and that the water in the Viraja river is made up of the sweat of religious devotion.

वेदाङ्गस्वेदजनित तोयैः प्रस्राविता शुभा॥

गुदस्य पृष्ठभागस्मिन् वीणादण्डस्सदेहभृत्।
दीर्घास्थि देहपर्यन्तं ब्रह्मनाडीति कथ्यते।
तस्यान्ते सुषिरं सूक्ष्मं ब्रह्मनाडीति सूरिभिः।
इडापिङ्गलयोर्मध्ये सुषुम्ना सूर्यरूपिणी।
सर्वं प्रतिष्ठितं तस्मिन् सर्वगं विश्वतोमुखम्।
तस्य मध्यगता स्सूर्यसोमाग्निपरमेश्वराः।
भूतलोकादिशः क्षेत्रा स्समुद्राः पर्वताश्शिलाः।
द्वीपाश्च निम्नगा वेदा श्शास्त्रविद्या कलाक्षराः।
स्वर मन्त्र पुराणानि गुणाश्चैते च सर्वशः।
बीजं बीजात्मकस्तेषां क्षेत्रज्ञः प्राणवायवः।
सुषुम्नान्तर्गतं विश्वं तस्मिन् सर्वं प्रतिष्ठितम्।

नानानाडी प्रसवगं सर्वभूतान्तरात्मनि।
ऊर्ध्वमूलमधरशाखं वायुमार्गेण सर्वगम्।
द्विसप्तति सहस्राणिनाड्यस्युर्वायुगोचराः।
द्विसप्तति सहस्राणि नाडीद्वाराणि पञ्जरे।
सुषुम्ना शाम्भवीशक्तिश्शेषास्त्वन्ये निरर्थकाः॥

योगशिखोपनिषत्॥

“The hollow through the spinal column is the BramhaNadi called Sushumna lying between Ida and Pingala. Thesun, moon, fire, Eswara, elements, Lokas, Dwipas, oceans,mountains, all lie within this Nadi; also the Vedas. Sastras,Puranas, Manthras &c. Its roots are above and the branchesare below. Out of the seventy-two thousand Nadis in thehuman body through which air courses, the Sushumna aloneis the Sakti of Siva, the rest are useless”.

The current mistakes could not however have arisen fromthis unavoidable method of treatment. The subsequenterection of temples and location of Bhowmathirthas, withthe terms in question applied to them as names, have givenan opportunity for confusion of facts, virtually for puttingthe cart before the horse. Neither the cart nor the horsewas a mistaken factor, but the mistake occurred in their misplacement. As matters are now interpreted, they have cometo mean that Vishnu originated after the temple at Srirangomwas constructed and Siva after that of Benares andnot the temples after them. The Sthala-puranas of suchplaces are also now completely misinterpreted and are exactlyabused and ill-treated like the Puranas themselves. Noneof them I dare say narrate any absurd and irrelevant storiesas now generally explained, but they very reasonably andingeniously furnish clues to the exact meanings of certaindefinite facts and formulas hitherto detailed. The Thirthasas a class invariably refer to Varana and Asi as in Benares.

The same story is repeated with slightly altered descriptionsto suit the differences of local conditions and necessities. Theproof of all this fact is but a simple matter of unbiased andsympathetic investigation; and I must entirely leave it tothe judgment of those who are sincerely interested in thesubject. In consideration of the limited scope of this littleessay, I cannot help ending the present section here. Hadit not been for the immense amount of irremediable confusionproduced by the mistaken interpretations of this religiousand philosophical geography, I would certainly have stoppedmuch earlier.

————————————

SECTION II.

ON TIME.

1. The main divisions of Time represented in oursacred literature are; Parardhas, Kalpas, Manwantaras,Yugas and the cycle of 60 years commencing with Prabhava. A more general classification of it is into Sthula and Sukshma, gross and subtle. This latter classification will have tobe first examined, as it is the foundation for the varied descriptions given, in accordance with the usual formulas
always followed for the purpose of expressing abstractmatters in more concrete terms. It is simply the ignoranceof these formulas that has led to the present confusions. Itmust however be admitted that such restrictions and limitations in the meanings of terms used in the treatment of anyscientific subject, are unavoidable even in the material sphere,and the necessity and plea for such a procedure is thereforegreater in the spiritual sciences. It is probable that theexistence itself of such a distinction in the calculations of

time might surprise our learned Pandits, but nevertheless, itis a bare fact in reference to the literature in question withwhich they are not perhaps sufficiently acquainted, owing tofalse dignity or for other serious reasons.

The following quotations denote the necessary methodfor understanding some of the given descriptions whichappear as pertaining to Time.

Quotation No. I.

मनोवशात् प्राणवायुः स्ववशे स्थाप्यते सदा।
नासिकापुटयोः प्राणःपर्यायेणप्रवर्तते।
तिस्रश्चनाडिकास्तासु स यावन्तं चरत्ययम्।
शङ्खिनीविवरे याम्ये प्राणःप्राणभृतां सताम्।
तावन्तञ्च पुनः कालं सौम्ये चरति सन्ततम्।
इत्थं क्रमेण चरता वायुना वायुजिन्नरः।
अहश्च रात्रिं पक्षञ्च मासमृत्वयनादिकम्।
अन्तर्मुखो विजानीयात् कालभेदं समाहितः॥

त्रिशिखब्राह्मणोपनिषत्॥

Q. No. II.

इडायां चन्द्रमा नित्यं चरत्येव महामुने।
पिङ्गलायां रविस्तद्वन्मुने वेदविदांवर।
पिङ्गलायाः इडायान्तु वायोस्संक्रमणन्तुयत्।
तदुत्तरायणं प्रोक्तं मुने वेदान्तवेदिभिः।
इडायाःपिङ्गलायान्तु प्राणसंक्रमणं मुने।
दक्षिणायनमित्युक्तं पिङ्गलायामिति श्रुतिः।
इडापिङ्गलयोस्संधिं यदा प्राणस्समागतः।
अमवास्या तदा प्रोक्ता देहे देहभृतांवर।
मूलाधारं यदा प्राणः प्रविष्टः पण्डितोत्तम।
तदाद्यं विषुवंप्रोक्तं तापसैस्तत्वचिन्तकैः।
निश्वासोच्छासनं सर्वं मासानां संक्रमो भवेत्
इडायाःकुण्डलीस्थानं यदा प्राणस्समागतः।

सोमग्रहणमित्युक्तं तदा तत्वविदां वर।
यदा पिङ्गलया प्राणःकुण्डलीस्थानमागतः।
तदा तदा भवेत् सूर्यग्रहणं मुनिपुङ्गव।
विषुवायनकालेषु ग्रहणे चान्तरे सदा।
वाराणस्यादिके स्थाने स्नात्वा शुद्धो भवेन्नरः॥

श्रीजाबालदर्शनोपनिषत्॥

Q No. III.

कालञ्च कुरुते यस्मात् कालमेवमुदाहृतम्।
प्राणिनां चैव देवानां विनाशोत्पत्तिकारणम्।
युगपत् सृष्टिसंहारौ स्थितिकाले निवर्तते।
केचित्कालात्सृजन्त्येव केचित्कालाद्भ्रमन्ति च।
कालञ्चद्विविधं प्रोक्तंस्थूलं सूक्ष्मं तथैव च।
लौकिकं स्थूलमाख्यातं योगिनां सूक्ष्ममेव च।
स्थूलञ्च द्विविधं वत्स चन्द्रादित्यस्य चारणम्।
चन्द्रस्य वर्तनाकालो मनुष्याणां प्रकीर्तितम्।
सूर्यस्य वर्तना कालो देवानान्तु प्रकीर्तितम्।
पृथिव्यादि शिवान्तञ्च सत्वकालं प्रकीर्तितम्।
ईश्वरस्य लयं यावत् आत्मनस्तु लयं भवेत्।
सदाशिवलयं यावत् नादान्तं लयमेव च।
ततः शक्तेर्लयं यावत् लयं गछेत् शिवान्तकम्।
तत्वानां लयमेवोक्तं सूक्ष्मकालं ततः शृणु।
श्वासैस्तु त्रुटिभिः प्राणो घटिका प्राणषट्कके।
अहोरात्रं ततः षष्टिघटिकादिविशेषतः।
पूर्ववद्दिनवृध्यातु पक्षादीनि विवर्द्धयेत्।
सूक्ष्मकालेन योगेन देवब्रह्मादिका लयः।
ज्ञानिनां योगिनां चैष सूक्ष्मकालं प्रकीर्तितम्॥

सुप्रभेदागमम्॥

Q. No. IV.

एवं चिन्तन योगेन यावत् भावयते परम्।

नाडीसूक्ष्मेण मार्गेण ऊर्ध्वं यात्युत्तरायणम्।
उभौ मार्गोतु विज्ञेयौ देहं संवत्सरं स्मृतम्॥

श्रीशिवमहापुराणम्॥

Quotation. No. I.

“The currents of breath may be controlled by the forceof mind. The breath ordinarily passes alternately throughthe left and right nostrils for three Nadikas at a time; andthe Yogi should base upon this fact, his internal calculationsof time regarding day and night, fortnight, month andAyanas”.

This Upanishad here is very clear in its postulation ofa formula for the Yogis, to calculate their own time as different from that of the ordinary man. The Pandit might particularly take note of the fact here, that the ancient Rishiswhose favourite residence was the forest, had more than onecloth to wear, but that in spite of his living in the town, hehas only one, with nothing to spare.

Q. No. II.

“The Ida or current of breath through the left nostril istechnically called the Moon, and Pingala on the right isknown as the Sun. The passing of breath from the rightto the left is also technically known among philosophersas Uttarayana. The reverse is Dekshinayana. The junctionof Ida and Pingala is Amavasya or new moon. When thelife breath reaches Muladhar, it is Vishuva or the New Year’sday. Inspiration and exhalation are beginnings of months.When the life-breath passes to Kundalini through Ida, it isLunar Eclipse, and through Pingala it is Solar Eclipse. Inthese specified holy times, such as Vishuva, Ayana, Eclipse&c., if one bathes in the similarly specified centres in thebody, such as Varanasi etc, he is sure to be purified”.

The above is indeed a double bombardument upon themodern interpretations of our religious times and places. Ifthe ignorant and impudent interpreters hope to escape fromthis, more shall be soon kept ready for them.

Q. No. III.

“That which creates time itself, which is the realcause of the creation and destruction of the Devas and othercreatures, is here known as time. When such time is preserved, creations and destructions vanish. Some create withthis time, others get entangled in it. There are two kindsof time, the Sthula and the Sukshma, the former is meantfor the worldly and the latter for the Yogis. The Sthulais again calculated in two ways; by the lunar rotations forman and by the solar for the Devas. The calculation fromthe Prithivi Tatwa to Siva Tatwa is known as Satwa kalaor time, pertaining to the gradual involutions of the Tatwasnamely of, Eswara, Atma, Sadasiva, Nadanta and Sakti upto Siva Tatwa. Three Sukshma breaths make one SukshmaPrana, and six such Pranas make oue Sukshma Ghatika,and sixty such Ghatikas make one Sukshma day. Furthercalculations of Pakshas, months and years go by the samemultiples ordinarily used for Sthula time. The involutionof the Devas and Bramha is calculated in Sukshma time, asalso the work of the Gnanis and Yogis”.

The divine energy that creates time itself is known asTime here. Three distinct varieties of this Time are hereelearly explained as the Sthula, the Sukshina and the Satwa.The Satwa refers to the involutions of the religious Tatwaswhich are entirely unknown factors to the modern interpreters of our sacred religion. The Sukshma is mentioned aspertaining exclusively to the Devas, Bramha, Gnanis andYogis. The modern Pandit and critic who belong to noneof these specified classes, ignorantly misapply the Sukshma

time to their own Sthula variety, which alone they haveevidently heard of hitherto. They are therefore entirelymistaken at the very foundation, and their ignorant presumption that all our religious and philosophical texts describeonly their householl affairs, certainly displays the most idiotic impertinence that one can imagine.

Q No. IV.

“Thus the Yoga of meditation has to be continued,until the ultimate Bramhan is reached. The two pathsprescribed for this Yoga should be followed, the one which
takes to the highest stage through the Sukshma Nadi isknown as Uttarayana and the human body is known asSamvatsara or year.”

The significance of our religious time is evidently becoming more and more irksome to the Pandit and hiscolleagues. The human body is here explained as the year.‘संवत्सरो वै प्रजापतिः’. Samvatsara or year is Prajapathy." समस्तानि हि भूतानि एतस्मिन् संवसन्तीति संवत्सरः" That withinwhich everything resides is Samvatsara. These are surelyquotations which are more than the modern Pandit couldbear. The only conception of the Samvatsara he is capableof, is the occurrence of the anniversaries in his house and the prospect of filling the stomach with bread and cake on theoccassions.The sacred religious literature bequeathed to usby our ancient sages, is so voluminous and so full of usefulinstructions conveyed in the simplest and clearest possiblelanguage, that it is indeed a pity that the Pandit with allhis Sanskrit learning is not destined to swallow and digest asingle useful drop out of it, so as to save himself from endless perdition.

बीजैरङ्कुरितं लताभिरुदितं वल्लीभिरुज्जृम्भितम्।
कन्दैः कन्दलितं जनैः प्रमुदितं धाराधरे वर्षति।

भ्रातश्चातकपातकं किमपि ते सम्यङ् न जानीमहे
येनास्मिन्नपतन्ति चञ्चुपुटकेद्वित्राः पयोबिन्दवः॥

** 2.** It is evident from the above quotations that thecalculation of time found detailed in the sacred texts clearlyrefer to its Sukshma form and represent the functions ofthought and breath as regulated by Yogic processes. Thegeneral terms of measurement however are retained as thesame in the treatment of both Sthula and Sukshma varieties,and a sort of analogical comparison is maintained with a viewto utilise the Sthula form for the practical benefit of theless qualified classes. The concretised forms and the ritualistic ceremonies of the Karma-kanda are based upon theseanalogical formulas and are consciously prescribed for thepurpose of attaining certain definite aims in the gradualprogress of religious practice. They are certainly not theaimless outcome of the whims and caprices of our venerablesages, nor are they useless and unscientific superstitions asthey are so lightly and conveniently pronounced in moderndays. The mere fancy or even respect for material sciencecannot form an excuse for off-hand criticisms of any facts ortheories without proper scientific investigations, and suchcriticisms in themselves are no signs of originality or respectable intelligence. ‘Critics all are ready made,’ and no bodyneed therefore care for them. The following passages enumerate the different divisions of time as described in the texts.

Quotation. No. I.

स्वस्थानराक्षिकोन्मील निमीलन्तु निमेषकम्।
निमेषस्य चतुर्भागं तुटिरेवमुदाहृतम्।
तुटिद्वयं लवं विद्धि लवद्वयनिमेषकम्।
निमेषो दशपश्चैव काष्ठासा त्रिंशतिः कला।
कलार्धस्तु क्षणं प्रोक्तंक्षणद्वयमुहूर्तकम्।

तदर्धंघटिका प्रोक्ता सर्वकार्यं तयाकृतम्।
सत्रिपादत्रिघटिका सन्धिरित्युच्यते बुधैः।
सन्धिद्वयं तथा यामं चतुर्यामं दिवास्मृतम्॥

सुप्रभेदागमम्॥

Q. No. II.

चरमः सद्विशेषाणामनेको संयुतः सदा।
परमाणुः सविज्ञेयो नृणामैक्यभ्रमो यतः।
सत एव पदार्थस्य स्वरूपावास्थतस्य यत्।
कैवल्यं परममहानविशेषो निरन्तरः।
एवं कालोप्यनुमितः सौक्ष्म्ये स्थौल्ये च सत्तम।
संस्थानभुक्त्या भगवानव्यक्तो व्यक्तभुग्विभुः।
सकालः परमाणुर्वैयोभुंक्ते परमाणुताम्।
ततो विशेषभुग्यस्तु सकालःपरमो महान्।
अणुर्द्वौ परमाणूस्यात्रसरेणुस्त्रयः स्मृतः।
जालार्करश्म्यवगतः खमेवानुपतन्नगात्।
त्रसरेणुत्रिकं भुंक्ते यः कालः स त्रुटिःस्मृतः।
शतभागस्तु वेधः स्यात्तैस्त्रिभिस्तु लवः स्मृतः।
निमेषस्त्रिलवो ज्ञेयः आम्नातस्तेयः क्षणः।
क्षणान् पञ्च विदुः काष्ठां लघुता दशपञ्च च।
लघूनि वै समाम्नाता दश पञ्च च नाडिका।
तद्वे मुहूर्तः प्रहरःषड्यामः सप्त वा नृणाम्।
द्वादशार्धपलोन्मानं चतुर्भिश्चतुरंगुलैः।
स्वर्णमाषैः कृतछिद्रं यावत्प्रस्थजलप्लुतम्।
यामाश्चत्वारश्चत्वारो मर्त्सानामहनी उभे I
पक्षः पञ्चदशाहानि शुक्लः कृष्णश्च मानद।
तयोः समुच्चयो मासः पितॄणां तदहर्निशम्।
द्वौतावृतुः षडयनं दक्षिणञ्चोत्तरं दिवि।
अयने चाहनी प्राहुर्वत्सरो द्वादशस्मृतः।
संवत्सरशतं नॄणां परमायुर्निरूपितम्।

ग्रहर्क्षताराचक्रस्थः परमाण्वादिना जगत्।
संवत्सरावसानेन पर्येत्यनिमिषोविभुः I
संवत्सरः परिवत्सर इडावत्सर एव च।
अनुवत्सरो वत्सरथ विदुरैवं प्रभाष्यते।

विदुर उवाच।

पितृदेव मनुष्याणामायुः परमिदं स्मृतम्।
परेषां गतिमाचक्ष्व येस्युः कल्पात् बहिर्विदः।
भगवान् वेदकालस्य गतिं भगवतो ननु।
विश्वं विचक्षते धीरा योगराद्धेन चक्षुषा।

मैत्रेय उवाच।

कृतं त्रेता द्वापरञ्च कलिश्चेति चतुर्युगम्।
दिव्यैर्द्वादशभिर्वर्षैः सावधानं निरूपितम्।
चत्वारि त्रीणि द्वे चैकं कृतादिषु यथाक्रमम्।
संख्यातानि सहस्राणि द्विगुणानि शतानि च।
संध्यांशयोरन्तरेण यः कालः शतसंख्ययोः।
तमेवाहुर्युगं तज्ञा यत्र धर्मो विधीयते।
धर्मश्चतुष्पान्मनुजान् कृते समनुवर्तते।
स एवान्येष्वधर्मेण व्येति पादेन वर्धता।
त्रिलोक्या युगसाहस्रं बहिराब्रह्मणो दिनम्।
तावत्येव निशा तातयन्निमीलति विश्वसृक्।
निशावसान आरब्धो लोककल्पोनुवर्तते।
यावद्दिनं भगवतो मनून् भुञ्जन् चतुर्दश।
स्वं स्वं कालं मनुर्भुङ्क्ते साधिकां ह्येकसप्ततिम्।
मन्वन्तरेषु मनवस्तद्वंशा ऋषयः सुराः।
भवन्ति चैव युगपत्सुरेशाश्चानु ये च तान्।
एष दैनंदिनः सर्गोब्राह्म त्रैलोक्यवर्तनः।
तिर्यङ् नृ पितृ देवानां सम्भवो यत्र कर्मभिः।
मन्वन्तरेषु भगवान् बिभ्रत्सत्वं स्वमूर्तिभिः।
मन्वादिभिरिदं विश्वमवत्युदित पौरुष।
तमोमात्रामुपादाय प्रतिसंरुद्धविक्रमः।

कालेनानुगताशेष आस्ते तूष्णीं दिनास्वये।
तमेवान्वपिधीयन्ते लोका भूरादयस्त्रयः।
निशायामनुवृत्तायां निर्मुक्तशशिभास्करम्।
त्रिलोक्यां दह्यमानायां शक्त्या सङ्कर्षणाग्निना।
यान्त्यूष्मणा महर्लोकाज्जनं भृग्वादयोर्दिताः।
तावत्त्रिभुवनं सद्यः कल्पान्तैधितसिन्धवः।
प्लावयन्त्युत्कटाटोप चण्डवातेरितोर्मयः।
अन्तः स तस्मिन् सलिल आस्तेऽनन्तासनो हरिः।
योगनिद्रानिमीलाक्षः स्तूयमानो जनालयैः।
एवं विधैरहोरात्रैः कालगत्योपलक्षितैः।
अपक्षितमिवास्यापि परमायुर्वयः शतम्।
यदर्धमायुषस्तस्य परार्धमभिधीयते।
पूर्वः परार्धोऽपक्रान्तो ह्यपरोद्य प्रवर्तते।
पूर्वस्यादौ परार्धस्य ब्राह्मो नाम महानभूत्।
कल्पो यत्राभवत् ब्रह्मा शब्दब्रह्मेति यं विदुः।
तस्यैवचान्ते कल्पोभूद्यंपाद्ममभिचक्षते।
यद्धरेर्नाभिसरस आसील्लोक सरोरुहम्।
अयन्तु कथितः कल्पो द्वितीयस्यापि भारत।
वाराह इति विख्यातो यत्रासीत्सूकरो हरिः।
कालोयं द्विपरार्धाख्यो निमेष उपचर्यते।
अव्याकृतस्यानन्तस्य अनादेर्जगदात्मनः।
कालोयं परमाण्वादि द्विपरार्धान्त ईश्वरः।
नैवेशितुं प्रभुर्भून्न ईश्वरो धाममनिनाम्॥

श्रीमद्भागवतम्॥

Q. No. III.

ब्राह्ममेकमहर्विप्राः कल्प इत्युच्यते बुधैः।
तावती रात्रिरित्युका ब्रह्मणः पण्डितोत्तमाः।
त्रिशतैः षष्टिभिः कल्पैर्ब्रह्मणो वर्षमीरितम्।
वर्षाणां यछतं तस्य द्विपरार्धमिहोच्यते ॥

स्कान्दपुराणम्॥ सूतसंहिता।

Quotation. No. I.

“Nimesha is the time taken to open and close the eyesin the normal condition. 1/4 of this is a Tuti; 2 Tutis make1 Lava; 2 Lavas make 1 Nimesha; 15 Nimeshas,. 1 Kashta;30 Kashtas, 1 Kala; 1/2 Kala, 1 Kshena; 2 Kshenas, 1 Muhurtha; 1/2 Muhurtha, 1 Ghatika by which everything ismeasured. 3¾ Ghatikas make 1 Sandhi; 2 Sandhis, 1Yama; 4 Yamas, the day time”.

The scale of time for the divisions of the day time startswith Nimesha or the twink-ling of the eye, one-fourth ofwhich is called Tuti, the lowest in the scale equal to about13 seconds. This is the scale for the ordinary calculation ofhuman time.

Q. No. II.

“The ultimate Bramhan is doubtless without form, without change, without attributes. The conception of thesmallest atoms or Paramanus as originating from this Bramhan is only a deductive inference. Both the Sthula and theSukshma forms of time are thus inferred. The smallestamount of time that pervades over a Paramanu is also calledParamanu. 2 Anus make 1 Paramanu and 3 Anus 1 Tresarenu which is the smallest atom that could be perceived inthe ray of sun’s light passing through a window. The timethat pervades over 3 Tresarenus is known as a Truti, 1/10of it is 1 Vedha; 3 Trutis, make 1 Lava; 3 Lavas, 1 Nimesha; 3 Nimeshas, 1 Kshena; 5 Kshenas, 1 Kashta; 15Kshenas, 1 Leghuta; 15 Leghutas, 1 Nadika; 2 Nadikas,1 Muhurta; 6 or 7 Nadikas, 1 Yama; 4 Yamas a day and4 Yamas one night. A Yama is measured by the flow ofone Presta of water through a small hole in a vessel. 15days make 1 Paksha, 2 Pakshas, 1 month or the day andnight of the Pitris. 2 months make 1 Rethu. 6 monthsmake 1 Ayana and 2 Ayanas, the Dekshina and Uttara37

make 1 year, the day and night of the Devas. 100 years isthe longivity of man. The universe including the planets,stars &c., is thus made up of Paramanus. Samvathsara,Parivatsara, Idavatsara, Anuvatsara and Vatsara are thevarieties of the year”.

“Vidura said— You have now described to me the divisions of time pertaining to man, Pitris and Devas. Kindlytell me the nature and method of calculation of time asapplying to others, who by their Yogic knowledge keep outof its limitations as just explained.

Mytreya said — The Yugas named Krita, Treta, Dwapara and Kali made up of 12,000 divine years apply to them.The Yugas consist of 4, 3, 2 and 1 thousand years, respectively, excluding 2000 years allowed for their mutual junctures Leaving the period for such junctions, the intervalsin which Dharma rules, is recognised by the wise as Yugas.This Dharma is complete in the Krita Yuga and diminishesby 1, 2 and 3 quarters respectively in the remaining Yugas.A thousand cycles of these four Yugas make one day forBramha, outside the first three Lokas. The same periodextends over his night. During the day time 14 Manus rulefor about 71 Chatur-yugas. each, during which Rishis andDevas are born. This is the daily creation by Bramha extending to the three Lokas. At the end of each day the threeLokas are burned down by the fire of Samkarshana andcovered by the ocean, agitated by the air. The Bhrigus andothers, at the time remove themselves from Mahar to Jenoloka. The days and nights of Bramha are thus calculatedup to 100 years as if his age is limited by that period.Half of his age is known as a Parardha. The first half ispassed which is called Bramha-kalpa when Bramha is knownas Sabda-bramhan. The second and the current half iscalled Padma-kalpa, owing to the lotus-earth that sprang

from Hari’s naval and is also known as Varaha-kalpa because Hari incarnated as a boar. These two Parardhas areafter all, in reality only a Nimesha of the Lord who is beginningless, endless and formless. The exhibition of his gloryextending from Paramanu to the two Parardhas, no mortalman given up to worldly desires can possibly comprehend”.

Q. No. III.

“The Bramha’s day and night are known as Kalpas. 366such days make one year for him and a hundred years socalculated make two Parardhas.”

The above quotations themselves tell more than theordinary story now prevailing about the divisions of Time asdetailed in our ancient literature. The calculation starts withthe smallest scientific atom which is multiplied and increasedin extent up to Parardhom. The atom virtually is a pointwithout dimensions and it creates only an idea of space. Theidea of Time is generated by calculating the time required forthought to pass from one point to another; and hence it isexactly the modern philosophical explanations of space andtime as co-existence and succession. From the Anu or atomat the bottom of the scale the calculation rises to the topmostfigure the Parardom, two of which makes a hundred years’life-time of Bramah the creator. There are Manwantarasand Yugas intervening, which are made up of years.The year is practically the highest figure that can becognised by its component parts, and it does not createany confusion so far, except perhaps in the application ofAyanas and Pakshas, the half-year and half-month as daysof Gods and Pitris respectively. We must however beginfrom the top of the scale, namely, Parardhom, to discover theclues for the correct interpretations of these uncommon andunknown terms in the calculation of time mentioned in thetexts.

In quotation 3, Vidura enquires of Mytreya regardingthe special kind of time, different from the human calculationjust explained, applicable to the working of those indifferentto worldly affairs, like the Yogis. The Yugas are then mentioned as referring to such time, in which the quantity ofDharna, is ascertained as their essential characteristics.

तमेवाहुर्युगं तज्ञा यत्र धर्मो विधीयते।

The Yugas according to the root meaning naturally applyto the work of the Yogis and fall under the Sukshma varietyof time. These Yugas have been already noticed in theprevious section as found only in the Bharata-varsha, thedevotional sphere of action for the religious man. The general significance of Yugas is thus clear at least so far as toits inapplicability to the years and centuries in A. D. or B.C.The error in the current interpretation of the Yugas, willbecome more evident from the special quotations, to followon the point. The difference between the first Parardha andthe second, the Bramha-kalpa and the Padma-kalpa shall beexplained in the next section on Personalities. We mayhowever safely note here that none of the modern interpreters have yet taken the trouble to enquire what a Parardhasignifies and whether any definition for the term is furnishedin our religious literature. How are they going to excusethemselves for this culpable mistake evidently caused byignorant pride and irresponsible prejudice? If they evercared to look into the sacred texts, they would not haveventured to play with our ancient religion in the mannerthey have done. The Pandit by his ignorant and irrelevantinterpretations, has unconsciously allowed more than sufficient room for the foreign critic to attack the acknowledgedworth of the literature from all its sides. In spite of theseunfortunate mistakes from two different quarters, the facttacitly remains that the majority of the educated and un-

educated Hindus are never satisfied with the Pandit’s explanations and are immensely annoyed at heart with the currentdestructive criticisms. That neither of these elucidations therefore contain anything sensible, useful or acceptable is virtually proved.

यदि सन्ति गुणाः पुंसां विकसन्त्येव केवलम्।
नहि कस्तूरिकामोदः शपथेन विभाव्यते॥

The following quotations explain the import of Parardha in the plainest language possible.

Quotation No. I.

गुणसाम्ये तदा तस्मिन् पुरुषेवात्मनि स्थिते।
प्राकृतः प्रलयो ज्ञेयो यावद्विश्व समुद्भवः।
ब्राह्मी रात्रिरियं प्रोक्तात्वहः सृष्टिरुदाहृता I
अहर्न विद्यते तस्य न रात्रिर्ह्युपचारतः॥

योयं संदृश्यते नित्यं लोके भूतक्षयस्त्विह।
नित्यः सङ्कीर्त्यते नाम्ना मुनिभिः प्रतिसञ्चरः।
ब्रह्मनैमित्तिको नाम कल्पान्ते यो भविष्यति।
त्रैलोक्यस्यास्य कथितः प्रतिसर्गो मनीषिभिः।
महदाद्यं विशेषान्तं यदा संयाति संक्षयम्।
प्राकृतः प्रतिसर्गोयं प्रोच्यते कालचिन्तकैः।
आत्यन्तिकस्तु कथितः प्रलयो ज्ञानसाधनः।
वाराहोवर्तते कल्यो यस्य विस्तर ईरितः।
असंख्यातास्तथा कल्पा ब्रह्मविष्णुशिवात्मकाः।
कथिता हि पुराणेषु मुनिभिः कालचिन्तकैः।
सात्विकेष्वथ कल्पेषु माहात्म्यमधिकं हरेः।
तामसेषु हरस्योक्तं राजसेषु प्रजापतेः।
योयं प्रवर्तते कल्पो वाराहस्सात्विको मतः॥

कूर्मपुराणम्।

Q. No. II.

अहस्तस्य तु या सृष्टिः प्रलयो रात्रिरुच्यते।
अहर्न विद्यते तस्य न रात्रिरिति धारणा।

उपचारः प्रक्रियते लोकानां हितकाम्यया॥

एकं कल्पसहस्रन्तु ब्रह्मणोऽब्दः प्रकीर्तितः।
एतदष्टसहस्रन्तु ब्रह्मणस्तद्युगं स्मृतम्।
एकं युगसहस्रन्तु सवनं तत्प्रजापतेः।
सवनानां सहस्रन्तु द्विगुणं त्रिवृतं तथा।
ब्रह्मणः स्थितिकालस्य चैतत् सर्वं प्रकीर्तितम्॥

कोटिकोटिसहस्राणि परार्ध इति कीर्त्यते।
परार्धद्विगुणञ्चापि परमाहुर्मनीषिणः।
एवमष्टादशैतानि स्थानानि गणना विधौ।
संख्यातस्तु परो ब्रह्मा तस्यार्धन्तु परार्धता।
संख्येयञ्चाप्यसंख्येयं सततञ्चापि तान्त्रिकम्।
संख्येयं संख्यया दृष्टम्अपरार्धाद्विभाव्यते।
राशौ दृष्टेन संख्यास्ति तदसंख्यस्य लक्षणम्॥

वायुपुराणम्॥

Q. No. III.

अथ प्राथमिकस्येह यः कालस्तदहः स्मृतम्।
सर्गस्य तादृशीरात्रिः प्राकृतस्य समासतः।
दिवा सृष्टिं विकुरुते रजन्यां प्रलयं विभुः।
औपचारिकमस्यैतदहोरात्रं न विद्यते।
पितामहस्याथ परः परार्धद्वयसम्मितः।
दिवा सृष्टन्तु यत्सर्वंनिशि नश्यति चास्य तत्।
भूर्भुवस्वर्महस्तत्र नश्यते चोर्ध्वतो न च।
रात्रौ चैकार्णवे ब्रह्मा नष्टे स्थावरजङ्गमे।
सुष्वापाम्भसि यस्तस्मान्नारायण इति स्मृतः॥

लिङ्गपुराणम्॥

Q. No. IV.

शतमाहुः परिवृढं सहस्रं परिपत्मकम्।
विज्ञेयमयुतं तस्मान्नियुतं प्रयुतं ततः।
अर्बुदं न्यर्बुदं चैव खर्बुदश्चततः स्मृतम्।

खर्वञ्चैव निखर्वश्च शङ्कुःपद्मं तथैव च।
समुद्रमन्त्यं मध्यञ्च परार्धञ्च परं ततः।
एवमष्टादशैतानि स्थानानि गणना विधौ।
शतादीनि विजानीयात् सांञ्जतानि महर्षिभिः।
कल्पसंख्या प्रवृत्तस्य परार्धोब्रह्मणः स्मृतः।
तावच्छेषोपि कालोस्य तस्यान्ते प्रतितिष्ठते।
पर एवपरार्धश्च संख्यातस्संख्यया मया।
यस्मादस्य परं वीर्यं परमायुः परं तपः।
परा शक्तिःपरो धर्मः परा विद्या परा धृतिः।
परं ब्रह्म परं ज्ञानं परमैश्वर्यमेव च।
तस्मात्परतरं भूतं ब्रह्मणो यन्नविद्यते।
परे स्थितो ह्येष परः सर्वार्थेषु ततः परम्।
संख्यातस्तु परो ब्रह्मा तस्यार्धस्य परार्धता।
संख्येयञ्चाप्यसंख्येयं सततञ्चापि तान्त्रिकम्।
संख्येयं संख्यया दृष्टम्अपरार्धाद्विभाष्यते।
राशौ दृष्टेन संख्यास्ति तदसंख्यस्य लक्षणम्।
आनन्त्यं सिकताद्येषु हृष्टं चान्यं त्वलक्षणम्।
ईश्वरैस्तत्प्रसंख्यानं शुद्धत्वाद्दिव्यदृष्टिभिः।
एवं ज्ञानप्रतिष्ठत्वात्सर्वं ब्रह्मानुपश्यति॥

ब्रह्माण्डपुराणम्॥

Q. No. V.

शक्तयः सर्वभावानामचिन्त्य ज्ञानगोचराः।
यत्ततो ब्रह्मणस्तास्तु सर्गाद्या भावशक्तयः।
उत्पन्नः प्रोच्यते विद्वान्नित्य एवोपचारतः।
निजेन स्वस्वमानेन आयुर्वर्षशतं स्मृतम्।
तत्पराख्यं परार्धञ्चतदर्धं परिकीर्तितम्॥

पद्मपुराणम्॥

Q. No. VI.

स्थानात् स्थानं शतगुणमेकैकं गण्यते द्विजाः।
ततोष्टादशमे भागे परार्धमभिधीयते।

परार्धे द्विगुणं यत्तु प्राकृतस्सलयो द्विजाः।
तदाऽव्यक्ते खिलं व्यक्तं सहेतौ लयमेति वैI
द्विपरार्धात्मकः कालः कथितो यो मया द्विजाः।
तदहस्तस्य विप्रेन्द्रा विष्णारीशस्य कथ्यते।
व्यक्ते तु प्रकृतौ लीने प्रकृत्यां पुरुषे तथा।
तत्रास्थिता निशा तस्य तत्प्रमाणा तपोधनाः।
नैवाहस्तस्य च निशा नित्यस्य परमात्मनः।
उपचारात्तथाप्येतत्तस्येशस्य तु कथ्यते।
इत्येष मुनिशार्दूलाः कथितः प्राकृतो लयः॥

ब्रह्मपुराणम्॥

Quotation. No. I.

“When the three gunas maintain their equilibrium, itis called Prakriti-laya or dissolution of Prakriti; and it ishere described as the night of Bramha. His day refers tothe divine creation here narrated. In reality, he has neithernight nor day. The annihilation of the material world isspoken of as Pratisanchara or re-absorption back into Prakriti. The destruction from the Mahat to the gross elements is called Pratisarga. Final and complete destructionor involution is secured only through gnana. The elaboratedescriptions given in the religious texts refer to the Varaha-kalya. Several such Kalpas pertaining to Vishnu, Rudraand Bramha are also mentioned in the Puranas by the Rishisin their treatment of Time. In the Satwic Kalpas, theglories of Vishnu are predominant, in the Rajasic, Bramha’sand in the Tamasic, Rudra’s. The current Varaha-kalpa isSatwic”.

It is plainly stated here that the division of time intothe days and nights of Bramha, alludes simply to his glories.The Prathisarga or secondary creation here mentioned refersdirectly to the involutionary processes by the annihilation ofmateriality.

महदाद्यं विशेषान्तं यदा संयाति संक्षयम्।
प्राकृतः प्रतिसर्गोयं प्रोच्यते कालचिनतकैः॥

The term refers to one of the five requirements of a Puranahardly understood by the Pandit.

सर्गश्च प्रतिसर्गश्च वंशो मन्वन्तराणि च।
वंशानुचरितं चैव पुराणं पञ्चलक्षणम्॥

Under the present state of ignorance, one need not evenbe astonished to hear some Pandits explaining Sarga andPratisarga as Chapters and Sections in a Purana. Thecurrent interpretation of Pratisarga as applying to materialcreation is therefore not only varying from truth, but diametrically opposed to it. However willingly and respectfully we may view the modern opinions, it is absolutelyhopeless to obtain even an atom of useful and correct information from them regarding the contents of our sacred texts.

Q. No. II.

“The creation described refers to his day and the dissolution to his night. Understand that he has neither nightnor day. They are so described in a complementary stylefor conveying the instruction to the religious public. Athousand Kalpas make 1 Abda of Bramha ; 8,000 Abdas,1 Yuga; 1,000 Yugas, 1 Savana; 6,000 Savanas representhis longivity. Koti into Koti into one thousand make oneParardha. Two Parardhas make one Parom. The seventeenth figure in the Arithmetical notation known as Parardhais mentioned as representing half the age of Bramha. Thehighest Arithmetical figure is here given only in accordancewith the Puranic method of description. A Parardha should therefore be properly interpreted as Aparardha or no Parardha, meaning infinity thereby”.

It is clearly explained here that a Paradha is the seventeenth and the highest figure in the Arithmetical Notationby multiples of one hundred, and that its application to theage of Bramha is in accordance with the Puranic formula.It is also stated as in the previous quotation that the daysand nights of Bramha are mere complementary descriptions.It is naturally feared that these facts would prove startlingnews to our enlightened interpreters.

Q. No. III.

“The creation by Bramha during the day and the dissolution in the night are only described in a complementarystyle. His age is specified as extending to two Parardhas. Whatever is created during the day dissolves when nightfalls. The four Lokas, Bhu, Bhuva, Swar and Mahar aredissolved at night, others above them are not affected. In thenight, when everything is covered by the ocean, Bramhasleeps in the waters, and then he is known as Narayana”.

This is a repetition of the facts already explained in thepreceding quotations. No Crìtic need now ingeniously devisespecious apologies for his sweeping remarks constantly made,as to the existence of contradictory statements in the religious texts. He has hardly seen for himself any statementsin their true light to enable him to judge of their contradictions or conformities. His traffic has all along beencarried on with the bankrupt of a Pandit and he could therefore show nothing to his own credit at present. He haspitiably failed in one of the fundamental requirements ofmerchandise, and it is now too late for him to brood over it.We have already noticed in the previous section that Bhuloka is stated to be far above this material earth, and wefind here that the creation and destruction attributed toBramha’s work apply only to the first four Lokas, from

Bhu to Mahar and therefore do not include this earthy globe.The ocean in which these four Lokas lie submerged duringthe night of Bramha, does not also form part of any of theoceans, seas or gulfs mentioned in our modern geography.Bramhas’ sleeping in the waters of this ocean is explained ashimself being converted into Narayana or Vishnu. This iscertainly an unbecoming statement to the delicate and keenear of the modern interpreters, but there is no help for it asit is so stated in the text. This point however will be explained in detail in the subsequent section on Personalities.

*** Q. No. IV.***

“Seventeen figures in the Arithmetical Notation, bymultiples of one hundred, are named by the Rishis as follows,Unit, hundred, ten thousand, Ayuta, Prayuta, Arbuda,Nyarbuda, Kharbuda, Kharva, Nikharva, Samku, Padma,Samudra, Antya, Madhya and Parardha. Two Parardhas make one Parom, thus there are eighteen figures. Two Parardhas are calculated for the two Kalpas or day and night ofBramah. The Parardha mentioned here denotes the higheststate imaginable, with regard to his power, longivity, tapas,Sakti, Dharma, knowledge, stability, Bramhatwa, gnanaand Iswarya. He is the highest and the noblest among thehigh and the noble. The Arithmetical finite figure given is in accordance with the Puranic method of description andsignifies infinity. The Parardha here actually means Aparardha or no Parardha and should be interpreted as beyondeven such an ultimate figure. His real nature is determinedby Eswaras with their pure and divine eyes. From this wemust understand that Gnana is the real foundation foreverything”.

Parardha is clearly explained here, as the highest figurein the Arithmetical notation by multiples of one hundred,and as denoting infinity in its application to the age of

Bramha. Both of these facts, the modern interpreters, haveprobably to learn now for the first time in their life. But without a study of the texts they knew for a long time, by,virtue of their own intellectual superiority, that Parardhaapplied to some early period in B. C. when Bramha was bornsomewhere in Tibet, and created India and their forefathersfor the propogation of the irrelevant and incoherent historyof the two dynasties that ruled over Oudh and Delhi. Whatan insolent and objectionable presumption concerning a subject, where one ought to tremble, before he makes bold tolay his hands upon ? Is there any evidence of intelligence,of religious spirit, of propriety or even of common sense inthis vandalic effort ?

गुणेषु क्रियतां यत्नः किमाटोपैःप्रयोजनम्।
विक्रीयन्ते न घण्डाभिर्गावः क्षीरविवर्जिताः॥

*** Q. No. V.***

“The Saktis or energies of creation &c., in Bramha,denote his innate nature, and are described as originated, only as a matter of complement. They can however beunderstood only by Gnana. His one hundred years of age,extending to Parom, and its half representing a Parardhaare only postulated, as a suggestion from man’s ownlongivity’.

The explanations here furnished are too plain andsimple to demand any commentaries. The age of Bramhaand his creations here described are thus religious conceptions, whose real signficance could be understood by theacquirement of Gnana. There is however not the slightestdoubt as to their inapplicability to any historical incidents taking place on the surface of this material earth.

*** Q. No. VI.***

“In the Arithmetical notation, eighteen places are namedby multiples of one hundred. The two Parardhas together

signify the Prakriti-laya, the involuion or merging of all theVyaktas into the Avyakta. This constitutes the day time ofVishnu, and when the Prakriti itself merges into the Purusha,it is the night of Vishnu. The eternal Vishnu however, has
neither night nor day. All this is simply stated in a complementary style. In this manner, the involutionary religiousprocesses up to Prakriti-laya are described”.

It is evident from this quotation that the two Parardhasof Bramha combined, complete the Prakriti-laya or the annihilation of finite conceptions. Here, Bramha’s jurisdictionends and Vishnu’s begins. The merging of Prakriti itselfinto the Purusha, is described as the night of Vishnu.These Puranic narrations in the texts are repeatedly assuredto be complementary descriptions, to avoid chances of misinterpretation.

इत्येष मुनिशार्दूलाःकथितः प्राकृतो लयः॥

Has the Critic, Pandit or Theosophist ever looked into theseexplanatory passages before they ventured to convert thecontents of the sacred religious texts into an insignificanthistory of the mortal man? For aught we know, the foreignCritic is sincere in his curiosity to understand the contents ofIndian religious literature. But the microscopic minorityof apish imitators among the educated Hindus are completely wanting in the sincerety and the curiosity of the Critic,when they volunteer to confirm and strengthen the Critic’sviews by their authoritative opinions as Hindus. It ispractically deception and misleading, when such confirmations are based upon entire ignorance of and culpable indifference to the subject. An educated Hindu of this typehas however the least claim to style himself a representativeof the religious and learned Hindus in the land. He isdoubtless responsible for his misleading the foreign patron

and betraying his own sacred religion in false colours to thediscredit of his fellowmen, besides subjecting himself to hisown religious deterioration. It is a pitiable truth that theso-called religious reformers of the modern day are mostly tobe found among this class. It is also a wonder how suchmen shamelessly take a pride in calling themselves benefactors of their countrymen, when they by their ignominious conduct only succeed in displaying their moral andintellectual weakness, religious indifference and want ofcharacter and self-respect. Whatever might be the apparenttemporary benefits acquired personally, the attempt as awhole being entirely a deviation from the right path, isinevitably doomed to fail in the long run, and it would betoo late then, to rue for the mistakes consciously committed.

यावत्स्वस्थमिदं शरीरमरुजं यावज्जरा दूरतो
यावच्चेन्द्रियशक्तिरप्रतिहता यावत् क्षयोनायुषः।
आत्मश्रेयसि तावदेव विदुषा कार्यः प्रयत्नो महान्
सन्दीप्ते भवने तु कूपखनने प्रत्युद्यमः कीदृशः॥

** 3**. The above quotations conclusively prove that thewhole affair is a simple rendering of the Infinite in thelanguage of the Finite, the abstract fact in the form of theconcrete Arithmetic for the express purpose of showing theimmensity and magnitude of the object described. TheParardhom is the 17th and the last figure in the Arithmetical Notation reckoned by multiples of one hundred, insteadof ten. Parom means great and Ardhom position. Thus,the highest state of existence to be attained is explained bythe height, the present low, degraded and mortal man has to ascend by strenuous efforts and religious devotion. Thehundred years making up a Bramha’s period are clearlystated in Quotaion V, as having been predicted in accordance with the longivity of man himself. This period is divided

into two exact halves consisting of 50 years each. Thecurrent time is represented as the beginning of the latterhalf. The applications of these divisions and variations ofTime could be easily understood when references to the’Personalities’ are examined in the subsequent section. Itmay however be noted here that the former half points tothe Gnana and Upasana processes and the latter to the Yogaand Karma processes.

वेदो ब्रह्मा इति शृतिः II

The Vedas are represented by Bramah and they prescribethe above two methods conforming to the capacities of manfor the attainment of salvation. Next to Parardhom, theManwantaras and Yugas have to be examined. The day ofBramha which covers all ideas of religious creation and existence is divided into 14 Manwantaras consisting of 1,000Chatur-yugas or cycles of four Yugas, each Manwantara extending to about 71 Chatur-yugas. The interval of timeelapsing between two Manus is called a Manwantara and itcan be better explained while treating of Manus themselves.Besides, the examination of the meanings of Yugas will alsothrow some light upon the calculation of a Manwantara. Asearching enquiry may therefore be first made with regardto the Yugas. The subjoined quotaions are I fear likely tofrighten our self-constituted interpreters out of their wits.

Quotation. No. 1.

सत्वं कृतं रजस्त्रेता द्वापरन्तु रजस्तमौ।
कलौ तमस्तु विज्ञेयं युगवृत्तवशेन तु।
अप्रवृत्तिः कृतयुगे कर्मणोः शुभपापयोः।
वर्णाश्रमव्यवस्थाश्च न तदासन्न सङ्करः।
कृते पुनःक्रिया नास्ति कुत एवाकृतक्रिया।
सकृदेवकृतं सर्वं यद्वैलोके कृताकृतम्॥

वायुपुराणम्॥

Q. No. II.

चत्वारि भारते वर्षे युगानिकवयोऽब्रुवन्।
कृतं त्रेता द्वापरञ्च कलिश्चान्यत्र न क्वचित्।
ध्यानं तपः कृतयुगे त्रेतायां ज्ञानमुच्यते।
द्वापरे यज्ञमेवाहुर्द्दानमेकं कलौ युगे।
आद्ये कृते तु धर्मोस्ति स त्रेतायां प्रवर्तते।
द्वापरे व्याकुलीभूत्वा प्रणश्यति कलौ युगे।

कूर्मपुराणम्॥

Q. No. III.

चत्वारि भारते वर्षे युगानि मुनिपुङ्गवाः।
कृतं त्रेता द्वापरञ्च कलिश्च द्विजसत्तमाः।
पूर्वं कृतयुगं नाम ततस्त्रेतायुगं द्विजाः।
तत्पश्चाद्वापरञ्चाथ ततस्तिष्यः प्रवर्तते।
चत्वारि तु सहस्राणि वर्षाणां मुनिपुङ्गवाः।
आयुःसंख्या कृतयुगे संख्याता हि तपो धनाः।
तथा त्रीणि सहस्राणि त्रेतायामायुषो विदुः।
द्वे सहस्रे द्वापरे तु भुवि तिष्ठन्ति साम्प्रतम्।
न प्रमाणस्थितिर्ह्यस्ति तिष्ये तु मुनिपुङ्गवाः।
गर्भस्थाश्च म्रियन्तेऽत्र तथा जाता म्रियन्ति च॥

पद्मपुराणम्॥

Q. No. IV.

यथा हानिक्रमं प्राप्तास्तथा ऋद्धिक्रमं गताः।
प्रगृहीते ततो धर्मे प्रपश्यंति कृतं युगम्।
साधुवृत्तिः कृतयुगे कषाये हानिरुच्यते।
एक एव तु कालोयं हीनवर्णो यथा शशी।
छन्नश्च तमसा सोमो यथा कलियुगं तथा।
मुक्तश्च तमसा सोमः एवं कृतयुगञ्च तत्।
अर्थवादः परं ब्रह्म वेदार्थ इति तं विदुः।
अविविक्तमविज्ञातं दायाद्यमिह धार्यते।

इष्टवादस्तपो नाम तपो हि स्थविरीकृतः।
गुणैः कर्माभिनिर्वृत्तिर्गुणाःशुध्यन्तिकर्मणा॥

ब्रह्मपुराणम्॥

Q. No. V.

हनूमानुवाच।

कृतं नाम युगं श्रेष्ठं यत्र धर्मः सनातनः।
कृतमेव न कर्तव्यं तस्मिन् काले युगोत्तमे।
न तत्र धर्माःसीदन्ति क्षीयन्ते न च वै प्रजाः।
ततः कृतयुगं नाम कालेन गुणतां गतम्।
देवदानवगन्धर्वयक्षराक्षस पन्नगाः।
नासन् कृतयुगे तात तदा न क्रयविक्रयः।
न साम ऋग्यजुर्वर्णाः क्रिया नासीच्च मानवी।
अभिध्याय फलं तत्र धर्मः सन्यास एव च।
न तस्मिन् युगसंसर्गे व्याधयो नेन्द्रियक्षयः।
नासूयानापि रुदितं न दर्पोनापि वैकृतम्।
न विग्रहः कुतस्तन्द्री न द्वेषो न च पैशुनम्।
न भयं नापि संन्तापो न चेर्ष्या न च मत्सरः।
ततः परमकं ब्रह्म सा गतिर्योगिनां परा।
आत्मा च सर्वभूतानां शुक्लो नारायणस्तदा।
आत्मयोगसमायुक्तो धर्मोयं कृतलक्षणः।
कृते युगे चतुष्पादश्चातुर्वर्ण्यस्य शाश्वतः।
एतत्कृतयुगं नाम त्रैगुण्य परिवर्जितम्।
त्रेतामपि निबोध त्वं यस्मिन् सत्रं प्रवर्तते।
पादेन हसते धर्मो रक्ततां याति चाच्युतः।
सत्यप्रवर्ताश्च नराः क्रियाधर्म परायणाः।
ततो यज्ञाः प्रवर्तन्ते धर्माश्च विविधाः क्रियाः।
त्रेतायां भावसङ्कल्पाः क्रियादानफलोपगाः।
प्रचलन्ति न वै धर्मात्तपोदान परायणाः।
स्वधर्मस्थाःक्रियावन्तो नरास्त्रेतायुगे भवन्॥

द्वापरे च युगे धर्मो द्विभागो न प्रवर्तते॥

विष्णुर्वैपीततां याति चतुर्धा वेदएव च।
ततोऽन्ये च चतुर्वेदास्त्रिवेदाश्च तथापरे।
द्विवेदाश्चैकवेदाश्चाप्यनृचश्चतथापरे I
एवं शास्त्रेषु भिन्नेषु बहुधा नीयते क्रिया।
तपोदानप्रवृत्ता च राजसी भवति प्रजा।
एकवेदस्य चाज्ञानाद्वेदास्ते बहवः कृताः।
सत्यस्य चेह विभ्रंशात्सत्ये कश्चिदवस्थितः।
सत्यात्प्रच्यवमानानां व्याधयो बहवोऽभवन्।
कामाश्चोपद्रवाश्चैव तदा वै दैवकारिताः।
यैरर्द्यमाना सुभृशं तपस्तप्यन्ति मानवाः।
कामकामाःस्वर्गकामा यज्ञांस्तन्वन्ति चापरे।
एवं द्वापरमासाद्य प्रजाः क्षीयन्त्यधर्मतः।
पादेनैकेन कौन्तेय धर्मः कलियुगे स्थितः।
तामसं युगमासाद्य कृष्णो भवति केशवः।
वेदाचाराः प्रशाम्यन्ति धर्मयज्ञक्रियास्तथा।
ईतयो व्याधयस्तन्द्री दोषाः क्रोधादयस्तथा।
उपद्रवाः प्रवर्तन्ते आधयो व्याधयस्तथा।
युगेष्वावर्तमानेषु धर्मो व्यावर्तते पुनः।
धर्मे व्यावर्तमाने तु लोको व्यावर्तते पुनः।
लोके क्षीणे क्षयं यान्ति भावा लोकप्रवर्तकाः।
युगक्षयकृता धर्माः प्रार्थनानि विकुर्वते॥

महाभारतं वनपर्व॥

Q. No. VI.

कालो वा कारणं राज्ञो राजा वा कालकारणम्।
इति ते संशयो माभूद्राजा कालस्य कारणम्।
दण्डनीत्यां यदा राजा सम्यक्कार्त्स्नेन वर्तते।
तदा कृतयुगं नाम कालः श्रेष्ठः प्रवर्तते।
भवेत् कृतयुगे धर्मोनाधर्मो विद्यते क्वचित्।
योगक्षेमाः प्रवर्तन्ते प्रजानां नात्र संशयः।

प्रसीदन्ति नराणाश्च स्वरवर्णमनांसि च।
दण्डनीत्या यदा राजा त्रीनंशाननुवर्तते।
चतुर्थमंशमुत्सृज्य तदा त्रेता प्रवर्तते।
अधर्मस्य चतुर्थांश स्त्रीनंशाननुवर्तते I
अर्धे त्यक्त्वा यदा राजा नीत्यर्धमनुवर्तते।
ततस्तु द्वापंर नाम स कालःसम्प्रवर्तते।
अशुभस्य यदात्वर्धं द्वावंशावनुवर्तते।
दण्डनीतिं परित्यज्य यदा कार्त्स्न्येन भूमिपः।
प्रजाः क्लिश्नात्ययोगेन प्रवर्तेन तदा कलिः।
कलावधर्मो भूयिष्ठो धर्मो भवति न क्वचित्।
योगक्षेमस्य नाशश्च वर्तते वर्णसङ्करः।
राजा कृतयुगस्रष्टा त्रेतायां द्वापरस्य च।
युगस्य च चतुर्थस्य राजा भवति कारणम्।
कृतस्य कारणाद्राजा स्वर्गमत्यन्तमश्नुते।
त्रेतायाः कारणाद्राजा स्वर्गं नात्यन्तमश्नुते।
प्रवर्तनाद्वापरस्य यथाभागमुपाश्नुते।
कले प्रवर्तनाद्राजा पापमत्यन्तमश्नुते॥

कृतं त्रेता द्वापरश्च कलिश्च भरतर्षभ।
राजवृत्तानि सर्वाणि राजैव युगमुच्यते॥

देवदेवो महादेवः कारणं जगतः परम्।
लोकसन्धारणार्थञ्चलोकसङ्करनाशनम्।
आत्मानमात्मना दण्डं ससृजे देवसत्तमः।
तस्माच्च धर्मचरणान्नीतिंदेवीं सरस्वतीम्।
असृजत् दण्डनीतिं वै त्रिषु लोकेषु विश्रुताम्।
यथासौ नीयते दण्डः सततं पापकारिषु।
दण्डस्य नयनात्साहि दण्डनीतिरिहोच्यते॥

शान्तिपर्व।

Q. No. VII.

चतुष्पादो हि धर्मस्य ज्ञानं ध्यानं शमो दमः।
आत्मज्ञानं स वै ज्ञानं ध्यानमध्यात्मचिन्तनम्।

मनः स्थिरत्वञ्च शमः दमस्तित्वन्द्रियनिग्रहः।
