यदा धर्मो भवेद्वृद्धः तदायुश्च विवर्धते॥

भविष्यपुराणम्॥

Q. No. VIII.

धर्मश्चतुष्पात्सम्पूर्णो वृषरूपधरश्चरन्।
पाति लोकानिमान् मूर्तस्तस्मै धर्माय वै नमः।
सत्यं दया तथा शान्तिरहिंसा चेति कीर्तिताः।
धर्मस्यावयवास्तात चत्वारः पूर्णतां गताः।
स्वल्पमप्यस्य धर्मस्य त्रायते महतो भयात्।
यथा स्वल्पमधर्मं हि जनयेत्तु महाभयम्॥

बृहद्धर्मपुराणम्॥

Quotation. No. I.

“In & treatinent of the history of the Yugas, Krita isSatwa; Treta is Reja; Dwapara is a combination of Rejaand Tama; and Kali is Tama. In the Krita, there is noaction of any kind, good or bad, all that has to be done inthe Lokas having been already done. There are also nodivisions of castesandAsramas, and no intermixtures”.

The Pundit, in his usual style, is sure to rush in here,with his thoughtless interpretations. If theYugas refer tosome ancient periods in the history of man, as he, the Criticand the Theosophistwould wish to establish, will they tellus how man could exist in the Krita, as described here,without actions of any kind? If again the Critic and Theosophist want to prove the non-existence of castes and Asramas in ancient days like the Krita, will they explain whythe absence of admixture is specially noticed ? The actionsgood or bad, said to have been already accomplished in Krita,are those pertaining to the various religious Lokas, whoselist has been already found to exclude this material earth.

सकृदेवकृतं सर्व यद्वै लोके कृताकृतम्॥

It is therefore certain that neither the transactions of theworldly man, nor the distinctions of Indian castes, nor againthe utility and urgency of destroying them, by interdiningand intermarrying, are here spoken of. Every layman ofordinary common sense can easily infer from every word inthis quotation, that both the current interpretations, andcriticisms, proceed from sheer ignorance of the subject andfrom an unbecoming spirit of unnecessary interference. Thesubsequent quotations are sure to exhibit this fact in strongerlight. The modern methods of explaining the subject for theenlightenment of the religious public are therefore extremelydistressing and ruinous.

ये संसत्सुविवादिनः परयशः शल्येन शूलाकुलाः
कुर्वन्ति स्वगुणस्तवेन गुणिनां यत्नात् गुणाच्छादनम्।
तेषां रोषकषायितोदरदृशां कोपोष्ण निःश्वासिनाम्
दीप्तारत्नशिखेव कृष्णफणिनां विद्या जनोद्वेगिनी॥

Q. No. II.

“The wise say that there are four Yugas in the Bharata-varsha and that they are nowhere else. Dhyana and tapasin the Krita; Gnana in the Treta; Yegna in the Dwaparaand Dana alone in the Kali are specified. In the first Krita,Dharma exists, it is manifested in Treta, it is distracted inDwapara and destroyed in Kali”.

The Pandit here is extremely happy to note that noneof the Yugas get out of Bharata-varsha.He preservesthem within the boundaries of his India. The Theosophistof course is prepared to go over this spot for his use of theYugas. The foreign Critic will surely get bewildered here.If Yugas allude to the periods of human history, why shouldother nations outside India be deprived of their benefit? Probably other nations in the world, were never affected by

the trammels of time, in ancient days. Different states ofDharma are stated to be the distinguishing characteristics ofthe Yugas. In the Krita however, this Dharma is not evenmanifested, it remains latent. Is there any modern interpretation available to make this statement intelligible? As times advance, why is this Dharma said to deteriorate anddwindle to nothing especially in these modern days of civilization and progress? Perhaps it is so described in uncivilized times. Will the Pandit at least tell us why Dyana,tapas, gnana and Yegna are uncourteously excluded from
Kali, when so many of his learned colleagues are found allover India? What is the harm if the present generation inKali take to any of these religious processes, and could the Pandit assure that no one in India is violating this rule?

My good God ! it is indeed a wonder why no answersare forthcoming for any of these pertinent questions, fromany of the quarters from which we had so much noisehitherto.

नैर्मल्यं वपुषस्तवास्ति वसतिः पद्माकरे जायते
मन्दं याहि मनोरमां वद गिरं मौनं न सम्पादय।
धन्यस्त्वं बकराजहंसपदवीं प्राप्तोसि किं तैर्गुणै-
र्नीरक्षीरविभागकर्म निपुणाशक्तिः कथं लभ्यते॥

Q. No. III.

“There are four Yugas in the Bharata-varsha, namely,Krita, Treta, Dwapara and Tishya. The longivity isreckoned as 4,000 years in Krita, 3,000 in Treta and 2,000in Dwapara. In the Tishya, it is uncertain, death occurringsometimes in the womb or soon after birth’.

Why is the much despised Kali called Tishya heremeaning auspicious or fortunate? In this quotation also, thefour Yugas are mentioned as found only in Bharata-varshaIf, in the current Kali, even the chances of living are so pre-

carious, as described here, why not the Pandit get out of his India to be free from its clutches? Again, does he believe that his forefathers lived for four, three and two thousand years respectively in the three previous Yugas, as described here, and if he does, has he any sort of proof to establish the same? On the other hand, will the Critic or Theosophist accept this description, and if not why? These are surely natural questions arising from the modern interpretation of the passage here quoted. If no reasonable answers are available from any of these so-called interpreters, how are we bound to accept their interpretation, while they invariably bring with them unmerited disrepute to the sacred texts as well as to their venerable authors? The interpretations of these self-made authorities are certainly not more valuable to us than the religious texts, and themselves not so venerable as the ancient Rishis.

लौकिकानां हि साधूनामर्थं वागनुवर्तते।
ऋषीणां पुनराद्यानां वाचमर्थोऽनुधावतिII

Q. No. IV.

“The advent of exaltation is also like the coming in of deterioration. When Dharma is well attained, the Krita Yuga is clearly seen. Goodness is the ruling principle in the Krita, it is lost in the Kashaya or Kali. Time is unchanging like the moon, which when veiled by darkness is Kali and when unveiled is Krita. The inseparable and unknowable Parom-bramhan is the Arthavada or object in view in the Vedas. The approved and valid process for obtaining it, is Tapas, and that is confirmed here. Cessation of Karmas is attained by meritorious virtues, which in themselves are purified by Karmas”.

It is clearly stated here, that the realisation of Bramhan is the chief aim of the teachings in the Vedas, and that the

proper process for it is Tapas. The absence of Tapas isspecified as Kali, Kashaya or confusion. The removal ofthis confusion, Tama or Agnana produces Krita. The important scope and extent of Tapas, and its different stages ofattainment are here established by the division of the Sukshma and religious time into four Yugas. It is repeatedlyassured that these Yugas are not found outside the limits ofBharata-varsha. This is an additional corroboration for thefact that Bharata-varsha refers to the devotional sphere ofreligious Karmas and that the Yugas explain the degrees ofperfection attained therein. The devotional sphere is therefore described as space in the Puranic style and the Yugasas time.

Q. No. V.

“Krita is the greatest of the Yugas, where eternalDharma is complete, having no more to be done. In theKrita, there are no Devas, Danavas, Yekshas, Rakshasas andPannagas; there is no buying no selling; no difference ofVedas and no human action. The Dharma is Sanyasa.Pertaining to this Yuga, there is no disease, no weakness ofthe senses, no laziness, no pride, no prejudice, no fear, nogrief, no quarrel. The highest Bramhan is the ultimateattainment for the Yogis in this Yuga. The Atman is inthe form of Narayana, pure and white, and Atma-yoga isthe distinguishing characteristic of this Yuga. The threegunas are here absent and Dharma has its four quarterscomplete. In the Treta, Vishnu becomes red and a quarterof Dharına is lost. Tapas, Dana, Satya, Yegna, Swadharma and religious Karma remain firm in Treta. In theDwapara half the Dharma is lost and Vishnu becomes brown.On account of the ignorance of the single Veda, it is dividedinto four, some taking to three, some to two or one andsome to none of them. Some fall from Satya or truth and

consequently diseases and misfortunes result. Dharma greatlydeteriorates and Yegnas are performed to obtain Swargaand to satisfy worldly desires. In the Kali, only one quarterof Dharma remains and Vishnu becomes dark. Dharma,Yegna and Achara dwindle to nothing. Diseases, misfortunes, sorrows, anger, laziness &c. arise. As the Yugasrevert, Dharma also reverts with the Lokas. The Lokasappear by meditation and when the Lokas disappear, everything deteriorates and spoils”.

The Yugas are here distinguished by the different degrees of Dharma prevailing. In the Krita it is completelyfinished, nothing more having to be done. It is clearlystated here that in the form of human action there is absolutely nothing in this Yuga, ‘क्रियानासीच्च मानवी’IAtma-yoga is said to be the distinguishing characteristic of theKrita Yuga.

आत्मयोगसमायुक्तो धर्मोऽयं कृतलक्षणः॥

These are extremely plain and unambiguous statementswhich will not in the least permit of the modern interpretation, as alluding to the historical periods of Hiudu, Mahamaden or European soverigns in India. The Pandit’s interpretation here displays his utter ignorance of the subjectand utter lack of common sense. It might perhaps suggest,by the laws of association, the funny slokas in Sanskritknown as Anterlapika.

का पाण्डुपत्नी गृहभूषणं किं को रामशत्रुः किमगस्त्यजन्म।
कः सूर्यपुत्रो विपरीतपृच्छा कुन्तीसुतो रावणकुम्भकर्णः॥

If the Pandit is still anxious to understand the Yugas ashistorical periods, he may have the consolation of knowingthat the Krita Yuga refers to the history of every Yogi

practising Atma-yoga in which all human affairs now worrying the Pandit’s brain are entirley annihilated. The practice of the lower forms of Yoga is described as representingthe three remaining Yugas. It is a noteworthy fact herethat the single Veda has to be divided into four by theadvent of Dwapara. Again another important fact noticedin this quotation is that meditation brings on the Lokas andthat when the Lokas are gone everything deteriorates.

लोके क्षीणे क्षयं यान्ति भावालोकप्रवर्तकाः॥

Have the modern interpreters any explanation to offer herefor our enlightenment? There is no poetical fancy nor anyexaggeration here. These are the only two expressionsyet known to them to cover their ignorance. They mustconfess here that the description is entirely unmeaning. Itcannot but be so, as the whole subject is misunderstood fromits very commencement. It is also a vain belief that theyhave understood anything before or after this passage. Thosewho understand the real nature of the subject can clearlyunderstand that every line in the text is completely misunderstood at present. Every school boy knows that arithmetic is not geography. The Pandit evidently knows neitherarithmetic nor geography and it is no wonder therefore thathe confounds the two together in his presumptuous attemptto explain an unknown subject.

Q. No. VI.

“You need not foster the least doubt as to whether thenature of time depends upon the character of the Raja, orthe character of the Raja depends upon the nature of time.The nature of time is entirely shaped by the character of theRaja. The four Yugas named Krita, Treta, Dwapara andKali allude to the history of the Raja; in fact, the Raja ishimself the Yuga. When the Raja enforces Denda-niti orjustice completely, it is called Krita the best of the Yugas.

Dharma is unabated and Yoga is safe in Krita. Voice,colour and mind are then highly developed. When three-quarters of justice are enforced, the Treta is originated. Whentwo-quarters of justice are enforced, the Dwapara is originated. When no justice at all is enforced, Kali is originated.Then, there is no Dharma and no safety for Yoga. Thecastes get intermixed. The Raja is actually the creator ofKrita, Treta, Dwapara and Kali. By creating Krita, heobtains the highest heaven and by creating Kali, he obtainsthe deepest hell. By the creation of the other two Yugas,he obtains the proportionate happiness. Mahadeva, the godof the gods, created from his own Atma, the Denda, for thepurpose of sustaining the Lokas and for preventing their admixture. From the quarters of Dharma he created alsothe goddess Saraswati called Niti. She directs the Dendalike punishment towards offenders and is therefore knownas Danda-niti”.

Now, let us look into the gist of the whole description.The different Yugas are said to take their names accordingto the amount of Denda-niti or justice enforced by the Raja.The Raja is independent of time, but time is entirely dependent on him. This directly contradicts the modern interpretations of Yugas even as Sthula time. That almost throughout the religious texts Sukshma time is dealt with as alreadyexplained here, is probably a new lesson to these interpreters. The Raja and Denda-niti are of course technical termshere used. The Denda and Niti are mentioned as creationsof Mahadeva. Have the Pandit, Critic or Theosophist anything to say against this quotation from the Maha-bharata,which undoubtedly puts them all to complete shame? Wehave already found that there is no human action in theKrita-yuga. If therefore Denda-niti means criminal justicein accordance with the modern interpretation, there is absolutely no relevancy in describing its complete enforcement.

in the Krita Yuga. Either Krita is not Krita, or Dendaniti is not criminal justice. These are then the two horns ofthe dilemma, in which the self-made authorities and Critics have inevitably landed themselves. The pretended knowledge and the assumed competency to interpret or criticise,could not be possibly concealed, when unexpectedly theproper time arrives for their naked exposure.

कृष्णं वपुर्वहतु चुम्बतुसत्फलानि
रम्येषु संवसतु चूतवनान्तरेषु।
पुंस्कोकिलस्य चरितानि करोतु कामम्
काकः कलध्वनिविधौ स तु काक एव॥

Q. Nos. VII & VIII.

“The four quarters of Dharma are Gnana, Dhyana,Sama and Dema. Gnana is the knowledge of the Atman.Dhyana is the meditation of Atman. Sama is stability ofmind and Dema is control of the senses. When Dharmaincreases, longivity increases. Dharma in the form of a bull,with its sound four legs roams about protecting the Lokas-Adoration to that holy form ! The four limbs of Dharmaare the perfect states of truth, kindness, peace of mind andharmlessness. The attainment of an atom of such Dharmasaves us from the greatest fears, exactly as addiction to alittle of Adharma is productive of much fear”.

The four quarters of Dharma are here stated to be thestandards by which the Yugas are determined and they areexplained as consisting of Dyana, Gnana, Sama and Dema.Dharma is generally described as a Vrisha or bull. Vrishaitself means Dharma in the Sanskrit language. Pada inthe same way means one fourth as well as a foot or leg inSanskrit and in the Indian vernaculars. The Pundit feelshighly elated at the opportunities here offered in the description of Dharma. He would have his Dharma in the form

of an actual bull the biggest and fairest obtainable in Indiaand would like to establish that, that is the correct and onlymeaning for the Puranic description. In the same way, hemust establish that the Yugas have their distinguishingfeatures in some concrete form and that they should be confined within the boundaries of India. Time as ordinarilyunderstood by human beings is an abstract idea whichcannot be dealt with as the Pandit handles it. It isclearly stated here that the names of Yugas signify thenature of the work done by the pious and the religious inin the field of Dharma, and the Pandit simply exhibits hisperverse obstinacy and lamentable ignorance in his interpretation of the subject. Gnana, Dhyana, Sama, Dema,truthfulness, control of the senses &c. are not certainly thequalities of time. He is however most anxious to establishthat the venerable authors of the sacred texts are not muchwiser than the wise-acres of his type.

वीणेवश्रोत्रहीनस्य लोलाक्षीव विचक्षुषः।
व्यसोःकुसुममालेव विद्यास्तब्धस्य निष्फला॥

** 4.** The words Yuga and Yoga are almost synonymous. To couple, to unite, or join the Jivathma with theParamatma, the lower self with the higher self is the ideapervading all these descriptions. The degrees of perfectionattained in this direction are explained with reference to thedefinite processes prescribed for the purpose. The KritaYuga expresses the stage of completion as the word Kritaclearly denotes. The appellations Kali, Thishya, Kashayaand Thamasa for the last Yuga are equally significant of theentire absence of religious merit. It is called the currentYuga as the instructions in the texts are naturally supposedto be always addressed to the ignorant and irreligious populace in general and are meant for their benefit. The following passages already quoted in Chaper I specifying the first

day of Kali as the date on which Sri Krishna quitted theearth, are indicative also of the loss of belief even in thetheory of the existence of a God consequent on therampantmaterialism prevailing all over the world, apart from theirtechnicalreference.

यस्मिन्नहनि यर्ह्येव भगवानुत्ससर्जगाम्।
तदैवेहानुवृत्तो सावधर्मप्रभवः कलिः॥

श्रीभागवतम्।

यस्मिन् दिने हरिर्यातो दिवं सन्त्यज्य मेदिनीम्।
तस्मिन्नेवावतीर्णोयं कालकायो बली कलिः॥

विष्णुपुराणम्॥

The main points of distinction in the four Yugas lie in theamount of Dharma prevailing, none being found in Kali.There is no ‘Yogakshema’ or prosperity for Yoga nor Yogaitself in Kali. It stands aloof from the rest as the worst inthe list and lowest in the scale of religious advancement.Half the quantity of Dharma prevails in Dwapara Yugaand three-fourths in Treta Yugs, as the words Dwapara andTreta themselves signify. Quotation VII clearly enumeratesthe four parts of Dharma as consisting of Gnana, Dhyana,Sama and Dema. Quotation VI, explains that the reckoning of the Yugas entirely depends upon the proportionateenforcement of criminal justice, Denda-niti. In fact thehistory of the Raja is said to be the specification of the Yuga.This is the Puranic method of description. The Raja, as
stated in the preceding pages, is the Atma or self seated inthe car or body. The horses are the senses, mind the reinsand intellect the charioteer.

आत्मानं रथिनं विद्धि शरीरं रथमेव तु।
इन्द्रियाणि हयान्याहुः मनः प्रग्रहमवे च।
बुद्धिन्तु सारथिं विद्यात्॥

The Danda-niti or criminal justice requires some explanation. It refers to the Yogic process prescribed for annihilating the external Vasanas. The Danda is the spinal cord with its plexes for meditation, as we have already noticed.

The most important item in the description determiningthe characteristic differences of the Yugas is the duration oftime detailed for each of them. A careful examination ofthe formulas and a correct calculation in accordance withthem, will, 1 confidently hope easily convince every readerthat the gist of the whole matter is far removed from thecommon interpretations as well as from those attempted bythe help of modern material sciences. The Sukshma andSthula classifications of time should be distinctly kept in the calculation, the former technically applying to the experiences and attainments of the Yogic processes and the latter tothe ordinary reckoning of days, months and years. In therendering of the Sukshma into the Sthula the formulas aregiven in the passages already quoted.

श्वासैस्तु त्रुटिभिः प्राणो घटिका प्राणषड्ककै।
अहोरात्रं ततः षष्टि घटिकादिर्विशेषतः॥

Three breaths make one Prana and six Pranas make oneSukshma Ghatika. Further calculations go by the samenumbers both for Sukshma and Sthula. 60 Sthula-Ghatikasmake 1 Sthula day; similarly 60 Suksma Ghatikas make1 Sukshma day. Again,

पिङ्गलायाःइडायान्तु प्राणसंक्रमणं मुने।
तदुत्तरायणं प्रोक्तं मुने वेदान्तवेदिभिः।
इडायाः पिङ्गलायान्तु प्राणसंक्रमणं मुने।
दक्षिणायनमित्युक्तं पिङ्गलायामिति श्रुतिः॥

The passing of breath from right to left, that is inhalingthrough the right nostril and exhaling through the left is

technically known amongst Yogis as Uttarayana, and viceversa as Dekshinayana, both of them together making aSukshma year.

Further,

प्राणापानवशो जीवो ह्यधश्चोर्ध्वं प्रधावति।
वामदक्षिणमार्गेण चञ्चलत्वान्नदृश्यते।
हकारेण बहिर्याति सकारेण विशेत् पुनः।
हंस हंसेत्यमुं मन्त्रं जीवो जपति सर्वदा।
शतानि षट् दिवारात्रं सहस्राण्येकविंशतिः।
एतत्संख्यान्वितं मन्त्रं जीवो जपति सर्वदा।
अजपा नाम गायत्री योगिनां मोक्षदा सदा।
अस्याः सङ्कल्पमात्रेण नरः पापैः प्रमुच्यते॥

ध्यानबिन्दूपनिषत्॥

Breath passes alternately through the right and left nostrils,through the force of Prana and Apana, and it repeats theprocess 21,600 times in a day. Meditation on this byYogis is Known as Ajapa-Mantra which is very efficaciousfor the destruction of sins. Taking the three above passages together, the question regarding the length of periodgiven for Kali Kuga namely; 1, 200 Divine years including200 years of Sandhi or 4,32,000 hunan years, may be easilyworked out.

3 x 6 = 18 Swasas make 1 Sukshma Ghatika.
18 × 60 = 1030 Swasas make 1 Sukshma day.

A Sthula day consists of 21600 Swasas probably calculatedfrom the normal condition observed in sleep. At othertimes, although respiration is an involuntary action itsnatural speed and duration will be constantly altered bychanges of external as well as internal conditions. Theproportion for conversion of a Sukshma day, month or yearinto a Sthula day, month or year is therefore 21600 ÷ 1080 = 20.

that is 1 to 20, is the proportion. Uttarayana and Dekshinayana together is one year and is tantamount to 1 Swasa,which is made up of both. The year here is Sukshma andit is therefore 20 Sthula years. 21,600 Swasas thereforemake up 432,000 Sthula years, which is exactly the numbergiven for the duration of Kali Yuga. We thus clearly seethat the purport of the whole affair is the Yogic account ofa single day of man. The doubling, trebling and quadrupling of this period for Dwapara, Treta and Krita Yugas,are consequent on the regulation of breaths by the processesprescribed in the Yoga-sastras with which we are not directly concerned at present. For instance, to obtain the numberof years given for Dwapara namely 864,000; a single Sthuladay whose account is practically the gist of the matter,being always a constant factor, the proportion in the rendering of the Sukshma to the Sthula, will have to be doubledby a corresponding reduction in the number of Swasas or breaths making up a Sukshma Ghatika. Instead of 18Swasas comprising a Sukshina Ghatika they should be reducedto 9, then the proportion will be21,600= 40.9 × 60 TheSthula years per day’s account, will then amount to 21,600 x 40= 864,000. Similarly, the necessary reduction of Swasas byYogic processes will give the figures for Treta and KritaYuagas. We thus clearly see that the figures given in thetexts are mathematically exact and not approximations, orexaggerations or even poetical fancies. It is however sufficient for our present purpose to know what a Yuga means,at least what it does not mean. The mere knowledge of itwill remove a good deal of misconception and further consequent errors, created by the ignorant people as well as bythe so-called scientific expositors like the Theosophists. We

have already seen how the latter are completely ignorant ofthe true significance of the geographical descriptions.Equally ignorant are they with regard to the question of timespecified. Their calling to aid geological discoveries in theelucidation of our sacred literature is more a mockery thananything else. Madam Blavadski’s explanation in her"Secret Doctrines”, of the duration of Dwapara Yuga namely864,000 years, as nearly approaching the earliest date discovered by modern Geology, is perhaps accepted by herdisciples and some others as a eulogistic observation in favorof Hindu Religion. What then about the duration of theTreta and Krita Yugas? We have perhaps to wait untilanother Geological discovery is available. What if the durations given for each of the four Yugas are pronounced to bediscovered immediately by Geology or any other materialsciences? The Yugas mentioned in our religious texts applyonly to Bharata Varsha (vide Q. 2) and not to the Theosophical India nor to any other locality outside the same onthe surface of this earthy sphere. Taking even the Theosophical interpretation (which is but a borrowing in toto fromthe local Pandits) of Bharata varsha as representing India,and the Yugas as referring to the ordinary calculation oftime, it must logically lead to the ridiculous but unavoidable
conclusion, that there is no ‘Time’ in America and perhapsno ‘space’ in Europe, both being outside Bharata-varsha. Itis high time that those who are really interested in our hoaryand sacred religion either religiously or even scientifically,should soon get over this deplorable ignorance and open theireyes. It is indeed a shame that we should have deterioratedto this depth to allow ourselves to be treated in this childishfashion both by our ignorant Pandits and the misleadingforeigners. It is certainly too late in these boasted days ofcivilization to console ourselves by excuses like want of time

or means, when side by side with us, the enlightened foreigners seek useful and valuable information in the interest ofscience from all corners of the world at the cost of immensewealth and convenience and even at the risk of personal life.It is utterly useless to be simply proud of our ancient civilization and religious supremacy.Standing still in the daysof progress, is positive retrogression and there is not theslightest doubt that we have fallen down thousands ofdegrees in our religious sphere.

विद्वत्ता वसुधातले विगलिता पाण्डित्यधर्मो गतः
श्रोतॄणां हृदयेष्व बुद्धिरधिका ज्ञानं गतं चारणे।
गाथा गीतविनोदवाक्यरचना युक्त्या जगद्रञ्जितम्
ज्योतिर्वैद्यकशास्त्रसारमखिलं क्षुद्रेषु जातं कलौ॥

5. The Manus and Manwantaras are matters ofvital importance in our Religion. They refer to certain definitePsychological and Physiological principles advantageouslyutilized in the religious practices prescribed. The subject isparticularly technical and perhaps peculiar to the Hindureligion. The facts expressed by the enumeration of the 14 Manus and of the durations of time intervening betweeneach of them are closely connected with the description ofthe Yugas and deal with scientific and technical matters, adetailed description of which is not possible to be attemptedhere. References will however have to be made occasionallywhere the necessary and available informations may be furnished. Regulation of breath called Prana-yama is the chiefprocess prescribed for Yoga. But it has to be supplementedby meditation accompanied by Manthras to make it effective.

मरुदभ्यसनं सर्वे मनोयुक्तं समभ्यसेत्॥

A scientific treatment of the physiology of sound styledSiksha is well-known to every student of Sanskrit Grammar,as forming an important portion of the subject. But it has

seldom been studied as a practical science, nor its specialapplication to the religious literature carefully noticed.Siksha has already been explained in Chapter II as one ofthe six Vedangas. It is thus one of the necessary items tobe first understood in the correct elucidation of religiousfacts and formulas. The natural relation or associationbetween thought and sound or language, the fact of theirinseparable coexistence and the consequent effects of theirmutual actions are all minutely and scientifically treated and,practically utilized for the practice of Yoga and religiousdevotion.

A science like the physiology of sound may perhapssound strange to a modern scientist, but nevertheless it isone of the oldest one known to our ancients and its possibility itself cannot be deniedwithout a proper enquiry. TheManthras are all composed in strict adherance to the principlesof this science. They are not valued for their meaning asgenerally supposed. The various Sahasranamas or thousandnames in praise of Vishnu or other Gods are not all of themrecognised as fit to be repeated as Manthras. Besides, thereare several single letters which ordinarily convey no meaning except a peculiar sound and do not permit of translationin any language but are particularly recognised as Manthraslike Hrim, Klim &c. Thus, the idea of translating theManthras in any language is a useless and unscientific task in as much as they lose their significance and effects even in aparaphrase in the Sanskrit language itself. It is but awell-known fact, that every poetical composition in anylanguage is not necessarily suited to be sung in every tunein music, unless the laws of composition for such purposesare strictly adhered to.

The word Manu ordinarily means mental faculty orthought as well as a Manthra. No great change is made

from this common interpretation, in its application in thetexts. But it is used in a somewhat restricted sense according to the requirements of the technical subject. The following quotations are subjoined with the hope of corroboratingthe interpretation here given, and I dare say it would beprofitless to criticise it as new or farfetched, without readingthe passages quoted, or to condemn them all, as unauthenticinterpolations. The texts containing these passages aresufficiently recognised as genuine for our present purposeand the passages themselves have not yet been marked outby modern critics and proclaimed as interpolations. Theonly probability is that they have not been properly noticedor understood in a searching or sympathetic spirit.

Quotation. No. I.

स्वरेण सन्धयेत् योगम्अस्वरं भावयेत्परम्।
अस्वरेण हि भावेन भावो नाभाव इष्यते।
तदेव निष्कलं ब्रह्म निर्विकल्पं निरञ्जनम्।
तत् ब्रह्माहमिति ज्ञात्वा ब्रह्म सम्पद्यते ध्रुवम्॥

ब्रह्मबिन्दूपनिषत्॥

Q. No. II.

आत्मा बुध्या समेत्यर्थान्मनोयुंक्ते विवक्षया।
मनः कायाग्निमाहन्ति स प्रेरयति मारुतम्।
मारुतस्तूरसि चरन मन्द्रं जनयति स्वरम्।
अनुस्वारो विसर्गश्च ᳶकᳶपौपराश्रितौI
अनुदात्तो हृदि ज्ञेयः मूर्ध्नि उदात्त उदाहृतः।
स्वरितः कर्णमूलीयः सर्वास्येप्रचय स्मृतः॥

शीक्षा॥

Q. No. III.

अथ वक्ष्यामि जगतो वागर्थात्मकता यथा।
नास्ति कश्चिदशब्दोऽर्थो नापि शब्दो निरर्थकः।

ज्ञाते हि समये शब्दः खर्वः सर्वार्थ बोधकः।
प्रकृतेः परिणामोयं द्विधा शब्दार्थभावितः।
तामाहुः प्रकृतिं भूतिं शिवयोः परमात्मनोः।
शब्दात्मिका विभूतिर्यासा त्रिधा कथ्यते बुधैः।
स्थूला सूक्ष्मा परा चेति स्थूला या श्रुतिगोचरा।
सूक्ष्मा चिन्तामयी प्रोक्ता चिन्तया रहिता परा॥

श्रीशिवमहापुराणम्॥

Q. No. IV.

मनोर्नाम मनुत्वञ्चयदेतत्पठ्यते किल।
प्रयोजनवशाद्विष्णुरसावेव तु मूर्तिमान्॥

वराहपुराणम्।

Q. No. V.

संज्ञा राज्ञि प्रभा छाया भागोभार्याः स्मृतास्त्विमाः।
सूते सूर्यान्मनुं संज्ञा यस्य वंशेऽभवन्नृपाः॥

सौरपुराणम्॥

Q. No. VI

मनुः स्वायम्भुवः पूर्वेततः स्वारोचिषो मतःI
उत्तमस्तामसश्चैव रैवतश्चाक्षुषस्तथा।
षडैते मनवोतीताः साम्प्रतन्तु रवेस्सुतः।
वैवस्वतोयं सप्तैतत्सप्तमं वर्तते परम्।
अस्मिन् मन्वन्तरे पूर्वं वर्तमाने महान् प्रभुः।
द्वापरे प्रथमे व्यासो मनुः स्वायम्भुवो मतः।
पञ्चविंशे तथा प्राप्ते यस्मिन् वै द्वापरे द्विजाः।
पराशरसुतो व्यासः कृष्णद्वैपायनोऽभवत्।
भविष्यति चसावर्णो दक्षसावर्ण एव च।
दशमो ब्रह्मसावर्णो धर्म एकादशस्मृतः।
द्वादशो रुद्रसावर्णो रौच्यनामा त्रयोदशः।
भौत्यश्चतुर्दशः प्रोक्तोभविष्या मनवः क्रमात्॥

कूर्मपुराणम्॥

Q. No. VII.

पूर्वेण पश्चिमं ज्ञेयं वर्तमानेन चोभयम्।
एतेन क्रमयोगेन मन्वन्तरविनिश्चयः।
एवं देवाश्च पितरः ऋषयो मनवश्चये।
मन्त्रैः सहोर्ध्वे गछन्ति ह्यावर्तन्ते च तैस्सह।
मन्वन्तरान्ते संहारःसंहारान्ते च सम्भवः।
देवतानामृषीणाञ्चमनोः पितृगणस्य च।
सप्तर्षयो मनुर्देवाः पितरश्च चतुष्टयम्।
मूलं मन्वन्तरस्यैते तेषाञ्चैवान्तरे प्रजाः।
ऋषीणां देवताः पुत्राः पितरो देवसूनवः।
ऋषयो देवपुत्राश्चइति शास्त्रविनिश्चयः।
स्वारोचिषोत्तमश्चैव तामसो रैवतस्तथा।
प्रियव्रतान्वया ह्येते चत्वारो मनवस्तथा।
अन्तरं चाक्षुषस्यात्र मनोः षष्ठन्तु हीयते।
मनोर्वैववस्वतस्यापि सप्तमस्य प्रजापतेः।
ततः प्रभृति लोकेस्मिन् प्रजाः मैथुनसंम्भवाः।
सङ्कल्पाद्दर्शनात्स्पर्शात् पूर्वेषां सृष्टिरुच्यते॥

वायुपुराणम्॥

Q. No. VIII.

शतरूपा च या नारी सावित्री सा त्विहोच्यते।
भार्या सा ब्रह्मणः प्रोक्ता ऋषीणां जननी च सा।
पुलस्त्याद्यान्मुनीन् सप्त दक्षाद्यांश्च प्रजापतीन्।
स्वायम्भुवादींश्च मनून् सावित्री समजीजनत्॥

पद्मपुराणम्॥

Q No. IX.

स्वरप्रधानं शिक्षायां कीर्तितो मुनिभिर्द्विजैः।
माणवद्व्यञ्जनं विद्यात् सूत्रवच्चस्वरं विदुः।
दुर्बलस्य यथा राष्ट्रं हरते बलवान्नृपः।
दुर्बलं व्यञ्जनं तद्वत् हरेत बलवान् स्वरः॥

नारदपुराणम्॥

Q. No. X.

स्थूलं सूक्ष्मं परञ्चेति त्रिविधं ब्रह्मगो वपुः।
पञ्चब्रह्ममयं रूपं स्थूलं वैराजमुच्यते।
हिरण्यगर्भं सूक्ष्मन्तु नादं बीजत्रयात्मकम्।
परं ब्रह्म परं सत्यं सच्चिदानन्दलक्षणम्।
अप्रमेयमनिर्देश्यम्अवाङ्मनसगोचरम्।
अक्षरं परमो नादःशब्दब्रह्मेति कथ्यते।
मूलाधारगता शक्तिः स्वाधारा विन्दुरूपिणी।
तस्यामुत्पद्यते नादः सूक्ष्मबीजादिवाङ्कुरः।
तां पश्यन्तीं विदुर्विश्वं यया पश्यन्ति योगिनः।
हृदये व्यज्यते घोषो गर्जत्पर्जन्यसन्निभः।
तत्र स्थिता सुरेशान मध्यमेत्यभिधीयते।
प्राणेन च स्वराख्येन प्रथिता वैखरी पुनः।
शाखापल्लवरूपेण ताल्वादि स्थानघट्टनात्।
अकारादिःक्षकारान्तान्यक्षराणि समीरयेत्।
अक्षरेभ्यः पदानि स्युः पदेभ्यो वाक्यसम्भवः।
सर्वे वाक्यात्मका मन्त्रा वेदशास्त्राणि कृत्स्नशः।
पुराणानि च काव्यानि भाषाश्च विविधा अपि।
सप्तस्वराश्च गाथाश्च सर्वे नादसमुद्भवाः।
एषां सरस्वती देवी सर्वभूतगुहाश्रया।
वायुना वह्नियुक्तेन प्रेर्यमाणा शनैश्शनैः।
तद्विवर्णपदैर्वाक्यैरित्येवं वर्तते सदा।
य इमां वैखरी शक्तिं योगी स्वात्मनि पश्यति।
स वाक्सिद्धिमवाप्नोति सरस्वत्याः प्रसादतः।
वेदशास्त्रपुराणानां स्वयं कर्ता भविष्यति॥

योगशिखोपनिषत्॥

Q. No. XI.

विराजमसृजद्विष्णुः सोसृजत्पुरुषं विराट्।
पुरुषं तं सनुं विद्यात्तस्य मन्वन्तरं स्मृतम्।
द्वितीयं मानसस्यैतन्मनोरन्तरमुच्यते।

स वैराजः प्रजासर्गं ससर्ज पुरुषः प्रभुः।
नारायणविसर्गस्य प्रजास्तस्याप्ययोनिजाः।
युगे युगे भवन्त्येते पुनर्दक्षादयो नृपाः।
पुनश्चैव निरुध्यन्ते विद्वांस्तत्र न मुह्यति।
ज्येष्ठं कानिष्ठमप्येषां पूर्वं नासी द्विजोत्तमाः।
तप एव गरीयोभूत्प्रभावश्चैव कारणम्॥

ब्रह्मपुराणम्॥

Q. No. XII.

सवै स्वायंभुवः पूर्वं पुरुषो मनुरुच्यते।
विराजमसृजत् ब्रह्मा सोभवत्पुरुषो विराट्।
सम्रान्मानसरूपात्तु वैराजस्तु मनुः स्मृतः।
स वैराजः प्रजासर्गः ससर्गे पुरुषो मनुः।
वैराजात्पुरुषाद्वीराच्छतरूपा व्यजायत।
प्रियव्रतोत्तानपादौ पुत्रौ तु पुत्रवतां वरौ।
कन्ये द्वे च महाभागे याभ्यां जाताःप्रजास्त्विमाः।
देवी नाम्ना तथा कूतिः प्रसूतिश्चैव ते शुभे।
स्वायम्भुवः प्रसूतिन्तु दक्षाय व्यसृजत् प्रभुः।
प्राणो दक्षस्तु विज्ञेयः सङ्कल्पो मनुरुच्यते।
स्रष्टुकामःप्रजा ब्रह्मा चिन्तयामास दुःखितः।
तस्य चिन्तयमानस्य प्रादुर्भूतः कुमारकः।
दिव्यगन्धः सुधापेक्षी दिव्यां श्रुतिमुदीरयन्।
अशब्दस्पर्शरूपां ताम्अगन्धां रसवर्जिताम्।
श्रुतिं ह्युदीरयन् देवो यामविन्दच्चतुर्मुखः।
स ओंकारे भवेद्वेदः अक्षरं वै महेश्वरः।
चतुर्मुखमुखात्तस्मादजायन्त चतुर्दश।
नानावर्णा स्वरादिव्यम्आद्यन्तच्चतदक्षरम्।
तस्मात् त्रिषष्टिवर्णा वै अकारप्रभवा स्मृताः।
अकाररूप आदौ तु स्थितः स प्रथमस्वरः।

ततस्तेभ्यःस्वरेभ्यस्तु चतुर्दश महामुखाः।
मनवः सम्प्रसूयन्ते दिव्या मन्वन्तरे स्वराः।
मुखात्तु प्रथमात्तस्य मनुः स्वायम्भुव स्मृतः।
अकारस्तु स विज्ञेयः श्वेतवर्णः स्वयंभुवः।
द्वितीयात्तु मुखात्तस्य आकारो वै मुखः स्मृतः।
नाम्ना स्वारोचिषो नाम वर्णः पाण्डुर उच्यते।
तृतीयात्तु मुखात्तस्य इकारो यजुषां वरः।
यजुर्मयः स चादित्यो यजुर्वेदो यतः स्मृतः।
ईकारःस मनुर्ज्ञेयो रक्तवर्णः प्रतापवान्।
ततः क्षत्रं प्रवर्तेत तस्माद्रक्तस्तु क्षत्रियः।
चतुर्थात्तु मुखात्तस्य ईकारःस्वर उच्यते।
वर्णतस्तु स्मृतः ताम्रः स मनुः तामसः स्मृतः।
पञ्चमात् तु मुखात्तस्य उकारो नाम जायते।
पीतको वर्णतश्चैव मनुश्चापि चरिष्णवः।
ततः षष्ठान्मुखात्तस्य ऊकारः कपिलः स्मृतः।
वरिष्ठश्च ततः षष्ठोविजयःस महातपाः।
सप्तमात् तु मुखात्तस्य ततो वैवस्वतो मनुः।
ऋकार स्वरस्तत्र वर्णतः कृष्ण उच्यते।
अष्टमात् तु मुखात्तस्य ऋकारः श्यामवर्णतः।
श्यामाक्षर सवर्णश्च ततः सावर्णिरुच्यते।
मुखात् तु नवमात्तस्य ऌकारो नवमः स्मृतः।
धूम्रो वै वर्णतश्चापि धूम्रश्च मनुरुच्यते।
दशमात् तु मुखात्तस्य ऌकारः प्रभुरुच्यते।
समश्चैव सवर्णश्च बभौ सावर्णिको मनुः।
मुखादेकादशात्तस्य एकारो मनुरुच्यते।
पिशङ्गो वर्णतश्चैव पिशङ्गो मनुरुच्यते।
द्वादशात्तु मुखात्तस्य ऐकारो नाम उच्यते।
पिशङ्गो भस्मवर्णाभः पिशङ्गो मनुरुच्यते।
त्रयोदशान्मुखात्तस्य ओकारो वर्ण उच्यते।

पञ्चवर्णसमायुक्त ओकारो वर्ण उत्तमः।
चतुर्दशमुखात्तस्य औकारो वर्ण उच्यते।
कर्बुरो वर्णतश्चैव मनुः सावर्णिरुच्यते।
इत्येते मनवश्चैव स्वरा वर्णाश्च कल्पतः।
विज्ञेया हि यथा तत्वं स्वरतो वर्णतस्तथा।
परस्परसवर्णाश्च स्वरा यस्माताद्वृताहि वै।
तस्मात्तेषां सवर्णत्वादन्वयस्तु प्रकीर्तितः॥

                      **वायुपुराणम्॥**
  • Q. No. XIII.*

परात्परतरात्तस्मा शिवाच्चैतन्यलक्षणात्।
स्वशक्ति सहिता देव द्विजाज्योतिर्मयः परः।
शब्दः सूक्ष्मः स्वभावेन प्रादुरासीदखण्डितः।
स शब्दः पुनराधारे प्राणिनामास्तिकोत्तमाः।
पिण्डीभूततया भाति तप्तजाम्बूनदप्रभः।
स पुनर्ब्रह्मनाड्यातु प्रविश्य हृदयाम्बुजम्।
विभक्तः सूक्ष्मरूपेण भाति वह्निप्रभः स्वतः।
ब्रह्मरन्ध्रंपुनस्साक्षाछिवस्य स्थानमुत्तमम्।
पिण्डीभूततया प्राप्य प्रकाशानन्दलक्षणे।
तत्र सन्निहिते शम्भौ विश्रान्ति लभते स्वतः।
आधारे परशक्तेस्तु स्थाने शब्दः प्रकाशितः।
परमेकाक्षरं साक्षात् भवत्यत्यन्तशोभनम्।
आज्ञा संस्थान्महास्थानादूर्ध्वं यत् स्थानमुत्तमम्।
तत्रस्थोयं द्विजाः शब्दः सूक्ष्मैकाक्षरतामियात्।
तृतीये परमाधारे पूरके पुण्यभाजने।
एकाकारत्वमाप्नोति स्वभावेनाक्षरद्वयम्।
अयमाद्यः परो मन्त्रः सुप्रसिद्धः स्वभावितः।
मननत्राणरूपत्वान्मन्त्र इत्यभिशब्दितः।
मातृका परमा देवि मन्त्रमाता महेश्वरी।
अस्मादाद्यान्महामन्त्रादाविर्भूता स्वभावतः।

अधोमुखी भवेदेका एका ऊर्ध्वमुखी भवेत्।
तस्माच्छ्रीमातृका शुद्धा चाद्यमन्त्रात्मिकी भवेत्।
आद्योयं परमो मन्त्रः सुप्रसिद्धोपि सुव्रताः।
सर्वेषामादिभूतस्य शिवस्य परमात्मनः।
स्वप्रकाशस्वरूपस्य वाचकोयं परो मनुः।
अपदं पदमापन्नं पदञ्चाप्यपदं भवेत्।
पदापदविभागञ्चयः पश्यति स पश्यति।
पदस्थस्य जिता मन्त्रा भवेयुः पण्डितोत्तमाः।
पदाभ्यासपराणान्तु न किञ्चिदपि दुर्लभम्।
अंश एकः पदस्यायमुपकाराय देहिनाम्।
भवेत् षोडशधा पूर्वं पञ्चधा च द्विधा पुनः।
पदस्यांशोऽपरः पूर्वो द्वात्रिंशत् भेदमाप्नुयात्।
त्रयस्त्रिंशत् पुनर्भेदं तथैव द्विविधं भवेत्।
एवं लोकोपकाराय पदं बहुविधं भवेत्।
स्थूला सूक्ष्मा सुसूक्ष्मा च त्रिविधा मातृकेश्वरी।
सा देवी शक्तिसम्भिन्ना शिवस्यामित तेजसः।
बुध्वा मन्त्रजपं कुर्यादेवं मन्त्रस्य वैभवम्।
परापरविभागेन प्रणवस्तु द्विधा मतः।
परः परतरं ब्रह्म प्रज्ञानन्दादि लक्षणम्।
प्रकर्षेण नवं यस्मात्परं ब्रह्म स्वभावतः।
अपरः प्रणवः साक्षाछब्दरूपः सुनिर्मलः।
प्रकर्षेण नवत्वस्य हेतुत्वात्प्रणवः स्मृतः।
परमप्रणवप्राप्ति हेतुत्वात्प्रणवोथ वा।
आकाशादि पदार्थानां ये शब्दा वाचका भुवि।
विना तानखिलान् शब्दान् लोक ओमिति भाषते।
सर्वावभासकत्वेन ब्रह्मणा सदृशः स्मृतः॥

** ** स्कान्दपुराणं सूतसंहिता॥

Q. No. XIV.

अकारादि क्षकारान्ता एकपञ्चादशक्षराः।
एते वर्णाः प्रशस्यन्ते कामितार्थ प्रदायकाः।

तेभ्यः समुद्भवं नाम रूपभेदं तथांशकम्।
तत्वमन्त्रादि भेदञ्चअधिदैवफलं तथा।
स्थूलसूक्ष्माकृतिञ्चैव जीवोपाधिविभेदकम्।
शिवतत्वे परे सूक्ष्मे बिन्दुरूपन्तु जायते।
बिन्दोर्नादस्समुत्पन्नो नादान्ते शक्तिजायते।
शक्तेस्तु जायते शब्दः शब्दाज्जायेत वाग्भवम्।
वाग्भवाच्च कला जाताः कलाभ्यो विकलास्तथा।
तस्माद्वै वाचको मन्त्रः मन्त्रस्तैरेव भिद्यते।
एतत्सृष्टिक्रमं प्रोक्तं तेषां लक्षणमुच्यते।
बिन्दुरूपा परा शक्तिः नादश्चैवादिरुच्यते।
शक्तिरिछेति विज्ञेया शब्दो ज्ञानमिहोच्यते।
वाग्भवं स्यात् क्रियाशक्तिःकला वै षोडशस्वराः।
इच्छाशक्तिश्च विद्या च तस्याः पर्यायवाचकाः।
ज्ञानं चैव प्रतिष्ठा च तस्याः पर्यायवाचकाः।
निवृत्तिस्यात् क्रियाशक्तिः तस्याः पर्यायवाचकाः।
प्रकृतिस्सप्तवर्णानि विकृतिस्तु नवार्णकम्।
कला मात्रा स्वरा जीवा प्रकृतिर्विकृतिस्तथा।
प्राणा आत्मा च देही च कलाःपर्यायवाचकाः।
ककारादिक्षकारान्ताः वर्णाश्च विकलाः स्मृताः।
देहोपाधिशरीरञ्च क्षेत्राधारस्तनुस्तथा।
व्यञ्जनं विकला शक्तिः बिन्दुपर्यायवाचकाः।
अकारादित्रयो व्योम ईकारदित्रयोनिलः।
ऋकारादीनि वर्णानि तेषामग्निरिति स्मृतः।
एकारादित्रयोह्यापः औकारादित्रयो मही।
प्रकृतिस्तत्वबीजं स्यात् विकृतिर्मूर्तिरुच्यते।
प्रभावं विकलाः प्रोक्ताः इत्येवं त्रिविधाभवेत्।
प्रकृतिर्हृस्वमित्युक्तं विकृतिः दीर्घमुच्यते।
एकमात्रो भवेध्रस्वः द्विमात्रो दीर्घ उच्यते
व्यज्ञनं त्वर्द्धमात्रं स्यात् इत्येतल्लक्षणं भवेत्।

कला जीवमितिख्यातं सकलं देहमुच्यते।
कलाश्च विकलाश्चैव देहिदेहमिति स्मृतम्।
स्थूलं शब्दमिति प्रोक्तं सूक्ष्मं चिन्तामयं भवेत्।
चिन्तया रहितं यत्तु तत् परं परिकीर्तितम्।
मननं सर्वपक्षेषु त्राणं संसारसागरात्।
मननत्राणधर्मित्वान्मन्त्रमित्यभिधीयते।
यथादरःस्वनाम्ना तु जनस्सन्निहितो भवेत्।
तथा मन्त्रप्रयोगेण तत्र सन्निहितश्शिवः॥

प्रणवं सर्ववेदाख्यं सर्वदेवमयं विदुः।
सर्वेषाञ्चैव मन्त्राणां प्रणवः प्राण उच्यते।
प्रणवं सर्ववर्णानां शिवबीजमिति स्मृतम्।
बिन्दुनादप्रकारेण प्रणवाकृतिरीरिता॥

** वातूलशुद्धागमम्॥**

Q. No. XV.

ओमिति ब्रह्मेति व्यष्टिसमष्टिप्रकारेण संहारप्रणवः सृष्टिप्रणवश्च अन्तर्बहिश्चोभयात्मकत्वात् त्रिविधो ब्रह्मप्रणवः। अन्तः प्रणवो व्यावहारिकप्रणवः। बाह्यप्रणव आर्षप्रणवः। उभयात्मको विराट्प्रणवः। संहारप्रणवो ब्रह्मप्रणव अर्द्धमात्रा प्रणवः। ओमिति ब्रह्म। ओमित्येकाक्षरमन्तः प्रणवं विद्धि। सचाष्टधा भिद्यते। अकारोकारमकारार्द्धमात्रा नादबिन्दुकलाशक्तिश्चेति। तत्र चत्वार अकारश्चायुतावयवान्वित उकारः सहस्रावयवान्वितो मकारःशतावयवोपेतोऽर्द्धमात्राप्रणवोऽनन्तावयवाकारः। सगुणो विराट्प्रणवः संहारो निर्गुणप्रणव उभयात्मकोत्पत्तिप्रणवो यथा प्लुतो विराटप्लुतः प्लुतसंहारोविराट्प्रणवः षोडशमात्रात्मकष्षट्त्रिंशत्तत्वातीतः। षोडशमात्रात्मकत्वं कथमित्युच्यते। अकार प्रथम उकारो द्वितीयो मकारस्त्रितीय अर्द्धमात्रञ्चतुर्थोनादः पञ्चमी बिन्दुः षष्ठी कला सप्तमी कलातीता अष्टमी शान्तिर्नवमी शान्त्यतीता दशमी उन्मन्यैकादशी मनोन्मणी द्वादशी पुरी त्रयोदशी मध्यमा चतुर्दशी पश्यन्ती पञ्चदशी परा षोडशी पुनश्चतुष्षष्ठिमात्रा प्रकृतिपुरुषद्वैविध्यमासाद्याष्टाविंशत्युत्तर भेदमात्रा स्वरूपमासाद्यं सगुणनिर्गुणत्वमुपेत्यैकोपि ब्रह्मप्रणवः सर्वाधारः०परञ्ज्योतिरेष सर्वेश्वरो विभुः॥

सर्वदेवमयःसर्वप्रपञ्चधारगर्भितः।
सर्वाक्षरमयः कालः सर्वागममयश्शिवः।
सर्वश्रुत्युत्तमो मृग्यः सकलोपनिषन्मयः॥

** नारदपरिव्राजकोपनिषत्॥**

Q. No. XVI.

एकमात्रो भवेध्रस्वो द्विमात्रो दीर्घ उच्यते।
त्रिमात्रस्तु प्लुतो ज्ञेयो व्यंजनन्त्वर्द्धमात्रकम्॥

कालपरिमाणपरमाणुःलव इत्युच्यते॥

नलिनीपत्रसंहत्यास्सूक्ष्मसूच्यभिवेथने।
दले दले तु यः कालः सकालो लवसंज्ञकः।
अतः सूक्ष्मतमः कालोनोपलभ्यो भृगूद्वह।
देशकालानवच्छिन्नं तदूर्ध्वं परमं महत्॥

** वरिवस्यारहस्यम्॥**

256 लवाः = 1 मात्रा 8 लवाः = नादान्तम्.
128do= बिन्दुः 4 do=शक्तिः
64 do=अर्धचन्द्रम् 2 do= व्यापिका.
32 do = रोधिनी. 1 do = समना.
16 do = नादम्. ½ do = उन्मना.

चक्रवाच्यानि षट्पद्मानि।शब्दसृष्टिसूक्ष्मरूपशालिनी त्रिपुरसुन्दरी सूक्ष्मरूपवत्वप्रवृत्तिं निमित्तकपरापदवाच्या। सैवमातितरति कशयति इति मातृका।तस्याञ्च विश्वसिसृक्षोत्पद्यते। सैव च पश्यन्त्याख्यामातृका।तदवयवाश्च वामादयोष्टौशक्तयः। सैव नाति सूक्ष्मापरावत् नाति स्थूलावैखरीवत् अतो मध्यमाख्या मातृका।अविकृतशून्यस्पर्शनात् अध्वनि बिन्दुशक्तिबीजाक्षराख्यं नादनवकं मूलाधारादिषट्केनादेनादान्ते ब्रह्मरन्ध्रे च स्थितम्। नवर्भिर्नादैः अकचटतपयशल्लाख्यवर्गनवकवती वैखर्याख्या मातृका जाता। वै निश्चयेन स्पष्टतरत्वात् खंकर्णविवरवर्ति नभोरूपश्रोत्रेन्द्रियं रातिगच्छति।शुद्धस्य शिवस्य शुद्धायाः शक्तेर्वा जंगत्कारणत्वं तत्र तत्रोच्यमानं शिवशक्ति रूपस्योभयात् मन एव बोध्यं। तत्रप्रकाशस्तु अक्रारस्वरूपः। तद्वाच्यश्च।

स्फुरता तु हकाररूपा। तद्वाच्या च। तावेतावकारहकारौ परा रूपौ सूक्ष्मतमौ। परादि सृष्टिमूलभूतस्य बीजस्थानीयस्य बिन्दुविशेषस्य तु व्यक्ताव्यक्तविलक्षणौ वाचकौ। तस्यापि जनकस्य परब्रह्मणस्तु केवलमव्यक्तायवशून्यस्वरूपौ वाचकौ॥

अहमित्येकमद्वैतं यत्प्रकाशात्मविभ्रमः।
अकारस्सर्ववर्णाभ्यःप्रकाशः परमः शिवः।
हकारोन्त्यःकला रूपो विमर्शाख्यः प्रकीर्तितः।
अनयोस्सामरस्यं यत् परस्मिन्नहमिस्फुटम्।
शून्याकाराद्विसर्गान्तात् बिन्दुप्रस्पन्दसंविदः॥

शून्याकारः शून्यमात्रस्वरूपः - यो विसर्गान्तः षोडशस्वरान्त्यः तस्मात् बिन्दुविशेष उत्पन्न इति तदर्थः। विसर्गस्याव्यक्तहकारतुल्यत्वेनाकारस्यापि तत्र सत्वेन षोडशस्वरकीर्तनं प्रकृतम्। तेनाकारहकारावेव शून्याकारी कीर्तितौ वेदितव्यौ ॥

वरिवस्यारहस्यम्॥

Q. No. XVII.

तत्र मन्त्रस्वरूपं ते वदामि मुनिसत्तम।
आद्यः स्वरः पञ्चमश्च पवर्गान्तस्ततः परम्।
बिन्दुनादौ च पञ्चार्णाःप्रोक्ता वेदैर्न चान्यथा।
एतत् समष्टिरूपो हि वेदादिःसमुदाहृतः।
नादःसर्वसमष्टि स्यात् बिन्द्वाद्यं यच्चतुष्टयम्।
व्यष्टिरूपेण संसिद्धं प्रणवे शिववाचके।

** श्रीशिवमहापुराणम्॥**

Q. No. XVIII.

क्रिया कर्मेज्य कर्तॄणामर्थं मन्त्रो वदत्यथ।
मननात्त्राणनान्मन्त्रस्सर्ववाच्यस्य वाचकः॥

** रामपूर्वतापिन्युपनिषत्॥**

  • Quotation. No. I.*

“The practice of Yoga should be accompanied by a Manthra or utterance of a vowel sound, also by the meditation of the Bramhan beyond the reach of sound, and identifying it with the self’’.

Three concomitant factors are here specified, the regulation of breath, utterance of a Manthra and meditation. The vowel sound in the Manthra is meant for the purpose of concentrating the flow of mind towards sound, name or Nama. The meditations prescribed are for the purpose of concentrating the mental flow towards objectivity, Rupa. According to our philosophy the whole cosmology of man consists only of nama and rupa.

*** Q. No. II.***

“The mind is set up by the intellect to express the name of an object hit upon by the intellect, which in itself is worked up by Atma. The Agni, fire or life principle in the body sets up the breath in motion, being itself acted upon by mind. A deep sound or low tone called Mandra, is then produced by the agitation of breath in the chest. The Anuswara M and Visarga ha &c., are not completely independent sounds. The accent known as Anudatta is produced in the heart, Udatha in the head, Swarita under the ear and Prachaya in the whole face”.

This gives the fundamental physiological principles of producing sounds by man. The accents refer to the directions of sound. We will see as we proceed with the quotations, how these principles are utilized for the formation of Manthras.

Q. No. III.

“Every sound or Nama refers to some object and every object is known by some sound or name. If the significance of a stipulated sound or Nama is known, a small sound could be found to apply to a large area of objectivity. The name and its object are the modifications of Prakriti which is the glory of Siva and his consort. The glory alluding to sound or Nama is of three varieties, namely, the Sthula which is

audible, the Sukshma which is only mentally known and the Para which is beyond the cognisance of mind”.

The coexistence of Nama and Rupa, sound and its object, is here explained, also the three states in which a sound could exist.

Q. No. IV.

“The name Manu and the characteristic of Manu, are mentioned in the texts with some object, and they refer to Vishnu in some form”.

The origin of Manu as well as the significance of the name are already beginning to differ from the Pandit’s conceptions and he must be prepared to hear stranger things soon about the Manus, which will make him sick to think of our sacred literature.

  • Q. No. V.*

“Samgna, Rajni, Prabha and Chaya are the four wives of Surya or the sun. Manu,in whose family all the kings and rulers originated, is the son of Surya by Samgna”.

Here Samgna clearly means the intellect, and the names of the other three wives are equally significant. Surya or sun represents the Atma. These terms shall be explained more fully in the next section on Personality. In the meantime, it is enough to note that the Pandit’s literal interpretation of Manu being the son of the sun, would naturally render the origin of the so-called earthly rulers here specified, unintelligible to ordinary human beings. It would be very uncharitable on his part to expect the rest of mankind to he furnished with unhinged brains like himself and his illustrious colleagues.

Q. No. VI.

“The first six Manus, namely, Swayombhuva, Swarochisha, Uttama, Tamasa, Ryvata and Chakshusha have

passed over. The seventh and the present Manu is Vyvaswata, the son of the sun. In the first Dwapara-yuga of thisManwantara, the first Manu, Swayambhuva himself held the post of Vyasa. In the twenty-fifth Dwapara, Krishnadwypayana, son of Parasara, became Vyasa. The future seven Manus are Savaranas or of the same caste of Vyvaswata, named, Savarna, Deksha-Savarna, Bramha-Savarna-Dharma, Rudra-Savarna, Rowchya and Bhowtya”.

These fourteen Manus will be explained in the subsequent quotations. But it is believed that the Pandit and Critic have no more explanations to offer here than a mere paraphrase in some indistinct style. The text however is simple enough to understand the language, and does not demand the help of the Pandit on that score. But the Pandit is of course quite indifferent to the purport of its contents, and it would certainly be an infringement upon his established rights to worry him with questions on such silly matters.

Q No. VII.

“The future should be ascertained from the past. and both from the present. The Manwantaras should be determined by this method. The basis for Manwantaras consists of the Sapta-rishis, Devas, Pitris and Manus and in their midst are the Prajas. The Rishis, Devas, Pitris and Manus ascend and descend accompanied by Manthras. They are destroyed at the end of a Manwantara and created at the end of the destruction. The Devas are the sons of Rishis and Pitris the sons of Devas. That the Rishis themselves are the sons of Devas, is settled in the Sastras. The four Manus named Swarochisha, Uttama, Thamasa and Ryvata belong to the family of Priyavrata. The Manwantaras of Chakshusha the sixth and Vyvaswata the seventh Manus are declining.

From their time, creation is by union. The previous creations are by thought, sight and touch”.

The quotations are surely becoming more and more vexatious. This gives the best opportunity for all the different varieties of modern interpreters to join together dropping their individual opinions, and to march out clearing the field altogether. None of them could find definite points for the exercise of their ingenuity here. There is no exaggeration, no poetical fancy. Everything here is irrelevant and incoherent as long as the subject is not studied.Every line in the quotation must be confessed as unintelligible to the modern learned interpreters. The Devas are said to be the sons of Rishis and Rishis the sons of Devas This paradox is not even allowed to be questioned. The Sastras have so settled. Could the Pandit or Critic tell us what the description means? The Rishis, Devas, Pitris and Manus ascend and descend with Manthras, in the Manwantaras. Will the Pandit enlighten us with some vague idea at least of all these statements? Creation in the previous Manwantaras is said to have been conducted by thought, sight and touch. Does the local Pandit at least understand the process? Modern creation is said to be by union. Here of course all the modern interpreters are in their own atmosphere. This is the only portion in the quotation they approve of as correct and clearly intelligible. They are so happy to find after all, the very thing sought for in these texts all this time. And these are our modern religious authorities.

कतिचिदुद्धतनिर्भरमत्सराः कतिचिदात्मवचः स्तुतिशालिनः।
अहहकेऽपि निरक्षरकुक्षयस्तदिह सम्प्रति कम्प्रति मे श्रमः॥

  • Q. No. VIII.*

“The woman named Sata-rupa, or of hundred forms, is known as Savitri the wife of Bramha, she is the mother of

the seven Rishis named Pulastya and others, of Deksha and other Prejapatis and of Swayambhuva and other Manus”.

Here, we have the parentage of the Rishis, Manus and Prajapathis traced to Bramha and Savitri.Gayatri or Savitri clearly represents the famous Manthra well-known to the Hindus. Our venerable Pandit well-versed in the sacred Manthras can now clearly understand that the fourteen Manus born of Savitri reigned in Oudh and Delhi in olden days with all the pomp and splendour of an Emperor. He knows Manthras producing kingdoms and rulers of. kingdoms in India. It is indeed a pity, he yet knows no Manthra which will furnish him with common sense. He could ere this have easily found out by a little thought in his sober moments, that for the said purpose, this very Gayatri is prescribed in our ancient religion.

गायकं त्रायते यस्मात् गायत्रीत्युच्यते हि सा॥

Q. No. IX.

“In the science called Siksha, the vowels are treated as more important than the consonants. The consonants are like gems strung in the thread of vowels. The vowels overpower the consonants like a powerful monarch appropriating the kingdom of a weak monarch”.

The use of this quotation will soon be explained.

  • Q. No. X.*

“The Bramhan has three kinds of body, namely, Sthula, Sukshma and Para.The Virat is Sthula known as Pancha-Brahman. Hiranyagarbha is Sukshma, called Nada or sound made of three Bija letters.Para is the unknowable Parom-Bramhan, whose attributes are, Sat, Chit, Ananda and Satya. The eternal Nada is known as Sabda-Bramhan. From the Sakti residing in the Muladhar in the form of Bindu, a Sukshma sound originates, known as Pasyanti, by

which the Yogis see everything. The same sound passing to the heart makes a thundering noise, and it is known as Madhyama. When this is combined with the vowels known as Prana, it is called Vykhari. It then expresses itself as the various letters of the alphabet, from A to Ksha. From these letters, words are produced; from words sentences originate. All Manthras are made of sentences, also the Vedas, Sastras, Puranas,languages, musical compositions &c. The force of breath slowly acting upon the life principle, produces this Vykhari sound. This Sakti or power residing in the heart of all is called Saraswati. When the Yogi perceives her in his Atma, he obtains the power of producing Vedas, Sastras and Puranas of his own accord”.

This quotation explains the highest imaginable form of Bramhan and the corresponding idea of the purest sound by which it may be named. This is an important matter in our religious literature, without a clear knowledge of which there would be endless confusion in the interpretation of the texts. Three forms are here postulated for the formless Bramhan known as Virat, Hiranyagarbha and Parom. The Parom is entirely formless and represents the true condition. The Virat or Sthula philosophically understood consists of name and form alone, that is Nama and Rupa. Hiranya-garbha is described as the Sukshma form, practically meaning the mere meditation of the Bramhan without a form. It represents the purest idea of Bramhan the human intellect is capable of grasping. Having virtually eliminated all possible forms in this grand conception of Bramhan, its name or Nama alone now remains. An appropriate name has now to be given to this most abstract idea. The very first and simplest sound uttered by man can alone properly apply to this conception of Sukshma-Bramhan. In fact, such a name or sound is explained here as its only characteristic mark and hence it is named Sabda-Bramhan.

हिरण्यगर्भं सूक्ष्मन्तुनादं बीजत्रयात्मकम्।
अक्षरं परमोनादःशब्दब्रह्मेति कथ्यते॥

We have just seen in quotation No. 2 that the very first and the purest sound produced in the human system is known as Mandra and this very sound is certainly the fittest nomenclature for the Bramhan under reference.

मारुतस्तूरसिचरन् मन्द्रं जनयतिस्वरम्॥

The subject will be explained more fully later on. If the Pandit has eyes and the willingness to use them, he could observe here that Bramha or Hiranyagarbha described as the father of the Rishis, Manus, Devas and Pitris has no form and that he is known as Sabda-Bramhan. His children specified here could therefore naturally possess no forms and they should represent some further evolutions of Bramha in the sphere of sounds or Namas constituting the essential ingredients of the religious and sacred Manthras. If the Pandit is prepared to digest these facts with repenting tears, he is likely to find ere long, that the hitherto unintelligible passages overflow with serious and important religious instructions.

पुस्तकेषु च नाधीतं नाधीतं गुरुसन्निधौ।
न शोभन्ते सभामध्ये हंसमध्ये बको यथा॥

*** Q. No. XI.***

“Vishnu created Virat and he created Purusha called Manu to whom Manwantara belongs. Manu is the second stage from Manasa, known as Manwantara. Manu created the Prejas and in the creation by Vishnu, no one is born from the womb of the mother. Deksha and other kings appear periodically in the Yugas and disappear in the same manner. There is no difference observed among themselves as elders or youngsters. Their positions depend upon the

amount of Tapas acquired. No wise man is therefore puzzled at their appearance or disappearance”.

The origin of Manus is here stated as the second stage from Manasa. The Manu is also mentioned as the production of Virat. We have already found that Manasa represents the twenty-fifth Tatwom. It is therefore certain that the term Manu also refers to one of the lower Tatwoms. The general standard by which the importance of Deksha and other periodical kings should be judged, is also said to be, the quantity of Tapas specified. As usual, the Pandit has absolutely nothing to enlighten us here. We may therefore very well proceed without waiting for his help. It would be a great boon if he only refrains from throwing filth on our way.

Q. No. XII.

“Bramha created Virat. From the Manasa, Vyraja known as Samraud originated, called Manu.The first Purusha named Swayambhuva, is known as Manu.This Manu created the Prajas. A daughter named Sata-rupa, two sons named Priyavrata and Uttanapada and again two daughters named Akuti and Presuti were born from him. He gave Presuti in marriage to Deksha. Here Deksharepresents Prana and Manu represents Samkalpa. Bramha desirous of creating Prajas meditated sorrowfully. Immediately Kumara of divine scent originated, uttering the divine Sruti, unknowable by the senses. The Veda then originated from Om. From its 14 faces,14 vowels originated also 33 consonants. Then from these vowels 14 Manus originated constituting the divine vowels of the Manwantaras. The first vowel A originated from the first of the 14 faces and is named Swayambhuva Manu. Similarly from the remaining 13 faces, 13 vowels originated with the names of the remaining Manus. They are of white, red, black and other varieties

of colours. In this manner, the vowels, consonants and Manus originated. Thevowels in themselves being of the same caste or family, the Anwaya or Vamsa of the Manus is thereby signified”.

A good deal of technicalities is here clearly explained. The significance of Manu and Deksha-Prejapati is pointed out in the plainest terms.

प्राणो दक्षस्तु विज्ञेयः सङ्कल्पो मनुरुच्यते॥

Deksha represents Prana or the Life Principle and Manu denotes Samkalpa, mental resolution or determination. The Pandit need not here shed his false tears for the deaths of his anthropological Manus and Dekshas. He has never loved or respected ther, and even when he comes to know that they are still alive, he is not going to be faithful to them.The 14 Manus are said to allude to the 14 vowel sounds originating from Bramha’s 14 faces. The vowels being of the same family, the idea is expressed as the Manu’s family or Vamsanucharita in the Puranas.

परस्परसवर्णाश्च स्वरायस्माद्वृता हि वै।
तस्मात्तेषां स वर्णत्वादन्वयस्तु प्रकीर्तितः॥

The Manwantara noticed in the previous quotation similarly refers to the continuity of the vowel sounds specified.

द्वितीयं मानसस्यैतन्मनोरन्तरमुच्यते॥

Concerning these two terms, namely, Manwantara and Vamsanu-charita, used in the Puranas and Itihasas, we can now easily perceive the extreme absurdity in the modern interpretation as referring to, the Geological periods of this mother-earth or the historical periods of its inhabitants. The significance of the 14 vowel sounds said to be produced from the faces of Bramha shall soon be understood by going

through the succeeding quotations. The modern interpreters in general are likely to be excited at the sight of these strange quotations. But could they with a vengeance condemn the whole as later interpolations? If so, will they kindly condescend to tell us for what purpose they were interpolated, when and by whom? They will certainly be compelled to lay the blame on the indigenous Pandit but his complete innocence in this matter could be easily proved by his own ignorance of the passages. No foreigner or stranger to the Sanskrit language could be pitched upon either. The theory of supposed interpolation therefore is but a frivolous attack upon the sacred literature and does not deserve to be noticed. Its frequent application however, naturally creates a strong suspicion against its motive and propriety. Those who claim to be recognised as civilized,ought to be more careful in the use of this weak but shameful weapon, in future.

Q. No. XIII.

“From Siva, the ultimate and pure intelligence, an unbroken perpetual sound of great. brightness has naturally emanated with the Sakti. That very sound shines brightly in the Muladhar all creatures. It then passes through the Bramha-nadi to the heart and becomes distinct as Sukshma. The same unbroken sound reaches the Bramharendra or brain, the brightest and blissful seat of Siva, and becomes tranquil by His proximity. In the Adhara, the seat of Sakti, the sound represents a single happy letter.In the centre above Aagna, the single letter becomes Sukshma. In the third centre called Pooraka two letters become one.This is the first natural and well-known Manthra. It is called a Manthra because it saves one meditating upon it. The goddess of letters has therefore naturally originated from this first Manthra. The direction of one letter here is

upwards and of the other is downwards. This first Manthra is therefore the significant word denoting the ever brilliant Siva and is the greatest Manu or Manthra. Thus the Apada or inexpressible becomes Pada or expressible and the latter again merges in the former. To know this is great knowledge. He who grasps the Pada obtains control over the Manthras and nothing is unattainable for him. For the benefit of mankind a portion of this Pada divides itself into 16, 5, 2, 32, or 33 &c. The Goddess of letters has three aspects, the Sthula, Sukshma and Susukshma being the development from the Sakti itself. Every Manthra should be uttered with a knowledge of this dignity of it. Pranava is of two sorts, the Para and Apara. The Para is the Para-Bramhan itself and is called Pranava being ever new. The Apara is in the form of the purest sound and is also called Pranava, because it serves as the medium for attaining the Para-Bramhan. The letter Om represents the totality of everything in the Universe, without the individual names of objects, and it therefore denotes Bramha”.

The religious technicalities of the varieties of sounds constituting the holy Manthras, as well as the philosophical and physiological origins of such sounds, are detailed in this quotation. We cannot here afford to go into the details of the Manthra-Sastra which is a great science in itself. It would be enough to note here, that the Manus undoubtedly allude to such Manthras, and that their apparent history deals with the actual explanation of their varieties and stages prescribed for devotional progress, accompanied by meditation upon the glories of God specified by their corresponding Manthras. We might also notice in this connection, especially for the purpose of satisfying the curiosity of our readers, that the creation by union mentioned in quotation 7 refers to the joining of single sounds or letters to consti-

tute Manthras. It never denotes the process of animal creation as absurdly and shamelessly explained by the modern interpreters. The mutual parentage of the Rishis, Devas and Pitris, paradoxically described in the same quotation, will shortly be explained in the next section on Personalities,exposing the complete ignorance of our existing religious authorities.

Q. No. XIV.

“There are 51 letters in all from. A to Ksha, by which the Manthras are composed, which allude to the forms and Tatwas prescribed for religious meditation. From Sivatatwa Bindu originates. From Bindu, Nada originates at the end of which Sakti originates. From Sakti, Sabda; from Sabda, Vakbhava; from it Kala and from which again Vikala originates. With these, Manthras are composed. This is the process of evolution or creation, whose characteristics shall here be explained. Bindu is Para-Sakti and Nada is Adi-Sakti. Sakti is Icha or desire to create, and Sabda is Gnana.Vakbhava means Kriya-Sakti and Kala represents the 16 vowels. The terms Icha, Vidya, Gnana, Pratishta, Nivriti and Kriya are synonymous. Seven vowels are known as Prakriti and nine as Vikriti. Kala, Matra, Swara, Jiva, Prakriti, Vikriti, Prana, Atma and Dehi are synonymous terms alluding to the vowels. The consonants constitute the Bindu and are known by thesynonymous terms, Deha, Upadhi, Sarira, Kshetra, Adhara, Tanu and Vikala. The first 3 vowels denote Akasa; the next 3, air; the next 4, fire; the next 3, water and the last 3, earth. Prakriti represents the Tatwa-bija or the essential letter, and Vikriti denotes the form. Vikala refers to Prabhava, power or efficacy. Prakriti is short and of one Matra, Vikriti is long and of two Matras, and consonant is of half Matra. Kala is the life and Vikala is the body. The

Sthula sound is called Sabda, the Sukshma is mental and Parom is beyond it. The meditation that saves one from worldly miseries is called a Manthra. Siva presents himself before us by the application of a proper Manthra, like one addressed courteously by his proper name. Pranava is the life of all Manthras and is the letter representing Siva among all other letters. The form of Pranava is constituted in accordance with the formulas relating to Bindu and Nada”.

This quotation itself furnishes more details than would be consistent with the scope of this essay. Those who are really interested in this special branch of religious science, could easilyobtain plenty of technical treatises on the subject. For our main purpose here, we have only to understand and remember one or two important facts explained in the quotation. The Manthras are said to be composed of vowels and consonants, the vowels being called Kalas divided into Prakritis and Vikritis, and the consonants being known as Vikalas. Viewed as a mere grammatical classification, the description conveys no meaning, as all the languages in the world are formed by the combinations of vowels and consonants. There must therefore be a technical difference maintained in all such religious matters, the modern ignorance of which naturally gives rise to unpleasant and unnecessary criticisms. First of all a Manthra is distinguished from a verbal expression of an ordinary idea, by its peculiar aptitude for saving a man from worldly miseries by his meditation upon the Tatwa alluded to in the Manthra.

मननघ्राणधर्मित्वान्मन्त्रमित्यभिधीयते॥

Secondly, the vowels and consonants used in the composition of a Manthra are called Kalas and Vikalas, only on account of their situation within the Manthra. The terms

Kriya-Sakti, Icha-Sakti, Vidya, Gnana and Pratishta are mentioned in the quotation as synonymous with Nivriti or involutionary process. The letters therefore that go to
form a Manthra which takes us back to the creator, are alone given the name specified here, namely, Kala, Prakriti, Vikriti and Vikala. The same letters used in any language, for the purpose of communicating common ideas or for expressing abuses, cannot therefore be called by the names here given.

निवृत्तिस्यात् क्रियाशक्तिः तस्याः पर्यायवाचकाः॥

There is after all, nothing very strange in the conception of this simple principle, as everything in this world could be used both for good and evil purposes. Another important point to be noticed here, is the formation of the syllable Om called Pranava. It is not the stipulation of any meaningless sound uttered by the ancient Rishis at random. It is clearly stated to be specially composed, conforming to the
principles relating to Nada and Bindu.

बिन्दुनादप्रकारेण प्रणवाकृतिरीरिता॥

It is earnestly hoped that the foregoing general explanations pertaining to the Manus and Manwantaras, will suffice for our respectable readers to form some definite idea of the subject as a whole. It is also anxiously feared that any more of similar explanations might not prove effectual in cowing down the presumptuous Pandit.

गले पाशस्तीव्रश्चरणयुगले गाढः निगटो
दृढं स्कन्धे बद्धः शिरसि सृणिपातः खरतरः।
नरः स्कन्धारूढो बत रमणयोग्येऽपि विषये
न जानीमोऽत्यर्थं द्विरद वद कस्मात्तव मदः॥

Q No. XV.

“The syllable Om referring to Bramhan viewed aggregately and as made up of individual bodies, is called Sam-

hara and Srishti. Pranavas respectively. It is also distinguished as internal, external or both, as half-matra Pranava or Samhara Pranava and Srishti-Pranava. The internal or Anta-pranava is divided into eight parts, namely, A, U, M, half-matra, Nada, Bindu, Kala and Sakti. The A has ten thousand parts; U, one thousand; M, one hundred, and half-matra, endless parts. Saguna is Virat-pranava; Nirguna is Samhara-pranava, both combined is Utpathi-pranava. The Samhara-pranava is beyond the thirty-six Tatwas and consists of 16 Matras, namely, A,U,M, half matra, Nada, Bindu, Kala, Kalatita, Santi, Santyatita, Unmani, Manonmani, Puri, Madhyama, Pasyanti and Para. Again, the Pranava splits itself into Purusha and Prakriti consisting of 64 Matras and takes the form of Saguna-nirguna consisting of 28 Matras. In this manner, the single Brahma-pranava takes different forms and it is the real basis for everything in the Universe”.

This quotation also is technical enough to be completely Greek to the Pandit and the Critic. The next quotation will be more explanatory, and it may be stated here that the details given in these passages will have to be referred to in future, for explaining many of the passages unintelligible to the modern interpreters.

Q. No. XVI.

“A short sound is of one Matra, long sound two Matras, protracted sound three Matras and a consonant is half-Matra. The smallest atom of time is named Leva. If a number of lotus leaves placed one above the other be pierced through by a sharp needle, the time taken for the needle to pass from one leaf to another is reckoned as a Leva, and it is the smallest unit of time above which is the Mahat unaffected by time and space. 256 Levas inake one Matra and the following is the measurement of the nine Nadas. A Bindu is 128 Levas;

Ardhachandra is 64; Rodhini, 32; Nada, 16; Nadanta, 8; Sakti, 4; Vyapika, 2; Samana, 1 and Unmana 1/2, Levas. The 6 lotuses are the Chakras.Tripura-sundari or the Goddess called Para is the creatress of the Sukshma sound. She shines there and is called Matrika. The desire to create Viswa originates in her and she is then called Pasyanti being made up of 8 Saktis known as Vama &c. Between the Sukshma and Sthula stages, she is called Madhyama, in which state the 9 Nadas specified above extend from Muladhar to Bramha-rendhra in their unmodified condition. In Sthula or audible state called Vykhari, the 9 Nadas develop themselves into the 9. sets of letters in the Alphabet, bėginning with A, Ka, Cha, Ta, Tha, Pa, Ya, Sa and La. The conjunction of the pure Siva and the pure Sakti here described for the origin of this creation detailed, should be understood as alluding to the work of the pure mind. The sounds A and Ha are Sukshma denoting the exposition of the brightness of Bramhan which is the real Ahom. The foremost of all sounds is A, and Ha is the last of the vowels, the former referring to Siva and the latter to its perception. Ha consists of double Bindu and combined with A refers to the totality of the 16 vowels and both the letters signify Sunya or nothingness”.

This quotation is equally technical and more explanatory than the former in its details.

Q. No. XVII.**

“I shall tell you the real character of a Manthra.The syllable Om or Pranava, made up of five parts,namely, A, U, M, Bindu and Nada, is the very starting point in the Veda and it is described as the real Manthra by the Vedas.Nada represents the total aggregate idea and the remaining four denote the individual separate ideas.”

The syllable Om is explained here as the real Manthra.

It is also said to contain within itself the total and individual conceptions of existence.

Q. No. XVII.

“A Manthra particularly signifies, the religious Karma, its mode of performance and the specific image or the performer’s conception of God.”

The devotee being saved by meditation, it is called a Manthra, and it is the verbal expression of the idea of God.

<MISSING_FIG href=”../../../../../books_images/U-IMG-1698729857Screenshot(34”/>.png)The above quotations on the point at issue are no doubt somewhat tiresome, although the necessary explanations are not yet sufficiently complete. The subject is strictly technical and most important for the purpose ofcomprehen-ding the applicability of the Vedas and Manthras. The temptation therefore to give as full a treatment as possible is great not only on account of the amount of scientific informations imbedded therein, but more on account of the immensity of ignorance, indifference and perversity unfortunately evinced in modern days in its interpretation.

The inseparable association of thought and word, object and its name being psychologically established, a detailed analysis of their origin and relation is scientifically treated in Siksha, specifying also the physiological locations of sound in the human body. The direct influence of words on thought is thus a scientific fact and not a matter of blind belief. must therefore be generally conceded that if any of the existing religions in the world would recognise the efficacy of prayer, the Manthras in themselves are not useless or superstitious. Taking a more scientific and philosophical view of the subject, the ultimate object to be attained, namely Brahman must logically have its corresponding word or name and this is known as Sabda-Brahman. Of course

it refers only to the highest stage below that of Para-Bramhan but leading to the same.

शब्दब्रह्मणि निष्णातः परं ब्रह्माधिगच्छति॥

The Manthras are therefore variously composed and classified so as to serve different purposes for advancement in religious merit and to suit the varying capacities and qualifications of man. It is thus clear that every Manthra is not fit to be adopted by everybody without discrimination, the oneprescribed for a Sanyasi is not suited to a family man. This simple fact in modern days is too often misunderstood and criticised as the product of Brahmanical pride consequent on the desire for superiority and exclusiveness. But those who are inclined to admit the efficacy of a Manthra in any manner cannot consistently deny the necessity of considering the fitness of the person who wishes to be benefited by the same. Otherwise, it is like the meddling with the contents of a Laboratory without a knowledge of the fundamental principles of the science. The effort is not only useless but may prove dangerous too. Bluntly ignoring the scientific facts like electricity or other forces will not help, if the apparatus and chemicals in the room are wrongly made use of. Obstinate and silly perversities of this kind are not very rare with regard to the subject in question and they deserve only to be pitied rather than condemned.

‘अनुशोचाम एवान्यान् न भ्रान्तैर्विवदामहे’॥

<MISSING_FIG href="../../../../../books_images/U-IMG-1698733256Screenshot(35"/>.png)In this section, we have examined and sifted al most every term used in the texts appearing as descriptions of time, extending from Lava or the minutest portion to Parardhom and Parom the highest figures in the Arithmetical Notation, and have clearly found that none of them have any reference to the ordinary reckoning of time so as to lead us to the belief in their applicability to the periods of histori-

cal incidents as commonly interpreted amongst us. The historical, archeological or geological proofs nowadays offered to establish the irrelevancies and inconsistencies in the Puranic statements, go therefore only to show the ignorance of the contents of our religious literature on the part of their Critics, without meaning anything derogatory to the scientific importance of their professed subjects. No better value or importance shall either be reasonably attached to the misdirected attempts of our native Pandits and Theosophists to explain those facts in a favourable attitude, by ununderstandable and extraneous methods virtually hood winking the public and concealing their own ignorance. We are helplessly compelled to turn round to them and say ‘Physician heal thyself’.

प्रयत्नैरस्तोकैः परिचितकुतर्कप्रकरणाः
परं वाचो वश्यान् कतिपयपदौघान्विदधतः।
सभायां वाचाटाः श्रुति कटुरटन्तो घटपटा-
न्न लज्जन्ते मन्दाः स्वयमपि तु जिहेति विबुधः॥

<MISSING_FIG href="../../../../../books_images/U-IMG-1698734959Screenshot(36"/>.png)

** SECTION III.**

ON PERSONALITY.

It is earnestly hoped that the sacred documents hitherto ransacked must have to a great extent, convinced every reasonable and unbiased reader, of the fact that in the matter of religious evolution as well as involution, detailed in the texts, the gods and other personalities more or less allude to the efficient cause or spiritual agencies, and that the holy centres and the so-called geographical specifications refer to the material causes in general. They are known

as the Nimitha and Upadana Karanas. In the first section of this Chapter, we have examined the technical terms connected with the latter, and the present section has to seek for the significance of terms used to denote the former. The second section on Time, we have just finished stands in the position of a connecting link between the two.

In this section, a logical classification of Personalities shall be maintained in accordance with their respective importance, for the proper comprehension of the ideas conveyed by each of them.

We have been noticing all through in this essay, that the ultimate entity is described in our philosophy, by two different names, in accordance with the kind of view taken of it, namely, Para and Apara Brahmans. The latter is known also as Sabda-Bramhan and Purana–Purusha referring to the possibility of its being described by philosophical methods in the Puranas and Itihasas. The former of course is the inconceivable infinite of self-experience or Swanubhuti, regarding which no oral explanations could be ventured, especially of a positive character. It is attained only by negation of all phenominal affairs, and no religion or philosophy can afford to deal with it directly except through the medium of this Sabda Bramhan, whose knowledge itself has to be obtained by the regular methods prescribed for the purpose of getting over worldly desires and other obstacles on the path to onward progress. By reaching the ultimate terminus of this Sabda-Bramhan, man is naturally transported to the highest region called Para-Bramhan, and that is the only way of securing it.

शब्दब्रह्मणि निष्णातः परं ब्रह्माधिगच्छति॥

This intervening territory of Sabda-Bramhan, between God and man is the blissful region of refuge provided for the

emancipation of the fallen man. The strange and insolent effort of the so-called Vedantists of the modern day to ignore this fact by hypocritical pretensions, and their attempt to transcend the limits of Sabda-Bramhan by impossible feats display only their intellectual weakness and moral bankruptcy. Ethics and religion are two inconvenient bug-bears to them obstructing freedom of thought and action. They can afford to jump over these unnecessary restrictions with their superior intellects and establish their rights to go ahead of all ordinary laws and rules. This is one of the worst and most pernicious use of religion and philosophy in the interest of unbridled and detestable conduct. Vedanta as generally understood, denotes the end of the Vedas, that could be reached only by going through the Vedas and by acting up to their ordinancesAs used by its modern professors, Vedanta practically means the end or annihilation of the Vedas altogether. All distinctions of right and wrong, good and bad, east and west, day and night, high and low, are abolished as unphilosophical, for the convenience of beastly self-interest, and universal indifference is preached all over the land as signifying true Vedantism.

ब्रह्मैवसत्यमखिलं न हि किञ्चिदस्ति
तस्मान्नमे सखि परावरभेदबुधिः।
जारे तथा निजवरे सदृशोनुरागो।
व्यर्थं किमर्थमसतीति कदर्थयन्ति॥
