Pitris are also classified as Agnishwatas. and Barhishadas as an imitation of the original Pitris owing to some external correspondence of Karms, but are entirely different from those noticed in the higher sense of the term.

Q. No. V.

तेषान्तु धर्मसाधर्म्यात् स्मृताः सायुज्यगाः द्विजैः॥

Among these human Pitris, 3 distinct varieties are mentioned. The deceased ancestors who have attained the Swarga-loka by virtuous life in this world rank first and they are venerated like the real original Pitris explained above, and are styled Manushya Pitris (Q. 5).

स्वर्गतादिविमोदन्ते पितृवत्त उपासते।

There are two more sets among the deceased ancestors to be enquired into.

The majority of mankind who have left this earth having probably lived not very honourable lives, it would certainly be unfair and unjust to class then among the Manushya-Pitris just described. These are divided into two sets, one undergoing punishments in the Hell as Pretas and ever hankering after food, drink and rest, and the other being born in the lower scales of creation in the animal and vegetable kingdoms.

Different kinds of Sradhas are prescribed for the Original Pitris and the varieties of Manushya-Pitris, and the food offered for the benefit of the latter are expected to meet them in the special forms of nourishinents required by them, by the virtue of Manthras and the purity of action, as a calf is capable of finding out its mother in the midst of a herd of COWS. This fact has been assured by Sinatkumara-Rishi, who is said to be gifted with the knowledge of the Pretas, by his Yogic development. What this assurance means could be easily made out when the significance of the said Rishi is known from the pages following.

In noticing again in this connection, the Theosophical explanation of the Pitris and Sradhas, the following extract from Sanathana-Dharma is significant in its own way.

Page 202. “The full meaning of descent from the Pitris is ascertainable only by study of Occult science”.

It can be easily understood by a careful reading of the passages already quoted from the sacred texts, that there are no mysteries represented with regard to the Pitris so far. The real and philosophical interpretation is first given and afterwards a secondary meaning in imitation of the same is furnished, in the usual Puranic style, with a view

to enforce the Ethical necessity of veneration towards the decensel ancestors. More than this nothing mysterious or confounding is discovered, nor even required in the interest of mankind either for worldly or religious purposes. I earnestly wish here to be clearly understood that it is far from my intentionor object to criticise the Theosophists for the work they have done in India, but on the contrary, I am gladly prepared to give them the most charitable considerations and thank the most heartily for having created a spirit of enquiry amongst some of us at least, especially at a time when we have almost reached a stage of utter indifference and disrespect for the contents of our sacred texts. In spite of this fact, I must be excused for what is being statel here, candidly and in plain terms, whenever the real interest of the sacred religion for which we have every legal and moral right, is seriously at stake.

We have unfortunately suffered enough already, by the innocent ignorance of our Pandits, whom we looked upon all along as our unerring guide; and they have practically reduced our religion to something insipid, unscientific and superstitious. We could therefore ill-afford to keep gazing hereafter at further interference in the present fashion. The Pandit’s process of deterioration, being an indigenous one, is capable of easy rectification, as it might be possible to diagnose the local disease without much difficulty. Bat the mistiken procedure of an entirely foreign type, might probably land us in greater confusion and hopelessly place us in irreneliable predicaments. We could however easily discera how the Theosophists have taken to a mistaken course in the present state of affairs, and could fully sympathise with themfor the sun, so far as the interpretations of our ancient literature are coacerned. They were compelled to collect second-hand informations from local Pandits as no

other source was virtually open to them. What was thus obtained could not help appearing absurd on its very face to a western civilized people under the circumstances so often explained. But we are bound to thank the creed for a charitable view they have somehow forined as to the likelihood of our sacred texts containing some sorts of useful and valuable informations. Explanations were therefore attempted naturally by the Western methods of enquiry which unfortunately did not and could not answer the purpose. Theresult of the two mistakes put together was the production of something ridiculous and certainly objectionable as the subject handled was an alien and a most sacred and hoary religion. With reference to the point at issue here the idea of Occultism put forth in the passage quoted from SanathanaDharma, is entirely irrelevant. If the English word ‘Occultism’ used, simply means pure ignorance, we have nothing to complain. Everything unknown and unsaught is of course Occult in that sense, but if it refers to any mystery not found explained in the sacred texts and therefore requiring to be learned from Theosophy, there is no other help than to denounce it as extraneous. There is no doubt that the Occultism here introduced refers to some mysterious powers recognised in Theosophy to find out the deceased ancestors and to keep communion with them or to explain the origin of mankind from the Monads in the Planets. Their peculiar theory, and probably the occultism in question here, as to the Pitris residing in the Moon and their taking birth on the earth as human beings, is as much unwarranted by the contents of our sacred texts as it is by common sense, That our deceased ancestors for whom we perform the Sradha ceremony should be interpreted as our future successors on the arth desce ling from the moon, caunot surely be believed to be the product of a sound brain. The mistake however,

has certainly originated as usual from sheer ignorance of the technical meanings of the words Soma and Soma-loka as used in the texts. They are simply taken to mean the moon as taught by our venerable Pandits. The application of the terms is clearly defined in quotation 2 as everywhere else in the religious literature, as referring to the Akasa.

आकाशाम्भोनिधेर्योसौ सोम इसभिधीयते।
आधारः सर्वभूतानां देवानाममृताकरः॥

With regard to the deceased ancestors, we have the view taken by the sacred texts distinctly stated in quotation 5,

**न मृतानां गतिः शक्या ज्ञातुं न पुनरागतिः।
तपसापि प्रसिद्धेन किं पुनर्मांसचक्षुषा॥ **

‛The ways of the deceased are undiscernible even by great Yogic powers, m ich less by flashy mortal eyes.’ Besides, the Yogic development detailed in the texts is not certainly meant for satisfying the curiosities of this transient material world. The most astonishing facts in this direction will not in the least create feelings of admiration in a Jivan-mukta or a real Yogi.

अपि शीतरुचावर्केसुतीक्ष्णेपीन्दुमण्डले।
अप्यधः प्रसरत्यग्नौजीवन्मुक्तो न विस्मयी॥

अन्नपूर्णोपनिषत्॥

“A Jivanmukta is not astonished even if the sun is made to emit cold rays and the moon hot rays, or if the fire is made to burn downwards”.

But even the powers of a Yogi recognised by the texts could not be soirresponsibly utilized for explaining away irrelevant or unwarranted facts. The texts strictly limit their scope, extent and use, and the acquirement of any such powers is not such an easy or light task as is made to appear, nor everybody in India is a baby ready to swallow

all that is spoken about them. The powers if possessed are not matters for oration but for action, without the least desire for display or fame; and the tests for their real attainment, as understood from the texts, are sufficiently explicit so as to prevent belief in deception. The eight Angas or component parts of Yoga such as Saina, Dama &c., are the preparatory processes necessary for the attainment of Yogic results and each Anga consists of the practice of several moral and religious virtues. Out of these large number of requisites, the very first virtue inculcated in Saina to commence with, is ‘Ahimsa’ or harmlessness. The test for having completely secured this first virtue, is recognised as consisting in the prevention of mutual harm among animals naturally inimical. Animals like lions and tigers, which are by the very nature of their creation, enemies and destroyers of milder animals, such as cows, sheep and deer, are said to behave friendly with them in the presence of the Yogi who has accomplished this single virtue. In the Puranic descriptions of the residences or Asramas of Rishis, this fact can be observed frequently noticed. The existence and non-existence of the Yogic powers claimed in accordance with our Sastras by any member of Theosophy, are thus easily ascertainable. A tiger and a cow let loose before him will immediately solve the problem satisfactorily, and under the existing state of affairs, there is no doubt that the tiger will alone remain to decide the question at issue. The Puranic description of the Pitris is virtually a treatment of Karm-Yoga, a serious and scientific subject in which no pretensions could be of any avail.

अनभ्यासवतश्चैव वृथा गोष्ठ्या न सिद्ध्यति॥

8. We have now to some extent examined the significance of the Devas and the Pitris, two important

personages constantly introduced in the religious texts. The Asuras, though often occurring in them are only mentioned for the purpose of being avoided. Before taking up the next important figures known as the Rishis, it may be desirable to examine particularly the nature of the Asuras named Mandehas, who are said to obstruct the path of the sun every day, and for the removal of whose obstruction the Hindus are strictly ordained to perform the Sandhya-vandana both morning and evening. The following passage from Vishnu-Purana clearly explains the whole subject.

दिवा नकं च सूर्यस्य मन्दा शीघ्रा च वै गतिः।
मन्दाह्नियस्मिन्नयने शीघ्रा नक्तं तदा गतिः।
शीघ्रा दिवा यथा चास्य तथा मन्दा गतिर्निशि।
एकप्रमाणमेवैष मार्गं याति दिवाकरः।
अहोरात्रेण यो भुंक्तेसमस्ता राशयो द्विज।
षडेव राशयो भुंक्ते रात्रावन्याश्च षट् दिवा।
राशिप्रमाणजनिता दीर्घह्रस्वात्मता दिने।
तथा निशायां राशीनां प्रमाणैर्लघुदीर्घता।
दिनादेर्दीर्घह्रस्वत्वं तद्भोगेनैव जायते।
उत्तरे प्रक्रमे शीघ्रा निशि मन्दा गतिर्दिवा।
दक्षिणेत्वयने चैव विपरीता विवस्वतः।
उषा रात्रिः समाख्याता व्युष्टिश्चाप्युच्यते दिनम्।
प्रोच्यते च तथा सन्ध्या उषाव्युष्ट्योर्यदन्तरम्।
सन्ध्याकाले तु सम्प्राप्ते रौद्रे परमदारुणे।
मन्देहा राक्षसा घोराः सूर्यमिच्छन्ति खादितुम्।
प्रजापतिकृतः शापस्तेषां मैत्रेय रक्षसाम्।
अक्षयत्वं शरीराणां मरणञ्च दिने दिने।
ततः सूर्यस्य तैर्युद्धं भवत्यत्यन्तदारुणम्।
ततो द्विजोत्तमास्तोयं प्रक्षिपन्ति महामुने।
ओंकारब्रह्मसंयुक्तं गायत्र्याचाभिमन्त्रितम्।

तेन दह्यन्ति ते पापा वज्रीभूतेन वारिणा।
अग्निहोत्रे हूयते या समन्त्रा प्रथमाहुतिः।
सूर्योज्योतिः सहस्रांशुस्तया दीप्यति भास्करः।
ओंकारो भगवान् विष्णुःत्रिधामा वचसां पतिः।
यदुच्चारणतस्ते तु विनाशं यान्ति राक्षसाः।
वैष्णवोंशः परः सूर्यो योन्तर्ज्योतिरसम्प्लवम्।
अभिधायक ओंकारस्तस्य स प्रेरकः परः।
तेन तत्प्रेरितं ज्योतिरोङ्कारेणाथ दीप्तिमत्।
दहत्यशेषरक्षांसि मन्देहाख्यान्यधानिवै।
तस्मान्नोल्लंघनं कार्यं सन्ध्योपासनकर्मणः।
स हन्ति सूर्य सन्ध्याया नोपास्तिं कुरुते हि यः॥

“In the half year known as Uttarayana and in that known as Dekshinayana, the durations of day and night differ. This difference is not owing to any variation in the rate of sun’s speed. The twelve Rasis or constellations or signs of the Zodiac, six of which extend to the day and six to the night cause this difference of duration. Usha means night, Vyushti is day and the intervening time is Sandhya. At this terrible Sandhya, the Rakshasas named Mandehas attempt to devour the sun by furiously fighting with him. By the curse of Prejapathi, they ever retain their body, but they die every day. The Bramhins at this time pour water muttering Om combined with Gayathri. This water turns into a diamond weapon and destroys the Rakshasas. The first offering of rice in the Agnihotra then adds lustre to the sun. Here Om refers to Vishnu the God of words, and the sun represents the Para-Bramhan the eternal and internal light. The Rakshasas allude to the sins of man. Therefore none shall violate the ordinance to perform this Sandhya, as he would ortherwise be doing harm to the sun”.

The sandhya here explained is regarded as an important religious ceremony to be daily perforined by the Hindus,

and it has now virtually become a meaningless ritual seldom cared for by the younger generation among the educatedHindus. This is indeed a deplorable state of fact for which somebody must be held responsible. Surely, the fault could not be attributed to modern education which undoubtedly improves the intellectual capacities of its sincere votaries. The real difficulty here is, that when education naturally demanded a reasonable explanation for the ceremony under reference, the Pandit authorities owing to their utter want of religious education were unable to furnish necessary explanations, The Sandhya being one of the simplest daily ceremonies ordained by religion, it is indeed a pity that everyone is groping in the dark at present with regard to its real significance. In the interest of our sacred religion and in that of the modern Hindu public, it is highly necessary that a better source of information should be immediately sought for than the misleading and ignorant Pandit authorities. The above quotation clearly proves that the ceremony ordained is no superstitious absurdity, nor mysterious occultism. The worship of the Sun at the Sandhya is plainly explained as referring to the adoration of the internal Atma.

**वैष्णवोंशः परः सूर्यो योन्तर्ज्योतिरसंप्लवम्॥ **

The Rakshasas named Mandehas are said to reprresent the sins of man obstructing the acquirement of real knowledge of the Atma.

दहत्यशेषरक्षांसि मन्देहाख्यान्यघानिवै॥

The process prescribed for the destruction of these Rakshasas or sins is the meditation of the Atma accompanied by the ordained Manthra.

ओंकारब्रह्मसंयुक्तं गायत्र्या चाभिमन्त्रितम्॥

The term Mandeha itself gives the necessary clue here for the Puranic description. It points to the variation of time in the day. Of course this is perceptible only at the Sandhyas, and the Rakshasas are described as appearing at those times. The Sun being the greatest and the grandest light-giver to this material world, the analogical representation of Atma is most appropriate, and the application of the analogy itself is plainly stated in all the religious texts.

सूर्य आत्मा जगतस्तस्थुषश्चइति श्रुतेः॥

असौ वा आदित्यो बहिरात्मान्तरात्मा प्राणो बहिरात्मागत्यान्तरात्मनोनुमीयते। आदित्य ओमित्येवं ध्यायंस्तथात्मानं युंजीतेति॥ मैत्रायण्युपनिषत्॥

“The Sun represents the Atma common to all the movables and immovables. The Sun outside is the objective Atma and Prana is the internal Atina. The workings of the one are compared to those of the other. Therefore meditate upon the Sun as Om and apply it to the Atma”.

There is no doubt that there is ample practical sense in this ordina ce on a psychological point of view. Besides, we could easily infer from these analogical prescriptions of religious ceremonies, that the ancient Rishis, who were masters of their own science, were not unmindful of the collateral effects accruing from external advantages utilized for the purpose of helping on the lower orders of society. These are ordinary observations which could not possibly miss the eye of an earnest and sincere enquirer of truth, more especially in the field of religion in which he is personally interested. There is also nothing surprising in the fact that indifference, incapacity, bias, pride or prejudice fails to perceive correctly and fully even the plainest matters, on account of these very natural defects. And it is equallyno wonder, that those subject to such unfortunate drawbacks, are generally prone to criticise. bare truth and plain

sense, as something derogatory to the dignity of mankind, guaged as they are by the low and vicious standard of their own.

जाड्यं ह्रीमति गण्यते व्रतरुचौ दम्भः शुचौ कैतवम्
शूरे निर्घृणता मुनौ विमतिता दैन्यं प्रियालापिनि।
तेजस्विन्यवलिप्तता मुखरता वक्तर्यशक्तिःस्थिरे
**तत्कोनाम गुणो भवेत्सगुणिनां यो दुर्जनैर्नाङ्कितः॥ **

Like Mahisha and the Mandehas already noticed among the Asuras, there are two well-known brothers named Madhu and Kytabha who are said to have originated from the ears of Vishnu during his sleep. These powerful Asuras once attacked Bramha who had to seek the help of Vishnu to be freed from their molestation. Vishnu destroyed them after a long and terrible fight, and from their Medas, marrow or fat the earthy globe originated called Medini.

पुरा चैकार्णवे जाते विलीने भुवनत्रये।
शेषपर्यङ्कसुप्ते च देवदेवे जनार्दने।
विष्णुकर्णमलोद्भूतौ दानवो मधुकैटभौ।
महाबलौ च तौ दैत्यो विवृद्धौ सागरे जले।
कालेन कियता विप्रा दानवाभ्यां यदृछया।
दृष्टः प्रजापतिर्ब्रह्मा पत्मासनगतः प्रभुः।
दृष्ट्वा तु मुदितावास्तां युद्धकामौ महाबलौ।
तमूचतुस्तदा तत्र युद्धं नो देहि सुव्रत।
नोचेत्पत्मं परित्यज्य यथेष्टं गच्छमा चिरम्।
यदि त्वं निर्बलश्चासि क्व योग्यं शुभमासनम्।
वीरयोग्यमिदं स्थानं कातरोसि त्यजाशु वै।
तयोरिति वचश्श्रुत्वा चिन्तामाप प्रजापतिः॥

रथाङ्गेन तदाछन्ने विष्णुना प्रभविष्णुना।
जघनोपरि वेगेन प्राक्लष्टेशिरसी तयोः।
गतप्राणौ तदा जातौ दानवौ मधुकैटभौ।

सागरस्सकलौ व्याप्तस्तदा वै मदसा तयोः।
मेदिनीति ततो जातं नाम पृथ्व्याः समन्ततः।
अभक्ष्या मृतिका तेन कारणेन मुनीश्वराः॥

देवीभागवतम्॥

The earth being thus made up of the fat of these terrible Asuras is said to have become un-edible. The Pandit evidently has nothing to enlighten us here. He understands nothing out of this story. The description given will doubtless prevent the critic from cooking up any Indian historical incident. Tthe birth and death of these Asuras are said to have taken place in the waters of the ocean which covered the three Lokas, and the earth itself originated from their fat afer their death. Although they were killed by Vishnu at last, their original aim was to attack Bramha. The modern Pandit who has certainly not studied the subject, is under the impression that such stories are meaningless and are left unexplained in the literature. The following gives a clear and sensible explanation of the description.

विघ्नस्तमसि सम्भूतो मधुर्नाम महासुरः।
तथा रजसि सम्भूतो ह्यसुरो नाम कैटभः।
तौ रजस्तमसोद्भूतौ सम्भूतौ तामसौ गुणैः।
एकार्णवं जगत्सर्वंक्षोभयेतां महाबलौ॥

मधुकैटभावूचतुः॥

नावयोः परमं लोके किश्चिदस्ति महामुने।
आवाभ्यां छादितं विश्वं तमसा रजसा च वै।
रजस्तमोमयावावा मृषीणामविलम्बितौ।
छाद्यमानौ धर्मशीलौदुस्तरौ सर्वदेहिनाम्।
आवाभ्यां मुह्यते लोको दुष्कराभ्यां युगे युगे।
आवामर्थश्च कामश्च यज्ञःसर्वपरिग्रहः।
सुखं यत्र मुदायुक्तंयत्र श्रीःकीर्तिरेव च।
येषां यत्कांक्षितं किञ्चित्तत्तदावां विचिन्तय॥

पद्मपुराणम्॥

“The obstruction originating from Tamas is Madhu and from Rejas is Kytabha. The qualities of both are Tamasic and they agitate the whole world, They said: There is none greater than both of us in the Lokas. By Rejas and Tamas we cover up the Viswa and confuse the Rishis in every Yuga. The desire for Artha, Kama, Yegna, happiness, fame &c., falls within our sway”.

Both of these Asuras are plainly said to represent Rejas and Tamas comprising all the varieties of desires as such. Their fat being described as the main ingredient in the composition of this earth, it clearly refers to the religiously objectionable materialistic tendency, and hence explained as unfit for man’s real enjoymet. Bramha alluding to the involutionary tendency of Budhi is naturally described as being attacked by these two Asuras.

आशानाम नदी मनोरथजला तृष्णातरङ्गाकुला
रागग्नाहवती वितर्कविहगा धैर्यद्रुमध्वंसिनी।
मोहावर्तसुदुस्तरातिगहना प्रोत्तुङ्गचिन्तातटी
तस्याः पारगंता विशुद्धमनसो नन्दन्ति योगीश्वराः॥

9. The next allied species of personages requiring explanation is that of the Rishis. We have heard of Rishis of various and curious origins, of different families, sometimes of different shapes and often of peculiar characters. All of them are known to possess immense superhuman powers by religious devotion and Tapas. Several of them are believed to be living in the heavens and the others on the earth. They also visit each other occasionally. No sort of inconvenience is experienced for their travelling freely to different Lokas such as those of Bramha, Vishnu or Siva at any time they desire. Although all of them in- variably are kind and pious, some are by nature angry and some quarrelsome. This is more or less the kind of Puranic

descriptions we possess. It is not difficult to see that on the whole, the appearance of a fable is imprinted on them. The modern mistake of the Pandit originated here in his attempt to reconcile the inconsistencies as they are found, without in the least considering whether the subjects dealt with are not entirely different from their sole appearance. In the fable of the lion and the mouse for instance, the Pandit leaving entirely the purport of the story began, to enquire the whereabouts of the animals and to seek reasons to justify the possibility of their transactions as well as of their conversation in human language. Thus the problem of the Pandit’s error is a simple one and is easily solved. But we are in no way jealous of the respect he is able to command from ordinary people, by his mere apparel, as a great portion of the generally acknowledged respect and inerit among mankind all over the world chiefly depends upon weavermade and tailor-made stuffs. A reasonable suggestion in the proper direction would certainly have saved him from all error, by a simple and convenient enquiry into the further details and the definitions clearly furnished in the texts themselves. No more proofs than the subjoined quotations, are, I daresay needed to convince us of this fact beyond a doubt.

Quotation. No. I.

ऋषीत्येष गतौ धातुः श्रुतौ सत्ये तपस्यथ।
एतत्सन्नियते तस्मिन् ब्रह्मणा स ऋषिःस्मृतः।
निवृत्तिसमकालन्तु बुद्ध्याऽव्यक्तमृषिः स्वयम्।
परं हि ऋषते यस्मात्परमर्षिस्ततः स्मृतः।
गत्यर्थादृषतेर्धातोर्नामनिर्वृत्तिरादितः।
यस्मादेष स्वयंभूतस्तस्माच्चात्मर्षिता स्मृता।
ईश्वराः स्वयमुद्भूता मानसाःब्रह्मणः सुताः।

यस्मान्नहन्यते मानैर्महान् परिगतःपुरः।
यस्मादृषन्ति ये धीरा महान्तं सर्वतो गुणैः।
तस्मान्महर्षयः प्रोक्ता बुद्धेःपरमदर्शिनः।
ईश्वराणां शुभास्तेषां मानसान्तरसाश्च ते।
अहङ्कारं तमश्चैव त्यक्त्वा च ऋषितां गताः।
तस्मात्तु ऋषयस्ते वै भूतादौ तत्वदर्शनाः।
ऋषिपुत्रा ऋषीकात्तु मैथुनात् गर्भसम्भवाः।
तन्मात्राणि च सत्यञ्च ऋषन्ते ते महौजसः।
सत्यर्षयस्ततस्ते वै परमाःसत्यदर्शनाः।
ऋषीणाञ्च सुतास्ते तु विज्ञेया ऋषिपुत्रकाः।
ऋषन्ति वै श्रुतं यस्माद्विशेषांश्चैव तत्वतः।
तस्मात् श्रुतर्षर्येस्तेपि श्रुतस्य परिदर्शनाः।
प्रवर्तते ऋषेर्यस्मान्महांस्तस्मान्महर्षयः।
मन्त्राणां कल्पनञ्चैव विधिदृष्टेषु कर्मसु।
मन्त्रो मन्त्रयतेर्धातोर्ब्राह्मणो ब्रह्मणोऽवनात्।
अल्पाक्षरमसन्दिग्धं सारवद्विश्वतो मुखम्।
अस्तोभमनवद्यञ्च सूत्रं सूत्रविदो विदुः॥

ज्ञेया ब्रह्मर्षयः पूर्वं तेभ्यो देवर्षयः पुनः।
राजर्षयःपुनस्तेभ्य ऋषिप्रकृतयस्त्रयः।
तेभ्य ऋषिप्रकृतयो मुनिभिः संशितव्रतैः।
कश्यपेषु वसिष्ठेषु तथा भृग्वङ्गिरोऽत्रिषु।
पञ्चस्वेतेषु जायन्ते गोत्रेषु ब्रह्मवादिनः।
यस्मादृषन्ति ब्रह्माणं तेन ब्रह्मर्षयः स्मृताः।
धर्मस्याथ पुलस्त्यस्य क्रतोश्च पुलहस्य च।
प्रत्यूषस्य प्रभासस्य कश्यपस्य तथा पुनः।
देवर्षयःसुतास्तेषां नामतस्तान्निबोधत।
देवर्षी धर्मपुत्रौ तु नरनारायणावुभौ।
बालिखिल्याःक्रतोः पुत्राः कर्दमःपुलहस्य तु।
कुबेरश्चैव पौलस्त्यः प्रत्यूषस्याचलः स्मृतः।

पर्वतो नारदश्चैव कश्यपस्यात्मजावुभौ।
ऋषन्ति देवान् यस्मात् ते तस्माद्देवर्षयः स्मृताः।
मानवे वैषये वंशे ऐडवंशे च ये नृपाः।
ऐडा ऐक्ष्वाकनाभागा ज्ञेया राजर्षयस्तु ते।
ऋषन्ति रञ्जनाद्यस्मात् प्रजा राजर्षयस्ततः।
ब्रह्मलोकप्रतिष्ठास्तु स्मृता ब्रह्मर्षयो मताः।
देवलोकप्रतिष्ठाश्च ज्ञेया देवर्षयः शुभाः।
इन्द्रलोकप्रतिष्ठाश्च सर्वे राजर्षयो मताः।
अभिजात्या च तपसा मन्त्रव्याहरणैस्तथा।
एवं ब्रह्मर्षयः प्रोक्ता दिव्या राजर्षयस्तु ये।
सप्तैते सप्तभिश्चैव गुणैः सप्तर्षयस्मृताः॥

षड्कृत्यस्तु पुनः शुक्रे ब्रह्मणा लोककारिणा।
हुते समभवंस्तत्र षट्बह्माण इति श्रुतिः।
मरीचिर्प्रथमस्तत्र मरीचिभ्यः समुत्थितः।
क्रतौ तस्मिन् सुते जज्ञे यतस्तस्मात् स वै क्रतुः।
अहं त्रितीय इत्यर्थः तस्मादत्रिः स कीर्त्यते।
केशैश्च निशितैर्भूतः पुलस्त्यस्तेन स स्मृतः।
केशैर्लम्बैःसमुद्भूतस्तस्मात्तु पुलहः स्मृतः।
वसुमध्यात्समुत्पन्नो वसुमान् वसुधाश्रयः।
वसिष्ठ इतितत्वज्ञैः प्रोच्यते ब्रह्मवादिभिः।
इत्येते ब्रह्मणः पुत्राः मानसाःषण्महर्षयः।
लोकस्य सन्तानकरास्तैरिमा वर्द्धिता प्रजाः।
प्रजापतय इत्येव पठ्यन्ते ब्रह्मणः सुताः॥

एतद्वंशसमुद्भूताः स्थानकालाभिमानिनः।
न च तेनैव रूपेण स्थापयेयुरिमाःप्रजाः।
युमादिनिधनाच्चैव स्थापयेयुरिमाःप्रजाः॥

वायुपुराणम्॥

Q. No. II.

अबुद्धिपूर्वकां विप्रा ब्राह्मीं सृष्टिं निबोधत।
अग्रे ससर्ज वै ब्रह्मा मानसान् आत्मनः समान्।

सनकं सनातनं चैव तथैव च सनन्दनम्।
क्रतुं सनत्कुमारञ्च पूर्वमेव प्रजापतिः।
पञ्चैते योगिनो विप्राः परं वैराग्यमाश्रिताः।
ततो दीर्घेण कालेन दुःखात् क्रोधोभ्यजायत।
समुत्पन्नो महादेवः शरण्यो नीललोहितः।
स्थानाभिमानिनः सर्वान् गदतस्तान् निबोधत।
आपोग्निरन्तरिक्षञ्च द्यौर्वायुः पृथिवी तथा।
नद्यः समुद्राः शैलाश्च वृक्षा वीरुध एव च।
लवाः काष्ठाः कलाश्चैव मुहूर्ता दिवसा क्षपाः।
अर्धमासाश्च मासाश्च अयनाब्दयुगादयः।
स्थानाभिमानिनःसृष्ट्वासाधकानसृजत्पुनः।
मरीचिभृग्वङ्गिरसः पुलस्त्यं पुलहं क्रतुम्।
दक्षमत्रिं वसिष्ठञ्च धर्मं सङ्कल्पमेव च।
प्राणात् ब्रह्मासृजद्दक्षं चक्षुर्भ्याञ्च मरीचिनम्।
शिरसोङ्गिरसं देवो हृदयात्भृगुमेव च।
नेत्राभ्यामत्रिनामानं धर्मञ्च व्यवसायतः।
सङ्कल्पञ्चैव सङ्कल्पात्सर्वलोकपितामहः।
पुलस्त्यञ्च तथोदानाध्यानाच्च पुलहं मुनिम्।
अपानात् क्रतुमव्यग्रं समानाच्च वसिष्ठकम्।
इत्येते ब्रह्मणा सृष्टाः साधका ग्रहमेधिनः।
आस्थाय मानवं रूपं धर्मस्तैः सम्प्रवर्तितः॥

पृथिवीविषयं सर्वे अरुन्धत्यामजायत।
शाण्डिल्यो नैध्रुवो रैभ्यः त्रयः पुत्रास्तु काश्यपाः।
नरप्रकृतयो विप्रा पुलस्त्यस्य वदामि वः।
तस्य पत्न्यश्चतस्रस्तु पौलस्त्यकुलवर्द्धिकाः॥

कूर्मपुराणम्॥

Q. No. III.

आदित्यश्चादिदेवत्वात् तत्राभूत्रिगुणात्मकः।
प्रातः प्रजापतिरसौ मध्याह्ने विष्णुरिष्यते।
रुद्रोपराह्नसमये स एवैकास्त्रिधामयः।

प्रातः प्रजापतेर्जाता मुनयो नवमानवाः।
मरीचिरत्र्यङ्गिरसौ पुलस्त्यः पुलहः क्रतुः।
भृगुर्वसिष्ठ इत्यष्टौ नारदो नवमः स्मृतः।
नवब्रह्माण इत्येष पुराणे निश्चयः स्मृतः॥

भविष्यपुराणम्॥

Q. No. IV.

ऋषयो वाव ते अग्रे सदासन्। तदाहुः।

के ते ऋषय इति। प्राणा वा ऋषयः॥

शतपथब्राह्मणम्॥

Q. No. V.

परत्वेन ऋषन्ते वै भूतादीनृषिकास्ततः।
ऋषीकाणां सुता येतु विज्ञेया ऋषिपुत्रकाः।
श्रुत्वा रूपं परत्वेन स्मृतास्तस्माच्छ्रुतर्षयः।
अव्यक्तात्मा महान्तात्माहङ्कारात्मा तथैव च।
भूतात्मा चेन्द्रियात्मा च तेषां तज्ञानमुच्यते।
इत्येवमृषिजात्यस्तु पञ्चधा नाम विश्रुताः॥

मत्स्यपुराणम्॥

** Q. No. VI.**

सप्त ऋषयः।रश्मयः सप्तर्षयः।ऋषयः द्रष्टारः। सप्तसंख्याश्चते ऋषयोद्रष्टारश्च त्रैलोक्यस्येति सप्तऋषयः॥

ऋषयः॥ ऋषन्ति अमुष्मात् कर्मण एवमर्थवता मन्त्रेण संयुक्तादमुना प्रकारेणैवं लक्षणं फलविपरिणामो भवतीत्यृषयः। ऋषिदर्शनात्। तदेतत्कर्मणः फलविपरिणामदर्शनं औपचारिक्या वृत्या उक्तम्। नहि धर्मस्यदर्शनमस्ति। अत्यन्तापूर्वोहि धर्मः॥

भेदोव्यास इत्यर्थः। भाषणमिति वा। वेदाङ्गविज्ञानेनभासते प्रकाशते वेदार्थ इति॥

विश्वामित्रः सर्वमित्रः सर्वस्यैवहि मित्रम्।सर्वमेव वा तस्यमित्रम्। सर्वे संसृतं भवति सङ्गतम्भवत्येकस्मिन्॥

यास्कनिरुक्तम्॥

Q. No. VII.

ये हि ते ऋषयः ख्याताःसप्तचित्रशिखण्डिनः।
तैरेकमतिभिर्भूत्वा यत्प्रोक्तं शास्त्रमुत्तमम्।
वेदैश्चतुर्भिः समितं कृतं मेरौ महागिरौ।
आस्यैःसप्तभिरुद्गीर्णं लोकधर्ममनुत्तमम्।
मरीचिरत्र्यङ्गिरसौ पुलस्त्यः पुलहः क्रतुः।
वसिष्ठश्च महातेजास्तेहिचित्रशिखण्डिनः।
सप्तप्रकृतयोह्येतास्तथा स्वायम्भुवोष्टमः।
एताभिर्धार्यते लोकस्ताभ्यः शास्त्रं विनिस्सृतम्।
एकाग्रमनसो दान्ता मुनयः संयमे रताः।
भूतभव्यभविष्यज्ञाः सत्यधर्मपरायणाः।
इदंश्रेय इदंब्रह्म इदं हितमनुत्तमम्।
लोकान् सञ्चिन्त्य मनसा ततः शास्त्रं प्रचक्रिरे।
तत्र धर्मार्थकामाहि मोक्षः पश्चाच्च कीर्तितः।
मर्यादा विविधाश्चैव दिवि भूमौ च संस्थिताः॥

अहङ्कारप्रसूतानि महाभूतानि पञ्चधा।
महाभूतानि सृष्ट्वैव तान् गुणान्निर्ममे पुनः।
भूतेभ्यश्चैव निष्पन्ना मूर्तिमन्तश्च तान् शृणु।
मरीचिराङ्गराश्चात्रिः पुलस्त्यः पुलहःऋतुः।
वसिष्ठश्च महात्मा वै यनुः स्वायम्भुवस्तथा।
ज्ञेयाः प्रकृतयोष्टौ ताः यासु लोकाः प्रतिष्ठिताः।
अष्टाभ्यः प्रकृतिभ्यश्च जातं विश्वमिदं जगत्॥

मरीचिरङ्गिराश्चात्रिःपुलस्त्यः पुलहः ऋतुः।
वसिष्ठ इति सप्तैते मनसा निर्मिता हि ते।
एते वेदविदो मुख्या वेदाचार्याश्च कल्पिताः।
प्रवृत्तिधर्मिणश्चैव प्राजापत्ये च कल्पिताः।
अयं क्रियावतां पन्था व्यक्तीभूतस्सनातनः।
अनिरुद्ध इति प्रोक्तो लोकसर्गकरः प्रभुः।
सनः सनत्सुजातश्च सनकःससनन्दनः।
वनत्कुमारः कपिलः सप्तमश्च सनातनः।

सप्तैते मानसाः प्रोक्ता ऋषयो ब्रह्मणस्सुताः।
स्वयमागतविज्ञाना निवृत्तिं धर्ममास्थिताः।
एते योगविदो मुख्याःसांख्यशास्त्रविशारदाः।
आचार्या धर्मशास्त्रेषु मोक्षधर्मप्रवर्तकाः॥

विद्यासहायवन्तं मामदित्यस्थं सनातनः।
कपिलं प्राहुराचार्याः सांख्या निश्चितनिश्चयाः।
पृथिवीवायुराकाशं आपो ज्योतिश्च पञ्चमम्।
ते समेता महात्मानः शरीरमिति संज्ञितम्।
न विना धातुसङ्घातं शरीरं भवति क्वचित्।
न च जीवं विना ब्रह्मन् वायवश्चेष्टयन्त्युत।
सजीवः परिसंख्यातः शेषः सङ्कर्षणः प्रभुः।
तस्मात्सनत्कुमारत्वं योलभत् स्वेन कर्मणा॥

महाभारतं- शान्तिपर्व॥

Q. No. VIII.

सनत्तु नित्यवचनः कुमारःशिशुवाचकः।
सनत्कुमारं तेनेममुवाच कमलोद्भवः॥

ब्रह्मवैवर्तपुराणम्॥

Q. No. IX.

यदोत्पन्नस्तदैवाहं कुमार इति विश्रुतः।
तस्मात्सनत्कुमारं मे नामैतत्कथितं मुने॥

श्रीशिवमहापुराणम्॥

** Q. No. X.**

सोऽयास्य अङ्गिरसोऽङ्गानां हिरसः प्राणो वा अङ्गानां रसः तस्माद्यस्माच्चाङ्गात्प्राण उत्क्रामति तदेव तछ्शुष्यत्येष हि वा अङ्गानां रसः॥ एष उ एव ब्रहस्पतिर्वाग्वै बृहती तस्या एष पतिस्तस्मादु बृहस्पतिः॥

वागेवात्रिर्वाचा ह्यन्नमद्यतेऽत्तिर्ह वै नामैतद्यदत्रिरिति सर्वस्यात्ता भवति सर्वमस्यान्नं भवति य एवं वेद॥

एष प्रजापतिर्यत् हृदयं एतत् ब्रह्मतत्सर्वं तदेतत् त्र्यक्षरं हृदयमिति। हृ इत्येकमक्षरं अभिहरन्त्यस्मै स्वाश्रान्ये च यएवं वेद। द इत्येकमक्षरं दद-

त्यस्मै स्वाश्चान्ये च य एवं वेद। यं इत्येकमक्षरं एति स्वर्ग लोकं य एवं वेद॥

अयमात्मा वाङ्मयो मनोमयः प्राणमयः। त्रयो लोका एत एव वागेवायं लोको मनोन्तरिक्षलोकः प्राणोऽसौ लोकः। यो वेदा एत एव वागेवर्ग्वेदो मनो यजुर्वेदः प्राणस्सामवेदः। देवाः पितरो मनुष्या एत एव वागेव देवा मनः पितरः प्राणो मनुष्याः। पिता माता प्रजैत एव मन एव पिता वाङ्माता प्राणः प्रजा॥

योहवै वसिष्ठां वेद वसिष्ठः स्वानाभवति वाग्वै वसिष्ठा वसिष्ठः स्वानां भवत्यपि च येषां बुभूषति य एवं वेद॥

बृहदारण्यकोपनिषत्॥

Q. No. XI.

यस्मात्सु दुश्चरं तपस्तप्यमानायात्रये पुत्रकामायाऽतितरां तुष्टेन भगवता ज्योतिर्मयेनात्मैव दत्तो यस्माच्चानसूययामत्रेस्तनयोऽभवत्तस्मादुच्यते दत्तात्रेय॥ इतिअथ योऽस्य निरुक्तानि वेद स सर्वं वेद॥

शाण्डिल्योपनिषत्॥

** Q. No. XII.**

शुको मुक्तो वामदेवोऽपि मुक्तभ्यां विना मुक्तिभाजो न सन्ति। शुकमार्गं येनुसरन्ति धीराः सद्योमुक्तास्ते भवन्तीह लोके॥

वामदेवं येनुसरन्ति नित्यं मृत्वा जनित्वा च पुनः पुनस्तत्। ते वै लोके क्रममुक्ता भवन्ति योगैस्सांख्यैः; कर्मभिस्तत्वयुक्तैः॥

शुकश्च वामदेवश्च द्वे सृती देवनिर्मिते।
शुको विहङ्गमः प्रोक्तो वामदेवः पिपीलिका।
अतद्व्यावृत्तिरूपेण साक्षाद्विधिमुखेन वा।
महावाक्यविचारेण सांख्ययोगसमाधिना।
विदित्वा स्वात्मनो रूपं सम्प्रज्ञातसमाधितः।
शुकमार्गेण विरजाःप्रयान्ति परमं पदम्।
यमाद्यासनजायास हठाभ्यासात्पुनः पुनः।
विघ्नबाहुल्यसंजात अणिमा दिवशादिह।
अलब्ध्वापि फलं सम्यक् पुनर्भूत्वा महाकुले।
पुनर्वासनयैवायं योगाभ्यासं पुनश्चरन्।

अनेकजन्माभ्यासेन वामदेवेन वै पथा।
सोपि मुक्तिं समाप्नोति तद्विष्णोः परमं पदम्।
द्वाविमवपि पन्थानौब्रह्मप्राप्तिकरौ शिवौ।
सद्योमुक्तिप्रदश्चैकः क्रममुक्तिप्रदः परः॥

बराहोपनिषत्॥

Q. No. XIII.

मोहभानुजसंक्रान्तं विवेकाख्यं मृकण्डुजम्।
तत्वाविचारपाशेन बद्धं द्वैतभयातुरम्।
उज्जीवयन्निजानन्दे स्वस्वरूपेण संस्थितः।
शेमुषी दक्षिणा प्रोक्ता सा यस्याभिक्षणे मुखम्।
दक्षिणाभिमुखः प्रोक्तश्शिवोसौ ब्रह्मवादिभिः॥

दक्षिणामूर्त्युपनिषत्॥

Q. No. XIV.

अरुन्धत्येव कथिता पुराविद्भिः सरस्वती॥

योगकुण्डल्युपनिषत्॥

Q. No. XV.

अरुन्धतीं ध्रुवं चैव विष्णोस्त्रीणि पदानि च।
आसन्नमृत्युर्नो पश्येत् चतुर्थं मातृमण्डलम्।
अरुन्धती भवेज्जिाह्वा ध्रुवो नासाग्रमुच्यते।
विष्णोः पदानि भ्रूमध्ये नेत्रयोर्मातृमण्डलम्॥

स्कान्दपुराणम्- काशीखण्डम्॥

** Quotation No. I.**

“The term Rishi is derived from its root signifying, going, hearing, truth and Tapas. That which takes you near to the Bramhan is therefore named Rishi. In the involutionary practice, that which carries Budhi to Avyakta and Parom is called Paraina Rishi. That which is self-originated and devoid of pame &c., is Atma-Rishi. The self.

originated sons of Bramha, who are the seers of Budhi and who lead to Mahat are called Maha-Rishis. They are devoid of egoism and ignorance and are great Eswaras. By their union, the Rishi-putras originate known as Satya-Rishis, because they lead to the subtle elements having complete knowledge of the elements or Satya. Sruta-Rishis are those who possess a knowledge of the gross elements and lead you to the Sruti or Vedas. The Maha-Rishis are so called, because they determine the Manthras in accordance with the Vedas and Mahat proceeds from them. The word Manthra is derived from its root, meaning deliberation, and Bramhana from its root meaning, pleasing the Bramhan. A Manthra is known to the wise as a Sutra or short sentence full of faultless and extensive meaning. There are three varieties of Rishis, the Bramha-Rishis being the first. From them the Deva-Rishis originated and from them again, the Raja-Rishis. The Bramha-Rishis are so named because they lead to Bramha. From the five Bramha-Rishis, namely, Kasyapa, Vasishta, Bhrigu, Angira and Athri, the family ofBramha-Rishis originated. From Dharma, Pulastya, Kretu, Pulaha, Pretyusha, Prebhasa and Kasyapa, the Deva-Rishis originated. Nara and Narayana are sons of Dharma; Balakhilyas are Kretu’s sons; Kardama and Kubera are Pulaha’s; Achala is Pretyusha’s; Parvata and Narada are Kasyapa’s. The Deva-Rishis are so named because they lead us to the Devas. In the families of Manu and of Ida, Ikshwaku, Ida, Nabhaga &c., are called Raja-Rishis, because they lead the Prejas by pleasing them. The Bramha-Rishis reside in Bramha-loka, the Deva-Rishis in Deva-loka and the Raja-Rishis in Indra-loka. By noble birth, Tapas and Manthras, the Rishis are thus divided. By the difference of seven qualities, they are called Sapta-Rishis Bramha divided his essence into six parts and sacrificed them for the creation of

the Lokas, and six Maha-Rishis originated from his mind called Prejapathis, from whom the families in the Lokas originated. From Marichi or rays of light, Marichi originated; from Kretu or sacrifice Kretu came up; Athri signifies ‘I am the third’; Pulastya is so named because he cameup from the pointed hair; and Pulaha from the hanging hair. Vasishta is from the midst of Vasu or glory; he is glorious and depends on the earth. These are known as originators of families and represent the basic principles of religious stages and times. The propagation of the Prejasis not carried on by these in themselves, but by a combination of Yugas and destruction”.

The term Rishi aud its various classifications are clearly explained here as referring to certain psychological principles, religious stages and times connected with Manthras. The main idea is the capacity or power to lead on step by step towards the real goal. None of these Rishis are stationed in this material world; and even by feeling every line in the quotation, the Pandit could not find the mention of the Mahamadan’s beard or the Byragi’s twisted lock, which form the distinguishing marks of an Rishi in accordance with his confounded conception.

** Q. No. II.**

“Understand that Bramha’s creation is without the use of Budhi. Bramha first created out of his mind five Yogis equal to him in rank named, Sanaka, Sanatana, Sanandana, Kretu and Sanatkumara. After a long time, Mahadeva of red and blue colours originated from his anger. Bramha then created the basic principles such as the five elements, rivers, oceans, mountains, trees, creepers and different divisions of time up to the Yugas. He then created Marichi, Bhrigu, Angira, Pulastya, Pulaha, Kretu, Deksha, Athri, Vasishta, Dharma and Samkalpa as executive authorities.

Angira came out of his head, Bhrigu originated from his heart, Dharma from his profession or trade, Samkalpa from his imagination, Pulastya from Udana, Pulaha from meditation, Kretu from Apana and Vasishta from Samana. Remaining in the human body they work out the Dharmas. All that is pertaining to Prithivi or Bhumi originated from Arundhati. Sandilya, Nydhruva, and Rybhya are the three sons of Kasyapa representing the nature of man. Pulastya has four wives who propagated his families”.

The divine creations by Bramha here detailed are said to be without the use of the Intellect.

अबुद्धिपूर्वकां विप्रा ब्राह्मीं निबोधत॥

Have the modern interpreters any reasonable explanation to offer here, if they pretend to understand the passage? Bramha was perhaps out of sobriety at the time, and it is therefore a very religious act for man to imitate him occasionally. The very first idea of Bramha’s creation here, is virtually not understood at all. In spite of this plain fact, misinterpretations must unhesit itingly proceed in right earnest. Is it because it has never before been understood or explained properly, except perhaps by occultisms in recent years by Theosophists? Certainly not. The modern Pandit does not and will not study the subject, that is the only mistake; and he must add insult to injury by volunteering his idiotic commentaries. He has absolutely not the slightest idea of Bramha or his creation or the objects said to be created. The ancient Pandits have no doubt carefully studied the subject and have sensibly explained the matter. The first creation here described is known in Puranic language as Tamasasarga. It refers to the natural impulse of Maya and its Avarana-sakti, actuated by the effects of inan’s previous karmas. The creation specified alludes therefore

to the religious qualifications of each individual. The modern Pandit is earnestly referred to the clear explanation furnished by respectable Pandits of his own class in ancient times, and it is hoped that he will now at least repent for his shameless deterioration.

अबुद्धिपूर्वकः सर्गः। स्रष्टाव्यप्राणिकर्मप्रेरणयैव प्रवर्तिते तद्विषयतया सविकल्पकत्वेन तदावरणमायाया यत्स्फुरणं सोयं तमसः सर्गः प्रथमः॥

** Q. No. III.**

“Aditya is so named because of his being the adi or first among the Devas. In accordance with his gunas, he is viewed in three aspects. In the morning he is Prejapathi, in the noon Vishnu and in the eve he is Rudra. From the Prejapathi of the morning, nine Rishis originated, who are established in the Puranas as the nine Bramhas, namely, marichi, Athri, Angira, Pulastya, Pulaha, Kretu, Bhrigu, Vasishta and Narada.”

The Triads here make up the sun; and nine Rishis called Bramhas originate from the rising sun. How is the Pandit going to establish his literal interpretation of sun here, which in itself is only a creation of Bramha. Has he any explanation for the nine Bramhas here specified, and how was this number fixed in the Puranas? The Pandit no doubt is entirely deaf to all such questions.

** Q. No. IV.**

“It is said that the Rishis originated in the beginning, Who are those Rishiş? They are Pranas or life-breaths”.

The Pandit would like to stick on some false beards at least to these Pranas, to establish his conception of Rishis still.

** Q. No. V.**

“Rishikas are those who lead the elements &c to Parom. Rishi-putras are known as their sone. Sruta-Rishis represent

those who having learned the nature of Parom, meditate upon it. The Rishis are said to be of five castes; Avyakta-Atma, Mahanta-Atma, Ahamkara-Atma, Bhuta-Atma and Indriya-Atma. They signify the knowledge of these items.”

It is clearly explained here that Rishis signify the knowledge of certain psychological items. The Pundit’s idea of knowledge and ignorance too is perhaps in human form without which his brain cannot conceive anything.

** Q. No. VI.**

“The rays of light are the sapta-Rishis. The Rishis are seers. The seers of the three Lokas are the sapta-Rishia. The Rishis lead by karma, manthra and its meaning, and producing a change in the effects, cause the perception of Dharma. As the perception of Dharma is very rare, the definition is somewhat complementary.”

“Vyasa, means dividing, also explaining. It denotes the understanding of the Vedas by a knowledge of the Vedangas.”

“Vishwamithra, means friend of all, or, all are his friends. It denotes that evrything unites or fits together harmoniously.”

The sapta-Rishis are here clearly explained as including to the seven rays, the seven Prakritis or glories belonging to the religious sun, the Apara-Atma, Sabda-Bramhan or Purana-purusha. The term Rishi meaning seer, represents the developed faculty for perceiving or experiencing the religious objects specified. Vyasa represents the faculty of analysing the Velas by the study of the Vedangas. Viswamithra, similarly alludes to manana, consideration or observation of particular facts, by which the various religious details are brought to a harmonious whole. There is not the slightest difficulty now to understand, that. the Rishis

signify the various important items in our religious psychology.

** Q. No. VII.**

“The Sapta-Rishis are known as Chithrasikhandins, consisting of Marichi, Athri, Angira, Pulastya, Pulaha, Kretu and Vasishta. They represent the seven Prakritis, and adding Swayambhuva make up eight. They are truthful, religious and all seeing Munis and are the supporters of the Lokas. These Rishis accompanied by the four Vedas, met together on Mount Meru; and in consideration of the Lokas, they produced the Sastras specifying the Dharmas for the. Lokas. Dharma, Artha, Kama and Moksha are clearly explained therein, also the nature of Bramhan, the bounds of morality in heaven and earth and everything pertaining to the welfare of man.

The subtle elements originated from Ahamkara. From these elements, the eight Rishis above named originated, known as the eight Prakritis that support the Lokas, and from which the Viswa and the Jagat originated. The seven Rishis originated from Bramha’s mind, are learnedin the Vedas. They are also the expounders of the Vedas and thesters of Pravriti-Dharma. This is the established-eternal path of Karma-yoga. The creator of the Lokas is known as Lord Anirudha. Sana, Sanat-sujata, Sanaka, Sanandana, Sanat-kumara, Kapila and Sanatana are also seven mind-born sons of Bramhs. They are self-illumined masters of Yoga and Sankhya, and are the propounders of Nivriti-Dharma leading to final emancipation. Those learned in the Sankhyas call me Kapila as I am seated in the sun combined with Vidya. The five elements joined together compose a body, otherwise, no body can exist. The vital sire cannot work without Jiva or Life principle. By nature

of its action therefore this Jiva is called Sesha, Samkarshana and Sanat-Kumara.”

The two sets of Sapta-Rishis are here clearly explained as originating from Bramha and as representing Karma-Yoga and Gnana-Yoga respectively. The Rishi named Kapila is virtually identified with Sankhya-Yoga and Sanat-kumara with the life principle, Sesha and Samkarshana being its synonymous terms. Kapila is in the Sun with his wife Vidya and the other Rishis are also of no tangible form. Tho Pandit cannot therefore hope to see them inhuman form with or without beards.

Qs. No. VIII & IX.

“Sanat, means eternal and Kumara means a boy. Bramha therefore called me Sanat-kumara. I ever remain as I was first born, and I am therefore named Sanat-kumara”.

The definition of Sanat-kumara is very clear here. The individual life in its pristine purity and complete innocenceis alluded to. When all the worldly dross is removed by devotional practices and the state of the real Twomor Thou is reached, the Rishihood specified is attained. The Pandit who is growing anxious about his old age might relish the idea of becoming a Sanat-kumara in his literal sense by his own transformation into an old boy again. It must take a pretty long time before he can expect to accomplish this.

Q. No. X.

“Angiras, alludes to Prana or life, as when it leaves. any Anga or limb in the body, that part withers. Vak, word or the Veda, is magnanimous, and its Pati or Lord is Brihaspati, Athri refers to Vak or the Veda, as everything is swallowed up or contained in the Vedas. Athri means eating up. He is wise who understands this. Prajapathi, represents Hridayam or the heart. The letter Hri takes in

everything belonging to oneself or to others. Da, signifies giving everything, and Yem denotes, leading to the Heavens. He is wise who understands this.

Mind, Word and Prana are the three divisions of this Atma. They represent the three Lokas, Word is this Loka, Mind is Akasic Loka and Prana is that Loka. They represent the three Vedas. Word is Ric-Veda, Mind, is Yejur-veda and Prana is Sama-veda. They are again the Devas, Pitris and men. Word refers to the Devas, Mind to the Pitris and Prana to the Prejas. Vak or Veda is Vasishta. He who understands this becomes Vasishta hinself. He is wise whounderstands this.”

The text is sufficien tly plain here, unless one is determined not to read it.

Q. No. XI.

“The God gave himself up, to the highly devotional Athri and his wife Anasuya, in the from of light and was born as their son named Dattathreya. He who understands the Niruktas of this description, understands everything”.

The logical conclusion here, must be that if the Niruktas pointed but are not cared for, nothing could be understood from this passage. Our venerable Pandit however, is unfortunately in bad terms with this confounding Nirukta.

** Q. No. XII.**

“There are two religious paths prescribed for securing final emancipation; one is called Suka-marga and the other Vamadevamarga. Suka means a flying bird and the path of that name, alludes to Sankhyayoga, Samadhi &c. by which emancipation is quickly obtained. Vama-deva means a crawling ant and the path of that name alludes to the practice of Ashtanga-yogas and other processes which secure

emaucipation, only after undergoing many difficulties and after several births”.

Two religious paths are naturally prescribed here to suit the different qualifications of man, the advanced stage named Sukamarga being for the use of the highly qualified and the lower one called Vamadeva-marga for the less qualified. The Panlit simply mistakes the road for thepassenger here. His erudition has evidently made his eyes dim.

** Q. No. XIII.**

“Dekshina-murthi or Siva saved Markandeya son of Mrikandu, from the noose of Death and gave the knowledge of the self. Here Death represents ignorance, and Markandeya stands for Viveka or discriminating faculty. The hoose refers to the bondage consequent on the ignoranceof the Tatwas. Fear of Death points to the existing idea of duality. Dekshina, means intellect and when that is developed in the proper direction, it is Dekshina-abhimukha representing Siva”.

The text here explains every word and every idea in the quotation, which will require a highly perverted intellect to misunderstand. The modern Pandit no doubt is sufficently gifted with this stuff for his notorions profession.

Q. Nos. XIV &. XV.

“The ancients clearly meant to represent Saraswati by the term Arundhati. A man whose death is near, fails to see Arundhati, Dhruva, Vishnu-pada and Mathri-mandala. Here Arundhati represents the tongue; Dhruva the tip of the nose; Vishnu-pada, the space bentween the eye-brows and Mathri-mandala, the eyes”.

The technical terms used in the quotation are explained in the same. The modern interpreters might erase some of

these lines as they are very vexing indeed. But how do they feel confident that their unauthorised, unqualified and unreasonable misinterpretations are exceedingly pleasing to others? No doubt they judge everything by their own standard, but forget that they will be judged at one time by better standards.

ये के विचित्ररसशालिषु सत्कवीनां सूक्तेषु कर्णपथगामिषु नाद्रियन्ते।
ते मालतीपरिमलेष्वपि कन्दलत्सु नासापुटंकरतलेन पिदध्युरेव॥

10. The descriptions of Rishis as found in the passages quoted above, disclose plainer, simpler and less complicated facts as compared with those enquired into, in the preceding paras, and we are consequently in a position to understand them without much thought and trouble.

The Rishis clearly represent certain definite conditions of intellectual development in man to be attained by Yoga and Sankhya practices. The significance of almost all the names may be invariably traced by referring to their derivations. it is easy to discover that none of the denote the proper names of any specific individuals, but point to some advanced stages of human conduct leading on to the ultimate goal. The large number of Rishis differing in character indicate the various halting places provided for, in the progressive path of religious devotion. Every one of them therefore deserves and demands due respect and consideration, if only the object of running out the prescribed course completely, is ever aimed at. The different classifications of Rishis furnished in the quotations should be correctly understood for the proper comprehension and practice of the ordained courses of action in our sacred religion without a knowledge of which they are apt to be treated as profitless and superstitious. Every Manthra or religious prayer has its particular Rishi recognised, clearly showing how the stage

of attainment of the devotee is distinctly marked and a suitable Manthra is provided for his benefit. There is thus not the slightest doubt as to the important part played by these Rishis throughout our religious ordinances, and it costs no effort to discover that invariably all the valuable and religious instructions conveyed in the texts are in the names of some specific Rishis. The names of the Instructors thus particularised are not therefore meaningless or purposeless. A very valuable clue is by this means furnished at the very commencement, for the correct interpretations of the contents of the instructions, and for noticing the intellectual, moral and religious status of the persons to whom they are intended. Quotation 7 classifies two sets of Sapta-Rishis or seven Rishis said to have been born from the mind of Bramha; referring directly to the seven Prakritis or material causes of creation. The two sets are distinguished from each other by the nature of their work, one pertaining to Nivriti, Sankhya or Gnana-Yoga; and the other to Pravriti or Karma-Yoga. The seven Rishis dealing with the former are, Sana, Sanatsujata, Sanaka; Sanadana, Sanat-kumara, Kapila and Sanatana; those dealing with the latter are, Marichi, Angira, Atri, Pulastya, Pulaha, Kretu and Vasishta, and adding Swayambhuva-Manu, the latter set makes up the eight Prakritis. The vital distinction between Karma-yoga and Gnana-yoga as well as their practical applications in detail are ingeniously explained by this classification.

In our philosophical analysis, we have already seen that the cosmological conception of the Universe resolves itself into seven Prakritis. Each of these Prakritis is here taken into consideration and utilized in two different ways for purposes of religious advancement. The Pravriti-marga or Karma-yoga deals with the Prakritis by cognising the energy of Eswara inherent in their respective functions in

the evolution of the religions universe, and meditates upon the unthwarted display of each Prakriti as the glories of the Almighty exhibited through them. The Nivriti-marga or Gnana-yoga, on the other hand simply notices the work of the Prakritis but passes on to the real goal beyond, leaving them as comparatively unimportant in consideration of the transient nature of the phenomenal existence as a whole. The processess for correctly understanding the scope and extent of each of the Prakritis, and for obtaining control over each of them with a view to pass over, one after another, are doubtless matters of practical and religious importance. It might perhaps be necessary to be reminded of the real significance of Prakriti and of its evolution and involution of the religious universe, lest the readers go astray even at the present stage of this essay. Let it be told again and again that Prakriti alludes to the Satwic Maya and not to Avidya, and that the evolution and involution of the universe here noticed are the work of the former explained as the glories of God. The evolution and involution of the material world with all its miseries and disappointments belong to the functions of Avidya, and they display no doubt, the glories of the wickedness and stupidity of the individual man, which the religious texts do not recognise either in the Karma-yoga or Gnana-yoga, in the Pravriti-marga or Nivrti-marga prescribed for devotional practices. The meditation of a God or Goddess in some material form prescribed for the lower grades of practice cannot be substituted by the meditation of the form of a whore for religious purposes. The Pandit always forgets this fact and imagines he is extremely religious in his own favourite meditations.

द्रष्टव्येषु किमुत्तमं मृगदृशां प्रेमप्रसन्नं मुखम्
घ्रातव्येषु च किं तदास्यपवनश्श्राव्येषु किन्तद्वचः।

किं खाद्येषु तदोष्टपल्लवरसः स्पृश्येषु किं तद्वपु-
ध्येयं किं नवयौवनं सहृदयैस्सर्वत्र तद्विभ्रमः॥

The derivative meaning of the word Rishi is clearly explained in quotation 1 as pointing to the capability of approaching or taking near to the Bramhan step by step. The gradual progress on the prescribed path of religious practice is marked distinctly at every specific stage, by giving suitable appellations to the Rishis concerned. In the same quotation we find full and significant definitions furnished for the following names.

  1. Rishi, 2. Parama-Rishi, 3. Atma-Rishi;
  2. Maha-Rishi; 5.Satya-Rishi; 6. Sruta-Rishi;
    7.Bramha-Rishi; 8.Deva-Rishi; 9. Raja-Rishi;
  3. Rishikas and 11. Rishi-putras.

We find again that six Rishis already enumerated are classed under Prajapathis; namely, Marichi, Kretu, Athri, Pulastya, Pulaha and Vasishta. In quotation 3 we find that three more names are added namely Bhrigu, Angira and Narada, thus making the number of Prajapathis into 9. They are dercribed in quotation 1, as follows.

लोकसन्तानकरा स्तैरिमा वर्द्धिता प्रजाः।
एतद्वंशसमुद्भूताः स्थानकालाभिमानिनः॥

Quotation 2 speaks of them thus.

साधकाः ग्रहमेधिनः॥

They are said to be the progenitors of the families in the Lokas and skilful adepts in family-life. Slightly equivocal descriptions of this kind occasionally might mislead the reader who has no idea of what is being narrated. For such mistakes, it is not proper to lay the blame on the venerable authors of these texts, as it is the privilege of no reader of books to pick up a single line or two and to criticise or inisinterpret the whole in his own way, utterly disregarding

the portions before and after. The Lokas have been already found on examination to be different from this earthy sphere, and the subjects, Prajas and families here mentioned, musttherefore represent something equally different. Quotation 10 clearly defines Prajapathi as the Heart and Praja as Prana.

“एष प्रजापतिर्यत् हृदयं एतत् ब्रह्मैतत्सर्वे तदेतत्र्यक्षरं हृदयामिति॥"
“पिता माता प्रजैत एव मन एव पिता वाङ्माता प्राणःप्रजा"

The Lokas thus refer to the several Prakritis identical with the corresponding Rishis themselves; and the families or Prajas originated in them denote the respective effects produced on the intellect of the devotee by the meditation of these Lokas and their working as the glories of God. Thus far the functions of one set of Sapta-Rishis and of the six or nine Prajapathis are explained. The remaining Sapta-Rishis deal solely with Gnana-yoga without special meditations on these Lokas and their workings.

Our quotations on the subject in question, furnish however, still further varieties of classification and they deserve careful examination.

The origin of three elasses of Rishis is detailed in quotation 1. The Bramha-Rishis came first. From them the second set styled Deva-Rishis originated. From the Deva-Rishis again the third set known as Raja-Rishis originated. Those who take us or lead us to the Bramhan direct aredefined as Bramha-Rishis, and those leading to the Devas are Deva-Rishis; and the rulers who lead and guide their subjects by pleasing them are styled Raja-Rishis. The last set alone demands some explanation. But any doubts with regard to their definitions will be cleared when we examine their whereabouts. The Bramha-Rishis are said to inhabit

the Brainha-loka, the Deva. Rishis, the Deva-loka and the Raja -Rishis the Indra-loka.

ब्रह्मलोकप्रतिष्ठास्तु स्मृता ब्रह्मर्षयो मताः।
देवलोकप्रतिष्ठाश्च ज्ञेया देवर्षयः शुभाः।
इन्द्रलोकप्रतिष्ठास्तु सर्वे राजर्षयो मताः॥

It is indeed surpsising to note that no Rishi has his residence in any of the modern towns or even forests situated on the surface of our mother earth.

The above classification is said to be based upon their caste, their Tapas and the nature of the Manthras attributed to them.

अभिजात्या च तपसा मन्त्रव्याहरणैस्तथा।
एवं ब्रह्मर्षयः प्रोक्ता दिव्या राजर्षयस्तु ये।
सप्तैते सप्तभिश्चैव गुणैःसप्तर्षयः स्मृताः॥

What is meant by their caste is clearly explained in quotation 5. They are divided into the five following castes and are said to represent the knowledge of Avyakta, Mahat, Ahamkara, Bhuta and Indriya.

  1. Avyakta-Atma: 2. Mahanta-Atma; 3. Ahomkara-Atma; 4. Bhuta-Atma and 5. Indriya-Atma respectively.

अव्यक्तात्मा महान्तात्माहङ्कारात्मा तथैव च।
भूतात्मा चेन्द्रियात्मा च तेषां तज्ञानमुच्यते।
इत्येवमृषिजात्यस्तु पञ्चधा नाम विश्रुताः॥

It would certainly be a pity still to doubt the significance of the Rishis and equally a hopeless task to furnish further explanations. The Lokas specified, represent the respective stages attributed to the Rishis and the Sastras pertaining to those Lokas are instructions for attaining them. All these are said to be the productions of the Rishis themselves, in quotation 7.

लोकान् सञ्चिन्त्य मनसा ततः शास्त्रं प्रचक्रिरे॥

The Lokas are identical with the psychological matters specified and are simply so describe for the purpose of making them easily understandable to the ordinary people. But unfortunately they are entirely misun lorstood and the object aimed at is frustrated completely in modern days.

‘लोक्यत इतिलोकः। ब्रह्मैवलोको ब्रह्मलोकः॥ब्रह्मणः पुरं ब्रह्मपुरमिति तदुपलब्धिस्थानं विद्याधिकारिशरीरमुच्यते॥

न तस्य प्राणा उत्क्रामन्त्यत्रैव समवलीयन्ते। ब्रह्मैव सन् ब्रह्माप्येति॥

“Lokya refers to reality. Bramha-loka is Bramha itself. Bramha-pura means the region or situation in which Bramha is attained, and this alludes to the qualifiel body of the Yogi. Attaining Bramhan is becoming Bramhan”.

Nothing could be more plainly explained in any human language. But the Pandit discards every human language as he has secured a different one for himself. In his language, everything in his universe is material.

द्वैतमेव हि सर्वत्र प्रवदन्ति हि केचन।
न ते मनुष्याः कीटाश्च पतङ्गाश्च घटा हि ते॥

From the enquiry so far regarding the significance of the terms conncetel with different forms of Rishis, the philosophical applications are simple and clear; and they do not of course demand any mysterious explanations to understand them in their proper light. This portion of philosophy, as a subject, stripped of its religious references to the point in question, is the common property of all civilized nations, and we have therefore the right to appeal to the philosophers all over the world for its safety, without being meddled with, by illogical and unphilosophical processes. On the pretext of religion, neither our Pandit nor the Theosophist has the privilege of interfering with God-given Intellect and wisdom in man, of ancient or modern

times. Any infringement in this direction could only be treated as an unreasonable and unsuthorisei attack upon Human Reason itself.

The religious utilization of the philosophical principles in this connection, could be perceived to rest on a scientific basis, provided the philosophy underlying, is properly understood. The Pandit’s ignorant interpretations without the knowledge of this philosophy are totally misleadingand the foreign alditions not even independently of the texts, are stranger still. The Theosophists freely quote pissages from Vayu, Vishnu, Padma and other Puranas and base their inferences on thom for their peculiar ideas, entirely new to our religious sphere, such as, spiritual ares and Physical arcs, Astral phantoms and Prototypes, Primaries and doubles &c. That the Rakshasas are the Atlantians belonging to the submerged races, that Varahà-Avatar is an antediluvian lacustrine auimal and that Americans and Europeans belong to the present 5th root-race, and similar theories promulgated in the Secret Doctrine, are certainly astonishing interpretations of our ancient religious texts, and they exhibit no doubt an entirely new method of manufacturing religious absurdities in the commencement of this twentieth century. What strikes one clearly here is that borrowed feathers were hardly needed, if the object were only to shine in this unique fashion.

झटिति प्रतिवक्तव्यं सभासु विजिगीषुभिः।
अबद्धं वा सुबद्धं वा कुन्तीपुत्रो विनायकः।
उच्चैरुच्चरितव्यं यत्किञ्चिदजानतापि पुरुषेण।
मूर्खा विश्वास्यन्ते विदुषामपि संशयो भवति॥

In further proof of the explanations already offered for Rishis in general, a few more terms which possess the appearance of proper names given to individual Rishis may be examined here.

Quotations 1 and 10 define Vasishta as connected with Prithivi and Vak.

वसुमध्यात्समुत्पन्नो वसुमान् वसुधाश्रयः।
वसिष्ठ इति तत्वज्ञैः प्रोच्यते ब्रह्मवादिभिः॥
वाग्वैवसिष्ठा वसिष्ठः स्वानां भवत्यपि च॥

Prithivi or earth is here meant to represent the Vedas, the very foundation upon which our sacred religion is built. Vak or word similarly denotes the knowledge of Sruthi or Vedas.

Quotations 2, 14 and 15 explain Arundhathi, the wife of Vasishta, as referring to the saine Prithivi. She is also defined as representing the tongue and the Goddess Saraswathy.

पृथिवीविषयं सर्वम्अरुन्धत्यामजायत॥
अरुन्धत्येव कथिता पुराविद्भिस्सरस्वती॥
अरुन्धती भवेजिह्वा॥

No clearer descriptions are here required to understand the significance of these two terms. The husband of Arundhati here by no mears can act without the help of this particular wife and she has always to depend upon this very husband to maintain her dignity and importance.

Quotation 6 explains Vyasa as the analyser and commentator of the Vedas exhibiting their true purport; thus referring to that particular faculty.

Quotation 7 explains Kapila as seated in the sun combined with Vidya aud referring to Sankhya-gnana.

Quotations 7, 8 and 9 define Sanat-kumara in unequivocal terms, as representing Jiva or individual soul, untainted by worldly filth and remaining as pure as it was while first born as the son of Bramha.

Quotation 10 describes Angiras as tantamount to Prana. Brahaspathi and Atri are said to be connected with Vak or Vedas and therefore almost synonymous with Vasishta.

Quotation 11 explains Dettatreya as Eswara who offered himself to Atri as his son, and notes that the Nirukta of this word will furnish complete information.

Quotation 15 explains three more words, than Arundhati already noticed. Dhruva, Vishnu-pada and Matri-mandala, are described as the end of the nose, the spot between the brows and the two eyes respectively.

Quotation 13 gives the full history of Markandeya-Rishi. It is plainly stated that the Rishi represents Viveka, distinguishing, analysing Intellect. Yema or death who is said to have attacked him, signifies Ignorance. Yema’s noose stands for the absence of philosophical insight; and the fear of Death is caused by the idea of Duality and the absence of the knowledge of Unity. Dekshina-murti or Siva who is said to have saved the Rishi from Death is equally well explained. Dekshina is defined as Semushi or Intellect and the effect of constantly
developing it in the right direction and extricating all the worldly dross from it is the God Siva himself.

तुषेण बद्धो व्रीहिस्यात् तुषाभावेन तण्डुलः।
एवं बद्धस्तथा जीवः कर्मनाशे सदाशिवः।
पाशबद्धस्तथा जीवःपाशमुक्तस्सदाशिवः॥

No plainer explanation is needed to understand this subject provided one is gifted with ordinary human reason.

Mrikanduja or Markandeya can also be known by a reference to its root meaning. Mri to kill and Kandu, itch or filth. The Intellect freed from sinful or evil thoughts and desires, is the idea expressed by the term.

Quotation 12 gives a detailed description of Suka and Vamadeva, which could on no account be mistaken for any current ideas as to their being two real personages. They are clearly explained as two different paths for the attainment of salvation. Suka-marga is explained as so named on account of its possibility to soar high at once like a bird and it distinctly refers to Sankhya-gnana. Vamadeva means to crawl slowly like an ant, and the Marga or path namedafter him represents the process of obtaining gradual progress,. overcoming the difficulties that intervene by long periods of trouble and effort. This path distinctly refers to the Karma-yoga. The two sets of Sapta-Rishis noticed in this para refer to the same differentiation. The distinction between these two paths of Yogas we have elaborately treated in Chapter II; and it may be observed here that they are not religious processes left to the free option or selection of man, but that they chiefly depend upon his qualifications for practice. As it is a matter of vital importance commonly misunderstood, a few lines from the passage quoted before, may be profitably noted below with a view to remind us of the qualifications insisted upon for their practice.

स्वसंवेद्यं हि तद्ब्रह्म कुमारी स्त्रीसुखं यथा।
अयोगी नैव जानाति जात्यन्ध इव वर्णिकान्।
बहुव्याकुलचित्तानां विचारात्तत्वधीर्न हि।
योगो मुख्यस्ततस्तेषां धीदर्पस्तेन नश्यति।
अव्याकुलधियां मोहमात्रेणाच्छादितात्मनाम्।
सांख्यनामा विचारस्यात् मुख्यो झटितिसिद्धिदः॥

Quotation 6 describes Viswamithra as the friend of all, towards whom everything rushes and in whoin everything joins, representing thereby the Reasoning Faculty in man known as Mauana. We have just before seen that Vasishta represents Sruti or Vedas and Manana is the next stage. New

facts learned from the Vedas are thought over for understnading them, and very often doubts arise for their immediate conviction. This idea is generally described as quarrels taking place between the two Rishis, and Vasishta of course triumphing at last over Viswamitra. We seldom hear stories of other Rishis quarrelling in this manner.

We must however stop with the subject here, as it is neither convenient nor necessary to give an exhaustive treatment of all the Rishis mentioned in the texts. Explanations may be offered wherever new names are introduced in the subsequent portions of this treatise. But it is hoped that the general formulas and explanations already furnished will enable the readers to find out for themselves the real clue to the significance of new names appearing in the religious literature.

11. Before closing this section, I feel it my duty to offer a word of apology to our venerable Pandits and Theosophists for the few unavoidable romarks I was compelled to make against their interpretations of our religious texts. It must anyhow be admitted that I have brought no fresh charges against them now, in behalf of the correct understanding of the important items explained in this little essay. Hinduisın versus Pandit and Theosophy, has virtually been an old case long pending in India, and I have only placed the two in their proper order, the Pandit appearing as the first and the Theosophist as the second. In justice to the earnest work done by the latter, I am strongly of opinion that all the current criticisms against Theosophy are uncharitable to say the least. Theosophy minus Hinduism we have absolutely no right to attack, and even the existing criticisms against its method of interpreting our religion are more or less whimsical and cowardly. It is surely unprofitable, and discourteous on our part to rejoice over its recent

confusions in the Mission. Even supposing that Theosophy leaves India for good, one of these days, there is not the slightest assurance of our countrymen not being ready to swallow any other sophy or ism that might at any future time, make its appearance in the lanl, armed with further modifications and explanations for our holy religion. The most shameful and culpable fact of our own ignorance of the subject, still remains intact, and no hopeful signs of improvement in the near future combined with the necessary zeal and earnestness to make up for the great fall for a few centuries past, are yet clearly visible. In the history of the Religions of the world, we at present really occupy a very unique and pitiable position, the natural result of our own indifference and lethargy. Our Pandit has gradually lost his dignified status, once commanded and gladly recognised in the country, by his deterioration in erudition, general knowledge and even self-respect, and he has virtually dwindled into one of the inutilities of a nation, still lingering by sheer force of existence. No similar charges could however be laid at the door of the Theosophist who is invariably a cultured gentleman, unfortunately misled in his attempt to do some useful work by his mistaken method of procedure. He is certainly amenable to reason aud conviction and is capable of turning to good account. The Pandit on the other hand has clearly washed his hands off everything useful and reasonable and simply stands stubborn in an uncouth fashion. These are bare facts which we could not afford to conceal in the interest of truth.

______________________________

Summary of the first three Chapters.

Part I of this essay has to be concluded by the end of this Chapter, having by this time examined the preparatory

details necessary to enable us to proceed with the main subject conveniently, in a convincing style of treatment. A general survey of what has been hitherto done for this purpose may be useful to keep us reminded of the important facts noticed in these three Chapters, with a view to apply them readily for the correct interpretations of terms and ideas demanding explanations in the subsequent pages forming Part II of this book.

Chapter I has been set apart almost as an introductory one to explain and prove the absurd and injurious conclusions, both scientific and religious, to which the current interpretations, local and foreign, are unconsciously but inevitably drifting. Apparent geographical descriptions and specifications of time as well as religious personalities treated in our ancient religious literature, have been shown to refer to serious and religious matters, and that their modern interpretations are not only unsatisfactory, but are also so irrelevant and incoherent that they furnish no respectable informations of any kind useful to mankind. We have also noticed in this Chapter that the literature in question is the product of literary giants, apart from its scientific and religious importance, and could not therefore be easily condemned as worthless or explained away in the present careless fashion, without clearly exhibiting one’s own ignorance,impertinence, bias or apathy. Sufficient instances have also been cited to show that the current silly method of interpretation as well as the irresponsible undertakings to calumnise are unwarranted and unjustifiable. In the circumstances detailed above, we have seen that a complete and searching enquiry was absolutely necessary to be instituted, in justice to the dignity and usefulness of the subject as well as to the veneration and gratitude due to the ancient sages as compilers of the texts, in which they have bequeathed volumes

of immense wisdom and knowledge for the real benefit of their beloved posterity. Chapter II was thus started to examine as clearly as possible the nature and scope of the varieties of religious literature owned by our countrymen, for ages yet unknown to the modern Historian and Archæologist. We have been able to see on enquiry that the knowledge required for religious perfection is described as twofold, consisting of the Para and Apara Vidyas, of which the former is reckoned as the ultimate knowledge by experience, which could be secured only by virtue of devotional practices specially prescribed in the Apara-vidy. The theoretical and practical portions of the subject have thus been clearly distinguished in the very beginning and the theoretical consisting of texts furnishing full instructions on the subject has been divided into 14 Vidyas, starting with the Vedas themselves. The scope and application of the Puranas and Itihasas falling within this classification have been particularly examined in detail, and we have found that they clearly refer to the treatinent of Sabda-Bramhan, Apara-Bramhan or Purana-Purusha, and its latent energies and glories discovered and utilized by the ancient sages for religious advancement by meditations on their evolutionary and involutionary effects.We have also thereby distinctly understood that the Puranic stories containing apparent descriptions of places, times and personalities as well as of creations, preservations and destructions of worlds such as 14 Lokas, Bramhandas &c, tell tales of far more serious matters than those connected with this evanescent material world and its still more transient and pigmy inhabitants.

Thus far we have examined the general significance of the subjects and their texts comprising our ancient religious

literature in Section I of this Chapter. It must however be specially noticed here that all the above explanations are entirely based upon original passages selected from authontic texts and that no personal views have been ventured to be foisted on the public, like most of the attempts of modern critics which are often conspicuous by the entire absence of any such authority.

The next and most important subject dealt with in the remaining portion of this Chapter, Section II, is the Hindu Philosophy as applied specially to our ancient religion. This subject however has taken up more space than was originally expected, consistent with the size and scope of this little essay, on account of its being the very foundation upon which the whole religion with its various grades and stages for practical application, is constructed. There is of course a general and reasonable impression prevailing amongst all intelligent enquirers of Indian affairs, that every national movement in India, Political, social or artistic is based uponsome religious conviction working like an undercurrent. But the further fact, of religious convictions having invariably originated ages ago, from their corresponding and long established philosophical foundations, has unfortunately been now forgotten and it therefore urgently demands its recognition in the permanent interest of our religion as a whole. The existing differences of views and uncertainties as to the details of various matters relating to our religion, accepted as it is in its general scope and function, can be easily and conveniently traced to the ignorance of the fundamental and philosophical principles, and a correct knowledge of the same is hopefully expected to set things aright. An examination of the several important points of philosophy as explained in the religious texts has clearly proved that they are by no means liable to be contradicted oven by the most recent

facts established in Western Philosophy. On the contrary, we have seen that many a new and grand theory of the modern day has been foretold and practically utilized, showing how familiar the ideas were to the ancient sages. In the comparison of Western with Eastern philosophy several important facts new to the former are found enunciated in the latter; and philosophy as a practical subject closely connected with our religion for the tangible attainment of the ultimate goal and summum-bonum of human existence is probably a fact yet altogether u known and undiscovered in the West. Greatly astonishing as this might appear to the Western philosopher and Critic, in spite of the historical and archaeological progress attained in their land,no biased or illogical criticisins put forward even in the strongest terms would be of any avail, as the facts explained in our philosophy are proved by the direct experience of venerable sages whose processes of reasoning and observation in themselves, are not yet uuderstood by the Western nations. The tendency not rarely exhibited in offering criticisms without proper study and earnest enquiry in the required direction, could only meet with ultimate failure, as abuses andsneers which are often the well-known arguments used on such occasions are not acceptable in the discussions of serious philosophical problems. Under the existing circumstances, the most profitable and the most honorable course for the Western philosophers would be to shake hands with the Easterns and put their shoulders together, with the broadest sympathy possible, for the purpose of recovering and resuscitating the lost treasures of humanity at large, viewed as the same creation of the Almighty One. If only the quantity of energy that might be voluntarily wasted for unnecessary criticisms be utilized for this purpose, inuch useful progress might soon be expected. A few simple facts explained in

this Chapter might again be noticed in this connection, lest they be lost amidst the crowd of descriptions under this heading.

(a) It can be freely noticed, throughout the Upanishads and other texts, that the very style of describing the Bramhan, is highly practical and hopeful. No tinge of pessimism or uncertainty or even indefiniteness is ever attached to it, although they are often mistakenly attributed to the ultimate aim of our philosophy. The following few lines from the various quotations furnished in this Chapter, are worthy of notice.

दारिद्र्याशा यथा नास्ति सम्पन्नस्य तथा मम।
ब्रह्मानन्दे निमग्नस्य विषयाशा न तद्भवेत्॥

अजकुक्षौ गजो नास्ति ह्यात्मकुक्षौ जगन्न हि॥

कीदृक्तर्हीति चेत्पृच्छेदीदृक्ता नास्ति तत्र हि।
यदनीदृक् अतादृक्चतत्स्वरूपं विनिश्चिनु।
अक्षाणां विषयस्त्वीदृक् च परोक्षस्तादृगुच्यते।
विषयी नाक्षविषयःस्वत्वान्नास्य परोक्षता॥

शक्येषु बाधितेष्वन्ते शिष्यते यत्तदेव तत्।
सर्वबाधे न किञ्चिच्चेत् यन्नकिञ्चित्तदेव तत्।
भाषा एवात्र भिद्यन्ते निर्बाधं तावदस्ति हि॥

(b) In the logical analysis of material and efficient causes, the former called Upadana-karana, as explained in the texts, is divided into three classes; Arambha, Parinami and Vivarta, the last being assigned for the explanation of the whole cosmological conception. Vivarta refers to theappearance of a change in the material without an actual change. This is probably a piece of additional information worth the notice of a Western Logician.

अवस्थान्तरभानन्तु विवर्तोरज्जुसर्पवत्।

निरंशेप्यस्त्यसौ व्योम्नि तलमालिन्य कल्पनात्।
ततो निरंश आनन्दे विवर्तोजगदिष्यताम्॥

(c) The evoluion and destruction of the universe cannot be attributed to Nature, nor to Karma in itself, nor again to Eswara alone. A combination of the individual’s Karmas and the enforcement of the Karmic law by Eswara who is himself the law-giver, must be accepted as the real cause. This is also an acknowledged theory in the texts and peculiar to Eastern Philosophy.

न स्वभावाज्जगज्जन्म स्थितिध्वंसा मुनीश्वराः।
न मया केवलेनापि न च केवलकर्मणा।
प्राणिनां कर्मपाकेन मया च मुनिसत्तमाः।
जगतः सम्भवो नाशः स्थितिश्च भवति द्विजाः।
एवं कर्मानुरूपेण जगज्जन्मादि यन्मया।
एव स्वभावो विप्रेन्द्राः इति वेदार्थनिर्णयः॥

(d) With regard to the vexed question of Free-will and Necessity, a very simple and reasonable solution is offered in the texts and it deserves the attention of those interested in Western Moral Philosophy. The unavoidable dependence on Atma accepts Necessity, but the Free-will of the in lividual is granted for action. Atina here is compared to the sun during the day setting every living being to work which is done according to its own Free-will.

आत्मचैतन्यमाश्रित्य देहेन्द्रियमनोधियः।
